('33', 0, 1, 2, 49) 1. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('33', 0, 2, 3, 75) It is matter of great grief and disappointment to me not to be able to complete the whole of the Bihar tour as was previously arranged.
('33', 0, 2, 4, 211) I see that the continuous travelling for the past 12 months has put a severe strain upon my constitution.
('33', 0, 2, 5, 317) I must therefore take the tour in easy stages.
('33', 0, 2, 6, 364) The Reception Committee has kindly accommo dated me.
('33', 0, 2, 7, 417) I hope that the committee and the people in the parts which are being omitted will forgive me.
('33', 0, 2, 8, 512) I shall endeavour early next year to finish the balance of the tour.
('33', 0, 3, 9, 581) The Searchlight, 25 9 1925
('33', 0, 4, 10, 608) 2. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, BIKRAM 1
('33', 0, 5, 11, 646) September 25,1925
('33', 0, 6, 12, 664) Mahatmaji .
('33', 0, 6, 13, 676) first apologized for not being able to go to them the previous day as arranged.
('33', 0, 6, 14, 756) Then he told them that he did not know what he was to say to them as the thing which he wanted to say they must have heard already.
('33', 0, 6, 15, 888) Their presence in such large numbers was a sufficient proof of it.
('33', 0, 6, 16, 955) The belief was growing in him every day that they had nothing except the charkha which would appease the hunger of crores of Indian villagers.
('33', 0, 6, 17, 1098) They knew that for four months in the year they had no work and that time could be employed best in plying the charkha.
('33', 0, 6, 18, 1218) The poorest of them had to spend on cloth at least five or ten rupees in a year.
('33', 0, 6, 19, 1299) The small sum amounted to crores which could be saved and brought in the villages only by the charkha.
('33', 0, 6, 20, 1402) He did not know why people did not understand such a simple thing.
('33', 0, 6, 21, 1469) If they did not do such a simple work even, it was impossible to establish swaraj, or Ramarajya or whatever they might call it.
('33', 0, 6, 22, 1597) Those who did not spin formerly, he hoped, would begin to spin now.
('33', 0, 6, 23, 1665) Then he turned towards the organizers of the meeting and said he was grieved to see the children who sang the opening song were not clad in khaddar.
('33', 0, 6, 24, 1814) He hoped that they would not repeat the mistake.
('33', 0, 6, 25, 1863) He told the Hindus that Hinduism recognized nothing like untouchability.
('33', 0, 6, 26, 1936) If anybody thought that touching another man was a sin, he was himself committing a sin.
('33', 0, 6, 27, 2025) As to Hindu Muslim unity he did not know what was to be said.
('33', 0, 6, 28, 2087) He had lost all influence over both communities.
('33', 0, 6, 29, 2136) But he did not forget that unless both communities joined hands, swaraj was a dream, never to be realized.
('33', 0, 6, 30, 2243) In the end with an appeal for Deshbandhu Das Memorial Fund he concluded.
('33', 0, 6, 31, 2316) The Searchlight, 27 9 1925
('33', 0, 7, 32, 2343) 1 Among those who accompanied Gandhiji during his visit to Bikram and later, in the afternoon, to the meeting, were Rajendra Prasad, Jamnalal Bajaj, Satis Chandra Das Gupta, and Jagat Narayan Lal.
('33', 1, 0, 1, 2540) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 1, 1, 2, 2580) 3. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL GANDHI
('33', 1, 2, 3, 2611) [About September 25,1925] 1
('33', 1, 3, 4, 2639) CHHAGANLAL, I have your letter.
('33', 1, 3, 5, 2671) The coconut for Nimu should be sent to Amreli for religious reasons.
('33', 1, 3, 6, 2740) It seems better if it is not sent to the Ash ram.
('33', 1, 3, 7, 2790) This is just my feeling.
('33', 1, 3, 8, 2815) If the same feeling persists, it can be made use of in future.
('33', 1, 3, 9, 2878) Ramdas is independent.
('33', 1, 3, 10, 2901) He has set up a house in Amreli.
('33', 1, 3, 11, 2934) He finds peace there.
('33', 1, 3, 12, 2956) Therefore, I would feel happy if the coconut is sent there.
('33', 1, 3, 13, 3016) I would like that the marriage, whenever it is to take place, should take place at Dr. Mehta’s bungalow.
('33', 1, 3, 14, 3121) However, I will abide by the wishes of Nimu’s grandfather.
('33', 1, 3, 15, 3180) I feel that its performance at Dr. Mehta’s bungalow will add to the solemnity of the occasion.
('33', 1, 3, 16, 3275) It is good that Nimu has started menstruating.
('33', 1, 3, 17, 3322) We will be happy to get her married the moment she reaches the age when she can bear the burden of children.
('33', 1, 3, 18, 3431) If her grandfather is indifferent, I would like to influence Nimu from today itself to postpone her marriage.
('33', 1, 3, 19, 3541) We seem to believe that Radha, Moti and others have reached the age of marriage.
('33', 1, 3, 20, 3622) However if their minds are pure, age is of no consequence.
('33', 1, 3, 21, 3681) Take the case of Miss Schlesin.
('33', 1, 3, 22, 3713) I find such women here too.
('33', 1, 3, 23, 3741) Only we believe that the girls should be married off the moment their bodies are filled out.
('33', 1, 3, 24, 3834) But the experience of the whole world shows that it is not true.
('33', 1, 3, 25, 3899) Sixteen is the minimum age.
('33', 1, 3, 26, 3927) Average age should be 20 years.
('33', 1, 3, 27, 3959) At that age, one is mentally mature.
('33', 1, 3, 28, 3996) I wish I am able to talk to Nimu as freely as I am able to talk with Ramdas today.
('33', 1, 3, 29, 4079) Now I would not write anything more.
('33', 1, 3, 30, 4116) I am happy that we all think of Nimu’s good.
('33', 1, 3, 31, 4161) If we find that she is getting impatient, we will solemnize her marriage soon as we did in Rami’s case.
('33', 1, 3, 32, 4265) I decided to do that after ascertaining Rami’s desire myself.
('33', 1, 3, 33, 4327) I hope you know my programme.
('33', 1, 4, 34, 4357) Blessings from
('33', 1, 6, 35, 4372) From the Gujarati original : S.N. 32852
('33', 1, 7, 36, 4412) 1 Ramdas and Nimu got married on January 27, 1928. The letter, however, appears to have been written about the same time as the one to the addressee dated ‘before September 23, 1925, Vide?Letter to Chhaganlal Gandhi”, before 23 9 1925.

('33', 2, 1, 2, 4697) 4. LETTER TO VALLABHBHAI PATEL
('33', 2, 2, 3, 4728) Saturday, September 26,1925
('33', 2, 3, 4, 4756) BHAI VALLABHBHAI, I shall reach Bombay on the 20th [October].
('33', 2, 3, 5, 4818) Will you come with me to Kutch on the 21st?
('33', 2, 3, 6, 4862) If so, you should be in Bombay on the 20th.
('33', 2, 3, 7, 4906) There is a telegram from Devdhar about Manibehn.
('33', 2, 3, 8, 4955) I have sent it to her.
('33', 2, 3, 9, 4978) He is willing to take her in December.
('33', 2, 3, 10, 5017) We may not put Dahyabhai to work in a mill.
('33', 2, 3, 11, 5061) If we place him with Birla, it is very likely that he would be put to work only in a mill.
('33', 2, 3, 12, 5152) We shall talk it over when we meet.
('33', 2, 3, 13, 5188) I am discussing this with Jamnalalji.
('33', 2, 4, 14, 5226) Blessings from
('33', 2, 5, 15, 5241) BAPU [PS.] I have no time to write more.
('33', 2, 5, 16, 5282) [From Gujarati]
('33', 2, 6, 17, 5298) Bapuna Patro—Sardar Vallabhbhaine
('33', 2, 7, 18, 5332) 5. LETTER TO MANIBEHN PATEL
('33', 2, 8, 19, 5360) Saturday [September 26,1925] 1
('33', 2, 9, 20, 5391) MANI, I enclose Devdhar’s telegram.
('33', 2, 9, 21, 5427) I think it is better to wait till then.
('33', 2, 9, 22, 5467) But, meanwhile if you like, I will try to put you in the Sevasadan at Bombay or, if you knows about the schools at Calcutta, but he is not in favour of your joining it.
('33', 2, 9, 23, 5636) He is, however, willing to make arrangements at the Girls’ School at Wardha.
('33', 2, 9, 24, 5713) There is Marathi in Wardha and you will feel at home there, so it is better to have your first experience there.
('33', 2, 9, 25, 5826) Let me know what you wish to do.
('33', 2, 9, 26, 5859) Send your reply to me at Patna.
('33', 2, 10, 27, 5891) Blessings from BAPU [From Gujarati] Bapuna Patro—Manibehn Patelne
('33', 2, 11, 28, 5957) 1 As in the source 2 Gandhiji was in Patna from September 20 to September 29 and also from October 12 to October 15.
('33', 3, 0, 1, 6074) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 3, 1, 2, 6114) 6. KHADI PROGRAMME
('33', 3, 2, 3, 6133) Although the following letter is full of criticism, I print it in the hope that all workers may learn from it whatever is worth learning: 1
('33', 3, 3, 4, 6273) I hope that no worker will misunderstand the aim behind this criticism.
('33', 3, 3, 5, 6345) It is the duty of khadi workers to accept whatever part of it is applicable.
('33', 3, 3, 6, 6422) What has been described as?inducement” by the critic I would call protection or?bounty” as it is known in English.
('33', 3, 3, 7, 6537) We have forsaken khadi for a long time.
('33', 3, 3, 8, 6577) It is natural that help should be necessary in the initial stage in order to propagate khadi amongst people who have less or no patriotism in them.
('33', 3, 3, 9, 6725) Everyone knows that such assistance cannot be given for ever.
('33', 3, 3, 10, 6787) Even during the period when assistance is given, there must be a gradual butcontinuous improvement in the quality of khadi, the cost of production should come down and the quantum of help diminish.
('33', 3, 3, 11, 6985) All this is happening.
('33', 3, 3, 12, 7008) There has been an improvement in the quality, there has been a reduction in the cost and in the assistance given.
('33', 3, 3, 13, 7122) I am not pained by the fact that the cloth produced in the Amreli Centre is being sent to Bombay, but it pains me that so little is sold in Amreli itself.
('33', 3, 3, 14, 7277) This is a measure of the sad plight of our country.
('33', 3, 3, 15, 7329) The thoughtful people of Amreli have not understood their natural duty of wearing khadi.
('33', 3, 3, 16, 7418) They fail to take advantage of the Ganga which flows by their doorstep.
('33', 3, 3, 17, 7490) Time alone will improve this state of affairs.
('33', 3, 3, 18, 7537) The residents of Amreli should let the khadi centre know if it is to blame for sending out locally manufactured cloth.
('33', 3, 3, 19, 7656) As far as I know the centre does try to sell khadi locally but its efforts have not met with the success they deserve.
('33', 3, 3, 20, 7775) In these circumstances, we cannot indeed deprive the poor in Amreli of the help they receive by way of wages for spinning.
('33', 3, 3, 21, 7898) It is, of course, necessary to see that the women who spin start wearing khadi themselves.
('33', 3, 3, 22, 7989) Experience suggests that even this cannot be brought about all at once.
('33', 3, 3, 23, 8061) The women who spin for money do so only to earn something and cannot be asked to buy expensive khadi.
('33', 3, 3, 24, 8163) They will wear khadi only if we reduce its price for them.
('33', 3, 3, 25, 8222) Hence, khadi workers who wish to make khadi wholly self supporting should take account of the difficulties involved.
('33', 3, 3, 26, 8339) If they do
('33', 3, 4, 27, 8350) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('33', 3, 4, 28, 8387) The correspondent had argued that the cause of khadi could prosper only through the spontaneous endeavour of farmers and not through the efforts of outside workers.
('33', 4, 0, 1, 8552) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 5
('33', 4, 1, 2, 8601) not, it will be impossible to advance the cause of khadi.
('33', 4, 1, 3, 8659) In such circumstances, one should use one’s common sense as to when one should rest satisfied with a little and when one may rest satisfied with anything short of perfection.
('33', 4, 1, 4, 8834) But we also need the services of workers who are disinclined to work in such an imperfect field and aim at perfection.
('33', 4, 1, 5, 8953) The following ways are open to them: 1. If they have the necessary strength—that is, the strength to work and maintain themselves with a little—they should spend all their time in carding, spinning and, if they feel inclined, weaving and thus become self reliant.
('33', 4, 1, 6, 9217) 2. Those who do not have such strength should spend in spinning all the time they can spare form their own work and gift that yarn for the sake of the country.
('33', 4, 1, 7, 9377) It should not be necessary to say that they themselves should exclusively wear khadi and persuade others to do so .
('33', 4, 1, 8, 9493) Let us consider in this connection the principles on which the khadi movement is based: 1. Crores of people in India are so poor that a few pice have the same value to them as one rupee.
('33', 4, 1, 9, 9680) 2. Crores of them remain unemployed for four months in a year.
('33', 4, 1, 10, 9743) 3. For such persons, there is no other work which can be taken up by one and all and which will produce immediate results.
('33', 4, 1, 11, 9866) A khadi worker should objectively apply these principles to his own sphere of work.
('33', 4, 1, 12, 9950) Only then can we say that the khadi movement is being carried on in a scientific manner.
('33', 4, 1, 13, 10039) In other words: 1. Those who have other occupations from which they earn something should not be induced to spin for money.
('33', 4, 1, 14, 10163) 2. Only in those parts where the people are very poor should they induce them to spin for money and even in such places they should pay no more in wages than the country can afford.
('33', 4, 1, 15, 10345) Experience shows that not more than four annas can be paid for a seer (the weight of forty rupees ) of number six yarn .
('33', 4, 1, 16, 10466) 3. In other places those who spin can be helped only by way of instruction, etc.
('33', 4, 1, 17, 10547) To spend money for them is to harm the interests of the poor who really need it.
('33', 4, 1, 18, 10628) It would be a different matter if they themselves offered to pay for instruction.
('33', 4, 1, 19, 10710) It would also be a different
('33', 5, 0, 1, 10739) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 5, 1, 2, 10779) matter if in a place like Bardoli some people gifted cotton and it was then distributed among others.
('33', 5, 1, 3, 10881) 4. No money should be spent for those who spin by way of yajna.
('33', 5, 1, 4, 10945) Yarn received in this manner should be treated as a pure gift.
('33', 5, 1, 5, 11008) It is wrong to accept anything as gift if securing the gift costs as much as the thing itself.
('33', 5, 1, 6, 11103) 5. Other expenses should be incurred only on training khadi workers, that is, on giving training in spinning, etc., on carrying on propaganda for khadi and on improvements in the spinning wheel.
('33', 5, 1, 7, 11298) To put it briefly, money should be spent only when it is likey to benefit the poor for whose sake the spinning movement has been conceived.
('33', 5, 1, 8, 11438) Wherever these principles are not followed, there is either ignorance or false attachment, or both, behind the work being done.
('33', 5, 2, 9, 11566) [From Gujarati]
('33', 5, 3, 10, 11582) Navajivan, 27 9 1925
('33', 5, 4, 11, 11603) 7. SOME QUESTIONS
('33', 5, 5, 12, 11621) A teacher from Kutch has asked several questions, which I reproduce below and answer, as they deserve to be answered in public:
('33', 5, 6, 13, 11749) 1. I am a school teacher.
('33', 5, 6, 14, 11775) I do not posses the required strength of character, truthfulness or capacity for brahmacharya, though of course I have been
('33', 5, 7, 15, 11899) making every effort to develop these qualities.
('33', 5, 7, 16, 11947) My father is in debt.
('33', 5, 7, 17, 11969) In these circumstances, do you advise me to resign my post as teacher?
('33', 5, 7, 18, 12040) I think that the idea of resigning on the ground of not possessing the necessary strength of character is a very good one.
('33', 5, 7, 19, 12163) Nevertheless, it is necessary to exercise discretion in this matter.
('33', 5, 7, 20, 12232) It should not be considered necessary to resign if, as we go ahead with our work, our shortcomings gradually disappear.
('33', 5, 7, 21, 12352) None of us is perfect.
('33', 5, 7, 22, 12375) At present we do not come across much strength of character among teachers.
('33', 5, 7, 23, 12451) We may be satisfied if we are conscientious in our own work and put in our best effort.
('33', 5, 7, 24, 12539) In such matters, however, the same rule cannot be applied to all.
('33', 5, 7, 25, 12605) Everyone should decide for himself.
('33', 5, 7, 26, 12641) The question about the father’s debt is easy to answer.
('33', 5, 7, 27, 12697) If it was properly incurred, it should be repaid.
('33', 5, 7, 28, 12747) If he cannot repay it by working as a teacher, he should take up another job or another
('33', 6, 0, 1, 12835) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 7
('33', 6, 1, 2, 12884) profession and repay it.
('33', 6, 2, 3, 12909) 2. Apart from the moral benefit, is there any advantage to health to be derived from a weekly day of silence?
('33', 6, 2, 4, 13019) In a general way, one may say, silence is beneficial to health.
('33', 6, 2, 5, 13083) However, a person who finds no happiness in silence will derive no benefit to his health.
('33', 6, 3, 6, 13173) 3. In your book entitled General Knowledge about Health you have said that
('33', 6, 4, 7, 13248) both milk and salt should be given up, the former from the point of view of non violence and the latter for the sake of health.
('33', 6, 4, 8, 13376) Anyone who gives up milk would also have to give up ghee, buttermilk and other milk products.
('33', 6, 4, 9, 13470) Has your opinion on this subject undergone any change, or does it remain what it was?
('33', 6, 4, 10, 13556) My views on this subject have not changed, but my practice has.
('33', 6, 4, 11, 13620) It is my conviction that those who do without milk derive benefit spiritually.
('33', 6, 4, 12, 13699) Giving up milk and milk products helps one in observing brahmacharya.
('33', 6, 4, 13, 13769) Anyone who gives up milk should also give up buttermilk or ghee.
('33', 6, 4, 14, 13834) Whether out of my strong desire to live or as a matter of necessity, I consented to take goat’s milk.
('33', 6, 4, 15, 13936) If I were not working in public life, I would again give up milk and continue my experiment.
('33', 6, 4, 16, 14029) Unfortunately, I have not met any doctor, vaid or hakim who would guide me in my experiment of milk free diet.
('33', 6, 4, 17, 14140) I had hoped that vaids would be helpful.
('33', 6, 4, 18, 14181) I had assumed that the health of the soul had a place in their system.
('33', 6, 4, 19, 14252) But I have not met a vaid who would inspire confidence in me.
('33', 6, 4, 20, 14314) I have, therefore, been obliged to use milk.
('33', 6, 4, 21, 14359) I see that it is useful for preserving one’s life and health and, therefore, no longer advise anyone to give it up.
('33', 6, 4, 22, 14475) I do not, however, wish to alter the views expressed in my book.
('33', 6, 4, 23, 14540) Some of my friends still experiment with a milk free diet, and I neither discourage nor encourage them.
('33', 6, 4, 24, 14644) There are two opinions regarding salt.
('33', 6, 4, 25, 14683) I do not think that going without salt does any harm.
('33', 6, 4, 26, 14737) However, I no longer insist upon avoiding salt completely.
('33', 6, 4, 27, 14796) I know that temporary or permanent abstinence from salt is beneficial from the spiritual point of view.
('33', 6, 4, 28, 14900) We should remember that through water, etc., we take in a little quantity of salt every day.
('33', 6, 4, 29, 14993) If anyone wants to try the experiment of milk free or salt free diet for the purpose of health, it is desirable that he should do so after consulting a good doctor or vaid.
('33', 6, 4, 30, 15166) Anyone who wants to try this for spiritual reasons should be strong in his desire for a life of abstinence.
('33', 6, 5, 31, 15274) 4. Anyone who wants to practise ahimsa would have to abstain from almost all kinds of food.
('33', 6, 5, 32, 15366) Even eating fruit involves violence, as there is life in fruits and flowers too.
('33', 6, 5, 33, 15447) However, there can be no objection to eating ripe fruits which
('33', 7, 0, 1, 15510) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 7, 1, 2, 15550) have fallen from the tree without anyone having plucked them.
('33', 7, 1, 3, 15612) But a poor person like me would find it very expensive to live on such fruits.
('33', 7, 1, 4, 15691) One may, however, live only on wheat, availing oneself of the freedom permitted in certain times and circumstances.
('33', 7, 1, 5, 15807) Even wheat may be taken only in the form of porridge made from the bran.
('33', 7, 1, 6, 15880) Vegetables and fruits may be excluded altogether.
('33', 7, 1, 7, 15930) Would you believe it possible, then, or say from experience, that a young man of nineteen, such as I am, who wishes to remain a brahmachari for life, can
('33', 7, 2, 8, 16084) live his whole life eating only this porridge morning and evening and whether it can provide sufficient nourishment for him?
('33', 7, 2, 9, 16209) Even the ripe fruit that falls to the ground has life in it and, therefore, eating it should also be regarded as a sin.
('33', 7, 2, 10, 16329) The fact of our having a body is itself an evil, and wherever there is evil there is suffering.
('33', 7, 2, 11, 16425) Hence the imperative need for moksha.
('33', 7, 2, 12, 16463) One cannot, however, be rid of the body by destroying it.
('33', 7, 2, 13, 16521) Our association with the body can be totally ended only through complete freedom from desire, indifference to material happiness and renunciation.
('33', 7, 2, 14, 16668) Desire or the ego is the root cause of the body.
('33', 7, 2, 15, 16717) Once they have vanished, the body cannot but cease to exit.
('33', 7, 2, 16, 16777) But while the body continues to exist, one must have the minimum quantity of food necessary to keep it functioning.
('33', 7, 2, 17, 16893) Man’s essential requirements of nutrition are met by fruits and foods obtained from plants.
('33', 7, 2, 18, 16985) Anyone who subsists on the smallest quantity of these, obtaining them with the least violence to ethical principles may be said to be free from sin though living on impure food.
('33', 7, 2, 19, 17163) Such a person eats not in order to satisfy his palate but to keep himself alive, to keep the body functioning.
('33', 7, 2, 20, 17274) It will now be seen that a ripe fruit which has fallen off the tree, if eaten to gratify one’s palate will be tainted food while a cooked meal of vegetables and cereals, prepared and served in the normal course, will be pure food if eaten to satisfy one’s hunger and without any thought of gratifying the palate.
('33', 7, 2, 21, 17587) I believe that a person of self control who is free from any disease, can subsist only on porridge of wheat bran.
('33', 7, 2, 22, 17701) My advice to the correspondent is that it will be enough if he takes ordinary food, without chillies or other spices, paying no attention to its taste or savour.
('33', 7, 2, 23, 17863) For observing brahmacharya, the essential thing is to learn to be indifferent to the pleasures which objects of sense give.
('33', 7, 2, 24, 17987) A person who enjoys all manner of rich dishes cannot be said to have conquered the desire for material pleasure.
('33', 7, 2, 25, 18100) The common people, however, who eat ordinary food may be regarded as having done so.
('33', 7, 2, 26, 18185) In the last analysis, every individual should examine himself to find
('33', 8, 0, 1, 18255) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 9
('33', 8, 1, 2, 18304) out when he eats in order to gratify his palate and when to meet the needs of his body.
('33', 8, 1, 3, 18392) Even in the matter of food, we have no straight path before us.
('33', 8, 1, 4, 18456) The only straight path there is in life is one’s heart.
('33', 8, 1, 5, 18512) The external world is a deceitful illusion; it is like an enormous banyan tree with intertwining boughs, and one has to live in this and attain union with the Brahman.
('33', 8, 2, 6, 18680) 5. If the mind is hankering after food and the body, too, is very hungry, does it do any good to repress the desire and fast?
('33', 8, 2, 7, 18806) Whether or not a fast will do any good depends on one’s motive and one’s capacity to undertake it.
('33', 8, 2, 8, 18905) The poet has compared the mind to a drunken ape, and to be sure there is no end to its desires.
('33', 8, 2, 9, 19001) These should be checked every moment.
('33', 8, 3, 10, 19039) 6. I do not take tea, but the other members of my family do.
('33', 8, 3, 11, 19100) As I am the earning member, would it be proper on my part to prevent them from doing so by not buying any tea at all?
('33', 8, 3, 12, 19218) Irrespective of whether or not I am the earning member, would it be regarded as coercion on my relatives if I made them give up tea by resorting to fasting?
('33', 8, 3, 13, 19375) The head of the family or the earning member who stops other members from taking tea because he himself does not do so is employing coercion.
('33', 8, 3, 14, 19517) The right thing for him is to reason with them patiently.
('33', 8, 3, 15, 19575) As long as they are not converted to his views, I believe that he should buy tea for them.
('33', 8, 3, 16, 19666) Resorting to fasting simply because others do not stop doing a particular thing is a form of blackmail, and that is coercion.
('33', 8, 4, 17, 19792) 7. I believe that no one is reformed through physical punishment.
('33', 8, 4, 18, 19858) If, nevertheless, I punished pupils in my class, would that not be violence on my part?
('33', 8, 4, 19, 19946) If I did not punish the naughty or the dull pupils myself and sent them instead to the head master, knowing that he would punish them, would I not, in that case, be guilty of violence?
('33', 8, 4, 20, 20131) There is violence in punishing pupils and also in sending them to the head master in order that they may be punished.
('33', 8, 4, 21, 20249) The correspondent has not asked whether a teacher is free to punish any pupil, but the question is implied in the one which he has asked.
('33', 8, 4, 22, 20387) I myself can imagine a situation in which it becomes one’s duty to punish a child who has done something wrong, knowing that it is wrong.
('33', 8, 4, 23, 20525) Every teacher should think and decide for himself what his duty is.
('33', 8, 4, 24, 20593) The general rule, however, is that a teacher should never inflict physical punishment on a pupil.
('33', 8, 4, 25, 20691) If anyone should have this right at all, let it rest with the parents.
('33', 8, 4, 26, 20762) A punishment is just only if the pupil
('33', 9, 0, 1, 20801) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 9, 1, 2, 20842) himself accepts it as such.
('33', 9, 1, 3, 20870) Such occasions are not frequent.
('33', 9, 1, 4, 20903) Even when an occasion has arisen, the pupil should not be punished if there is any doubt about the punishment being justified.
('33', 9, 1, 5, 21030) In any case, no one should be punished in anger.
('33', 9, 2, 6, 21079) 8. Supposing I am not really angry—for I know that anger has a harmful effect both on health and character—but even then pretend to be angry with a pupil or threaten to punish without intending to do so, would that be a dishonest act on my part?
('33', 9, 2, 7, 21325) We find many people guilty of this wrong.
('33', 9, 2, 8, 21367) To pretend to punish is altogether reprehensible.
('33', 9, 3, 9, 21417) 9. I accept the argument that observing brahmacharya is the only right
('33', 9, 4, 10, 21488) method of birth control.
('33', 9, 4, 11, 21513) Though my heart accepts this, my reason revolts against it and doubts whether, in the same way that there can be no wrong in the use of any of the other sense organs, that it might do harm on the contrary not to use them, it might not be harmful not to exercise this function of the body.
('33', 9, 4, 12, 21802) It was to this effect that the president of the committee for birth control had addressed a letter to you in The Chronicle.
('33', 9, 4, 13, 21926) Would you, therefore, deal with
('33', 9, 5, 14, 21958) this argument?
('33', 9, 5, 15, 21973) There is no such principle that the use of all organs of the body is essential.
('33', 9, 5, 16, 22053) The man who deliberately gives up the use of speech lays the world under an obligation.
('33', 9, 5, 17, 22141) Dharma requires not that we use the sense organs but that we control them.
('33', 9, 5, 18, 22216) Control of the senses practised intelligently and voluntarily is beneficial spiritually, and not harmful.
('33', 9, 5, 19, 22322) The use of the sexual organs is permitted only for the sake of procreation.
('33', 9, 5, 20, 22398) However, the Shastras honour those who renounce the desire for progeny.
('33', 9, 5, 21, 22470) The glorification of passion is taken to such lengths in this age that irreligion has come to be known as religion.
('33', 9, 5, 22, 22586) It is a grave error to believe that the world is benefited by the encouragement or gratification of lust.
('33', 9, 5, 23, 22692) This is my conviction, this is the testimony of the Shastras and this is the undisputed experience of people who have realized the self.
('33', 9, 5, 24, 22829) In India, we are forced into the prison of marriage right from childhood.
('33', 9, 5, 25, 22903) In such circumstances, to devise means for the gratification of passion and establish associations for popularizing them is the very limit of ignorance and of blind imitation.
('33', 9, 5, 26, 23079) To say that passion cannot be curbed or that curbing it is harmful is itself very harmful.
('33', 9, 5, 27, 23170) I have no doubt that the Indian nation will lose vigour and finally perish if a movement for encouraging the gratification of lust ever comes to thrive in this country of weaklings.

('33', 10, 0, 1, 23420) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 11
('33', 10, 1, 2, 23470) not be harmful in countries where the human body has the strength of a monster and is nourished on food and drink proper for a monster, but India’s good lies only in the lesson of self control.
('33', 10, 2, 3, 23664) 10. One who practises ahimsa cannot use any conveyance and must give up eating almost all edible substances.

('33', 11, 7, 21, 27354) I was taken to see the goshala there.

('33', 19, 1, 2, 39311) 20. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, PATNA 1
('33', 19, 2, 3, 39349) September 29,1925
('33', 19, 3, 4, 39367) Mahatma Gandhi replying expressed his gratitude for the presentation of the address.
('33', 19, 3, 5, 39452) It was not the first time that he had come into their midst.
('33', 19, 3, 6, 39513) It was now four years since he had met them last and, though he recollected the details of that visit vividly and the fact that though both he and they were the same, the difference between then and now was tremendous.
('33', 19, 3, 7, 39732) He scarcely needed to dilate on it, the difference in the atmosphere about them and in their outlook.
('33', 19, 3, 8, 39834) He was glad to be able to meet them and he would like to address them briefly on their civic duties and problems connected with municipal life which was dear to him and of which he could claim some knowledge.
('33', 19, 3, 9, 40043) If the municipal commissioners and citizens of a town were to attend seriously to municipal improvement, they would be doing a great service to the country.
('33', 19, 3, 10, 40200) It was supremely necessary to do so, for the reflection of town life on their villages was unmistakable.
('33', 19, 3, 11, 40305) If town life was dirty, the dirt and the squalor were reflec ted in the villages as well.
('33', 19, 3, 12, 40395) If they had cinemas in the towns, village life was also to some extent influenced.
('33', 19, 3, 13, 40478) He had seen this interconnection between towns and villages for himself in Bengal and he remembered vividly the charges made against town dwellers by village folk.
('33', 19, 3, 14, 40642) On the residents in a town the responsibility lay not only of keeping their towns pure, their lanes clean, but they had a duty towards their village brethren.
('33', 19, 3, 15, 40801) Little though that duty might be, it made them in some sense the trustees of the villages.
('33', 19, 3, 16, 40892) In the manner they in the towns conducted themselves, the people in the villages would.
('33', 19, 4, 17, 40980) The worst was their inner life was becoming as dirty as the dirt accumulated about them.
('33', 19, 4, 18, 41069) There were not many roads in Patna and yet, when he saw their condition, he felt pained beyond measure just as he was on seeing the degeneration in their inner life.
('33', 19, 4, 19, 41235) There were some very pertinent questions in respect of their civic duties which he would put before them.
('33', 19, 4, 20, 41341) Did they properly look after the cleanliness of the town or did they leave it solely to the Bhangis?
('33', 19, 4, 21, 41442) What arrangements, if any, had they made for
('33', 19, 5, 22, 41487) suply of pure and cheap milk to the children?
('33', 19, 5, 23, 41533) Were their men and women as dirty as were likely to impart their own dirt to others?
('33', 19, 5, 24, 41618) What did they do for their untouch ables?
('33', 19, 5, 25, 41660) And, lastly, did they have drink shops in the town and, if so, how many?
('33', 19, 5, 26, 41733) He knew they could not altogether control the number and the existence of these shops and much depended on the Government.
('33', 19, 5, 27, 41856) But it was not altogether the fault of the government either, for if they bestirred themselves, satisfied those who drank about

('33', 23, 1, 2, 48551) 22. LETTER TO DEVCHAND PAREKH
('33', 23, 2, 3, 48581) Aso Sud 13, 1981 [September 30, 1925]
('33', 23, 3, 4, 48619) BHAISHRI DEVCHANDBHAI, I have your letter.
('33', 23, 3, 5, 48662) It is good that you have discussed the matter in detail.
('33', 23, 3, 6, 48719) Let me first take up what you have written about the franchise of the new khadi organization.
('33', 23, 3, 7, 48813) 1 You must have come to know from the newspapers that there are two categories of franchise.
('33', 23, 3, 8, 48906) [A member of] the first category has to spin and send one thousand yards every month, while [a member of] the second has to spin and send two thousand yards every year.
('33', 23, 3, 9, 49075) We can include the professional spinners in the second category, but we shall not do so just now.
('33', 23, 3, 10, 49173) We should so work that we do not give rise to the fear that we may capture the Congress with the help of these voters.
('33', 23, 3, 11, 49292) In this way we can free the Swaraj Party from fear and suspicion.
('33', 23, 3, 12, 49358) It does not mean that we want to restrict the number of new spinners.
('33', 23, 3, 13, 49428) We should enrol as many of them as possible, and herein lies the success of this Association.
('33', 23, 3, 14, 49522) By putting a contribution of two thousand yeards for the second category, we have made it easy for the new spinners.
('33', 23, 3, 15, 49639) Even half a pound of cotton is not consumed in spinning two thousand yards of yarn of five or six counts.
('33', 23, 3, 16, 49745) This much cotton would cost less than 4 annas and, if the yarn is finer, it would hardly cost 2 as.
('33', 23, 3, 17, 49845) Whatever the member contributes to the Association over and above the cost of cotton is like his respectful offering to the spinning wheel.
('33', 23, 3, 18, 49985) And at present the Association would welcome even this.
('33', 23, 3, 19, 50041) So you see this suits your wishes.
('33', 23, 3, 20, 50076) Now let us consider the next problem raised by you, that of the production and sale of khadi.
('33', 23, 3, 21, 50170) In regard to the sale of khadi the procedure of the old Association is quite clear.
('33', 23, 3, 22, 50254) It gives interest free advances against good surety to traders in khadi.
('33', 23, 3, 23, 50327) The margin of profit has been kept at 6
('33', 23, 5, 24, 50367) per cent so that they should not be tempted to charge higher prices and exploit the people’s love for khadi; in case of loss, the association undertakes to compensate it by a bounty of 2 per cent.
('33', 23, 5, 25, 50564) In this manner, the traders will gradually stand on their own, and the Association will have little to do in this regard.
('33', 23, 5, 26, 50686) Thus, you will find that there is nothing to object to in this procedure, seeing that it involves little
('33', 23, 6, 27, 50791) 1 The All India Spinners’ Association, whose constitution was finalized on September 24, 1925.
('33', 24, 0, 1, 50886) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 25
('33', 24, 1, 2, 50936) botheration and has the additional advantage of getting the use of the traders’ capital.
('33', 24, 1, 3, 51025) Now let us come to the question of production.
('33', 24, 1, 4, 51072) This involves training people through the spread of education in schools to spin and wear clothes made out of their own yarn.
('33', 24, 1, 5, 51198) This work must continue.
('33', 24, 1, 6, 51223) The result of this effort, however, will be visible only in the long run.
('33', 24, 1, 7, 51297) Therefore, it would not be right to depend entirely on this.
('33', 24, 1, 8, 51358) The more I observe the more I notice that we have not yet been able to reach those areas where the spinning wheel is natural and cheap.
('33', 24, 1, 9, 51494) In some of these areas, the work is going on in such a way that they can afford to maintain skilled workers and pay them adequate wages.
('33', 24, 1, 10, 51631) We can easily put the khadi work on a sound footing by deputing to such areas adequately paid experts in the craft and the economics of khaddar to remedy the few defects found there.
('33', 24, 1, 11, 51814) If we cut down on this, it would be short sighted economy.
('33', 24, 1, 12, 51873) Therefore I think it necessary to employ paid experts in the trade and technique of khadi.
('33', 24, 1, 13, 51964) I see the need of many such men.
('33', 24, 1, 14, 51997) But we do not have trained men.
('33', 24, 1, 15, 52029) Therefore, we must find men who claim to love this work and undertake to train them.
('33', 24, 1, 16, 52114) I have also seen from experience that it won’t do to have men who have had mere superficial training.
('33', 24, 1, 17, 52216) It is essential to give them thorough training.
('33', 24, 1, 18, 52264) For this purpose, we should have one or more centres to impart all round training in khadi.
('33', 24, 1, 19, 52356) Thus, we will try to infuse life in those areas which show signs of hope, but which are dormant and backaward.
('33', 24, 1, 20, 52467) At the same time, we shall have to put in great effort in some areas which seem to be recalcitrant.
('33', 24, 1, 21, 52567) We shall have to patronize the weavers also for some time.
('33', 24, 1, 22, 52626) Otherwise, there will always be danger of every kind of deceit and frequent depression, and it is quite likely that our work may be washed out.
('33', 24, 1, 23, 52770) In order to cope with all these problems, I think we need an army of efficient, staunch and honest workers.
('33', 24, 1, 24, 52878) We must not be impatient in this matter.
('33', 24, 1, 25, 52919) We should be careful in the choice of men.
('33', 24, 1, 26, 52962) We should also practise strict economy.
('33', 24, 1, 27, 53002) I am sure all this work will not be difficult if we are alert.
('33', 24, 1, 28, 53065) I have no doubt that as and when these areas get stabilized, they will earn the hire of the workers.
('33', 24, 1, 29, 53166) I am already noticing several such instances.
('33', 24, 1, 30, 53212) Besides this, there are many other matters which I wish to explain to you.
('33', 24, 1, 31, 53287) But I leave them for another occasion.
('33', 24, 1, 32, 53326) Remamber that khadi has to be produced also to prevent famine.
('33', 24, 1, 33, 53389) We may not turn back a single woman who wants to spin for her livelihood.
('33', 24, 1, 34, 53463) Hence we will need houses, etc.

('33', 26, 1, 2, 55123) 24. THE ALL INDIA CONGRESS COMMITTE
('33', 26, 2, 3, 55159) The transfer of power into the Swarajists’ hands was completed by the All India Congress Committee at Patna.
('33', 26, 2, 4, 55268) The resolutions 1 were keenly debated and on the whole with the greatest self restraint.
('33', 26, 2, 5, 55357) The majorities for the different parts of the resolution were not always as large as I had expected or desired, so as to warrant a change in the constitution of a parent body by its subordinate.
('33', 26, 2, 6, 55552) But I feel that I consulted the best interests of the country in allowing the resolutions.
('33', 26, 2, 7, 55643) I have admitted before now that the making of the change in the constitution was outside the ordinary jurisdiction of the All India Congress Committee and that it was of the nature of a rebellion.
('33', 26, 2, 8, 55840) But I hold that it is the duty of every institution jealous of its reputation courageously to face such a crisis if it is convinced that the rebellion is needed for the existence or welfare of the insititution itself.
('33', 26, 2, 9, 56058) It was for that reason that I invited the Committee in the first instance to decide whether a crisis had arisen justifying a change in the constitution without waiting for the Congress session.
('33', 26, 2, 10, 56252) The majority in favour of an immediate change was overwhelming.
('33', 26, 2, 11, 56316) I was not, therefore, insistent upon similar majorities in connection with votes for the resolution itself.
('33', 26, 2, 12, 56424) It now remains for the congress either to endorse the action of the All India Congress Committee or to censure it by rejecting it or even to censure the action even while accepting its decision, it being an accomplished fact.
('33', 26, 2, 13, 56650) It was suggested by one or two members that censure was an impossible thing because the resolution of the All india Congress Committee was to be enforced immediately and that therefore those who would come to the Congress would come naturally under the new franchise and those who benefited by it could hardly be expected to censure the action of their benefactor.
('33', 26, 2, 14, 57015) Such, however, need not be the case.
('33', 26, 2, 15, 57052) If the change made by the Committee is resented on pure constitutional grounds, even men who may take advantage of the benefit conferred may still very properly condemn the unconstitutional action of the Committee.
('33', 26, 2, 16, 57267) They may admit the advisability of the change but repudiate the right of All India Congress Committee to make it under any circumstance whatsoever.
('33', 26, 2, 17, 57415) As to the substance of the change made, there is really nothing
('33', 26, 3, 18, 57479) 1 Vide”A. I. C. C. Resolutions”, 1 10 1925.
('33', 27, 0, 1, 57523) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 27, 1, 2, 57564) drastic in it.
('33', 27, 1, 3, 57579) No interest in injured.
('33', 27, 1, 4, 57603) No single person is disfranchised.
('33', 27, 1, 5, 57638) No single party is in a worse position than it was before the change.
('33', 27, 1, 6, 57708) Non co operators need not complain, because non co operation as a national policy has been suspended.
('33', 27, 1, 7, 57810) The constructive programme remains unaffected.
('33', 27, 1, 8, 57857) Hand spinning and khaddar still remain part of the national programme.
('33', 27, 1, 9, 57928) The Council programme which was being worked by the Swaraj Party in the name of the Congress will now be worked by the Congress through the Swaraj Party .
('33', 27, 1, 10, 58083) This may be called a distinction without a difference.
('33', 27, 1, 11, 58138) Those who put spinning before the political programme and those who believe in spinning to the exclusion of any political programme strictly so called are not injured because they have a separate organization for its development and because hand spinning still remains as an alternative part of the franchise and the use of khaddar on Congress and other public occasions still remains obligatory.
('33', 27, 1, 12, 58535) Nor are the other parties who are outside the Congress adversely affected by it.
('33', 27, 1, 13, 58616) Whereas under the Belgaum resolution they had to convert or negotiate with both No changers and Swarajists, now they have only to convert or confer with the Swarajists.
('33', 27, 1, 14, 58785) The change therefore in every respect extends the right of representation and makes the union of all the parties less difficult than it was.
('33', 27, 1, 15, 58926) No Congress can possibly resent a change in extension of pupular liberty.
('33', 27, 1, 16, 59000) What is more, the change in my opinion, is in accordance with the requirements of those who have hitherto been identified with the Congress.
('33', 27, 1, 17, 59141) For them, perhaps, it does not go far enough.
('33', 27, 1, 18, 59187) I should be sorry if such is the fact.
('33', 27, 1, 19, 59226) The discussion at the meeting betrayed on the part of some members a fear that the delivery of the yarn suscription directly to the All India Spinners’ Association might result in an unscrupulous exploitation of professional spinners or, worse still, in dishonest practices to flood the Congress, thus bringing about an undesirable state of things and defeating the very end sought to be accomplished by the resolution.
('33', 27, 1, 20, 59646) This fear was felt not if the yarn was to be delivered at the centre, but if it was to be delivered to the provincial agencies.
('33', 27, 1, 21, 59774) There was no difficulty in meeting this objection.
('33', 27, 1, 22, 59825) The clause in the constitution of the Association requiring Congress members who wanted to spin rather than pay a four anna subscription to send their yarn to the central offices was inserted to meet this difficulty.
('33', 27, 1, 23, 60042) My own view is certainly not to flood the Congress with spinners and thus to convert it once more into a purely or predominantly spinners’ organization to the exclusion of Council policies.
('33', 27, 1, 24, 60232) I would like it to be so undoubtedly, but that can only happen when those to whom the
('33', 28, 0, 1, 60318) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 29
('33', 28, 1, 2, 60368) transfer has been made bcome converted to spinning out and out.
('33', 28, 1, 3, 60432) And that can only happen by the spinners’ action not within the Congress but without it.
('33', 28, 1, 4, 60521) If hand spinning has any intrinsic vitality and becomes so universal as to bring us within a measurable distance of excluding foreign cloth—and that can happen only by incessant and exclusive effort on the part of those who believe in spinning out and out, working out their belief in practice—the Swarajists will become complete converts.
('33', 28, 1, 5, 60861) My strong advice, therefore, is that those who are at present spinning members of the Congress may, if they wish, continue to be so by sending their yarn to he central office.
('33', 28, 1, 6, 61037) No canvassing need be made by them for increasing the strength of membership through hand spinning.
('33', 28, 1, 7, 61137) They may work to the utmost of their ability to enrol as many members of the Association as possible.
('33', 28, 1, 8, 61239) And if we can get a large number of voluntary spinners drawn not from the professional class, but from those who spin purely for sacrifice and not for livelihood, it would be an achievement that cannot but tell.
('33', 28, 1, 9, 61451) But, at the present moment, and up to the time that all suspicion is set at rest, they should refrain from becoming members of the Congress.
('33', 28, 1, 10, 61592) I have always held that the National Congress should have no wrangling within its ranks and that there should be no unseemly attempt to capture the Congress.
('33', 28, 1, 11, 61750) Those who cannot see eye to eye with the policy of the majority should either refrain from fighting to the division point in vital matters, or if their conscience would not allow it they should for the time being retire altogether from the Congress.
('33', 28, 1, 12, 62000) I will, therefore, urge the fierce Non co operators, who if they remain in the Congress would consider it their duty to fight the Swarajists at every step and stage, to retire from the Congress, and build up public opinion if they so will, from without.
('33', 28, 1, 13, 62254) They must leave the Swarajists an open field and give them the best opportunity of working out their policy.
('33', 28, 1, 14, 62363) In my opinion, if they are to create an impression upon the government they must have the Congress organization undisturbed by Non co operators.
('33', 28, 1, 15, 62508) Hence, in my opinion, wherever the two parties are evenly balanced, Non co operators or No changers should surrender full control to theSwarajists and voluntarily give up offices if they hold any.
('33', 28, 1, 16, 62705) Where the No changers are in an overwhelming majority, they should not hamper the Swarajists, and should help them wherever they conscientiously can.
('33', 28, 1, 17, 62855) In no case may any Congres Committee put up for the legislatures condidates that are not selected by the Swarajists or are in opposition to them.
('33', 28, 1, 18, 63001) One pleasing thing I must not omit to note.
('33', 28, 1, 19, 63045) There was a decided inclination on the part of the majority to make khaddar wear the
('33', 29, 0, 1, 63130) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 29, 1, 2, 63171) National dress for all Congressmen.
('33', 29, 1, 3, 63207) The motion to that end was not pressed only when it became clear that it would embarrass the Swaraj Party.
('33', 29, 1, 4, 63314) But an improvement upon the Belgaum resolution was heartily accepted to the effect that whilst khaddar was obligatory on Congress and other public occasions it was expected of all Congressmen to wear khaddar on all the occasions, but in no case shall they wear or use foreign cloth.

('33', 30, 1, 2, 64586) 26. SIKHISM
('33', 30, 2, 3, 64598) During his visit to Patna for the A.I.C.C., Sardar Mangal Singh drew my attention to an article in Young India entitled”My friend, the revolutionary” in the issue dated 9th April last.
('33', 30, 2, 4, 64783) 1 He told me that many Sikh friends were offended because they thought I have described Guru Govind Singh as a misguided patriot whereas I had glorified krishna.
('33', 30, 2, 5, 64945) The Sardarji asked me to take an early opportunity of explaining what I meant by the passages he drew my attention to.
('33', 30, 2, 6, 65064) The careful reader will note that my language is most guarded.
('33', 30, 2, 7, 65127) I have made no positive assertion.
('33', 30, 2, 8, 65162) All that I have said is that believing every statement made about the heroes mentioned including Guru Govind Singh to be true, had I lived as their contemporary I would have called every one of them a misguided patriot.
('33', 30, 2, 9, 65382) But, in the very next sentence, I have hastened to add that I must not judge them and that I disbelieve history as far as the details of the acts of the heroes are concerned.
('33', 30, 2, 10, 65557) My belief about the Sikh Gurus is that they were all deeply religious teachers and reformers, that they were all Hindus and that Guru Govind Singh was one of the greatest defenders of Hinduism.
('33', 30, 2, 11, 65751) I believe, too, that he drew the sword in its defence.
('33', 30, 2, 12, 65806) But I cannot judge his actions, nor can I use him as my model so far as his resort to the sword is concerned.
('33', 30, 2, 13, 65916) What I would have done had I lived in his times and held the same views that I hold now I do not know.
('33', 30, 2, 14, 66019) Such speculation I regard as perfect waste of time.
('33', 30, 2, 15, 66071) I do not regard Sikhism as a religion distinct from Hinduism.
('33', 30, 2, 16, 66133) I regard it as part of Hinduism and the reformation in the same sense that vaishnavism is.
('33', 30, 2, 17, 66224) I read in the Yeravda Prison all the writings that I could lay my hands upon regarding the Sikhs.
('33', 30, 2, 18, 66322) I read portions of Granth Saheb.
('33', 30, 2, 19, 66355) Its deeply spiritual and moral tone I found to be uplifting.
('33', 30, 2, 20, 66416) In the collection of hymns we have at the Ashram, we have some of Guru Nanak’s also.
('33', 30, 2, 21, 66501) At the same time, I do not quarrel with the Sikhs for considering, if they wish, Sikhism as totally distinct from Hinduism.
('33', 30, 2, 22, 66625) And when during my first visit to the Punjab, a few Sikh friends told me that my reference to Sikhism as part of Hinduism displeased them, I ceased to refer to it as such.
('33', 30, 2, 23, 66797) But the Sikh friends will pardon me for avowing my belief when I am asked to express my opinion about Sikhism.
('33', 30, 2, 24, 66908) Now about Krishna.
('33', 30, 2, 25, 66927) Whilst I have dealt with the Gurus as
('33', 30, 3, 26, 66965) 1 Vide”My Friend, the Revolutionary”, 9 4 1925.
('33', 31, 0, 1, 67013) 32 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 31, 1, 2, 67054) historical personages about whose existence we have trustworthy records, I have no knowledge that the Krishna of the Mahabharata ever lived.
('33', 31, 1, 3, 67195) My Krishna has nothing to do with any historical person.
('33', 31, 1, 4, 67252) I would refuse to bow my head to the Krishna who would kill because his pride is hurt, or the Krishna whom non Hindus portray as a dissolute youth.
('33', 31, 1, 5, 67400) I believe in Krishna of my imagination as a perfect incarnation, spotless in every sense of the word, the inspirer of the Gita and the inspirer of the lives of millions of human beings.
('33', 31, 1, 6, 67586) But if it was proved to me that the Mahabharata is history in the same sense that modern historical books are, that every word of the Mahabharata is authentic and that the Krishna of the Mahabharata actually did some of the acts attributed to him, even at the risk of being banished from the Hindu fold, I should not hesitate to reject that Krishna as God incarnate.
('33', 31, 1, 7, 67953) But to me the Mahabharata is a profoundly religious book, largely allegorical, in no way meant to be a historical record.
('33', 31, 1, 8, 68075) It is the description of the eternal duel going on within ourselves, given so vividly as to make us think, for the time being that the deeds described therein were actually done by the human beings.
('33', 31, 1, 9, 68274) Nor do I regard the Mahabharata as we have it now as a faultless copy of the original.
('33', 31, 1, 10, 68361) On the contrary I consider that it has undergone many emendations.
('33', 31, 2, 11, 68428) Young India, 1 10 1925
('33', 31, 3, 12, 68451) 27. ALL INDIA SPINNERS’ ASSOCIATION
('33', 31, 4, 13, 68487) The reader will see printed elsewhere the constitution of the All India Spinners’ Association.
('33', 31, 4, 14, 68582) A careful study of it will show that it is, at the present moment, not only not a democratic institution but that, in efect, it is a one man’s show.
('33', 31, 4, 15, 68731) It may represent either the arrogance of the person who calls into being such an institution or his absolute faith in the cause and in himself.
('33', 31, 4, 16, 68875) So far as man can be aware of himself, I know that there is no arrogance in giving an autocratic character to the Association.
('33', 31, 4, 17, 69002) Commercial bodies can never be democratic.
('33', 31, 4, 18, 69045) And if hand spinning is to become universal and successful in the country, its non political and purely economical side must be now fully devel oped.
('33', 31, 4, 19, 69195) That development is sought to be attained by the All India Spinners’ Association.
('33', 31, 4, 20, 69277) In choosing my colleagues in the Association, I have been guided by the sole consideration of utility.
('33', 31, 4, 21, 69380) Each one has been selected
('33', 32, 0, 1, 69407) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 33
('33', 32, 1, 2, 69457) for his special qualification.
('33', 32, 1, 3, 69488) In making the selection there was no question of representation of different provinces.
('33', 32, 1, 4, 69576) And some of the best workers have been left out of the Council because of the possibility of misunderstandings.
('33', 32, 1, 5, 69688) What special qualification from the spinners’ standpoint has Maulana Shaukat Ali, it may be asked.
('33', 32, 1, 6, 69787) The special qualification that he has is that he is a Mussalman, a pukka believer in khadi, wants to spin one thousand yards every month and to do all he can for the charkha and khaddar.
('33', 32, 1, 7, 69974) I have purposely omitted active Swarajists because, for obvious reasons, they cannot give their time predominantly to khaddar.
('33', 32, 1, 8, 70101) At the time of the formation of the Association at which I was assisted by over one hundred khaddar lovers, including Swarajists, I was asked whether I had ceased to believe in the political importance of khadi or of its ability to produce an atmosphere for civil resistance.
('33', 32, 1, 9, 70377) My answer was an emphatic ‘no’.
('33', 32, 1, 10, 70409) The political importance of khaddar consists in its economic capacity.
('33', 32, 1, 11, 70480) A people that are starving for want of occupation can have no political consciousness.
('33', 32, 1, 12, 70567) Khaddar will have no political importance in a country where no cloth is needed and where people live on hunting, or in a country where people live on exploitation of peoples belonging to other countries.
('33', 32, 1, 13, 70772) The political importance of khaddar in India is derived from her peculiar condition in that it needs cloth, it exploits no other country, and its millions have nothing to do for four months in the year, though they are starving.
('33', 32, 1, 14, 71001) The ability of khaddar to give an atmosphere of civil resistance consists in its ability, if successful, of making us conscious of some power within us and its ability to produce an atmosphere of calmness, and yet fixed determination behind that calmness.
('33', 32, 1, 15, 71257) Many people who have civil resistance on their lips have still little notion of what it means.
('33', 32, 1, 16, 71352) They mix it up with an atmosphere of intense excitement, ready at any moment to develop into actual violence, whereas civil resistance is the very opposite of it.
('33', 32, 1, 17, 71515) And neither the political result nor the calm atmosphere are possible without khadi becoming an economic success.
('33', 32, 1, 18, 71629) Hence it is necessary to emphasize its paramount and economic aspect which is also its direct result.
('33', 32, 1, 19, 71731) The preamble, therefore, is deliberate and vital.
('33', 32, 1, 20, 71781) The fiercest politician and the fiercest civil resister may join the Association, but he does so as an economic worker.
('33', 32, 1, 21, 71901) No maharaja need shun the Association if he admits the great economic value of khadi and the paramount necessity of finding a proper supplementary employment for the starving millions of India.
('33', 32, 1, 22, 72095) I, therefore, venture to invite all
('33', 33, 0, 1, 72131) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 33, 1, 2, 72172) those who believe in khadi and the spinning wheel to join the Association irrespective of their politics and irrespective of race or creed.
('33', 33, 1, 3, 72312) I would invite Englishmen and other Europeans who are mindful of the welfare of the starving millions of India to join the Association.
('33', 33, 1, 4, 72448) I know that there are many who believe in khadi, who believe in hand spinning, but will not spin themselves.
('33', 33, 1, 5, 72557) Let them become Associates, if they will not even wear khadi and yet want khadi to make all the progress it can.
('33', 33, 1, 6, 72670) Let them support want khadi to make all the progress it can.
('33', 33, 1, 7, 72731) Let them support the Association with their donations.
('33', 33, 2, 8, 72786) Let there be, however, no mistake that so long as it pleases the Congres to allow it, the Association will remain an integral part of the Congress organization.
('33', 33, 2, 9, 72947) As such it will be its duty to render all the assistance it can to the Congress in its programme of hand spinning and khadi.
('33', 33, 2, 10, 73072) The connecting link between the Congress and the Association is thus a common faith in the spinning wheel and khadi.
('33', 33, 2, 11, 73189) The Association as such will not concern itself or be in any way affected by the varying politics of the Congress.
('33', 33, 2, 12, 73304) Its existence will be independent, its object merely confined to the propagation of the spinning wheel and khadi, and it will be governed by its own separate constitution, so much so that it has adopted a different franchise and it can take in, as I have already said, non congressmen as members and no congressman, not even a spinning member, is bound to become a member of the Association.
('33', 33, 3, 13, 73696) The constitution is not as rigid as I had at first intended.
('33', 33, 3, 14, 73757) The drafts circulated by me required two thousand yards of yarn per month for membership of A class; and a declaration to the following effect was intended to be required from such members:”It is my firm belief that the economic salvation of the masses of India is impossible without the universal adoption by the country of the spinning wheel and its product khaddar.
('33', 33, 3, 15, 74126) I shall, therefore, except when desabled by illness or some unforeseen event, spin daily, for at least half an hour and habitually wear hand spun and hand woven khaddar, and in the event of my belief undergoing a change, or my ceasing to spin or wear khaddar, I shall resign the membership of this Association.”
('33', 33, 4, 16, 74438) The two thousand yards were reduced to one thousand because a strenuous fight was put up on behalf of those who wanted to become A class members and yet found it difficult to give 2,000 yards per month.
('33', 33, 4, 17, 74641) The declaration itself was dropped because the vey idea of a
('33', 34, 0, 1, 74702) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 35
('33', 34, 1, 2, 74752) solemn undertaking seemed to be repugnant, I still think quite wrongly, to others.
('33', 34, 1, 3, 74835) My own opinion and that of many others is that promises or vows are necessary for the strongest of us.
('33', 34, 1, 4, 74938) A promise is like a right angle not nearly but exactly of 90°.
('33', 34, 1, 5, 75001) The slightest deflection makes it useless for the grand purpose that the right angle serves.
('33', 34, 1, 6, 75094) A voluntary promise is like a plumb line keeping a man straight and warning him when he is going wrong.
('33', 34, 1, 7, 75198) Rules of general application do not serve the same purpose as an individual vow.
('33', 34, 1, 8, 75279) We find therefore the system of declarations followed in all large and well conducted institutions.
('33', 34, 1, 9, 75379) The Viceroy has to take the oath of office.
('33', 34, 1, 10, 75423) Members of Legislatures have to do likewise all the world over, andin my opinion rightly so.
('33', 34, 1, 11, 75516) A soldier joining an army has to do likewise.
('33', 34, 1, 12, 75562) Moreover, a written undertaking reminds onw of what one has promised to do.
('33', 34, 1, 13, 75638) Memory is a very frail thing.
('33', 34, 1, 14, 75668) The written word stands for ever.
('33', 34, 1, 15, 75702) But as there was fairly strong opposition to the retention of declarations, I felt that I should waive them as it was common ground among all that, whilst the declaration might not be taken as a matter of fact, the belief affirmed in the declaration was and should be the belief of every member and that every member was expected to spin at least for half an hour daily except when unavoidably prevented from doing so.
('33', 34, 1, 16, 76121) There was an additional clause to the declaration to be made by members of the Council, and it was this: “I promise faithfully to discharge the obligations of my office as member of the Council of the Association and give preference to the furtherance of its objects over all other work, public or private, that I might undertake.” It was suggested that whilst the declaration should not be taken, the promise of faithful discharge of obligations of office must be an understood thing in an association whose Council was necessarily to consist of whole timers.
('33', 34, 1, 17, 76682) Indeed, the holding of office in the Council is all duty and no right.
('33', 34, 1, 18, 76753) And where it is all service and no certificate save that of one’s own conscience, all can take part in it whether they hold office or not.
('33', 34, 1, 19, 76892) I hope therefore that no omission will be resented or misunderstood.
('33', 34, 1, 20, 76961) On the contrary I am hoping that allo the khadi workers, who had any new or important idea, or special talent for serving, will not fail to give the association the benefit of his or her idea or talent.
('33', 34, 1, 21, 77164) If its activity is to succeed, it will need all the assistance that the lowliest among us can give.
('33', 34, 2, 22, 77264) Young India, 1 10 1925

('33', 35, 1, 2, 77328) 28. NOTES
('33', 35, 2, 3, 77338) MY APOLOGIES It is a matter of deep regret that I had to be party to the postponement of the rest of my tour in Bihar.
('33', 35, 2, 4, 77457) But I was helpless.
('33', 35, 2, 5, 77477) I saw that my health was becoming gradually undermined by the incessant travelling which I have been doing since the fast 1 of last year.
('33', 35, 2, 6, 77615) There seems to be nothing organically wrong with me.
('33', 35, 2, 7, 77668) Only tired limbs need some rest.
('33', 35, 2, 8, 77701) Babu Rajendra Prasad observed my dilapidated condition and observed also that I was ill able to stand the shouts of thousands of men, however lovingly meant they were.
('33', 35, 2, 9, 77869) He has, therefore, absolved me from the tour beyond 15th October, and the revised programme even up to that date has been made so light as to give me ample rest every day and leave me two clear days per week for my editing.
('33', 35, 2, 10, 78093) The U.P. friends have been equally indulgent and obliging and will be satisfied with only two days in the U.P. The Maharashtrian khaddar lovers have absolved me from my promise to visit some parts of Maharashtra during November.
('33', 35, 2, 11, 78322) And I am to finish this year’s travelling with an easy fortnight in Cutch.
('33', 35, 2, 12, 78397) The Cutch friends are insistent that I should visit them during October.
('33', 35, 2, 13, 78470) But they promise to make my tour in Cutch noiseless and thoroughly restful and they have dangled before me a fat purse for the advancement of hand spinning, spinning wheel and khaddar.
('33', 35, 2, 14, 78655) I thank all those who have been so kind and considerate to me.
('33', 35, 2, 15, 78718) I expect the Cutch friends to be true to their promise.
('33', 35, 2, 16, 78774) To those provinces who have been indulgent to me I promise that I will visit them if they still wish me to do so next year.
('33', 35, 2, 17, 78898) The programme can be fixed by mutual consultation at Cawnpore.

('33', 35, 5, 21, 79371) In the opinion of the All India Congress Committee, India should not become a party to any scheme of repatriation whether described as voluntary or compulsory.

('33', 36, 2, 6, 80496) POOR ON 14 LACS A friend writes: You are reported to claim to be a sannyasi and yet to have taken scrupulous care to have provided yourself with handsome living for yourself and your dependents and that you have made to that end a trust of tour estate which is worth fourteen lacs and that you are leading a very easy and comfortable life.
('33', 36, 2, 7, 80836) Some of us were staggered to hear this.
('33', 36, 2, 8, 80876) Will you kindly enlighten the public on the point?
('33', 36, 2, 9, 80927) I myself refuse to believe the report.
('33', 36, 2, 10, 80966) If this query had not come from an honest friend whom I know, I would have taken no notice of it, especially as some months ago, in answer to a question about my personal expenses, I have dealt with my private affairs.
('33', 36, 2, 11, 81185) I never had 14 lacs of rupees which I could call my own.
('33', 36, 2, 12, 81242) What I did have I had certainly reduced to a trust when I renounced all property.
('33', 36, 2, 13, 81324) But it was a trust for public purposes.
('33', 36, 2, 14, 81364) I re tained for myself nothing out of that trust.
('33', 36, 2, 15, 81414) But I have never described myself as a sannyasi.
('33', 36, 2, 16, 81463) Sannyas is made of sterner stuff, I regard myself as a householder, leading a humble life of service and, in common with my fellow workers, living upon the charity of friends who defray the expenses of Satyagraha Ashram at Sabarmati of which I am one of the founders.
('33', 36, 2, 17, 81731) The life I am living is certainly very easy and very comfortable, if ease and comfort are a mental state.
('33', 36, 2, 18, 81837) I have all I need without the slightest care of having to keep any personal treasures.
('33', 36, 2, 19, 81924) Mine is a life full of joy in the midst of incessant work.

('33', 45, 1, 10, 104025) He would suck the poison out of the body of an untouchable if bitten by a snake, even at the risk of his life and he does not regard his religion (dharma) as suffering a whit by the touch of an untouchable.
('33', 45, 1, 11, 104232) In so acting he simply follows the religion of love and kindness (daya) taught by Tulsidas, in the pursuit of which, if one were to die, one would go straight to heaven.
('33', 45, 1, 12, 104402) Thus, this saint regards untouchablity as a great sin.
('33', 45, 1, 13, 104457) He takes untouchables away from the place where they live to a better surrounding and offers them food enough to satisfy their hunger—not in the manner in which you and I throw the refuse of our dishes to them.
('33', 45, 1, 14, 104668) I myself have seen my mother and my wife doing so—but he feeds them lovingly and a affectionately.
('33', 45, 1, 15, 104767) In our houses separate arrangements exist for cooking food for our dogs, cows, oxen, etc.
('33', 45, 1, 16, 104857) But these untouchables receive but the very refuse of our dishes.
('33', 45, 1, 17, 104923) I do not regard it as daya dharma.
('33', 45, 1, 18, 104958) We must be loving and affectionate in feeding even the untouchables and our religion would not suffer in any way for that.
('33', 45, 1, 19, 105081) Some people act in that spirit with the result that they have been boycotted by society.

('33', 45, 1, 23, 105548) When influential men in society go wrong, when out of ignorance or malice they want to boycott a certain man, then it is his duty, he who does not agree with them, to allow himself to be boycotted by them.

('33', 49, 1, 15, 114976) They, therefore, find it difficult to dispose of such hides in the market.

('33', 51, 2, 3, 119163) ON TOUR, October3, 1925
('33', 51, 3, 4, 119187) DEAR FRIEND,
('33', 51, 4, 5, 119200) You asked me questions now over a month ago about the advisability of getting enough recognition from the Calcutta University so as to enable you to take boys who might desire to appear for its examinations.
('33', 51, 4, 6, 119408) Personally I am averse to it.
('33', 51, 4, 7, 119438) I do not like this mania for examinations.
('33', 51, 4, 8, 119481) It has undermined the mental and physical health of our youth.
('33', 51, 4, 9, 119544) For this reason alone, if for no other, I would like national institutions to remain unbending and depend for their progress upon their own inherent merit.
('33', 51, 4, 10, 119700) I would like a proper revolt against the soul destroying examinations.
('33', 51, 4, 11, 119771) But you know best what you should do in the circumstances that face you and if you have not the same repugnance that I have for the mania for university certificates, you would unhesitatingly secure the restricted recognition you mention.
('33', 51, 4, 12, 120010) What with my temperament would be bad for me need not be necessarily bad for you or anyone else with a different temperament.
('33', 51, 4, 13, 120136) I would therefore like you not to follow my opinion unless it appeals to you so forcibly as to give you satisfaction, even though without recognition your school may contain only twenty boys or even less.
('33', 51, 4, 14, 120341) I would love to train even one boy with robust independence.
('33', 51, 4, 15, 120402) I thoroughly understand and appreciate all that you say in favour of securing ‘recognition’ of the limited type referred to by you and it is a view that deserves respectful consideration.
('33', 51, 4, 16, 120590) I would not therefore misunderstand you if, after weighing all the pros and cons, you come to the conclusion that it is best for you and the people in whose midst you are working to apply for recognition .
('33', 51, 5, 17, 120796) Yours sincerely,
('33', 51, 6, 18, 120813) M. K. GANDHI

('33', 52, 1, 2, 120904) 32. TO MY BROTHERS AND SISTERS OF KUTCH
('33', 52, 2, 3, 120944) On the 21st of October, I shall, God willing, set foot in Kutch for the first time in my life.
('33', 52, 2, 4, 121039) 1 In agreeing to go there at this time I have yielded to the power of love.
('33', 52, 2, 5, 121115) Other provinces, out of compassion for me, have left me free for this year.
('33', 52, 2, 6, 121191) You want me to go there while the Maharao 2 is present and the thought was painful to me that, if I did not go in October, a trip that had been talked about for nine months could not be undertaken until April.
('33', 52, 2, 7, 121401) You have assured me that you will let me have rest in Kutch and that you will hand me large sums of money for the cause of the spinning whel and khadi.
('33', 52, 2, 8, 121553) This is great temptation for me.
('33', 52, 2, 9, 121586) I too am eager to meet the Maharao Saheb.
('33', 52, 2, 10, 121628) I am a good friend and servant of the Princes.
('33', 52, 2, 11, 121675) My father, grand father and other relations were in the service of Indian States.
('33', 52, 2, 12, 121757) Even today, I see a few of my relations earning their living in the States of kathiawar.
('33', 52, 2, 13, 121846) But my connections with Indian States cannot blind my eyes to facts.
('33', 52, 2, 14, 121915) I am not unaware of the state of misrule in certain States.
('33', 52, 2, 15, 121975) I have received a pile of letters from the people regarding the Maharao Saheb’s administration.
('33', 52, 2, 16, 122071) I shall express my genuine regards for the Maharao Saheb by putting the substance of these letters before him with an open mind.
('33', 52, 3, 17, 122200) I do not hanker after respect from either the Princes or their subjects.
('33', 52, 3, 18, 122273) I have had too much of respect.
('33', 52, 3, 19, 122305) If I was not afraid of appearing guilty of discourtesy, I would agree to visit a place only on condition that I was not given an address of welcome there.
('33', 52, 3, 20, 122460) The cries of”Victory to the Mahatma” jar on my ears.
('33', 52, 3, 21, 122513) All shouting has become unbearable to me.
('33', 52, 3, 22, 122555) I wish to remain an untouchable so far as touching of my feet in reverence is concerned.
('33', 52, 3, 23, 122644) If people feel any respect for me, I should certainly like to see them emulate whatever is good in me.
('33', 52, 3, 24, 122747) My brothers and sisters in Kutch have showered love on me.
('33', 52, 3, 25, 122806) They have also given me large sums of money for my work.
('33', 52, 3, 26, 122863) My hunger, however, can never be satisfied.
('33', 52, 3, 27, 122907) In my old age now I have only two or three means of worshipping God.
('33', 52, 3, 28, 122976) I should like to devote the rest of my life to these.
('33', 52, 4, 29, 123030) 1 Gandhiji reached Kutch on October 22,1925. 2 The ruler of the then princely State of Kutch
('33', 53, 0, 1, 123123) 54 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 53, 1, 2, 123164) The name of Rama is dear to my lips; if, however, this is not engraved in my heart, its mechanical repetition would only bring me degradation.
('33', 53, 1, 3, 123307) What is in one’s heart is certain to be expressed in one’s actions.
('33', 53, 1, 4, 123375) I have, therefore, always regarded the service of others as the only true dharma.
('33', 53, 2, 5, 123457) Thus it is that I found the spinning wheel and the work of eradication of untouchability.
('33', 53, 2, 6, 123547) Through the spinning wheel I serve the poorest of the poor in the country.
('33', 53, 2, 7, 123622) I invite the Maharao Saheb and his subjects to join me in this yajna.
('33', 53, 3, 8, 123692) Howerever, the people of Kutch are of a venturesome spirit.
('33', 53, 3, 9, 123752) They cross the oceans for the sake of trade.
('33', 53, 3, 10, 123797) It is not enough for them to spin and wear khadi.
('33', 53, 3, 11, 123847) I expect them to give me money and help the walking skeletons in the country to put on some flesh.
('33', 53, 3, 12, 123946) It should not be forgotten that this is what we have resolved to do to perpetuate Deshbandhu’s memory.
('33', 53, 3, 13, 124049) I have heard it said that I take money from Kutch and send it elsewhere.
('33', 53, 3, 14, 124122) This is a fact, but it should not be a complaint.
('33', 53, 3, 15, 124172) Why should I collect money for Kutch?
('33', 53, 3, 16, 124210) If there is poverty in Kutch, the fact is a slur on the Maharao Saheb and on the multi millionaires of Kutch.
('33', 53, 3, 17, 124320) I have never lived there.
('33', 53, 3, 18, 124346) Through whom can I use the money there?
('33', 53, 3, 19, 124386) It would be proper for the people of Kutch to collect the money which they need and use it there.
('33', 53, 3, 20, 124484) It is my job to collect money from wherever possible and use it where I see the need and for work which seems essential to me or for specified, worthy causes.
('33', 53, 3, 21, 124643) There are rich Vaishnavas in Kutch.
('33', 53, 3, 22, 124679) Being myself a Vaishnava, I believe I know what the term means.
('33', 53, 3, 23, 124743) My conscience can never accept the idea that a Vaishnava can regard himself polluted by the touch of an Antyaja and still be a Vaishnava.
('33', 53, 3, 24, 124881) Just as, through the spinning wheel, I wish to serve the Divine Mother, whose children are the poor, so I wish to purify Hinduism by working for the eradication of untouchability and serving the Antyajas thereby.
('33', 53, 3, 25, 125094) We cannot persist in the practice of untouchability, and at the same time hope to preserve Hinduism.
('33', 53, 3, 26, 125195) I cannot bear Antyajas being treated with contempt.
