('33', 55, 0, 1, 128013) 56 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 55, 1, 2, 128054) 33. SPINNERS’ ASSOCIATION
('33', 55, 2, 3, 128080) The establishment of the spinners’ Association is no ordinary event.
('33', 55, 2, 4, 128149) It is the fruit of the pledge taken by its founders.
('33', 55, 2, 5, 128202) It proclaims their faith in the spinning wheel and their determination to sacrifice everything for its sake.
('33', 55, 2, 6, 128311) To me, it stands for swaraj.
('33', 55, 2, 7, 128340) I believe it to be impossible to serve the millions except through it.
('33', 55, 2, 8, 128411) No one can serve all individually.
('33', 55, 2, 9, 128446) Every person, however, can engage himself in work which involves the service of all and whose fruit will be shard by everyone.
('33', 55, 2, 10, 128573) Only the spinning wheel can reach crores of people, can satisfy their hunger and function as Annapoorna 1 to them.
('33', 55, 2, 11, 128688) If I start a factory which makes baskets, I would thereby be able to help thousands of persons, if a soap factory, I can provide employment to about four thousand persons, and to the same number through a textile mill,—all the mills taken together provide employment to fifteen lakhs of persons and offer dividentds to about four thousand persons.
('33', 55, 2, 12, 129036) If, however, I engage myself in promoting spinning, I join an industry providing employment to crores.
('33', 55, 2, 13, 129139) On reflection, the reader will see that there is no other work which can benefit crores.
('33', 55, 2, 14, 129228) Agriculture is indeed one such profession.
('33', 55, 2, 15, 129271) But, for one thing, it has not disappeared and, for another it is not a kind of work which anyone can do at any hour and for any length of time.
('33', 55, 2, 16, 129416) But spinning?
('33', 55, 2, 17, 129430) One can do it at any place, and if one carries a takli in one’s pocket, one can spin a few yards by way of yajna even while walking.
('33', 55, 2, 18, 129563) Spinning done even for a minute is useful, but one cannot do farming in that way.
('33', 55, 2, 19, 129645) That work must be done for a certain minimum, and considerable length of time at one place.
('33', 55, 2, 20, 129737) Spinning, therefore, is a great sacrifice in which all can easily join.
('33', 55, 2, 21, 129809) Is there anyone who would not like to join an Association devoted to such work?
('33', 55, 2, 22, 129889) How can we argue with people who object to spinning?
('33', 55, 2, 23, 129942) Why should anyone fail to welcome the addition of a few yards of yarn to the country’s wealth, and that too through work done in spare time?
('33', 55, 2, 24, 130083) I wish that all men and women will join this Association.
('33', 55, 2, 25, 130141) I did not like and many others also did not like, the change permitting the contribution of 1,000 instead of 2,000 yards of yarn.
('33', 55, 2, 26, 130271) This however
('33', 55, 3, 27, 130284) 1 Goddess of plenty
('33', 56, 0, 1, 130304) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 57
('33', 56, 1, 2, 130354) is no reason for keeping out of the Association.
('33', 56, 1, 3, 130403) Anyone who wishes may certainly contribute 2,000 yards.
('33', 56, 1, 4, 130459) It is a very desirable thing to take a pledge, but the omission of the clause requiring a pledge does not mean that those who were in favour of taking a pledge should not join the Association.
('33', 56, 1, 5, 130652) They may, as individuals, certainly take the pledge.
('33', 56, 1, 6, 130705) Moreover, even though a pledge is not necessary the understanding is that, except for circumstances beyond one’s control, every member will spin daily for half an hour.
('33', 56, 1, 7, 130874) The idea of prescribing a pledge was dropped, but every member of the Executive Committee will regard the spinning movement as his principal sphere of work.
('33', 56, 1, 8, 131031) But what about persons under eighteen and those who cannot spin regularly?
('33', 56, 1, 9, 131106) As in the past, they should spin and send as gift as much yarn as they can.
('33', 56, 1, 10, 131182) No cotton will be given this time, and no attempt will be made to flatter and persuade people to spin.
('33', 56, 1, 11, 131285) Let only those send yarn who accept spinning as a sacred duty.
('33', 56, 1, 12, 131348) Cotton costs very little and, besides, we should not spend on anything more than it is worth.
('33', 56, 1, 13, 131442) The very purpose of begging for voluntary gifts of cotton is that: 1. khadi may be made cheaper; 2. people, instead of idling away their time, may spend it in the service of the country; 3. the rich may establish a direct link with the poor and think of them every day; 4. Everyone may help in bringing about boycott of foreign cloth; 5. everyone may serve the country in one way or another to the best of his or her ability; 6. the middle class, which at present lives on the toil of the poor and willingly gives nothing in return, may now give something; 7. the middle class may, by its example of spinning, show to the poor who have lost faith in life itself the means of recovering that faith.
('33', 56, 1, 14, 132140) These results will follow only if people spin with love.
('33', 56, 1, 15, 132197) Much monetary help will be required in this great task.
('33', 56, 1, 16, 132253) I hope that those who have faith in the spinning wheel will not only contribute yarn but also, if they can afford it, help with money.
('33', 56, 1, 17, 132388) This body will provide employment to many in the middle class.
('33', 56, 1, 18, 132451) The figures which I have published show that even today a large number are earning their livelihood through this work.
('33', 56, 1, 19, 132570) If the Asso ciation works in a big way it can become a means of providing
('33', 57, 0, 1, 132644) 58 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 57, 1, 2, 132685) employment to thousands.
('33', 57, 1, 3, 132710) It is not at all surprising that a work which involves trade worth crores of rupees can help thousands to earn an honest living.
('33', 57, 1, 4, 132839) And now about the question of confidence.
('33', 57, 1, 5, 132881) Are the members of the Committee men of ability and do they inspire confidence?
('33', 57, 1, 6, 132961) In my humble view, they are and they do.
('33', 57, 1, 7, 133002) It is true that there are other workers of equal worth who have been left out.
('33', 57, 1, 8, 133081) It has been suggested that a sort of Brains Trust should be formed by including in it all those who ought to have been on the Committee but are not.
('33', 57, 1, 9, 133230) I have thought over this suggestion, and feel that there is no need for such a body.
('33', 57, 1, 10, 133315) There is less to think about and more to do.
('33', 57, 1, 11, 133360) It would, therefore, be better to have as small a body as possible consisting of men who would give all their time to the task of setting up a machinery for implementing the decisions.
('33', 57, 1, 12, 133545) This is an Association for service, and not for satisfying one’s desire for power and authority.
('33', 57, 1, 13, 133642) In a body in which there is no scope at all for anyone to assume leadership and the only duty is that of service, there can be no rivalry for positions of authority.
('33', 57, 1, 14, 133808) I wish that those whose one aim is to serve will send whatever suggestions they feel like making any time.
('33', 57, 1, 15, 133915) If we form a Brains Trust, it should meet and deliberate.
('33', 57, 1, 16, 133973) This may be necessary when we have to consider a new policy or method of work.
('33', 57, 1, 17, 134052) In the present instance, what is required is supervision of work.
('33', 57, 1, 18, 134118) I, therefore, feel that a committee of twelve is sufficient for our purpose.
('33', 57, 1, 19, 134195) I have given up the idea of filling the three vacancies which remain even in this small number, for it is not necessary that every place should be filled.
('33', 57, 1, 20, 134350) Experience alone will teach us what more we need.
('33', 57, 1, 21, 134400) Our aim in undertaking trade in khadi is service.
('33', 57, 1, 22, 134450) The service motive has no place in other forms of trade.
('33', 57, 1, 23, 134507) It is believed that business and service do not go together.We cannot do trade in khadi at all without State patronage or unless we undertake it with service motive.
('33', 57, 1, 24, 134673) If those who undertake it should do so with such a motive, those who buy khadi should be actuated by the same motive.
('33', 57, 1, 25, 134791) There is no doubt that anyone who gives up the use of Paris lace or Manchester muslin, despite all his love for them, and takes to khadi, will be serving others by his action.
('33', 57, 1, 26, 134967) May God increase the number of dedicated khadi workers.

('33', 61, 1, 2, 140233) 39. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, GIRIDIH October 7, 1925
('33', 61, 2, 3, 140287) Gandhiji received addresses from the Local Board, the public, the Municipality and the goshala in a public meeting attended by not less than ten thousand men.
('33', 61, 3, 4, 140446) Mahatmaji said that he was given to understand that Giridih being a mica field labourers could not be induced to take to the charkha when they got more money by working in the pits.
('33', 61, 3, 5, 140628) To them he said that he could understand labourers not spinning, but he could not understand where was the difficulty in their not using khadi.
('33', 61, 3, 6, 140772) The middle class people had ample time to spare and they could easily afford to give half an hour to spinning, not for themselves but for the sake of their country, and give over the yarn produced as charity to the Congress.
('33', 61, 3, 7, 140997) One yard of khaddar was certainly comparatively dearer than the cheaper foreign cloth, but all the same it was cheaper as it enabled some money to go direct into the pockets of their poor sisters and the weavers.
('33', 61, 3, 8, 141210) He next referred to untouchability and said that it was a standing disgrace for Hinduism, and although he thanked them for running a school for the untoucha bles, he could not be satisfied if they themselves did not go to them to mix with them and enquire about their poverty and their grievances, and try to remove them.
('33', 61, 4, 9, 141532) In the Local Board address it was hinted that the obstinacy of the laws and their differences with the District Board stood in the way of their doing even their own work.
('33', 61, 5, 10, 141703) In these conditions it was practically impossible for them to claim any solid work to their credit .
('33', 61, 5, 11, 141804) But they could promise to do any work whatever in future when conditions improved.
('33', 61, 5, 12, 141887) To them Mahatmaji said that no obstacle was too great if they only had the will to surmount it.
('33', 61, 5, 13, 141983) On this somebody whispered that it was difficult to keep the roads in a good condition when they had no money.
('33', 61, 5, 14, 142094) Mahatmaji retorting said that they should work on the roads themselves and see that they were well kept if they had not sifficient money to repair them.
('33', 61, 6, 15, 142247) A municipal commissioner said that he had not sufficient money to engage scavengers.
('33', 61, 6, 16, 142332) In that case, Mahatmaji said they must do the work of scavengers themselves and clean even the night soil themselves.
('33', 61, 6, 17, 142450) He had done these things in Durban and he knew the dignity of it.
('33', 61, 6, 18, 142516) The goshala address referred to cow protection.
('33', 61, 6, 19, 142564) To them he would only say this—that the Hindus themselves were responsible for the large number of cows slaughtered.
('33', 61, 6, 20, 142681) If they wanted, they could stop cow slaughter today for which they would have to raise its price and not appeal to or fight with the Muslims or Englishmen to spare the cows.
('33', 61, 6, 21, 142855) They had to establish dairies where cheapest and purest milk could be had.
('33', 61, 6, 22, 142930) They must not look upon the business of tannery as a peculiarly low one, but should organize the mochis 1 and have tanneries of their own where hides of only dead, and not slaughtered, animals could be used.
('33', 61, 6, 23, 143138) Their goshalas were not working well.
('33', 61, 7, 24, 143176) 1 Cobblers or shoe makers
('33', 62, 0, 1, 143202) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 63
('33', 62, 1, 2, 143252) They must be run on commercial lines.
('33', 62, 1, 3, 143290) With an appeal for the Deshbandhu fund he concluded his address.
('33', 62, 1, 4, 143355) A decent collection was made on the spot and a purse of Rs. 2,075 was presented to him on behalf of the Giridih public.
('33', 62, 1, 5, 143475) The Searchlight, 9 10 1925
('33', 62, 2, 6, 143502) 40. SPEECH AT WOMEN’S MEETING, GIRIDIH
('33', 62, 3, 7, 143541) October 7, 1925
('33', 62, 4, 8, 143557) Gandhiji in reply 1. .
('33', 62, 4, 9, 143580) .thanked the the ladies for the kind words expressed in the address.
('33', 62, 4, 10, 143649) He said that, in order to attain swaraj which was not only the political Home Rule but also dharma raj of the kind which was generally understood as Ramarajya,
('33', 62, 5, 11, 143809) which was something higher than ordinary political emancipation, they must try to become like Sita of yore who was the soul of Ramarajya.
('33', 62, 5, 12, 143947) In the days of Sita every
('33', 62, 6, 13, 143973) household had its charkha just as they find a hearth in every home.

('33', 62, 8, 18, 144406) 41. BIHAR NOTES
('33', 62, 9, 19, 144422) WITH ABORIGINALS
('33', 62, 10, 20, 144439) From Chakradharpur to Chaibasa is a pleasant motor ride over a very good road.
('33', 62, 10, 21, 144518) It was at Chaibasa that I made the acquaintance of the Ho tribe—a most interesting body of men and women, simple as children, with a faith that it is not easy to shake.
('33', 62, 10, 22, 144687) Many of them have taken to the charkha and khaddar.
('33', 62, 10, 23, 144739) Congress workers began the work of reformation among them in 1921. Many have given up eating carrion and some have even taken to vegetarianism.
('33', 62, 10, 24, 144883) The mundas are another tribe whom I met at Khunti on my way to Ranchi.
('33', 62, 10, 25, 144954) The scope for work in their midst is inexhaustible.
('33', 62, 10, 26, 145006) Christian missionaries have been doing valuable service for generations, but, in my humble opinion, their work suffers because at the end of it they expect conversion of these simple people to Christianity.
('33', 62, 10, 27, 145213) I had the pleasure of seeing some of their schools in these places.
('33', 62, 10, 28, 145281) It was all pleasing, but
('33', 62, 11, 29, 145306) 1 An address was presented to Gandhiji by the Head Mistress of the local girls’ school.

('33', 63, 1, 2, 145494) I could see the coming conflict between the missionaries and the Hindu workers.

('33', 63, 1, 7, 146215) Among these tribes there is quite a colony of them called bhaktas, literally meaning devotees.

('33', 63, 2, 14, 146680) IN CHHOTA NAGPUR Almost the whole of my travelling in Chhota Nagpur was in motor cars, but the roads are all good and the scenery around magnificent.
('33', 63, 2, 15, 146830) From Chaibasa we had to retrace our steps to chakradharpur and from there we motored to Ranchi, halting at Khunti and one or two other places.
('33', 63, 2, 16, 146973) Just before reaching Ranchi at 7 o’clock in the evening a meeting of ladies had been arranged.
('33', 63, 2, 17, 147068) I do not think that either the organizers or the ladies had bargained for my appeal for the Deshbandhu Memorial Fund.
('33', 63, 2, 18, 147186) But as I hardly ever fail to make that appeal when I address public meetings, I made it at this meeting also.

('33', 63, 2, 20, 147329) Many being unprepared had no money with them.

('33', 63, 2, 23, 147584) Needless to say, I make it perfectly clear at these meetings that the whole of the gifts would be utilized for spreading the charkha and khaddar.

('33', 64, 1, 6, 148423) There were two theatrical performances given at Ranchi by amateur companies for the purpose of Deshbandhu Memorial Fund.
('33', 64, 1, 7, 148544) One was given by Bengalis and the other by Biharis.
('33', 64, 1, 8, 148596) As they were given by amateurs I had no difficulty in accepting their invitations but I was severely disappointed over the Bengali performance.
('33', 64, 1, 9, 148740) I could see little difference between the performances of professionals and this amateur company.
('33', 64, 1, 10, 148838) There was complete aping of professionals.
('33', 64, 1, 11, 148881) The dresses were all made of foreign material.
('33', 64, 1, 12, 148928) The colouring of faces was also resorted to whereas I had expected that these performances would be subdued and that there would be at least khaddar used for dress material.
('33', 64, 1, 13, 149102) So when I undertook to go to the Bihari amateurs’ play I made the condition that if they wanted me to see their play they should have their dresses made of khaddar and that not merely for the occasion but for all their performances.
('33', 64, 1, 14, 149335) To my agreeable surprise, the condition was readily accepted.
('33', 64, 1, 15, 149397) There were only a few hours left for making all that change, but they did it and the manager made the announcement of the promise given to me and prayed for God’s help that they might be able to fulfil the promise.
('33', 64, 1, 16, 149612) What the Biharis’ play lost in tinsel effect it gained, in my opinion, in dignity by the change adopted.
('33', 64, 1, 17, 149717) I commend this very desirable change to all amateur theatrical companies.
('33', 64, 1, 18, 149791) Indeed, even the professionals who have any patriotic instinct can easily make this change and thus contribute, though ever so little, to the economic uplift of the teeming millions of India.
('33', 64, 1, 19, 149983) I must omit several interesting items including a very pleasing discussion on khaddar with Messrs N. K. Roy and S. K. Rao of the Department of Industries and a visit to the Brahmacharya Ashram which owes its existence to the munificence the Maharajah of Kasimbazar.

('33', 64, 1, 21, 150435) I spoke to the students on social service and endeavoured to show that it was impossible without character and that such service on a large scale
('33', 65, 0, 1, 150581) 66 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 65, 1, 2, 150622) in India was only possible through penetration into the villages and that it had to be its own reward for it brought no excitement, no advertisement and had often to be done under most trying circumstances and in the teeth of superstition and ignorance.
('33', 65, 1, 3, 150876) I endeavoured to show that the best form that social service could take in India was through the spinning wheel and khaddar, because it brought young men in touch with the villagers, it enabled them to put a few coppers every day into the pockets of the villagers and created an indissoluble bond between the latter and themselves, and it helped them to know their maker because the selfless service of the poor was the service of God.
('33', 65, 2, 4, 151312) KHUDA BUX LIBRARY
('33', 65, 3, 5, 151330) From Hazaribagh, with a few stoppages on the motor road to Gaya we went to Patna where the main work was the activity of the All India Congress Committee and the inauguration of the All India Spinners’ Association.
('33', 65, 3, 6, 151545) It was at Patna that I discovered my health would break down under the incessant fatigue of travelling.

('33', 65, 3, 10, 152034) I was able to fulfil the long cherished desire of visiting the Khuda Bux Oriental Library.
('33', 65, 3, 11, 152125) I had heard much about it.

('33', 65, 4, 19, 152834) A GOVERNMENT EXPERIMENT
('33', 65, 5, 20, 152858) The other interesting thing I was able to see in Patna was the workshop conducted by the Department of industries.
('33', 65, 5, 21, 152973) Mr. Rao is the
('33', 66, 0, 1, 152988) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 67
('33', 66, 1, 2, 153038) Superintendent.
('33', 66, 1, 3, 153054) The workshop itself is a modern building, well lighted, well ventilated, well planned and scrupulously clean.
('33', 66, 1, 4, 153164) Handloom weaving and toy making, which is the speciality of Patna are the features of this workshop.
('33', 66, 1, 5, 153265) Improved looms for weaving tapes and bedstead straps are commendable.
('33', 66, 1, 6, 153335) I could, however, not help feeling that in this admirable workshop, the central thing, the spinning wheel, was wanting.
('33', 66, 1, 7, 153455) Improved toy making will certainly give better wages to the makers of toys and it has therefore properly a place in a workshop in a city like Patna.
('33', 66, 1, 8, 153604) An Indian workshop is also incomplete without handloom weaving.
('33', 66, 1, 9, 153668) But no national department of industries can be considered to be at all complete that takes no note of hand spinning and there through of millions of villagers who are at present without a supplementary industry.
('33', 66, 1, 10, 153881) The difficulties that were suggested to me in making hand spinning a succes were mainly two: (1) Hand spun yarn can never compete with mill spun yarn because it has never yet been found to be as strong as mill spun yarn.
('33', 66, 1, 11, 154102) (2) The output of the spinning wheels is too small to be profitable.
('33', 66, 1, 12, 154171) The experience of those who have worn khaddar for years is that where it is made of good hand spun yarn it is any day more durable than the best mill spun cloth of the same count.
('33', 66, 1, 13, 154351) For instance, some of my Andhra friends have shown me their dhotis which have lasted four years and upwards against mill spun dhotis which wear out inside of a year.
('33', 66, 1, 14, 154517) But my point is not that hand spun is more durable, but that hand spinning being the only possible supplementary industry for the peasantry of India, which means 85 per cent of its population, all our arrangements regarding clothing should be fashioned on the understanding that it must be supplied from hand spun yarn.
('33', 66, 1, 15, 154837) Thus, our energy should be concentrated not on finding out the best and the cheapest yarn, no matter where and how spun, but on finding out the cheapest and the best hand spun yarn.
('33', 66, 1, 16, 155019) If my proposition is sound all the industrial departments of the nation should revolve round the charkha as the centre.
('33', 66, 1, 17, 155139) The Department of Industries, therefore, would make improvements in the spinning wheels so as to increase the output.
('33', 66, 1, 18, 155257) They would buy nothing but hand spun yarn, so that hand spinning is automatically stimulated.
('33', 66, 1, 19, 155351) They would devise means of utilizing every quality of hand spun yarn obtainable.
('33', 66, 1, 20, 155432) They would issue prizes for the finest hand spun yarn.
('33', 66, 1, 21, 155487) They would explore all possible fields for getting good hand spun
('33', 67, 0, 1, 155553) 68 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 67, 1, 2, 155594) This does not mean less encouragement to hand weaving.weaving.
('33', 67, 1, 3, 155657) It simply means adding to the encouragement of hand weaving and hand spinning and thereby serving those most in need of help.
('33', 67, 1, 4, 155783) But it has been objected that hand spinning is not profitable.
('33', 67, 1, 5, 155846) But surely it is profitable for those who have many an idle hour at their disposal and to whose scanty income even a pice is a welcome addition.
('33', 67, 1, 6, 155991) The whole of the charkha programme falls to pieces if millions of peasants are not living in enforced idleness for at least four months in the year.
('33', 67, 1, 7, 156140) Wherever khaddar workers are doing their labour of love, it has become not only profitable but a blessing to villagers to have men who would buy their yarn.
('33', 67, 1, 8, 156297) Those whose income does not exceed five to six rupees per month and have time at their disposal would gladly take in work that brings them an addition of two rupees per month.
('33', 67, 2, 9, 156473) MALKHACHAK AND OTHER CENTRES
('33', 67, 3, 10, 156502) I have before me a report of work done by a band of volun teers in several parts of Bihar.
('33', 67, 3, 11, 156593) I visited their centre at Malkhachak after my visit to the industrial workshop.
('33', 67, 3, 12, 156673) The place is about twelve miles from Patna.
('33', 67, 3, 13, 156717) In Malkhachak alone, with a population of about a thousand there are four hundred wheels going and there are thirty weavers weaving hand spun yarn.
('33', 67, 3, 14, 156865) I saw some of the sisters plying their wheels.
('33', 67, 3, 15, 156912) They were indifferently constructed.
('33', 67, 3, 16, 156949) Yet the spinners seemed to be happy with them.
('33', 67, 3, 17, 156996) They get two rupees per month on an average.
('33', 67, 3, 18, 157041) An addition of eight hundred rupees per month in a village containing one thousand souls is surely a big income any day.
('33', 67, 3, 19, 157162) I do not count the wages earned by the weavers at the rate of fifteen rupees per month.
('33', 67, 3, 20, 157250) That may not be a new addition.
('33', 67, 3, 21, 157282) These workers, in addition to organizing spinning, are also giving the village folk such medical relief as is possible with their limited resources and still more limited medical knowledge.
('33', 67, 3, 22, 157472) The report of their work whichwas started in 1921 mentions that they are serving six centres, viz., Madhubani, Kapasia, Shakri, Madhepur and Pupri, besides Malkhachak.
('33', 67, 3, 23, 157640) They wove in 1922, Rs. 62,000 worth of khaddar, in 1923, Rs. 84,000, in 1924, Rs. 63,000. And they have already woven one lac worth during the nine months of 1925. They wove less in 1924 because of want of cotton.
('33', 67, 3, 24, 157854) Their capacity for extension, the report says, is almost unlimited, given a regular supply of cotton and a market insured for the disposal of their wares.
('33', 67, 3, 25, 158009) They believe that almost every village

('33', 68, 1, 2, 158098) in the neighbourhood would welcome the presence of these workers.
('33', 68, 1, 3, 158164) The quality of khaddar produced by them is excellent and is by no means all of the coarsest variety.
('33', 68, 1, 4, 158265) Some of it is even exceedingly fine.
('33', 68, 1, 5, 158302) They pay four annas per seer of 40 tolas for spinning ten counts and 2
('33', 68, 2, 6, 158373) 1 2 annas per yard of 45 inches width for weaving.
('33', 68, 2, 7, 158424) They have 28 workers.
('33', 68, 2, 8, 158446) The upkeep of these depots including food and travelling amounts to Rs. 25 per month per worker on an aver age.
('33', 68, 2, 9, 158558) These depots are not at a loss.
('33', 68, 2, 10, 158590) They organize their own sales.
('33', 68, 2, 11, 158621) The quality of yarn they receive shows a steady improvement from month to month.

('33', 68, 2, 13, 158856) These workers are responsible for 7,000 wheels and 250 looms weaving hand spun yarn in the villages.
('33', 68, 2, 14, 158957) The condition of Bihar is in no way extraordinary.
('33', 68, 2, 15, 159008) It is more or less the same in many parts of Bengal, Andhra, Tamilnad and the United Provinces.
('33', 68, 2, 16, 159104) I have mentioned these provinces because the condition of those who have taken up spinning can be studied there.
('33', 68, 2, 17, 159217) At the present moment, most of the other provinces would show the same state of things.
('33', 68, 2, 18, 159305) Orissa for instance where the people are living from hand to mouth only awaits skilled workers and efficient organization.
('33', 68, 2, 19, 159428) Rajputana, in spite of its millionaires, is again a tract where the art of spinning is still alive and where the people are extremely poor.
('33', 68, 2, 20, 159568) If only the Rajahs and the Maharajahs will lend their hearty support to the movement, encourage khaddar wear in their States and remove the handicap on khadi wherever it exists, this land of chronic droughts will, without any great outlet of capital and without any fuss, have lacs of rupees per year for its poor people.

('33', 68, 4, 22, 159913) 42. FATE OF NON CO OPERATORS
('33', 68, 5, 23, 159942) A friend asks :
('33', 68, 6, 24, 159958) With your complete surrender to the Swaraj Party what will be the fate of those who have made non co operation their political religion?
('33', 68, 6, 25, 160095) The questioner forgets that I remain just as confirmed a non co operator as ever.
('33', 68, 6, 26, 160177) And it is not only my political but it is also my domestic and social religion.
('33', 68, 6, 27, 160257) As I has repeatedly said in these pages, voluntary and health giving co operation is impossible without the
('33', 69, 0, 1, 160365) 70 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 69, 1, 2, 160406) possibility of non co operation at a certain stage and under certain conditions.
('33', 69, 1, 3, 160487) The Congress does not prescribe to anybody his religion.
('33', 69, 1, 4, 160544) It is a sensitive barometer from time to time registering the variation in the temperament of politically minded India.
('33', 69, 1, 5, 160664) No Congressman is bound to act contrary to his political religion.
('33', 69, 1, 6, 160731) But he may not now use the name of the Congress for furthering non co operation.
('33', 69, 1, 7, 160812) Under the resolution, the prestige and financial resources of the Congress where they are not earmarked are pledged for the support of furthering the Swarajist Council policy and, therefore, not only are Congress organizations entitled to vote supplies for the furtherance of the Swarajist policy, but they are bound, where they would spend money for Council propaganda at all, to use them for the Swarajist policy.
('33', 69, 1, 8, 161228) Conversely, no Congress organization where there is a clear majority against spending or raising money for any pure political work is bound by the resolution to do so contrary to their own belief.
('33', 69, 1, 9, 161425) All Congress resolutions are for guidance and direction; they cannot be for coercion.
('33', 69, 1, 10, 161511) The correspondent further asks:
('33', 69, 2, 11, 161543) What will be the position of the Spinners’ Association with reference to non co operation?
('33', 69, 2, 12, 161634) The association has nothing to do with political non co operation.
('33', 69, 2, 13, 161701) The preamble precludes politics.
('33', 69, 2, 14, 161734) I am the President of that association, not in my capacity as a confirmed non co operator, but in that of an out and out khadi lover.
('33', 69, 2, 15, 161868) It is a commercial or economic association with philanthropic motives.
('33', 69, 2, 16, 161939) It will conduct commerce in khaddar not for the benefit of its members but of the nation.
('33', 69, 2, 17, 162029) The members instead of receiving dividends will give yearly sub scriptions.
('33', 69, 2, 18, 162105) It invites the politically minded co operators and non co operators, Rajahs, Maharajahs and persons belonging to all castes and creeds who have faith in the economic capacity of the spinning wheel and khaddar.
('33', 69, 2, 19, 162315) The correspondent adds:
('33', 69, 3, 20, 162339) The programme of the Spinners’ Association cannot be complete without the fivefold boycott.
('33', 69, 3, 21, 162431) I do not see it at all.
('33', 69, 3, 22, 162455) Why may not the busiest lawyer at least wear khaddar as some are now doing?
('33', 69, 3, 23, 162531) Why may not the scholars and teachers of Government schools do likewise?
('33', 69, 3, 24, 162604) The Council goers are certainly doing it, so far as the Swarajists are concerned.
('33', 69, 3, 25, 162686) They have taken khaddar to the Assembly and the Councils.
('33', 69, 3, 26, 162744) Several titled men
('33', 70, 0, 1, 162763) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 71
('33', 70, 1, 2, 162813) habitually wear khaddar.
('33', 70, 1, 3, 162838) The last difficulty of my correspondent is:
('33', 70, 2, 4, 162882) If the irreconcilable non co operators are driven out of the Congress and also find no place in the Spinners’ Association, will it be possible for them to form an all India association of their own?
('33', 70, 2, 5, 163081) The question is extremely badly put.
('33', 70, 2, 6, 163118) No one is ever driven out of the Congress.
('33', 70, 2, 7, 163161) People may and do retire from it when they find the action of the majority to be in conflict with their conscience.
('33', 70, 2, 8, 163277) The majority cannot be blamed for not suiting itself to the conscience of a minority.
('33', 70, 2, 9, 163363) And if there are non co operators who consider it to be repugnant to their conscience to remain in the Congress while it countenances Council entry, they may certaily retire.
('33', 70, 2, 10, 163538) I would even go further and suggest that they should retire, if by remaining in the Congress they wish to hamper Council work.
('33', 70, 2, 11, 163665) In my opinion the Congress machinery needs to be worked without any friction from within.
('33', 70, 2, 12, 163755) I have already shown that there is room for non co operators in the Spinners’ Association as there is also for co operators.
('33', 70, 2, 13, 163880) If in spite of it there are non co operators who consider it their duty to form an all India association of their own, it is certainly possible for them to do so, but I would consider it to be thoroughly inadvisable.
('33', 70, 2, 14, 164097) It is enough if the non co operators will, for the time being, carry on their non co operation in their own persons.

('33', 70, 4, 16, 164237) 43. FROM EUROPE
('33', 70, 5, 17, 164253) When I think of my littleness and my limitations on the one hand and of the expectations raised about me on the other, I become dazed for the moment, but I come to myself as soon as I realize that these expectations are a tribute not to me, a curious mixture of Jekyll and Hyde, but to the incarnation however imperfect but compara tively great in me, of the two priceless qualities of truth and non violence.
('33', 70, 5, 18, 164663) I must therefore not shirk the responsibility of giving what aid I can to fellow seekers after truth from the West.
('33', 70, 5, 19, 164779) I have already dealt with a letter from America.
('33', 70, 5, 20, 164828) I have before me one from Germany.
('33', 70, 5, 21, 164863) It is a closely reasoned letter.
('33', 70, 5, 22, 164896) It has remained with me for nearly a month.
('33', 70, 5, 23, 164940) At first I thought I would send a private reply and let it be published in Germany, if the correspondent desired it.
('33', 70, 5, 24, 165057) But, having reread the letter, I have come to the conclusion that I
('33', 71, 0, 1, 165125) 72 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 71, 1, 2, 165166) should deal with it in these columns.
('33', 71, 1, 3, 165204) I give the letter below in full: 1
('33', 71, 2, 4, 165239) In my travels I have not the file of Young India before me, but there is no difficulty about my endorsing the statement that”Satyagraha demands absolute non violence and that even a women who is in danger of being violated must not defend herself with violence.” Both these statements relate to an ideal state and, therefore, are made with reference to those men and women who have so far purified themselves as to have no malice, no anger, no violence in them.
('33', 71, 2, 5, 165701) That does not mean that the woman in the imagined case would quietly allow herself to be violated.
('33', 71, 2, 6, 165800) In the first instance, such a woman would stand in no danger of violence and, in the second, if she did, without doing violence to the ruffian she would be able completely to defend her honour.
('33', 71, 2, 7, 165994) But I must not enter into details.
('33', 71, 2, 8, 166029) Even women who can defend themselves with violence are not many.
('33', 71, 2, 9, 166094) Happily, however, cases of indecent assaults are not also very many.
('33', 71, 2, 10, 166163) Be that as it may, I believe implicitly in the proposition that perfect purity is its own defence.
('33', 71, 2, 11, 166262) The veriest ruffian becomes, for the time being, tame in the presence of resplendent purity.
('33', 71, 3, 12, 166355) The writer is not correctly informed about my attitude in regard to General Dyer.
('33', 71, 3, 13, 166437) He would be pleased to know that not only did I not recommend any punishment of General Dyer but even my colleagues, largely out of their generous regard for me, waived the demand for punishment.
('33', 71, 3, 14, 166633) What, however, I did ask for, and I do press for even now, is the stopping of the pension to General Dyer.
('33', 71, 3, 15, 166740) It is no part of the plan of non violence to pay the wrong doer for the wrong he does which practically would be the case if I became a willing party to the continuation of the pension to General Dyer.
('33', 71, 3, 16, 166942) But let me not be misunderstood.
('33', 71, 3, 17, 166975) I am quite capable of recommending even punish ment to wrong doers under conceivable circumstances; for instance I would not hesitate under the present state of society to confine thieves and robbers, which is in itself a kind of punishment.
('33', 71, 3, 18, 167217) But I would also admit that it is not satyagraha and that it is a fall from the puredoctrine.
('33', 71, 3, 19, 167311) That would be not an admission of weakness of the doctrine but weakness of myself.
('33', 71, 3, 20, 167394) I have no other remedy to suggest in such cases in the present state of society.
('33', 71, 3, 21, 167475) I am therefore satisfied with advocating the use of prisons more as reformatories than as places of punishment.
('33', 71, 4, 22, 167587) 1 For the text of this letter, vide”From Europe”, 8 10 1925.
('33', 72, 0, 1, 167648) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 73
('33', 72, 1, 2, 167698) But I would draw the distinction between killing and detention or even corporal punishment.
('33', 72, 1, 3, 167790) I think that there is a difference not merely in quantity but also in quality.
('33', 72, 1, 4, 167869) I can recall the punishment of detention.
('33', 72, 1, 5, 167911) I can make reparation to the man upon whom I inflict corporal punishment.
('33', 72, 1, 6, 167985) But once a man is killed, the punishment is beyond recall or reparation.
('33', 72, 1, 7, 168058) God alone can take life, because He alone gives it.
('33', 72, 1, 8, 168110) I hope there is no confusion in the writer’s mind when he couples the self immolation of a satyagrahi with the punishment imposed from without.
('33', 72, 1, 9, 168254) But, in order to avoid even a possibility of it, let me make it clear that the doctrine of violence has reference only to the doing of injury by one to another.
('33', 72, 1, 10, 168415) Suffering injury in one’s own person, is on the contrary, of the essence of non violence and is the chosen substitute for violence to others.
('33', 72, 1, 11, 168557) It is not because I value life low that I can countenance with joy thousands voluntarily losing their lives for satyagraha, but because I know that it results in the long run in the least loss of life and what is more, it ennobles those who lose their lives and morally enriches the world for their sacrifice.
('33', 72, 1, 12, 168867) I think that the writer is correct in saying that non co operation is not merely an ideal but also”a safe and quick way to freedom for India”.
('33', 72, 1, 13, 169010) I do suggest that the doctrine holds good also as between States and States.
('33', 72, 1, 14, 169087) I know that I am treading on delicate ground if I refer to the late War.
('33', 72, 1, 15, 169160) But I fear that I must in order to make the position clear.
('33', 72, 1, 16, 169220) It was a war of aggrandizement, as I have understood, on either part.
('33', 72, 1, 17, 169290) It was a war for dividing the spoils of the exploitation of weaker races, otherwise euphemistically called the world commerce.
('33', 72, 1, 18, 169417) If Germany today changed her policy and made a determination to use her freedom not for dividing the commerce of the world but for protecting through her moral superiority the weaker races of the earth, she could certainly do that without armament.
('33', 72, 1, 19, 169666) It would be found that, before general disarmament in Europe commences, as it must some day unless Europe is to commit suicide, some nation will have to dare to disarm herself and take large risks.
('33', 72, 1, 20, 169864) The level of non violence in that nation, if that event happily comes to pass, will naturally have risen so high as to command universal respect.
('33', 72, 1, 21, 170010) Her judgments will be unerring, her decisions will be firm, her capacity for heroic self sacrifice will be great, and she will want to live as much for other nations as for herself.
('33', 72, 1, 22, 170192) I may not push this delicate subject any further.
('33', 72, 1, 23, 170242) I know that I am writing in a theoretical way upon a practical question without knowing all its bearings.
('33', 72, 1, 24, 170348) My only excuse is, if I understand it correctly, that that
('33', 73, 0, 1, 170407) 74 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 73, 1, 2, 170448) is what the writer has wanted me to do.
('33', 73, 1, 3, 170488) I do justify entire non violence and consider it possible in relations between man and man and nations and nations, but it is not”a resignation from all real fighting against wickedness”.
('33', 73, 1, 4, 170676) On the contrary, the non violence of my conception is a more active and more real fighting against wickedness than retaliation whose very nature is to increase wickedness.
('33', 73, 1, 5, 170848) I contemplate a mental and, therefore, a moral opposition to immoralities.
('33', 73, 1, 6, 170923) I seek entirely to blunt the edge of the tyrant’s sword, not by putting up against it a sharper edged weapon, but by disappointing his expectation that I would be offering physical resistance.
('33', 73, 1, 7, 171116) The resistance of the soul that I should offer instead would elude him.
('33', 73, 1, 8, 171188) It would at first dazzle him and at last compel recognition from him which recognition would not humiliate him but would uplift him.
('33', 73, 1, 9, 171321) It may be urged that this again is an ideal state.
('33', 73, 1, 10, 171372) And so it is.
('33', 73, 1, 11, 171386) The propositions from which I have drawn my arguments are as true as Euclid’s definitions which are none the less true because in practice we are unable even to draw Euclid’s line on a blackboard.
('33', 73, 1, 12, 171583) But even a geometrician finds it impossible to get on without bearing in mind Euclid’s definitions.
('33', 73, 1, 13, 171683) Nor may we, the Ger man friend, his colleagues and myself, dispense with the fundamental propositions on which the doctrine of satyagraha is based.
('33', 73, 1, 14, 171831) There remains for me now only one ticklish question to answer.
('33', 73, 1, 15, 171894) In a most ingenious manner the writer has compared the English arrogation of the right of becoming tutors to the whole world to my views on relations between married people.
('33', 73, 1, 16, 172068) But the comparison does not hold good.
('33', 73, 1, 17, 172107) The marriage bond involves seeing each other only by mutual agreement.
('33', 73, 1, 18, 172178) But surely abstention requires no consent.
('33', 73, 1, 19, 172221) Married life would be intolerable, as it does become, when one partner breaks through all bonds of restraint.
('33', 73, 1, 20, 172331) Marriage confirms the right of union between two partners to the exclusion of all the others when, in their joint opinion, they consider such union to be desirable, but it confers no right upon one partner to demand obedience of the other to one’s wish for union.
('33', 73, 1, 21, 172595) What should be done when one partner on moral or other grounds cannot conform to the wishes of the other is a separate question.
('33', 73, 1, 22, 172724) Personally, if divorce was the only alternative I should not hesitate to accept it, rather than interrupt my moral progress,— assuming that I want to restrain myself on purely moral grounds.

('33', 74, 1, 2, 172988) 44.”TAKLI” UNIVERSAL
('33', 74, 2, 3, 173009) It is wonderful what hold upon mankind the simple instrument takli has retained in spite of the inroads of spinning mills.
('33', 74, 2, 4, 173132) Not only am I finding its use spread all over India but Dr. Ansari sent me a postcard in which a woman is portrayed comfortably seated with a takli plying in a little earthen pot which she has held in her right hand with the left holding the sliver from which she is drawing the thread.
('33', 74, 2, 5, 173419) It is a picture of a scene in Beirut.
('33', 74, 2, 6, 173457) The capacity of takli for giving use anywhere and at all odd times is really remarkable.
('33', 74, 2, 7, 173546) A busy man who may find it difficult to sit down for half an hour at a stretch at the wheel cannot do better than carry a takli about him and spin his quota on the takli.

('33', 76, 2, 3, 177696) DEBTS OF HONOUR
('33', 76, 3, 4, 177712) I had some time ago in the pages of Navajivan to refer to the default on the part of Congress debtors in Gujarat.
('33', 76, 3, 5, 177826) Now that I have taken up the burden of the All India Spinners’ Association, the first present I received was a list from Mr. Banker of 70 debtors to the Bihar Provincial Khadi Board.

('33', 76, 3, 7, 178106) They amount to over Rs. 20,000. It is a matter of shame and sorrow that there should be so many debts outstanding.
('33', 76, 3, 8, 178221) The Khadi Board has, in my opinion, been over lenient.
('33', 76, 3, 9, 178276) All public institutions are public trust and those who are in charge of them have oftentimes to harden their hearts and rigorously collect all debts owing to the trust under their charge.
('33', 76, 3, 10, 178464) Leniency in the management of a public trust is a misplaced virtue and may often amount to an unpardonable breach.
('33', 76, 3, 11, 178579) I know that a false notion of non co operation has often come in the way of proceedings being taken against defaulters.
('33', 76, 3, 12, 178699) But as I have so often pointed out, laws are made by institutions for self preservation, not for suicide.
('33', 76, 3, 13, 178805) When, therefore, they hamper their growth they are worse than useless, and must be set aside.
('33', 76, 3, 14, 178899) Boycott of law courts was undertaken in order to invigorate the nation, to wean people from running on the slightest pretext to law courts, to popularize private arbitration, never to bolster up fraud or cover defaulters.
('33', 76, 3, 15, 179121) It proceeded upon the assumption that Congressmen would at least carry out their obligations to one another and to the Congress without the necessity of resort even to arbitration, much less to law courts.
('33', 76, 3, 16, 179327) I hope, therefore, that those gentlemen who owe anything to the Khadi Board will hasten to discharge their debts and will not put the Board to the painful necessity of taking proceedings against them.

('33', 80, 1, 2, 185709) 49. IF EXPELLED FROM ONE’S COMMUNITY
('33', 80, 2, 3, 185746) When the leaders of a community thoughtlessly expel persons from it, guided by nothing but their unthinking attachment to ideas and customs, superstitions, ignorance and envy, it is better for one to be boycotted by it than to continue as a member of it, for no one who loves truth can remain in a society from which another such person has been expelled.
('33', 80, 2, 4, 186102) This is the principle.
('33', 80, 2, 5, 186125) Although it cannot always be followed in practice, it needs to be borne in mind.
('33', 80, 2, 6, 186206) We observe nowadays that heads of communities are becoming increasingly high handed.
('33', 80, 2, 7, 186291) There are heads who regard it as a sin even to serve a meal to an Antyaja.
('33', 80, 2, 8, 186366) A Hindu who invites an Antyaja to sit with other Hindus at a dinner or consents to another doing this is regarded as having committed a sin.
('33', 80, 2, 9, 186507) Let all lovers of goodness join the company of such sinners.
('33', 80, 2, 10, 186568) To be sure, boycott is not easy to bear.
('33', 80, 2, 11, 186609) One is not served meals, and is denied the services of the dhobi, the barber and, it is not impossible, even of the doctor.
('33', 80, 2, 12, 186733) They inflict every hardship, short of putting one to death.
('33', 80, 2, 13, 186793) A reformer who is boycotted must have the strength to remain steadfast unto death.
('33', 80, 2, 14, 186876) The best service to Antyajas can be rendered only by Hindus who have made their lives pure, dedicated their lives.
('33', 80, 2, 15, 186991) What does it matter whether one is served meals or not?
('33', 80, 2, 16, 187047) Why cannot we stay at home, cook our own food and eat in peace?
('33', 80, 2, 17, 187111) If the dhobi refuses to wash our clothes, we may wash them ourselves and save money.
('33', 80, 2, 18, 187196) Shaving oneself has now become a common practice.
('33', 80, 2, 19, 187246) Yes, but how to find a match for one’s daughter, and a bride for one’s son, it will be asked .
('33', 80, 2, 20, 187341) If we are particular that the partner for either should be from our own community and cannot find one, the daughter or the son should cultivate self control.
('33', 80, 2, 21, 187499) If they do not have the strength for this, we should look for a partner in some other community.
('33', 80, 2, 22, 187596) If we are disappointed even in this, we should resign ourselves to what cannot be helped.
('33', 80, 2, 23, 187686) There are only four castes, whether communities number four or forty thousand.
('33', 80, 2, 24, 187765) The merger of sub divisions in communities is something to be actually welcomed.
('33', 80, 2, 25, 187846) Small social circles with rigid barriers have done great harm to Hinduism.

('33', 90, 3, 9, 210260) But if such is not possible, you should send me to Sitapur by motor and not keep me engaged for five hours at Lucknow.
('33', 90, 3, 10, 210379) A train journey is preferable to a motor ride but a motor ride is preferable to work till a late hour.
('33', 90, 3, 11, 210482) I have grown so weak that I am washed out at 7 p.m.
('33', 90, 3, 12, 210534) When I attend meetings at night I yawn.
('33', 90, 3, 13, 210574) Now you know all about me and my wish and you may do what you think is best in the public interest.
('33', 90, 3, 14, 210674) For I have no stomach left for addresses.
('33', 90, 3, 15, 210716) Better ask me to give a spinning demonstration.
('33', 90, 4, 16, 210764) Yours sincerely,
('33', 90, 5, 17, 210781) M. K. GANDHI

('33', 91, 1, 2, 211332) 54. SPEECH AT VISHANPUR 1
('33', 91, 2, 3, 211358) October 13, 1925
('33', 91, 3, 4, 211375) In his reply Mahatmaji said, with other things, that it was not quite happy on the part of the reception committee to have made allegations against Darbhanga Raj without sufficient proofs and specially in an address, but if they had really any grievances, they ought to try to get them removed.
('33', 91, 4, 5, 211670) The Searchlight, 16 10 1925
('33', 91, 5, 6, 211698) 55. BIHAR NOTES
('33', 91, 6, 7, 211714) HINDU MUSLIM QUESTION
('33', 91, 7, 8, 211736) From Patna we went to Bhagalpur.
('33', 91, 7, 9, 211769) At Bhagalpur there was a very great public meeting at which I was obliged to make a somewhat lengthy reference to the Hindu Muslim question.
('33', 91, 7, 10, 211910) Though my influence over those who are agitating the question is gone, they continue to discuss with me the various problems arising from it.
('33', 91, 7, 11, 212052) I felt, therefore, that I should redeclare my views for what they might be worth.
('33', 91, 7, 12, 212134) Apart from merits I must confess that I have not liked this constant reference to the Government by both the parties on matters which they by mutual settlement or appeal to the sword can adjust.
('33', 91, 7, 13, 212329) I, therefore, told the audience that since neither party was prepared to compromise and each was afraid of the other, the best way would be without seeking the intervention of the Government to settle the matters in dispute by the method of the lathi.
('33', 91, 7, 14, 212581) Retreat out of fear was cowardice and Cowardice would not hasten a settlement or the advent of non violence.
('33', 91, 7, 15, 212690) Cowardice was a species of violence which it was most difficult to overcome.
('33', 91, 7, 16, 212767) One could hope to persuade a violently inclined person to shed his violence and take up the superior force of non violence, but since cowardice was negation of all force, it was impossible to teach a mouse non violence in respect of a cat.
('33', 91, 8, 17, 213007) 1 According to the report, the reception by a disciplined, fifty thousand strong gathering at this important interior village in the Purnia district of Bihar was attended with pageantry in which scores of elephants and horses featured long a two mile, specially constructed road.
('33', 91, 8, 18, 213287) Gandhiji was presented an address of welcome and contributions were made to the Deshbandhu Memorial Fund.
('33', 92, 0, 1, 213393) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 93
('33', 92, 1, 2, 213443) would simply not understand what non violence could be, because he had not the capacity for violence against the cat.
('33', 92, 1, 3, 213561) Would it not be a mockery to ask a blind man not to look at ugly things?
('33', 92, 1, 4, 213634) Maulana Shaukat Ali and I were at Bettiah in 1921. The people of a village near Bettiah told me that they had run away whilst the police were looting their houses and molesting their womenfolk.
('33', 92, 1, 5, 213828) 1 When they said that they had run away because I had told them to be non violent, I hung my head in shame.
('33', 92, 1, 6, 213936) I assured them that such was not the meaning of my non violence.
('33', 92, 1, 7, 214001) I expected them to intercept the mightiest power that might be in the act of harming those who were under their protection, and draw without retaliation all harm upon their own heads even to the point of death, but never to run away from the storm centre.
('33', 92, 1, 8, 214257) It was manly enough to defend one’s property, honour or religion at the point of sword.
('33', 92, 1, 9, 214345) It was manlier and nobler to defend them without seeking to injure the wrongdoer.
('33', 92, 1, 10, 214427) But it wasunmanly, unnatural and dishonourable to forsake the post of duty and in order to save one’s skin to leave property, honour or religion to the mercy of the wrongdoer.
('33', 92, 1, 11, 214603) I could see my way of successfully delivering the message of ahimsa to those who knew how to die, not to those who were afraid of death.
('33', 92, 1, 12, 214740) I told the audience further, that those like me who deliberately did not want to fight and were powerless to effect a settlement might follow the example of those Mussalmans who, during the time of the first four Caliphs, sought the refuge of the cave when brothers began to fight one against the other.
('33', 92, 1, 13, 215044) The mountain cave in these days was a practicalimpossibility but they could retire to the cave which each of us carried within himself.
('33', 92, 1, 14, 215180) But such could be only those who had mutual regard for one another’s religion and customs.
('33', 92, 2, 15, 215271) FOLLY OF EXCOMMUNICATION
('33', 92, 3, 16, 215296) Then there was a Provincial Marwari Sammelan where I spoke on the question of social boycott and on the crying need of social reform.
('33', 92, 3, 17, 215430) I told the Marwari friends that ex communication was a lawful weapon in the hands only of those who deserved to be classed as mahajan, which meant pure men who were real representatives of their respective groups or castes and who declared ex communication not from personal spite but from the selfless motive of conserving the interest of fellow beings.
('33', 92, 3, 18, 215785) It was an immoral abuse of power to put
('33', 92, 4, 19, 215825) 1Vide”Speech at Bettiah”, 8 12 1920.
('33', 93, 0, 1, 215862) 94 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 93, 1, 2, 215903) under the ban of ex communication a person who for the sake of learning or legitimate gain crossed the waters or who for the sake of obtaining a suitable match for his son or daughter went outside his sub caste or who dared to remarry his widowed daughter of tender age.
('33', 93, 1, 3, 216174) If varnashrama which had a useful and proper place in the Hindu social system was to be rescued from destruction it was high time that the innumerable sub divisions were fused into one.
('33', 93, 1, 4, 216360) There was, for instance, no reason why a Marwari Brahmin or Vaisya should not seek marriage relations with a Bengali Brahmin or Vaisya.
('33', 93, 1, 5, 216496) The mahajan to be truly great will have to encourage rather than suppress tendencies towards fusion.
('33', 93, 1, 6, 216597) If ex communication was ever deserved nowadays, it was deserved by those who gave away their daughters in marriage before they were full grown, at least before they were sixteen, and if secret immorality was to be discountenanced, it was the duty of parents of child widows to encourage their remarriage.
('33', 93, 2, 7, 216902) THE”PANDAS”
('33', 93, 3, 8, 216914) From Bhagalpur we motored to Banka where there was a district conference presided over by Maulana Shaffi Sahib.
('33', 93, 3, 9, 217026) There was nothing noteworthy here except for the huge and embarrassing crowds through which I passed with difficulty with my bruised toe.
('33', 93, 3, 10, 217164) We went thence to Devgarh otherwise known as Vaidyanath Dham.
('33', 93, 3, 11, 217226) This is not only a famous place of pilgrimage, but also a health resort beautifully situated and surrounded by hills.
('33', 93, 3, 12, 217344) This is a favourite place with the Bengalis.
('33', 93, 3, 13, 217389) Unlike as in other places of pilgrimage, I found here the pandas, i.e., the priests in charge of the shrines, to be a fairly cultured body of men.
('33', 93, 3, 14, 217536) The majority of volunteers were smart panda youths who rendered great assistance, I was told, to the pilgrims.
('33', 93, 3, 15, 217647) There are several educated men amongst them, one being even a High Court pleader.
('33', 93, 3, 16, 217729) I had the pleasure too of a visit from the elderly pandas.
('33', 93, 3, 17, 217788) They wanted me to tell them what they should do to serve the people and, when I told them that they should serve the pilgrims instead of seeking to profiteer at their expense, and endeavour to make the places of pilgrimage really holy places by themselves leading pure and restrained lives, they readily agreed and there seemed to me to be a ring of sincerity about their assent to my proposals and a humble recognition of the existence of the evils I had ventured to point out.
('33', 93, 3, 18, 218267) I was agreeably surprised to discover that the great temple was open to the so called untouchables.
('33', 93, 3, 19, 218367) The usual women’s meeting was arranged
('33', 94, 0, 1, 218406) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 95
('33', 94, 1, 2, 218456) in the spacious temple compound just opposite the shrine.
('33', 94, 1, 3, 218514) The order kept by the panda volunteers wherever I went in Devgarh was certainly much better than I have observed elsewhere.
('33', 94, 2, 4, 218638) VIRTUE OF SUFFERING
('33', 94, 3, 5, 218658) The public meeting was so well organized as to ensure perfect quiet.
('33', 94, 3, 6, 218727) The public address made pointed reference to terrible sufferings that the people of this district underwent in 1921 22. It should be noted here that this is the district called Santhal Parganas.
('33', 94, 3, 7, 218922) It is a Non Regulation part of Bihar.
('33', 94, 3, 8, 218960) The Commissioner’s will is therefore the law of the land.
('33', 94, 3, 9, 219018) The address also referred to the fact that whereas during 1921 and 1922 the drink habit had all but disappeared, It was again making headway amongst the Santhals.
('33', 94, 3, 10, 219181) The possibilities of khaddar were stated to be very great.
('33', 94, 3, 11, 219240) In my reply I pointed out that no nation had ever come to its own without much suffering.
('33', 94, 3, 12, 219330) I, therefore, did not mind the sufferings that the people underwent in 1921 22. Only suffering to be beneficial must be voluntary and must be enjoyed.
('33', 94, 3, 13, 219481) When it came, such suffering left the sufferer stronger and happier at the end of it.
('33', 94, 3, 14, 219567) I was, therefore, grieved to discover that the suffering in the district had caused demoralization amongst the people.
('33', 94, 3, 15, 219686) It meant that all the suffering was not voluntary.
('33', 94, 3, 16, 219737) It was up to the workers to set an example in pure and voluntary suffering.
('33', 94, 3, 17, 219813) There should be persistent agitation amongst Santhals against the drink habit and the charkha work should be systematically organized.
('33', 94, 4, 18, 219948) TWO PICTURES
('33', 94, 5, 19, 219961) There was, too, a separate presentation of an address by the Municipality.
('33', 94, 5, 20, 220036) I take note of this event especially for the exceedingly tasteful but simple arrangements made for the presentation in the open air.
('33', 94, 5, 21, 220169) The attendance was evidently regulated by tickets and was confined to so few that the audience could have been easily accommodated in any commodious building.
('33', 94, 5, 22, 220328) But the Commissioners chose to erect a little pandal decorated with foliage tastefully arranged in the midst of beautiful natural scenery.
('33', 94, 5, 23, 220467) I could not, therefore, help recalling in my reply to the address of the Municipality the dirty state of the road leading to the temple and the dilapidation surrounding it.
('33', 94, 5, 24, 220640) I have visited almost all the places of pilgrimage in India, and everywhere the condition in and about the temples is deplorable— disorder, dirt, din and stench.
('33', 94, 5, 25, 220802) All these are probably less marked in
('33', 95, 0, 1, 220840) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 95, 1, 2, 220881) Devgarh than elsewhere.
('33', 95, 1, 3, 220905) But all the same the contrast between the temple surroundings and the place where the address was presented was painful.
('33', 95, 1, 4, 221026) If the Municipality, the pandas and the pilgrims combined together, they could make the temple and its precincts beautiful, sweet smelling and uplifting as they ought to be.
('33', 95, 1, 5, 221200) If honest and proper management could be assured, I had no doubt, I told them, that the rich pilgrims would gladly pay for the comfort that they would get at such holy places.
('33', 95, 2, 6, 221376) USELESS AND UGLY
('33', 95, 3, 7, 221393) From Devgarh we proceeded to Kharagdeha which is reached through Giridih from where it is a motor ride of 26 miles.
('33', 95, 3, 8, 221509) At this place the programme began with a meeting of ladies.
('33', 95, 3, 9, 221569) Hitherto I have restrained myself from criticizing the heavily ornamental decoration of some of my fair audiences, oppressive though it has often appeared to me.
('33', 95, 3, 10, 221731) But the bangled arms from wrist practically to elbow, the huge thick nose rings with about a three inch diameter which could with difficulty be suspended from two holes, proved beyond endurance, and I gently remarked that this heavy ornamentation added nothing to the beauty of person, caused much discomfort, must often lead to disesase and was, I could plainly see, a repository of dirt.
('33', 95, 3, 11, 222121) I had never seen so much ornamentation anywhere else.
('33', 95, 3, 12, 222175) Heavier articles I have seen, as for instance the unbearable heavy ankle hoops—I cannot call them rings—of Kathiawar ladies, but never so much body space covered over with so many bangles and what nots.
('33', 95, 3, 13, 222378) I was told that these huge nose rings often resulted in cutting the delicate nasal membranes.
('33', 95, 3, 14, 222472) I was nervous about the effect my very straight remarks would produce upon my gentle audience.
('33', 95, 3, 15, 222567) I was, therefore, considerably relieved when at the end of my speech and in response to my appeal for Deshbandhu Memorial Fund, they crowded round me and gave liberally from their purses.
('33', 95, 3, 16, 222755) I took care to drive my point home to every donor individually and asked her to give up a large part of her superfluous ornaments.
('33', 95, 3, 17, 222886) The ladies received my remarks with a gracious smile and some of them even gave me a part of these ornaments.
('33', 95, 3, 18, 222996) I do not know whether the quality and the quantity of adornment has anything to do with the development of character.
('33', 95, 3, 19, 223114) That it has something to do with the intellect can be proved from innumerable instances.
('33', 95, 3, 20, 223203) That it has connection with culture as distinguished from character is also obvious.
('33', 95, 3, 21, 223288) But as I put character before even culture, I wonder whether I would be always right in
('33', 96, 0, 1, 223376) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 97
('33', 96, 1, 2, 223426) making use, for advocating reform in the art of decoration, of the privilege I enjoy of addressing thousands of women in all the different parts of India.
('33', 96, 1, 3, 223581) Be that as it may, I would urge upon the parents and husbands of these simple folk, on grounds of economy and health, the necessity of inducing among them a considerable reduction in these articles of personal furniture.
('33', 96, 2, 4, 223802) MAHURIS
('33', 96, 3, 5, 223810) It was at this place that I made the acquaintance of Mahuris, otherwise known as Mathuris, a body of Vaisyas who, generations ago, are supposed to have migrated from Mathura and the surrounding country and settled in Bihar.
('33', 96, 3, 6, 224034) They are fairly well to do and enterprising.
('33', 96, 3, 7, 224079) Their chief occupation is commerce.
('33', 96, 3, 8, 224115) Some of them are staunch reformers.
('33', 96, 3, 9, 224151) They have taken to khaddar and appreciate its advantages for the poor people.
('33', 96, 3, 10, 224229) Many of them have given up meat and drink which they used to take before.
('33', 96, 3, 11, 224303) In their address they stated that they understood the movement of non co operation as purely one of self purification, and that it had revolutionized their inner life.
('33', 96, 3, 12, 224471) They take little or no part in politics but they are intent upon making all kinds of reforms in their own little community.
('33', 96, 3, 13, 224595) This moral effect of non co operation upon so many people all over India is perhaps its most enduring result.
('33', 96, 3, 14, 224705) It is fraught with consequences of which we can have as yet but little notion.
('33', 96, 3, 15, 224784) Similar reforms were reported to me as having taken place also amongst the Santhals, many of whom have become, from having been habitual drunkards, complete teetotallers.
('33', 96, 3, 16, 224955) That movement among them received a check when picketing was withdrawn, but it is again reviving without the element of violence which had crept into the movement in 1921. It will be the saving of the simple but ignorant races like the Santhals if they can be weaned from the drink habit.
('33', 96, 4, 17, 225244) Young India, 15 10 1925
('33', 96, 5, 18, 225268) 56. NATIONAL EDUCATION
('33', 96, 6, 19, 225291) During my travels, those who are interested in national education tell me that, whereas I constantly harp upon khaddar, untouchability, Hindu Muslim unity, nowadays one rarely finds mention even of national education in Young India.
('33', 96, 6, 20, 225524) As a matter of fact the statement is true, but it must not be cited as a ground of complaint against me, if only because I am directly interested in the
('33', 97, 0, 1, 225677) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 97, 1, 2, 225718) largest national university in India.
('33', 97, 1, 3, 225756) But national education is not a thing which can now be advanced by any writing on my part.
('33', 97, 1, 4, 225847) Its advance depends totally upon a proper working of the institutions now in existence.
('33', 97, 1, 5, 225935) We cannot, we must not, any longer appeal to the youth of the country who are now receiving education in the Government insititutions to leave them for they now know the pros and cons of the subject.
('33', 97, 1, 6, 226135) They are in Government institutions either out of weakness or out of their fondness for them or for their want of faith in national institutions.
('33', 97, 1, 7, 226281) Whatever the reason, the only way to deal with their weakness, fondness or want of faith is to make the national institutions strong and popular by sheer force of the character and ability of the teachers.
('33', 97, 1, 8, 226487) There is before me an appeal by the South Calcutta National School.
('33', 97, 1, 9, 226555) In a covering letter, I am reminded that I paid during my prolonged stay in Calcutta a hurried visit to the institution.
('33', 97, 1, 10, 226676) The appeal is signed by influential men.
('33', 97, 1, 11, 226717) Hand spinning, I am reminded, is compulsory.
('33', 97, 1, 12, 226762) There are one hundred boys on the rolls and eighteen teachers, so the appeal runs.
('33', 97, 1, 13, 226845) The school receives an annual grant of Rs. 200. There are many such institutions throughout the length and breadth of India from whose teachers I receive requests either for advertising them in these columns or, better still, becoming signatory to a direct appeal for funds.
('33', 97, 1, 14, 227120) I must not yield to the temptation, even at the risk of overlooking some very deserving institutions.
('33', 97, 1, 15, 227222) A hurried visit and an impression created by such a visit must not be allowed to harm an institution if the impression is bad.
('33', 97, 1, 16, 227349) Nor must a false but favourable impression be allowed to bolster up an institution that is in reality undeserving.
('33', 97, 1, 17, 227464) It is my settled conviction that no deserving institution ever dies for want of support.
('33', 97, 1, 18, 227553) Institutions that have died have done so either because there was nothing in them to commend them to the public or because those in control have themselves lost faith or, which is perhaps the same thing, lost stamina.
('33', 97, 1, 19, 227771) I would, therefore, urge the conductors of this and other such institutions not to give in because of the general depression.
('33', 97, 1, 20, 227897) It is a time of test for worthy institutions.
('33', 97, 1, 21, 227943) There are several at the present moment in India which are struggling against the heaviest odds, where, though the teachers are living in want, they have faith in themselves and their cause.
('33', 97, 1, 22, 228134) I know that they will prosper in the end and be the stronger for the ordeal they are passing through.
('33', 97, 1, 23, 228236) I would advise the public to study such institutions and support them if they find them desirable and deserving.
('33', 98, 0, 1, 228349) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 99
('33', 98, 1, 2, 228399) I have observed in many institutions I have visited a tendency to patronize spinning because it has become somewhat of a fashion nowadays.
('33', 98, 1, 3, 228538) It is far from doing justice to a great cause or to pupils.
('33', 98, 1, 4, 228598) If spinning is to be revived as an indispensable industry, it must be treated seriously and must be taught in proper and scientific manner like the other subjects taught in well managed schools.
('33', 98, 1, 5, 228793) The wheels will then be in perfectly good order and condition, will conform to all the tests laid down in these columns from time to time, the pupils’ work would be regularly tested form day to day just as all their exercises would be or should be.
('33', 98, 1, 6, 229042) And this is impossible unless all the teachers will learn the art with its technique.
('33', 98, 1, 7, 229128) It is a waste of money to have a spinning expert.
('33', 98, 1, 8, 229178) Every teacher has to become one if spinning has to be effectively taught, and if the teacher believes in the necessity of spinning, he can learn it without any difficulty in a months’s time if he would give two hours to it daily.
('33', 98, 1, 9, 229408) But I have said that whilst charkha spinning may be taught so as to enable boys and girls if they wish to use the spinning wheel in their own homes, for class spinning the takli is the most economical and the most profitable instrument.
('33', 98, 1, 10, 229645) It is any day better that five hundred boys spin twenty five yards each for half an hour at a stated time daily than fifty boys at intervals spinning one hundred yards each in the same half hour.
('33', 98, 1, 11, 229841) Five hundred boys will spin 12,500 yards daily on the takli against 5,000 of fifty boys on the charkha.
('33', 98, 2, 12, 229945) Young India, 15 10 1925
('33', 98, 3, 13, 229969) 57. ABOUT EDUCATED CLASSES
('33', 98, 4, 14, 229996) A friend has handed me during my tour in Bihar the following questions for answers through these columns:
('33', 98, 5, 15, 230102) You complain that the educated classes in India do not follow your lead and have gone out of your hands.
('33', 98, 5, 16, 230207) Is it not due to the fact that you threw them overboard at the very beginning of the movement and demanded impossible sacrifices from them?
('33', 98, 5, 17, 230347) I do not know that I have complained about the educated class not following my lead.
('33', 98, 5, 18, 230432) If anything, I have complained of my own failure to convince that class as a body of the truth of my essential position.
('33', 98, 5, 19, 230553) To say that I threw the educated class overboard at any time is to misunderstand me.
('33', 98, 5, 20, 230638) Does a reformer ever throw anybody overboard?
('33', 98, 5, 21, 230684) He simply invites people to join him in a particular reform.
('33', 98, 5, 22, 230745) He begins with his own conversion.
('33', 98, 5, 23, 230780) In other words, he isolates
('33', 99, 0, 1, 230808) 100 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 99, 1, 2, 230850) himself from society and remains in that condition till society sees the virtue of reform, and it is not the fault of the society if its heart orhead cannot understand or appreciate a particular reform.
('33', 99, 1, 3, 231053) There is obviously something wanting in the reform or the reformer if he does not get the members of the society to which he belongs to take up his reform.
('33', 99, 1, 4, 231209) I suppose it must be admitted that the sacrifices that the new movement demanded were impossible for the educated class as a whole, and yet are not the exceptional cases brilliant?
('33', 99, 2, 5, 231390) If we remember aright, in the beginning of the movement you gave out that you did not care for the intelligentsia if the masses were with you.
('33', 99, 2, 6, 231533) If this is correct, have you now modified your views?
('33', 99, 2, 7, 231587) If so, what are you doing or intend doing now to bring the intelligentsia to your views?
('33', 99, 2, 8, 231676) I hope I never”gave out” that I”did not care for the intelligentsia”.
('33', 99, 2, 9, 231746) A reformer cannot afford to say or do so.
('33', 99, 2, 10, 231788) But I did say and do hold even now that if the masses take up the spirit of non co operation, swaraj is attainable even without the educated classes.
('33', 99, 2, 11, 231938) For the masses the chief thing they have to do in that line is to non co operate with foreign and mill spun cloth and establish closest co operation with cloth of their own spinning and weaving.
('33', 99, 2, 12, 232133) Unfor tunately even this very simple looking thing cannot be done with out the aid of the educated class.
('33', 99, 2, 13, 232239) I gratefully and fully confess that if hundreds of educated men and women were not helping me in spreading the message of the spinning wheel and khaddar, it would not have made the progress it has, and if the progress is not as fast as it might be, it is because the educated class as a whole stands aside from the khaddar movement.
('33', 99, 3, 14, 232572) Are you seriously of opinion that the masses are with you or they simply applaud you as a Mahatma, little caring for your advice?
('33', 99, 3, 15, 232702) I do believe that the masses are wholly with me mentally.
('33', 99, 3, 16, 232760) But they lack the heart to do what their mind approves.
('33', 99, 3, 17, 232816) I have examined thousands upon this point and every one of them without exception practically has said.”What can we do?
('33', 99, 3, 18, 232936) We understand what you say.
('33', 99, 3, 19, 232964) But we lack the strength for it.
('33', 99, 3, 20, 232997) Give us the strength to do it.” If the strength was in my gift, the masses would have been transformed by now.
('33', 99, 3, 21, 233108) But I know my helplessness in that direction.
('33', 99, 3, 22, 233154) God alone can give the strength which they vainly seek from me.
('33', 99, 4, 23, 233218) Do you think the masses can be so organized as to be thoroughly fitted for mass civil disobedience and are they not always liable to run amok and kill any political movement by their over enthusiasm and indiscipline?
('33', 100, 0, 1, 233435) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 101
('33', 100, 1, 2, 233486) I do believe, in spite of appearances to the contrary, that the masses can be thoroughly organized for mass civil disobedience, that is to say, more quickly than for violence.
