('33', 104, 2, 4, 243263) SUBSIDIARY INDUSTRY”PAR EXCELLENCE”
('33', 104, 3, 5, 243299) A friend sends me the following from Keatinge’s Agricultural Progress in Western Inida:
('33', 104, 4, 6, 243387) Attempts have been made to get cultivators to take up unskilled work such as cotton spinning by hand, but in view of the efficiency of spinning mills such operations can be justified economically on the assumption that the cultivator now wastes so much of his time that any work which he does, however badly paid, will be better than nothing.
('33', 104, 4, 7, 243730) Unfortunately, the existing facts in many cases justify such an assumption, but to condemn the cultivators to this uphill and uneven competition is a counsel of despair.
('33', 104, 4, 8, 243900) The subsidiary industry par excellence of the cultivators should be breeding and rearing of
('33', 104, 5, 9, 243992) livestock which provides an occupation and income at all seasons, and returns to the soil the manure which is necessary to maintain it in high fertility.
('33', 104, 5, 10, 244146) This question is valuable for its two simple admissions, namely, that in many cases the cultivator in india has much time to waste and that any occupation during that time, however badly paid, is better than nothing.
('33', 104, 5, 11, 244363) The writer, however, discourages hand spinning because of the efficiencey of spinning mills.
('33', 104, 5, 12, 244456) Upon a close examination the argument will be found to be fallacious.
('33', 104, 5, 13, 244526) The cultivator has not to compete with efficient mills at his own door.
('33', 104, 5, 14, 244598) The only thing he has to compete with is his new fangled taste for starchy and flimsy mill made cloth.
('33', 104, 5, 15, 244701) If he would only revive his old taste and return to the simple but soft and beautiful khaddar, he is never in the danger of having an idle moment thrown upon him.
('33', 104, 5, 16, 244864) The efficient hotels and bakeries offer no inducement or competition to the millions of people who prefer their crudely made chapatties to the geometrically rounded and well baked and well spiced biscuits.
('33', 104, 5, 17, 245070) The subsidiary industry of cattle breeding that has been suggested is no doubt good and any day more paying than spinning.
('33', 104, 5, 18, 245193) But it requires capital and a knowledge of breeding which the ordinary cultivator does not possess and cannot and will not possess without much previous preparation.
('33', 104, 5, 19, 245359) Turn it how you will therefore, for Indian conditions there is no other subsidiary industry that can compete with hand spinning.
('33', 105, 0, 1, 245488) 106 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 105, 1, 2, 245530) inestimable value consists not in its capacity for paying a few individuals highly but in immediately providing a remunerative occupation for millions.
('33', 105, 1, 3, 245682) It is the only subsidiary occupation, therefore, that is capable of being successfully organized.
('33', 105, 1, 4, 245780) Hence, not cattle breeding, however good it is in itself, but hand spinning is the subsidiary industry par excellence.
('33', 105, 2, 5, 245899) NECESSITY OF BODILY LABOUR
('33', 105, 3, 6, 245926) A vigilant friend writes:
('33', 105, 4, 7, 245952) In your address to the Jamshedpur gathering published in Young India of the 20th August, 1 in the first paragraph, after stressing the importance of bodily labour above intellectual, you are reported to have said:”The same thought runs throughout Hindu religion.
('33', 105, 4, 8, 246215) ‘He who eats without labour eats sin, is verily a thief.’ This is the literal meaning of a verse in the Bhagavad Gita.” Now, the question apart whether the Gita makes any such distinction between (so called) manual and (so called) intellectual labour, I can say that the only passage in the Gita which could conceivably be taken to mean what (according to the report) you have said a verse in the Gita literally means is the passage, Ch. III, verses 12 & 13; so that in the first place it is not a verse but two, which have been requisitioned in support of your view of”labour”, and secondly there is no mention of”labour”, manual or other, in either of those verses; but in the first verse there is mentioned, by way of explanation of the duty of yajna, man’s partaking with or dedicating to the higher powers what they have bestowed upon him—failing in which”he is verily a thief”, —and in the second verse we are told that”they eat sin who cook for themselves alone”.
('33', 105, 4, 9, 247186) So that is pretty far removed from”the literal sense of a verse” in the Gita as you are reported to have given it in your own paper by M.D. I hope you will make a note of it at your convenience.
('33', 105, 4, 10, 247381) Technically speaking the writer is correct in saying that the translation given by M. D. is not of one verse but a combination of parts of two verses, and I am thankful to the writer for the accuracy of his correction.
('33', 105, 4, 11, 247600) But the substance of his argument seems to me to be that there is no warrant for the translation given in the report of my speech of the famous word yajna in the Gita.
('33', 105, 4, 12, 247768) But I propose to stand by that translation and venture to suggest that in the verses 12 & 13 of Chapter III quoted by the writer, the word is capable of only one meaning.
('33', 105, 4, 13, 247939) The fourteenth verse makes it absolutely clear which means:
('33', 105, 5, 14, 247999) By food the living live; food comes of rain, And rain comes by the pious sacrifice, And sacrifice is paid with tithes of toil
('33', 105, 6, 15, 248125) —ARNOLD
('33', 105, 7, 16, 248133) 1Vide”Speech at Indian Association, Jamshedpur”, 8 8 1925.
('33', 106, 0, 1, 248192) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 107
('33', 106, 1, 2, 248243) Here therefore there is not only the theory, in my opinion, of bodily labour propounded, but there is also the theory established of labour not only for oneself but for others, when and when only it becomes yajna or sacrifice.
('33', 106, 1, 3, 248470) The rains come not through intellectual feats, but through sheer bodily labour.
('33', 106, 1, 4, 248550) It is a well established scientific fact that where forests are denuded of trees, rains cease, where trees are planted, rains are attracted and the volume of water received increases with the increase of vegetation.
('33', 106, 1, 5, 248766) Laws of nature are still unexplored.
('33', 106, 1, 6, 248803) We have but scratched the surface.
('33', 106, 1, 7, 248838) Who knows all the ill effects, moral and physical, of the cessation of bodily labour?
('33', 106, 1, 8, 248924) Let me not be misunderstood.
('33', 106, 1, 9, 248953) I do not discount the value of intellectual labour, but no amount of it is any compensation for bodily labour which every one of us is born to give for the common good of all.
('33', 106, 1, 10, 249129) It may be, often is infinitely superior to bodily labour, but it never is or can be a substitute for it, even as intellectual food, though far superior to the grains we eat, never can be a substitute for them.
('33', 106, 1, 11, 249339) Indeed without the products of the earth those of the intellect would be an impossibility.

('33', 109, 3, 4, 255334) BABU BHAGWANDAS, TEACHERS, STUDENTS, BROTHERS AND SISTERS, It is true that this Vidyapith was started by me.
('33', 109, 3, 5, 255443) But that it still exists is due, first, to the generosity and love, or attachment if you like, of Shri Shivprasad and, secondly, to the love of Shri Bhagwandas.
('33', 109, 3, 6, 255604) It cannot be called attachment in his case for he uses discretion in doing what he considers his duty.
('33', 109, 3, 7, 255707) It is owing to the enthusiasm, the intellectual effort and the money of these two that the Vidyapith is there even today.
('33', 109, 3, 8, 255829) I have been asked if I still believe in these Vidyapiths.
('33', 109, 3, 9, 255887) Was I right or in error when, in 1921, I asked the students to leave Government shcools and colleges?
('33', 109, 3, 10, 255989) I have often asked myself.
('33', 109, 3, 11, 256016) As you know I am not ashamed to admit my mistakes and am always ready to repent.
('33', 109, 3, 12, 256097) I confess my errors publicly.
('33', 109, 3, 13, 256127) I ask my inmost self whether I am right or wrong and it is my experience that the voice that comes from there expresses the truth.
('33', 109, 3, 14, 256258) I have not known it to prove false.
('33', 109, 3, 15, 256294) Now, after all this bitter experience the voice still says that I was on the right path.
('33', 109, 3, 16, 256383) What was done in 1921 was just the thing to do.

('33', 113, 7, 25, 265789) Mahatmaji began by saying that he was taken unawares.
('33', 113, 7, 26, 265843) He never knew he would have to address a public meeting at Lucknow.
('33', 113, 7, 27, 265911) He regretted that Lucknow of which he held a very good opinion should have turned into a battle ground of communal animosities.
('33', 113, 7, 28, 266039) When he was keeping twenty one days’ fast at Delhi, he had received a letter from the Hindu and Muslim leaders of Lucknow asking him to intervene in the matter.
('33', 113, 7, 29, 266200) He had agreed to it, but no one had turned up.
('33', 113, 7, 30, 266247) He thought they had better compose their differences among themselves without his aid.

('33', 116, 8, 24, 273091) 68. ABOUT UNTOUCHABILITY
('33', 116, 9, 25, 273116) A friend has asked some questions about untouchability which I believe I ought to answer as best as I may and which, therefore, I give below: 1
('33', 116, 10, 26, 273260) In my opinion, untouchability in the form in which we practise it today is not, and ought not to be, an essential part of Hinduism.
('33', 116, 10, 27, 273392) There is sheer ignorance and cruelty behind it.
('33', 116, 10, 28, 273440) I look upon it as an excrescence on Hinduism.
('33', 116, 10, 29, 273486) It does not protect religion, but suffo cates it.
('33', 116, 10, 30, 273536) Its practice on certain occasions, as during the days following the death of a near relation, is in a different class.
('33', 116, 10, 31, 273655) One may follow it to the extent one wants to.
('33', 116, 10, 32, 273701) It is not followed with equal rigidity by all communities.
('33', 116, 10, 33, 273760) The practice of untouchability in this form should be treated as a matter of hygiene.
('33', 116, 10, 34, 273846) To a greater or less extent,
('33', 116, 11, 35, 273875) 1 The questions are not translated here.
('33', 116, 11, 36, 273916) The correspondent had compared restrictions about marrying and eating and the practice of untouchability to three concentric walls erected to protect Hindu society and asked (1) whether the last was not a fundamental principle for the Hindus like the other two and (2) whether the pulling down of the outer wall would not weaken the inner two walls.
('33', 117, 0, 1, 274266) 118 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 117, 1, 2, 274308) some such regulations are found all over the world.
('33', 117, 1, 3, 274360) But treating Antyajas as untouchables is a cruel form of boycott.
('33', 117, 1, 4, 274426) Whatever justification there may have been for the practice when it started, there is none now.
('33', 117, 1, 5, 274522) Like tuberculosis, therefore, it is eating into the vitals of Hinduism.
('33', 117, 1, 6, 274594) Just as the many dilapidated and useless parts of a building, if not pulled down, weaken the rest of the building, so the outer wall of untouchability weakens, instead of protecting, the inner wall of restrictions in regard to eating in company and marrying outside one’s circle.
('33', 117, 1, 7, 274874) It is true that, in the same way as we look upon untouchability as an evil, there are some who regard these restrictions also as an evil and attack them as such.
('33', 117, 1, 8, 275036) There is, however, some reasonable principle behind them.
('33', 117, 1, 9, 275094) It would ordinarily be improper for a conscientious vegetarian to eat at a non vegetarian’s place.
('33', 117, 1, 10, 275193) But I see no dharma in treating as untouchables those who do not follow the rules that we do.
('33', 117, 1, 11, 275287) No one practises such a dharma.
('33', 117, 1, 12, 275319) Anyone who wants to practise it would have to treat everyone else in the world as an untouchable.
('33', 117, 2, 13, 275417) The movement for the eradication of untouchability has no connection with the problem of caste.
('33', 117, 2, 14, 275513) However, according to the rule that one important reform leads to another, reformers have turned their eyes to the problem of caste division too.
('33', 117, 2, 15, 275659) I desire the disappearance of sub castes, and in fact they are disappearing.
('33', 117, 2, 16, 275736) I do not, however, see the same evil in them as I see in the practice of untouchability.
('33', 117, 2, 17, 275825) These sub divisions are a source of inconvenience.
('33', 117, 2, 18, 275876) They obstruct social intercourse in some ways.
('33', 117, 2, 19, 275923) But their abolition is a reform which can wait.
('33', 117, 2, 20, 275971) The eradication of untouchability cannot wait and it is, therefore, very necessary to keep the two apart and understand the distinction between them.
('33', 117, 3, 21, 276121) I see no harm in accepting clean water from a pot filled in a clean manner by a clean Antyaja.

('33', 119, 1, 3, 278962) These thoughts occur to me as I reflect on my speech to the Marwari Conference 1 in Bhagalpur.
('33', 119, 1, 4, 279057) A many sided movement for reform is going on among Marwaris.
('33', 119, 1, 5, 279118) This particular conference was of Agarwal Marwaris.
('33', 119, 1, 6, 279170) As we see heads of communities in some places in Gujarat employing the weapon of boycott in connection with the movement on the issue of Antyajas, so also among Marwaris, we see the heads using that weapon in other circumstances too.
('33', 119, 1, 7, 279404) The issues of widow remarriage, child marriage, etc., affect all sections of Hindu society in some degree.
('33', 119, 1, 8, 279511) And, therefore, though I have already reproduced in Young India a part of what I told the Marwari friends, I wish to elaborate on the subject a little here.
('33', 119, 1, 9, 279668) Boycott is a dangerous weapon and, if not used carefully, it can easily degenerate into a species of violence.
('33', 119, 1, 10, 279779) If this happens, the community using it will perish.
('33', 119, 1, 11, 279832) I, therefore, advised the Marwari friends never to use the weapon of boycott.
('33', 119, 1, 12, 279910) So long as the heads of communities are not wise and selfless men, filled with the spirit of love, they should never think of using the weapon of boycott.
('33', 119, 1, 13, 280065) Anyone who wishes to introduce a reform should be allowed to do so.
('33', 119, 1, 14, 280133) In what way does he harm the community?
('33', 119, 1, 15, 280173) One can understand action being taken to prevent or discourage what the whole world believes to be immoral.
('33', 119, 1, 16, 280281) But is there any ground for expelling from the community a person who mixes with Antyajas, another who has decided to get his daughter married only after she has attained puberty, a third who comes forward to marry a girl who became a widow while she was still a child and a fourth who is ready to accept a partner for his son from another sub division of his own community, all because they think that it is dharma to act as they do?
('33', 119, 1, 17, 280716) Boycotting such persons will have the effect of preventing reform of any kind and rule out the possibility of progress of one’s religion and community and of the country.
('33', 119, 1, 18, 280887) I have no doubt in my mind that the weapon of boycott ought not to be misused in this manner.
('33', 119, 1, 19, 280981) As I keep touring in other provinces, the tales which I hear of the sufferings of widows, of the immorality which prevails because of child widows and of the marriages of children of very tender age make me shudder.
('33', 119, 1, 20, 281197) Is it any wonder that the progeny of such social life as the Hindus’ should lack virility?

('33', 120, 1, 2, 281511) them best, they would encourage reformers who tried to rid society of such evils.
('33', 120, 1, 3, 281593) I discussed at the conference the problem of cow protection and of social reform.
('33', 120, 1, 4, 281675) As I see more of goshalas, I realize that the people do not get all the benefit they can from them.
('33', 120, 1, 5, 281775) How very painful it is that hides of dead animals, worth nine crores of rupees, are exported every year to countries like Germany while we use foot wear made from the hides of slaughtered animals and still believe that we are preserving our dharma!
('33', 120, 1, 6, 282024) Marwaris run the largest number of goshalas in the country.
('33', 120, 1, 7, 282084) They seem to be contributing most to the cause of cow protection.
('33', 120, 1, 8, 282150) But the money they give is not used wisely, with the result that the number of cows and bullocks slaughtered is increasing, instead of decreasing.
('33', 120, 1, 9, 282297) Their quality is degenerating, milk is becoming costlier and its adulteration is becoming more widespread.
('33', 120, 1, 10, 282404) What a chaotic state of affairs!
('33', 120, 1, 11, 282437) Marwari friends do not mismanage their business in this manner.
('33', 120, 1, 12, 282501) Why do they, after contributing money for goshalas, take no further interest in them?
('33', 120, 1, 13, 282587) Does not a philanthropic cause call for efficiency and practical ability?
('33', 120, 1, 14, 282661) It is in the power of Marwaris to stop the use of the hides of slaughtered cattle.
('33', 120, 1, 15, 282744) It is their dharma to take in their hand, with a purely philanthropic motive, the trade in the hides of dead cattle.
('33', 120, 1, 16, 282861) At present, we refuse, in the name of religion and through sheer superstition, to utilize the hides of cattle which die in goshalas.
('33', 120, 1, 17, 282994) We thereby encourage the slaughter of other cattle, for it would be a different matter if we refused to use the hides of cattle altogether, dead or slaughterd.
('33', 120, 1, 18, 283154) But no Hindu looks at the matter in this way; on the contrary, Hinduism permits free use of hides, in the same way that, though we venerate the cow, we regard her milk as holy and encourage its consumption.
('33', 120, 1, 19, 283361) I can look at this matter objectively, since I never consume cow’s or buffalo’s milk and use leather as little as possible.
('33', 120, 1, 20, 283485) I have, from experience, come to the conclusion that, if we wish to protect the cow and the buffalo, we shall have to use their milk and hides and the manure which they yield to the fullest extent.
('33', 120, 1, 21, 283683) If a time comes when we will not use even milk, we should welcome it; but, when it comes, we shall no longer be running goshalas and Nature will protect cows and buffaloes according to her own laws as she now does with other animals which we have not domesticated.
('33', 120, 1, 22, 283948) Till that time comes, the principle behind cow protection seems to me to be the protection of all useful cattle which have been or may be domesticated; and their protection, too, means refusing to kill them for food or pleasure and looking after
('33', 121, 0, 1, 284194) 122 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 121, 1, 2, 284236) their physical well being, as long as the animals are alive, with as much care as we exercise in looking after our own bodies.
('33', 121, 1, 3, 284363) If with that end in view we do not use their hide after they are dead, the number of cattle slaughtered is bound to increase from day to day.
('33', 121, 1, 4, 284505) This is why I wish to plead with Marwari friends who want to serve the cause of cow protection that they use their intelligence and their business acumen in one year, and, in the course of time, will succeed in stopping their slaughter altogether without having to entreat anyone for the purpose.
('33', 121, 1, 5, 284802) Those who see no wrong in eating beef will not desist from eating it just out of respect for the Hindu sentiment, so long as it is cheap.
('33', 121, 1, 6, 284940) Giving up something even though it costs little requires a sensibility of a very high order.
('33', 121, 1, 7, 285033) Such sensibility is a religious feeling, and it can be awakened neither through force nor through entreaties.
('33', 121, 1, 8, 285143) I wish, therefore, to make the same suggestion to other Hindus which I have made to Marwari friends.

('33', 121, 2, 16, 286198) Second, propagating Hindi in non Hindi areas.
('33', 121, 2, 17, 286244) My belief is that this work is going on systematically in the South.
('33', 121, 2, 18, 286313) Practically nothing, however, is being done in a large field such as Bengal offers.
('33', 121, 2, 19, 286397) Able teachers of Hindi should be engaged there, free classes for teaching Hindi should be started and, as has been done in the South, simple books easy to read should be brought out which would help people to learn Hindi through Bengali.

('33', 126, 5, 11, 295846) 76. SPEECH AT BOMBAY 1
('33', 126, 6, 12, 295869) October 21, 1925
('33', 126, 7, 13, 295886) Mahatmaji .
('33', 126, 7, 14, 295898) thanked the Cutchi residents of Bombay and the people of Cutch for extending him an invitation to visit their province.
('33', 126, 7, 15, 296018) He did not know why he was going to Cutch, except that, perhaps, it was the love of the Cutchi people that was dragging him there.
('33', 126, 7, 16, 296149) They all knew the things that were dear to his heart and he did not propose to say anything anew about them.
('33', 126, 7, 17, 296258) He was nearing death, but all the same his ideals and ambitions remained unlimited.
('33', 126, 7, 18, 296342) In fact, the nearer he approached his end, the higher and wider grew his ambition.

('33', 126, 7, 20, 296578) He would in passing remind them that in everything he did, he was prompted by his love for truth and dharma.

('33', 126, 7, 22, 296815) Continuing, Mahatmaji said that he was in urgent need of rest and he looked forward to getting that in Cutch.
('33', 126, 7, 23, 296925) He was too much over burdened with anxiety.

('33', 127, 1, 2, 297750) 77. BOYCOTTS V. CONSTRUCTION
('33', 127, 2, 3, 297779) An Andhra friend, in his urgent invitation asking me to be present at the forthcoming Ganjam District Conference, writes as follows:
('33', 127, 3, 4, 297912) The best part of our Congress work in connection with the constructive programme was done in places round Hiramandalam.
('33', 127, 3, 5, 298032) Majority of the people wear khaddar.
('33', 127, 3, 6, 298069) You are probably aware that Andhra Desha is not in love with Council work.
('33', 127, 3, 7, 298144) It belongs to the No change party.
('33', 127, 3, 8, 298179) It never excuses you for dropping the boycotts.
('33', 127, 3, 9, 298227) Our hope lies in constructive work.
('33', 127, 3, 10, 298263) People are getting disheartened.
('33', 127, 3, 11, 298296) Their enthusiasm is at a low ebb.
('33', 127, 3, 12, 298330) Hiramandalam is a great khaddar producing centre.
('33', 127, 3, 13, 298380) The Fiska Congress Committee manufactures several varieties of khaddar and has one of the best shops in the district.
('33', 127, 3, 14, 298498) It has also a national school.
('33', 127, 3, 15, 298529) It is a Vaisya (Bania) centre.
('33', 127, 3, 16, 298560) They are almost all khaddarwalahs.
('33', 127, 3, 17, 298595) But what good?
('33', 127, 3, 18, 298610) Their enthusiasm for swaraj is well nigh extinguished.
('33', 127, 3, 19, 298665) Without the boycotts people have no faith in constructive work.
('33', 127, 3, 20, 298729) Our efforts to rekindle enthusiasm are unavailing.
('33', 127, 3, 21, 298780) I have surrendered all my worldly prospects, been rendered utterly destitute and am still at the work, hoping against hope to achieve swaraj.
('33', 127, 3, 22, 298922) I have informed him that it is impossible for me to be present at the Ganjam District Conference however much I should like to be able to do so.
('33', 127, 3, 23, 299067) I am, with great difficulty, and for me, in slow stages, finishing the remaining and indispensable part of the tour programme for the year, after which I hope to have rest from incessant travelling.
('33', 127, 3, 24, 299266) I am, therefore, sorry to have to disappoint the Andhra friends.
('33', 127, 3, 25, 299331) But I have reproduced the foregoing extract not for the purpose of advertising the necessity for rest for my tired limbs, but in order to remove the confusion of thought that has enabled the writer to attribute want of interest in constructive work to the suspension of boycotts by the Congress.
('33', 127, 3, 26, 299627) In the first place, if Andhra Desh has no love for Council work, the Congress does not compel it tomanufacture love for Councils.
('33', 127, 3, 27, 299757) It merely authorizes those who believe in Council work to take it up on behalf of and in the name of the Congress.
('33', 127, 3, 28, 299872) It withdraws the prohibition from those who gave up such work not out of faith but merely out of loyalty to the Congress.
('33', 127, 3, 29, 299994) It prohibits people from using the name of the Congress to condemn entry into the legislative bodies and, lastly, it encourages those who believe in such political work to prosecute it with zeal.
('33', 127, 3, 30, 300190) But it does not in any way fetter a single Congressman’s conscience.
('33', 127, 3, 31, 300259) Those must have a poor
('33', 128, 0, 1, 300282) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 129
('33', 128, 1, 2, 300333) faith in themselves whose zeal is damped for want of extraneous support.
('33', 128, 1, 3, 300406) Moreover, the writer forgets that the Congress has not only not dropped boycott of foreign cloth, but it will bless and issue a certificate of merit to those who will achieve that boycott.
('33', 128, 1, 4, 300595) I am striving my best to deserve that certificate and I invite everybody to join me in the endeavour.
('33', 128, 1, 5, 300697) That boycott can be achieved only when khaddar becomes popular enough to be universal.
('33', 128, 1, 6, 300784) Hence the inauguration of the All India Spinners’ Association.
('33', 128, 1, 7, 300847) Every boycott has its constructive side.
('33', 128, 1, 8, 300888) The Association will devote its best energy ot the constructive effort.
('33', 128, 1, 9, 300960) What have the other boycotts—for instance that of titles or schools or law courts—to do with the manufacture and wearing of khaddar?
('33', 128, 1, 10, 301093) The beauty of these boycotts lies in their individuality and capacity to stand alone.
('33', 128, 1, 11, 301179) The individual taking part in any or all of them always benefits, and when a sufficiently large number take part in them the nation becomes fit for swaraj.
('33', 128, 1, 12, 301335) Blind enthusiasm and blind faith can lead to no lasting good.
('33', 128, 1, 13, 301397) It is, therefore, necessary to realize that the constructive programme by itself has an inestimable value even apart from its undoubted capacity to fit us for swaraj.
('33', 128, 1, 14, 301564) The writer has done well in surrendering all his worldly prospects and in rendering himself utterly destitute.
('33', 128, 1, 15, 301675) But let him consider that sacrifice to be its own reward.
('33', 128, 1, 16, 301733) Thousands upon thousands will have to do likewise before swaraj is attained by the nation.
('33', 128, 1, 17, 301824) He who has sacrificed his all for swaraj has certainly attained it for himself.
('33', 128, 1, 18, 301904) There is no need, therefore, for such a one to ‘hope against hope’, for if his sacrifice is voluntary and intelligent, it is all hope without any disappointment.
('33', 128, 1, 19, 302066) One’s faith has got to be bright and intelligent before it can enkindle faith in others.
('33', 128, 1, 20, 302155) Those, therefore, who believe in khaddar and other parts of the programme of 1921 must be able to stand unmoved in spite of variations in the policy, politics and programme of the Congress.

('33', 128, 4, 23, 302379) A CORRECTION
('33', 128, 5, 24, 302392) In the issue of 8th October, in my Bihar Notes , I have said:”In Ranchi I was taken to Golcunda.” This was a stupid slip on my part.
('33', 128, 5, 25, 302525) The Bihari friends are now laughing at my geographical ignorance and tell me that Golcunda is not near Ranchi but near Purulia.
('33', 129, 0, 1, 302653) 130 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 129, 1, 2, 302695) an apology to Purulia for the blunder.
('33', 129, 1, 3, 302734) When, however, several villages and several places in the same village or town have to be visited on the same day and these performances follow in quick succession it is difficult for one to remember all the places accurately.
('33', 129, 1, 4, 302961) I am, therefore, obliged to omit the mention of the names of many places and persons and simply confine myself to narration of events because at the moment I do not remember either the names of places or persons concerned.
('33', 129, 1, 5, 303184) When, therefore, people find that the names of persons or places, that in their opinion I should have mentioned, have been omitted, let them understand that often the omission is unintentional and that it is due purely to my weak memory.
('33', 129, 2, 6, 303422) SPINNING ESSAY
('33', 129, 3, 7, 303437) The reader will remember that early this year 1 Sjt.
('33', 129, 3, 8, 303490) Rewashanker Jagjivan announced a prize of one thousand rupees to be given to the writer of the best essay on hand spinning, its history and its use.
('33', 129, 3, 9, 303639) These were the terms: (1) The essay should be in English in four parts; the first part to contain the history of hand spinning and the khaddar (meaning hand spun, including the celebrated shubnum of Dacca) trade of India before the British advent, the second part should trace the history of the ruin of hand spinning and the khaddar trade, the third part should be an examination of the possibilities of hand spinning and khaddar and a comparison between the Indian mill industry and hand spinning and handweaving, the fourth part should examine the possibilities of achieving boycott of foreign cloth through the spinning wheel.
('33', 129, 3, 10, 304270) The essay should be supported by authoritative statistics and should have an appendix containing a list of all the reference books and authorities used by the author in support of his argument.
('33', 129, 3, 11, 304464) (2) The essay may be as brief as the competitors wish to make it, consistently with the giving of a full record of facts and figures.
('33', 129, 3, 12, 304598) (3) The essay should be sent to the office of Young India by registered book post with the author’s name on a separate sheet and should reach the office of Young India not later than 15th March next.
('33', 129, 3, 13, 304798) The judges will be Messrs Shankerlal Banker, Maganlal K. Gandhi and myself.
('33', 129, 3, 14, 304874) The result will be announced not later than 31st March 1925. The judges will reserve to themselves the right of rejecting all the essays if they fall below a certain standard.
('33', 129, 3, 15, 305050) The prize will be paid to the winner on the announcement thereof.
('33', 129, 3, 16, 305116) The right of publication will vest in the All India Khadi Board in accordance with the donor’s wishes.

('33', 130, 2, 17, 306656) SPINNERS, PLEASE NOTE
('33', 130, 3, 18, 306678) Those who were in charge of the yarn that was received under the All India Congress Committee resolution last year ask me to warn the spinners who become members of the A.I.S.A. against sending yarn that is not evenly spun and uniform.
('33', 130, 3, 19, 306914) A quantity of bad yarn still lies unused.
('33', 130, 3, 20, 306956) Just as bread that is stodgy and ill baked is no bread, similarly yarn that is not easily woven is no yarn, and the condition of membership is not a thousand yards of self spun yarn merely but a thousand yards per month of self spun yarn well twisted and uniform for A class and two thousand yards yearly of the same quality of self spun yarn for B class members.
('33', 130, 3, 21, 307320) Therefore, if the secretaries are to do their duty well, it will be necessary for them not to take yarn that is considered to be below standard, and the standard while it need not be stiff will certainly be stiff enough to meet the elementary requirements of good weavable yarn.
('33', 130, 3, 22, 307599) In cash subscriptions a bad coin cannot be accepted as a proper tender nor can bad yarn be accepted as proper tender when subscription is payable in yarn.
('33', 130, 4, 23, 307754) WHAT HAVE YOU DONE?

('33', 131, 2, 17, 309500) LOHANI AT LAST
('33', 131, 3, 18, 309515) After I had given up all hope of finding Lohani, I received help from an unexpected quarter and I have now before me full details in the shape of newspaper cuttings.
('33', 131, 3, 19, 309681) I observe that these cuttings are based upon my first reference to Lohani in the pages of Young India.
('33', 131, 3, 20, 309784) The writers of these newspaper reports evidently thought that I would see their references.
('33', 131, 3, 21, 309876) They are obviously unaware of the fact that I do not get the time to read the numerous newspapers which the kind editors and proprietors send me in exchange for Young India or Navajivan.
('33', 131, 3, 22, 310063) I have often requested and I repeat the request that those who seek to give me information or correct me or advise me through their writings in newspapers will kindly send me the cuttings in question.
('33', 131, 3, 23, 310264) The writer in one of the cuttings expresses his surprise and astonishment that I should not know where Lohani is.
('33', 131, 3, 24, 310378) I share the regret.
('33', 131, 3, 25, 310398) But why astonishment?
('33', 131, 3, 26, 310420) I have before now admitted my ignorance of the geography of my own country.
('33', 131, 3, 27, 310496) In the vernacular
('33', 132, 0, 1, 310514) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 133
('33', 132, 1, 2, 310565) school I had the barest outlines of the geography of India and, in the English school, from the very first standard I was called upon, on pain of being caned, to learn by heart the names of all the counties of England and many other foreign names which it gave me headache to pronounce and remember.
('33', 132, 1, 3, 310865) Nobody taught me, and I am sure my teacher did not know, where Lohani was.
('33', 132, 1, 4, 310940) Even Bhiwani, near which, I now see, Lohani is situated, was unknown to me before I went to the Punjab.
('33', 132, 1, 5, 311044) Lohani then according to the cutting in my possession, is a little Hindu village, six miles from Bhiwani.
('33', 132, 1, 6, 311150) The Hindu zamindars, the cutting proceeds, introduced in Lohani some Musalmans.
('33', 132, 1, 7, 311230) The Hindus and the Mussalmans are now fighting over a piece of land which , the Mussalmans claim, is consecrated and the Hindus claim has never ceased to be their property.
('33', 132, 1, 8, 311403) The matter is before the courts.
('33', 132, 1, 9, 311436) And there I must leave it.
('33', 132, 1, 10, 311463) The writer of the newspaper article invites me to investigate the matter and pronounce my own opinion upon it.
('33', 132, 1, 11, 311574) If I had the authority which I thought at one time I possessed, I would certainly investigate and prevent the quarrel from being decided in a court of law.
('33', 132, 1, 12, 311730) But I must now plead my incapacity.
('33', 132, 1, 13, 311766) I would, however, advise both the parties to approach those in whom they have confidence and seek their intervention.
('33', 132, 2, 14, 311884) A TOTAL DENIAL
('33', 132, 3, 15, 311899) With regard to the charges of bribery, corruption and intimidation brought against the Swarajists of Madras in connection with the late Municipal elections and recently referred to in these columns, I have a long letter from Sjt.
('33', 132, 3, 16, 312129) P. S. Doraiswamy Mudaliar totally and specifically denying every one of those charges and on the contrary holding that the defeated party was guilty of the very charges brought against the Swarajists.

('33', 132, 4, 20, 312799) THE GOANESE UNDER SWARAJ
('33', 132, 5, 21, 312824) A Goan friend asks: What would be your attitude and that of all Indians towards the Goanese who reside and earn their living in this country when swaraj is attained?
('33', 133, 0, 1, 312990) 134 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 133, 1, 2, 313032) In briefest terms the answer is, that the attitude towards the Goanese will be exactly the same as towards any other Indian, for, the Goanese are as much inhabitants of India as the inhabitants of any other part.
('33', 133, 1, 3, 313245) That they are under another foreign Government can make no difference in their treatment.
('33', 133, 1, 4, 313335) If the fear underlying this question is due to difference of religion, then, it has been repeatedly stated in these columns that swaraj is not intended for any one religion only but for all, and that those who are not born or domiciled in India would be fully protected, as fully as under the present Government, where they are not unduly favoured.
('33', 133, 1, 5, 313684) That is the swaraj of my conception.
('33', 133, 1, 6, 313721) What it is ultimately going to be depends upon what thinking humanity in India does in the long run.
('33', 133, 1, 7, 313822) The Goanese population has the making of the India of the future as much in their hands as any other group.
('33', 133, 1, 8, 313930) No one need therefore ask what will become of him under swaraj because no one but idiots and the imbecile will live on sufferance.
('33', 133, 1, 9, 314061) Each one will guard his own individual liberty, if the State encroaches upon it.
('33', 133, 1, 10, 314142) Not until many people acquire that power of resistance will India obtain real freedom.
('33', 133, 2, 11, 314229) WHEN CRIME NOT IMMORAL
('33', 133, 3, 12, 314252) A fair friend sends me ‘crisp sayings’ by Dan Griffiths on crime and wants me to find room for them in these pages.
('33', 133, 3, 13, 314368) Here are some extracts which a satyagrahi can readily subscribe to:
('33', 133, 4, 14, 314436) State law is not necessarily moral.
('33', 133, 4, 15, 314472) Crime is not necessarily immoral.
('33', 133, 4, 16, 314506) There is a world of difference between illegality and immorality.
('33', 133, 4, 17, 314572) Not all illegalities are immoral and not all immoralities are illegal.
('33', 133, 4, 18, 314643) Who can say that, whilst not to crawl on one’s belly at the dictation of an officer might be an illegality, it is also an immorality?
('33', 133, 4, 19, 314777) Rather is it not true that refusal to crawl on one’s belly may be illegal, but it would be in the highest degree moral?
('33', 133, 4, 20, 314897) An other illuminating passage is the following:
('33', 133, 5, 21, 314945) Modern society is in itself a crime factory.
('33', 133, 5, 22, 314990) The militarist is a relative of the murderer and the burglar is the compliment of the stock jobber.
('33', 133, 5, 23, 315090) The third excerpt runs as follows:
('33', 133, 6, 24, 315125) The thief in law is merely a person who satisfies his acquisitive instincts in ways not sanctioned by the community.
('33', 133, 6, 25, 315242) The real thief is the person who takes more out of society than he puts into it.
('33', 133, 6, 26, 315323) But society punishes those who annoy it, not those who injure it, the retail and not the wholesale offenders.

('33', 134, 5, 6, 315977) 79. THAT ETERNAL QUESTION
('33', 134, 6, 7, 316003) However much I may wish to avoid it, the Hindu Muslim question will not avoid me.

('33', 134, 6, 11, 316415) I had written to him telling him point blank that I did not believe those allegations, but that, if he had proof and gave it to me I would gladly examine it, and if I was satisfied, I would denounce it although I might not be able to do any tangible good.
('33', 134, 6, 12, 316671) Since then I have had cuttings from newspapers describing in harrowing detail cases of kindnapping.
('33', 134, 6, 13, 316771) I had told the friend that newspaper extracts could not be accepted as any evidence of the crime, that in many cases newspaper paragraphs were inflammatory, misleading and often absolutely false.
('33', 134, 6, 14, 316967) There are Hindu and Muslim sheets that delight in blackguarding Mussalmans and Hindus respectively and if both of them could be accepted as true, both the parties were loathsome creatures.

('33', 134, 6, 16, 317277) I have, therefore, asked for such incontestable proofs as would be accepted in any court of law.

('33', 134, 6, 18, 317417) A Hindu girl had been kidnapped.

('33', 135, 1, 2, 317492) supposed to have embraced Islam and in spite of the court’s order she has not yet been produced so far as I am aware.

('33', 135, 1, 6, 317873) I refrain at the present moment from going into it because it is not before me in its completed form.
('33', 135, 1, 7, 317975) Such cases set one athinking and need the attention of all well wishers of the country.
('33', 135, 1, 8, 318063) There is then the question of music in front of mosques.
('33', 135, 1, 9, 318120) I have heard of a peremptory demand for total cessation of music, soft or loud, at any time whatsoever in front of mosques.
('33', 135, 1, 10, 318244) There is too a demand for the stopping of arati during prayer hours in temples in the neighbourhood of mosques.
('33', 135, 1, 11, 318356) I heard in Calcutta that even boys passing by a mosque early in the morning and reciting Ramanama were stopped.
('33', 135, 1, 12, 318468) What is to be done?
('33', 135, 1, 13, 318488) Recourse to law courts in such matters is a broken reed.
('33', 135, 1, 14, 318545) If I allow my daughter to be kidnapped and then go to court for protection, the latter would be powerless or, if the judge got angry over my cowardice, he would dismiss me from his presence with deserved contempt.
('33', 135, 1, 15, 318759) Courts deal with ordinary crimes.
('33', 135, 1, 16, 318793) General kidnapping of girls or boys is not an ordinary crime.
('33', 135, 1, 17, 318855) People in such cases are expected to look after themselves.
('33', 135, 1, 18, 318915) Courts help those who are largely able to help themselves.
('33', 135, 1, 19, 318974) Theirs is supplementary protection.
('33', 135, 1, 20, 319010) So long as there are weak people so long will there be someone to prey upon their weakness.
('33', 135, 1, 21, 319102) The remedy therefore lies in organizing for self defence.
('33', 135, 1, 22, 319160) I could find it in me to justify the most violent defence in such cases unless the people concerned are capable of a non violent defence.
('33', 135, 1, 23, 319298) No doubt where girls or boys of poor and helpless parents are kidnapped, the case becomes much more complicated.
('33', 135, 1, 24, 319411) There the remedy has to be found not by the individual but by a whole clan or caste.
('33', 135, 1, 25, 319496) A presentation, however, of authentic cases of kidnapping is a prime necessity before public opinion can be well organized.
('33', 135, 1, 26, 319620) The question of music is much simpler than that of kidnapping.
('33', 135, 1, 27, 319683) Either continuous music, arati or the repeating of Ramanama is a religious necessity or it is not.
('33', 135, 1, 28, 319782) If it is a religious necessity, no prohibition order by a court of law can be held obligatory.
('33', 135, 1, 29, 319877) Music must be played, arati must be made and Ramanama repeated, cost what it may.
('33', 135, 1, 30, 319959) If my formula were accepted a procession of the meekest
('33', 136, 0, 1, 320015) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 137
('33', 136, 1, 2, 320066) men and women, unarmed even with lathis, would march with Ramanama on their lips, supposing that that was the bone of contention and draw down on their heads the whole of the Mussalman wrath.
('33', 136, 1, 3, 320258) But, if they would not accept that formula, they would still proceed with the sacred name of their lips and fight every inch of the ground.
('33', 136, 1, 4, 320398) But to stop music for fear of a row or because of an order of court is to deny one’s religion.
('33', 136, 1, 5, 320493) But, then, there is the other side to the question.
('33', 136, 1, 6, 320545) Is continuous playing of music even while passing mosques at prayer time always a religious necessity?
('33', 136, 1, 7, 320648) Is repeating of Ramanama a similar necessity?
('33', 136, 1, 8, 320694) What about the charge that the fashion nowadays is to organize processions purely for the sake of irritating Mussalmans and to make arati just at the time of prayer and to utter Ramanama not because it is held religiously necessary but in order to create an occasion for a fight?
('33', 136, 1, 9, 320974) If such be the case it will defeat its own end and naturally, the zest being wanting, a court’s order, a military display or a shower of brickbats would end the irreligious show.
('33', 136, 1, 10, 321153) A religious necessity must, therefore, be clearly established.
('33', 136, 1, 11, 321216) Every semblance of irritation must be avoided.
('33', 136, 1, 12, 321263) A mutual understanding should be sincerely sought.
('33', 136, 1, 13, 321314) And where it is not possible, an irreducible minimum should be fixed making due allowance for the opposite sentiment and then without seeking the intervention of courts or in spite of a prohibition order, a fight must be put up for that minimum.
('33', 136, 1, 14, 321560) Let no one charge me with ever having advised or encouraged weakness or surrender on matters of principle.
('33', 136, 1, 15, 321667) But I have said, as I say again, that every trifle must not be dignified into a principle.
('33', 136, 2, 16, 321758) Young India, 22 10 1925
('33', 136, 3, 17, 321782) 80. BIHAR NOTES
('33', 136, 4, 18, 321798) FUNCTION OF LOCAL BOARD MEMBERS
('33', 136, 5, 19, 321830) At Giridih the addresses presented to me contained interesting references and there was also, as in Chaibasa, an address from the Goshala Committee.
('33', 136, 5, 20, 321979) The Local Board address referred to the bad condition of the roads under its charge.
('33', 136, 5, 21, 322064) The justification given was shortage of funds.
('33', 136, 5, 22, 322111) I had no hesitation in replying that shortage of funds was no excuse for keeping the roads in bad repair when
('33', 137, 0, 1, 322221) 138 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 137, 1, 2, 322263) Congresssmen manned local boards.
('33', 137, 1, 3, 322297) After all, roads were national property, Congressmen were national servants and when by entering local boards, they obtained charge of roads they were expected to keep them in good repair whether there were funds or not.
('33', 137, 1, 4, 322518) They might put up on every good point a valiant fight with the Government, but their constructive work should in no way be allowed to be neglected.
('33', 137, 1, 5, 322666) If they found that they could not properly discharge their trust, they must resign.
('33', 137, 1, 6, 322750) Want of funds was no cause for resignation because that could be made up for by voluntary effort.
('33', 137, 1, 7, 322848) Let the members of such boards take up the pickaxe and the shovel, gird up their loins and themselves work at the roads and call a party of volunteers to asist them.
('33', 137, 1, 8, 323014) They will earn the blessings of the public as also of the dumb cattle and command the respect of the superior authority.
('33', 137, 1, 9, 323135) Indeed, in all municipal work everywhere, a large part of it is done by the councillors unofficially and with the voluntary support of the public.
('33', 137, 1, 10, 323282) The late Mr. Joseph Chamberlain 1 turned Birmingham into a clean city studded with statues and other decorations, not merely through the paid service of the Corporation but by the voluntary support, pecuniary and other, of its citizens.
('33', 137, 1, 11, 323519) The Municipality of Glasgow dealt with its plague epidemic in summary and exemplary fashion only because the members of the Corporation received the willing and unstinted support of its citizens.
('33', 137, 1, 12, 323715) The Municipality of Johannesburg, within my own experience, dealt with similar trouble in the same summary manner.
('33', 137, 1, 13, 323830) It counted no cost too great for the eradication of plague, burnt down its market buildings and its location and had behind it the resources of its determined citizens.
('33', 137, 1, 14, 323999) I told my audience that therefore I was asking for nothing heroic of the Local Board members by askingthem to do the road repair themselves with the assistance of Congress volunteers if they had not enough funds.
('33', 137, 1, 15, 324212) If we captured municipalities and local boards, we must be able to give a good account of ourselves in all the constructive work that was entrusted to our charge under statutory authority.
('33', 137, 2, 16, 324401) COW PROTECTION
('33', 137, 3, 17, 324416) The Committee of the Giridih goshala said in its address that it had an annual income of nine thousand rupees in donations and an
('33', 137, 4, 18, 324546) 11836 1914; British statesmen.
('33', 137, 4, 19, 324577) He was mayor of Birmingham from 1873 to 1876.
('33', 138, 0, 1, 324623) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 139
('33', 138, 1, 2, 324674) income of only two thousand rupees from milk, etc.
('33', 138, 1, 3, 324725) The reader will recall that it is the same tale as that of Chaibasa.
('33', 138, 1, 4, 324794) Much cry but little wool.
('33', 138, 1, 5, 324820) An ideal goshala would supply the city of its domicile with cheap and wholesome milk from cattle of its own keeping and cheap and lasting foot wear not out of slaughtered hide but out of the hide of dead cattle.
('33', 138, 1, 6, 325032) Such a goshala will not be on one or two acres of ground in the heart of a city or in its immediate neighbourhood, but it would have, at some distance but within easy reach, fifty to a hundred acres of ground where a modern dairy and a modern tannery would be conducted on strictly business but national lines.
('33', 138, 1, 7, 325343) Thus there would be no profits and no dividends to be paid and there would be also no loss incurred.
('33', 138, 1, 8, 325444) In the long run such institutions dotted all over India would be a triumph of Hinduism and would be proof of Hindu earnestness about cow, that is, cattle protection and it would provide decent employment for thousands of men including educated men; for both dairy and tannery work require expert scientific knowledge.
('33', 138, 1, 9, 325762) Not Denmark but India should be a model State for the finest dairy experiments and India should not to her shame have to export nine crore rupees worth of dead cattle hide annually and for her own consumption use slaughtered cattle hide .
('33', 138, 1, 10, 326001) If such a state of things is a shame for India it is a greater shame for Hindus.
('33', 138, 1, 11, 326082) I wish that all the goshala committees will take to heart the remarks I made in reply to the Giridih address 1 and make their goshalas into ideal dairies and tanneries and a refuge for all worn out and maimed cattle.
('33', 138, 2, 12, 326299) WHO SHOULD SPIN?
('33', 138, 3, 13, 326316) A third interesting reference in the Giridih address was to non spinning by its labourers.
('33', 138, 3, 14, 326407) Giridih has several mica mines.
('33', 138, 3, 15, 326439) It has, therefore, many labourers working in those mines.
('33', 138, 3, 16, 326497) These labourers get naturally a higher wage than they can possibly get from spinning and they are, therefore, not spinning at all.
('33', 138, 3, 17, 326628) As a matter of fact, there need have been no such apologetic reference as was made in the address.
('33', 138, 3, 18, 326727) The readers of Young India know that I have never suggested that those who are more lucratively employed should give up their lucrative employment and prefer hand spinning.
('33', 138, 3, 19, 326900) I have said repeatedly that those only are expected and should be induced to spin who have no other paying employment and that too only during the hours of unemployment.
('33', 138, 3, 20, 327070) The whole theory of hand spinning is based
('33', 138, 4, 21, 327113) 1Vide”Speech at Public Meeting, Giridih”, 7 10 1925.
('33', 139, 0, 1, 327166) 140 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 139, 1, 2, 327208) upon the assumption that there are millions of men and women in this land who are idle for at least four months in the year for want of some employment.
('33', 139, 1, 3, 327361) There are only, therefore, two classes of people who are expected to spin, those who would spin for hire, whom I have already mentioned, and the thinking part of India who should spin for sacrifice by way of example and in order to cheapen khaddar.
('33', 139, 1, 4, 327610) But whilst I could understand labourers not spinning, I could not understand their not wearing khaddar.
('33', 139, 1, 5, 327714) There was no excuse for a single person in that vast audience not to wear khaddar.
('33', 139, 1, 6, 327797) Giridih can produce and manufacture its own yarn and weave its own khaddar without any difficulty and, in any case can get all its supply of khaddar ready made and comparatively cheap from the other parts of Bihar.
('33', 139, 1, 7, 328012) But I notice that, whilst these addresses admit shortcomings about khaddar and the charkha, they are mentioned, I fear, not as an earnest of reform in the immediate future, but by way of consolation for continuing the same state of things.
('33', 139, 1, 8, 328252) A confession is good only when it is intended to be followed up by a retracing; it is worse than that the confessions made in the many addresses presented to me will be precursors of a definite change.
('33', 139, 2, 9, 328454) NATIONAL SCHOOLS
('33', 139, 3, 10, 328471) From Giridih we came to Madhupur.
('33', 139, 3, 11, 328505) There I was called upon to perform the opening ceremony of its new elegant looking little Town Hall.
('33', 139, 3, 12, 328606) In performing the opening ceremony and in congratulating the Municipality on possessing its own abode, I expressed the hope that the Municipality would make Madhupur a beauty spot worthy of the climate and natural surroundings it possessed.
('33', 139, 3, 13, 328847) The difficulties in the way of improving big cities like Calcutta and Bombay were very great.
('33', 139, 3, 14, 328941) But in little places like Madhupur, if municipalities had a very small income, they had also no difficulty to face in keeping their areas spotlessly clean and free from diseases.
('33', 139, 3, 15, 329120) I visited, too, the national school which Madhupur boasts.
('33', 139, 3, 16, 329179) The head master in the address which he read drew a gloomy picture of the prospects before him— decreasing attendance and decreasing pecuniary support from the people.
('33', 139, 3, 17, 329347) He mentioned also that some parents withdrew their boys because hand spinning was compulsory.
('33', 139, 3, 18, 329441) The address asked me to point the way out of the difficulties mentioned.
('33', 139, 3, 19, 329514) I replied that if the teachers believed in their mission, they need not be disappointed.
('33', 139, 3, 20, 329603) Ups and downs in all new institutions were their natural lot.
('33', 139, 3, 21, 329665) Their difficulties, therefore, were the teachers’ testing time.
('33', 140, 0, 1, 329729) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 141
('33', 140, 1, 2, 329780) convictions only could be described as stable which would stand the stress of storms.
('33', 140, 1, 3, 329866) The teachers should, therefore, count no sacrifice too great if they believed that they had a message to deliver to their surroundings through their schools.
('33', 140, 1, 4, 330024) They would then remain unconcerned whether there was only one boy or there were one hundred in the school, provided it was perfectly clear to them that they had done their best for the school and that it was not their shortcomings that estranged the parents and the boys but that the very principle for which they stood was repugnant to them.
('33', 140, 1, 5, 330367) If they had faith in hand spinning, they would not mind the parents withdrawing their children from the school.
('33', 140, 1, 6, 330479) If they had retained spinning only because it was a fashion, or because the Congress resolution required it, and not because they had faith in it, they need not hesitate then to do away with spinning and retain the goodwill of the people.
('33', 140, 1, 7, 330718) Time has arrived when national teachers have to make a definite choice for themselves, because, when new changes are made there are always some people who resent one or all of them.
('33', 140, 1, 8, 330900) It is only the teacher with faith in himself and his cause who could resist opposition to the changes which he considers to be necessary and which alone, perhaps, justify the existence of his new enterprise.
('33', 140, 2, 9, 331108) MISCELLANEOUS
('33', 140, 3, 10, 331122) From Madhupur we proceeded to the Purnea District, which meant a new surrounding and a new country.

('33', 140, 3, 17, 331624) We went from Maniari by train to Katihar Junction where there were the usual public meetings.
('33', 140, 3, 18, 331718) The next day we went to Kishangunj where also there were the usual meetings and a purse.
('33', 140, 3, 19, 331807) Kishangunj contains a large Marwari population.
('33', 140, 3, 20, 331855) They had made a good collection.
('33', 140, 3, 21, 331888) A deputation came to me complaining that although they were ready and willing to wear khaddar they could not get any in Kishangunj.
('33', 140, 3, 22, 332020) They said that the whole of the cloth trade was in the hands of the Marwari merchants who sold only foreign cloth, bcause, the deputation said, the Marwari merchants told them it paid them best.
('33', 140, 3, 23, 332215) I told the deputation, however, that whilst I would gladly speak to the Marwari friends, their excuse
('33', 141, 0, 1, 332317) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 141, 1, 2, 332359) was really inadmissible because, if there was a large demand for khaddar in Kishangunj, they could open a co operative store themselves.
('33', 141, 1, 3, 332496) If was no use blaming the Marwari merchants who were after all in Kishangunj for their business.
('33', 141, 1, 4, 332593) It was for those like the deputation who believed in khaddar to set the fashion, go to some trouble in stocking it, and then induce Marwari friends to take it up also.
('33', 141, 1, 5, 332761) This, however, I saw, they were not prepared to do.
('33', 141, 1, 6, 332813) I told them, too, that if they guaranteed a minimum sale I would undertake to persuade Rajendra Babu to open a khaddar depot in Kishangunj.
('33', 141, 1, 7, 332953) This they were not prepared to risk.
('33', 141, 1, 8, 332990) I spoke to the leading Marwari merchants who told me that, as a matter of fact, for some time some Marwaris did have some khaddar in their stores, but there was no great demand for it.
('33', 141, 1, 9, 333175) And they admitted that there was no special effort made by the Marwari merchants to push khaddar before the public.
('33', 141, 2, 10, 333291) CONFUSION
('33', 141, 3, 11, 333301) From Kishangunj we went to Araria, and from Araria to Forbesgunj, the north eastern extreme point of Bihar near which commences the Nepal border, and from where, I was told, on a clear day one could see the magnificent snowy range of the Himalayas.
('33', 141, 3, 12, 333550) Before we reached Forbesgunj, I was inclined to congratulate Rajendra Babu and his band of workers upon the excellent control they had obtained upon the people in that, unlike as on previous occasions, the vast crowds of people were orderly, noiseless and exercised exemplary self restraint by refraining from besieging me to touch my feet.
('33', 141, 3, 13, 333891) I was, however, disillusioned at Forbesgunj, because the order broke down there.
('33', 141, 3, 14, 333972) The crowd was immense.
('33', 141, 3, 15, 333995) The meeting had to take place under the fierce sun.
('33', 141, 3, 16, 334047) The people had been waiting since morning without any shade over head.
('33', 141, 3, 17, 334118) The noise and the din were terrible.
('33', 141, 3, 18, 334155) It was impossible for me to get any quiet; and volunteers were unable to restrain the vast crowd from coming to touch me.
('33', 141, 3, 19, 334277) The fact is that not much work had been done there before.
('33', 141, 3, 20, 334336) The volunteers were new to the task.
('33', 141, 3, 21, 334373) The poor fellows tried their best.
('33', 141, 3, 22, 334408) Nobody was to blame.
('33', 141, 3, 23, 334429) It was a new situation and a new experience for them.
('33', 141, 3, 24, 334483) And the people were not to be deprived of what they must have considered to be the only opportunity of coming near me and touching me.
('33', 141, 3, 25, 334618) It is an affectionate superstition; but it is also most embarrassing for me.
('33', 141, 3, 26, 334695) I spoke to them about khaddar, about the spinning wheel, about temperance, gambling and the like; but I am afraid that it was all like foreign speech to them.
('33', 141, 3, 27, 334854) Mysterious are the ways of God.
('33', 141, 3, 28, 334886) Tens of
('33', 142, 0, 1, 334894) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 143
('33', 142, 1, 2, 334945) thousands of people irresistibly drawn to someone or to something of whom or which they had but the vaguest idea.

('33', 142, 1, 4, 335116) a perfectly strange being to them.
('33', 142, 1, 5, 335151) I do not know whether it was worth while my going to Forbesgunj.
('33', 142, 1, 6, 335216) Perhaps it is as well that we do not know the results of all we do, if only we do things for the service of God and humanity and do nothing which we know to be wrong.
('33', 142, 2, 7, 335383) CONCLUSION

('33', 142, 3, 26, 337127) I hope, if all goes well, to finish the balance of the Bihar tour early next year, but I expect that the Biharis will show much further progress in khaddar and charkha during the intervening months.

('33', 143, 3, 5, 337676) 81. A DILEMMA
('33', 143, 4, 6, 337690) A friend finds himself in a dilemma.
('33', 143, 4, 7, 337727) He is serving in an Indian concern that requires his services from 8 a.m.
('33', 143, 4, 8, 337801) to 9 p.m., I suppose with a break for dinner.
('33', 143, 4, 9, 337847) But the employers do not prescribe the kind or the quality of the material of which his dress should be made.
('33', 143, 4, 10, 337957) And by choice therefore he wears khaddar.
('33', 143, 4, 11, 337999) A foreign firm, however, offers him double the salary with fewer hours of service but will not have his dress made of khaddar.
('33', 143, 4, 12, 338126) Now the difficulty which faces him is this: If he accepts the foreign service, he can not only improve his material position but get enough time for spinning daily in which he believes but has to deny himself khaddar dress which he loves.
('33', 143, 4, 13, 338365) If he remains where he is he has to slave for 12 hours, pinch himself and get no time for spinning.
('33', 143, 4, 14, 338465) What is he to do?
('33', 143, 4, 15, 338483) I have little hesitation in giving my opinion.
('33', 143, 4, 16, 338530) Apart from the question of khaddar, for a self respecting man, the foreigner’s tempting offer is totally unacceptable for the simple reason that it is coupled with an undue restraint upon one’s liberty, especially when that restraint is against national interest and, from the fact stated is due to prejudice against khaddar.
('33', 143, 4, 17, 338856) On merits, too, I would any day prefer liberty to wear khaddar although for want of time spinning may have to be sacrificed for the time being.
('33', 143, 4, 18, 339000) If all were obliged to discard khaddar spinning will have no value.
('33', 143, 4, 19, 339068) The vartue of spinning is not absolute but relative.
('33', 143, 4, 20, 339121) If the product of spinning is not marketable, it would be a cruel mockery to call upon millions of semi starved men and women to spin.
('33', 143, 4, 21, 339256) The need of the time is, therefore, popularization ofkhaddar wear.
('33', 143, 4, 22, 339323) Spinning is undoubtedly necessary.
('33', 143, 4, 23, 339358) But when there is a choice between spinning and wearing khaddar, naturally the latter has the undisputed preference.
('33', 143, 4, 24, 339475) Spinning is required from those who want to add to their slender resources and that, too, during spare hours and without payments from those who have time to spare for giving even a few moments’ labour in that particular form to the nation.
('33', 143, 4, 25, 339716) In the case in point the will to spin being there, the time will certainly be found in due course.
('33', 143, 4, 26, 339815) Probably, the correspondent has to go by tram or train to
('33', 144, 0, 1, 339873) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 145
('33', 144, 1, 2, 339924) his office.
('33', 144, 1, 3, 339936) Let him take the takli with him and give the odd moments to it.
('33', 144, 1, 4, 340000) There are many within my knowledge who are thus utilizing their odd moments.
('33', 144, 1, 5, 340077) I therefore hope that the correspondent will never, for any temptation, give up his khaddar wear.
('33', 144, 1, 6, 340175) I had hoped that the prejudice against khaddar had died down in the foreign mercantile firms.
('33', 144, 1, 7, 340269) The European merchants in Calcutta to whom I had the privilege of talking showed no prejudice against khaddar wear.
('33', 144, 1, 8, 340385) I wish that influential European merchants who may see this paragraph will exert their influence to remove the prejudice reported by my correspondent.
('33', 144, 1, 9, 340536) And it is high time for Indian firms to remodel their businesses so as to curtail the inordinately long hours for which their employees are detained.
('33', 144, 1, 10, 340686) The world’s experience shows that long hours do not mean more but actually less work.
('33', 144, 1, 11, 340772) It simply requires a little courage and a little initiative to make the much needed reform voluntarily and generously—a reform that is otherwise bound to come in any case.
('33', 144, 1, 12, 340944) But, then, when it comes under pressure it will have lost all its grace.
('33', 144, 1, 13, 341017) Shorter hours for employees is a world movement which nobody can stop.
('33', 144, 1, 14, 341088) Will not the Indian Chamber of Commerce or some such mercantile association lead the way?
('33', 144, 2, 15, 341178) Young India, 22 10 1925

('33', 145, 1, 2, 341654) 83. LETTER TO RANCHHODDAS PATWARI
('33', 145, 2, 3, 341688) Kartika Sud 5 [October 22,1925] 1

('33', 146, 2, 4, 343860) 85. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, BHUJ 1
('33', 146, 3, 5, 343897) October 22, 1925 I had expected from your welcome address that you would not be drawing a line between the Antyajas and others in this meeting, but when I saw that you had done so, I felt that my place was with the former.
('33', 146, 3, 6, 344120) For, wherever I have gone I have described myself as a Bhangi.
('33', 146, 3, 7, 344183) I do not make that claim out of vanity nor is it an instance of my ignorance or of Western influence on me.
('33', 146, 3, 8, 344291) I make the claim wholly in a spirit of service, and that too after a life long study of Hinduism and effort to live it by carefully following the example of my pious parents, and not, I repeat, under the influence of Western ideas I have endeavourd to understand the relationship beteween the body and the Dweller within.
('33', 146, 3, 9, 344613) I have studied the Shastras with as much care as is possible for a layman, and have also tried to put their teachings into practice.
('33', 146, 3, 10, 344746) From my study of them and my experience of living in accordance with their teachings, I have come to the firm conclusion that if Hinduism clings to the practice of untouchability, it will perish, Hindus will perish and India will perish.
('33', 146, 3, 11, 344984) As I discuss the subject with innumerable shastris and pundits in the course of my tours in the various parts of the counry, I become daily more confirmed in my view.
('33', 146, 3, 12, 345151) I frankly tell you , therefore, that if, holding the views that I do, I am an untouchable in your eyes, with whom it is proper that all contact should be avoided, you should be firm and keep away from me, and ask me to end my visit in a day.
('33', 146, 3, 13, 345393) Far from causing me pain, you will make me happy by acting in this way.
('33', 146, 3, 14, 345465) I will think that Kutch has self respect, that it has courage and its people are not afraid of expressing their difference from even a reputedly big man.
('33', 146, 3, 15, 345619) If, therefore, you ask me to leave, you will be doing good not only to yourself but also to the Antyajas and to me.

('33', 148, 2, 10, 349794) If either Shastras or history taught us that a kingdom could be ruled only by a person like Rama, I would have been an implacable enemy of monarchy.

('33', 148, 2, 13, 350184) I would offer my worship to the government of a king—I long for such a government—under whose rule no one would ever die of hunger, a girl might safely move about where she willed and no wicked person would dare to cast evil glances at her, a king who looked upon his subjects as his children and all women, other than his wife, as his mothers or daughters, who never drank and had no addictions, who would see to the safety of his subjects as they slept before himself retiring for the day and ensured that they had enough to eat before he ate himself.

('33', 152, 4, 14, 359432) 88. HOW TO WORSHIP GOD
('33', 152, 5, 15, 359455) A Parsi gentleman has written to me from Persia.
('33', 152, 5, 16, 359504) He has addressed to me some profound questions 1 which I quote below in his own words.
('33', 152, 5, 17, 359591) At two or three places where he has used English words I have given their Gujarati equivalents instead.
('33', 152, 5, 18, 359695) If even a single leaf does not stir without the will of God, what is there left for man to do?
('33', 152, 5, 19, 359790) This is a question dating back to times immemorial and it will always continue to be asked in the future; however, the answer is included in the question itself as it is God Himself who has given us the capacity to ask it.
('33', 152, 5, 20, 360013) All our actions are governed by laws, and the same is true of god.
('33', 152, 5, 21, 360080) As our laws and our knowledge are imperfect, we can violate these laws in a civil or uncivil manner.
('33', 152, 5, 22, 360181) Being all knowing and omnipotent God never violates His own laws.
('33', 152, 5, 23, 360247) These admit of no improvements or additions.
('33', 152, 5, 24, 360292) They are immutable.
('33', 152, 5, 25, 360312) Our freedom lies in the capacity bestowed on us to think, distinguish and choose between good and evil in various ways.
('33', 152, 5, 26, 360432) This freedom is strictly limited.
('33', 152, 5, 27, 360466) It is so limited that a learned person has said that it is even less than that enjoyed by a sailor on board a ship, to walk on the deck.
('33', 152, 5, 28, 360603) However little it may be, there is this freedom and even though it is not much, it is sufficient, at any rate, to enable a
('33', 152, 6, 29, 360726) 1 Not translated here
('33', 153, 0, 1, 360748) 154 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 153, 1, 2, 360790) human being to attain mukti 1 through it.
('33', 153, 1, 3, 360832) Destiny and man’s effort to attain the aims of life go hand in hand.
('33', 153, 1, 4, 360901) However.
('33', 153, 1, 5, 360910) destiny does not thwart the prupose of anyone who treads the road of mukti.
('33', 153, 1, 6, 360986) Hence, all that now remains to consider is how to serve or worship God.
('33', 153, 1, 7, 361058) He can be served in one way alone.
('33', 153, 1, 8, 361093) To serve the poor is to serve God.
('33', 153, 1, 9, 361128) By serving even an ant, one serves Him .
('33', 153, 1, 10, 361169) It is He who gives the tiny particle [of food] to the ant and the six maunds to the elephant.
('33', 153, 1, 11, 361263) Anyone who refrains from trampling an ant also serves it; one who does not intentionally harm it will not harm other animals or his fellowmen.
('33', 153, 1, 12, 361406) At each place and at each point of time service assumes a different form, although the sentiment involved in it is the same.
('33', 153, 1, 13, 361531) In serving those who suffer, one serves God.
('33', 153, 1, 14, 361576) Discretion should be exercised in this service.
('33', 153, 1, 15, 361624) There is no reason to believe that one is doing nothing but service by giving grains to the hungry.
('33', 153, 1, 16, 361724) It is a sin to provide food for an idle person who makes no effort and depends on others for food.
('33', 153, 1, 17, 361823) It is a meritorious act to provide him with an occupation and, if he refuses to work, to let him starve is to render service to him.
('33', 153, 1, 18, 361956) God’s name should be chanted and it is necessary to worship Him with rituals as this leads to self purification, which in its turn enables man to find his own way.
('33', 153, 1, 19, 362120) However, ceremonial worship by itself does not constitute the service of God.
('33', 153, 1, 20, 362198) It is a means of doing that service.
('33', 153, 1, 21, 362235) It is for this reason that Narasinh Mehta has sung:”Nothing is achieved by bathing and worshipping, or counting one’s beads and chanting His name.” And from this reply we get the answer to the third question which is as follows.
('33', 153, 1, 22, 362464) What is the aim of life?
('33', 153, 1, 23, 362489) It is to know the Self.
('33', 153, 1, 24, 362513) In the words of Narasinh Mehta,”So long as the essence of the Self is not realized, all our efforts are in vain.” This realization of the Self, or Self knowledge, is not possible until one has achieved unity with all living beings—has become one with God.
('33', 153, 1, 25, 362769) To accomplish such a unity implies deliberate sharing of the suffering of others and the eradication of such suffering.

('33', 154, 4, 11, 363790) THE MEANING OF KHADI
('33', 154, 5, 12, 363811) Just as some people wear coarse material thinking it is khadi although it has been spun and woven in a textile mill, others persist in the belief that khadi necessarily means thick and coarse cloth made of hand spun yarn.
('33', 154, 5, 13, 364033) This latter belief is not borne out by facts.
('33', 154, 5, 14, 364079) Hand woven cloth made of hand spun yarn is of course khadi, however fine it may be.
('33', 154, 5, 15, 364163) It may be made of cotton, silk or even of wool.
('33', 154, 5, 16, 364211) One should wear whichever of these one happens to find convenient.
('33', 154, 5, 17, 364278) The khadi from Andhra is very fine.
('33', 154, 5, 18, 364314) In Assam, one can get some khadi made of silk.
('33', 154, 5, 19, 364361) Woollen khadi is made in Kathiawar.
('33', 154, 5, 20, 364397) In other words, the only criterion of khadi is its being hand spun and hand woven.
('33', 154, 5, 21, 364480) Ordinarily, hand spun khadi is found to be coarse and thick, hence, some people erroneously believe that khadi can only be of this type, though in fact fine khadi of sixty to eighty count yarn is also made.
('33', 154, 5, 22, 364687) Nevertheless, those who have used thick khadi know that the touch of coarse rough khadi is soft to the body and, being rough, it affords better protection to the skin.
