('33', 158, 1, 2, 369871) 94. NOTES
('33', 158, 2, 3, 369881) WOOL OR COTTON
('33', 158, 3, 4, 369896) A friend enquires whether the hill tribes who never use cotton, who have plenty of wool and who always wear woollen clothing can become members of the Congress by spinning and sending woollen yarn instead of cotton yarn.
('33', 158, 3, 5, 370117) The hillsmen can certainly send wool yarn and become Congress members.
('33', 158, 3, 6, 370188) The emphasis is not on cotton, but on hand spinning.
('33', 158, 3, 7, 370241) And I do hope that Congressmen who are working in the hills will enrol as many wool spinners as they can for both the Congress and the All India Spinners’ Association.
('33', 158, 4, 8, 370409) A SPINNER’S DIFFICULTY
('33', 158, 5, 9, 370432) A correspondent writes:”The postage required for sending yarn subscription to the A.I.S.A. is greater than the value of yarn to be sent.
('33', 158, 5, 10, 370569) Is there no way of saving this cost?
('33', 158, 5, 11, 370606) Must all packets be registered?
('33', 158, 5, 12, 370638) Or if not, may they be sent ‘not paid’?” This objection was considered when in terms of the Ahmedabad resolution yarn had to be sent to the All India Khadi Board.
('33', 158, 5, 13, 370801) It is impossible to save the postage in its entirety at the present moment or at any moment altogether.
('33', 158, 5, 14, 370905) But much may be saved even now.
('33', 158, 5, 15, 370937) Registration of packets containing yarn is totally unnecessary.
('33', 158, 5, 16, 371001) It would not, however, do to send ‘not paid’ packets.
('33', 158, 5, 17, 371055) The postage must be borne by the senders; but there is no reason why everyone should send his or her yarn separately.
('33', 158, 5, 18, 371173) In every village or street wherever members may be living within easy reach of one another, one party should collect all the yarn at one place and send the whole of it in one parcel.
('33', 158, 5, 19, 371356) This can be easily arranged by someone taking the initiative and making himself responsible.
('33', 158, 5, 20, 371449) Then, again, it is not obligatory to send the yearly subscription in twelve instalments.
('33', 158, 5, 21, 371538) Those who have got ample leisure may spin their twelve thousand in one month and send the whole in one parcel or, it may be sent in as many instalments as is convenient.
('33', 158, 5, 22, 371708) The quesion then arises what will become of the idea of spinning regularly every day.
('33', 158, 5, 23, 371794) Regular spinning should be done although the subscription may be paid and yarn thus spun may be utilized for one’s own personal use.
('33', 158, 5, 24, 371927) The obligation of regular spinning is distinct from the obligation of sending twelve thousand yards of self spun yarn.
('33', 158, 5, 25, 372046) And it is necessary in the interest of national economy to spin
('33', 159, 0, 1, 372110) 160 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 159, 1, 2, 372152) twelve thousand yards in the quickest possible time so as to save postage.
('33', 159, 1, 3, 372227) I hope after some time arrangements will be made for establishing receiving depots in suitable centres so as to avoid postage.
('33', 159, 2, 4, 372354) ONE THOUSAND RUPEES PRIZE
('33', 159, 3, 5, 372380) A text book on cow protection has been found to be a necessity.
('33', 159, 3, 6, 372444) An American friend who is interesting himself in the question of cow protection wanted me to supply him with a book upon it.
('33', 159, 3, 7, 372569) I failed to find for him a volume that would give him all the information that he needed.
('33', 159, 3, 8, 372659) I therefore approached Sjt.
('33', 159, 3, 9, 372687) Revashanker Jagjivan and asked him whether he would issue a prize for a cow protection essay.
('33', 159, 3, 10, 372781) He has kindly consented to pay one thousand rupees for the best essay on the subject.
('33', 159, 3, 11, 372867) The terms are that the essay should be delivered at Satyagraha Ashram, Sabarmati, to the Secretary, All India Cow Protection Association, on or before March 31, 1926. It may be in English, Sanskrit or Hindi.
('33', 159, 3, 12, 373075) It should deal with the origin, meaning and implications of cow protection quoting texts in support.
('33', 159, 3, 13, 373176) It should contain an examination of the Shastras and find whether there is any prohibition in the Shastras for conducting dairies and tanneries by Associations interested in cow protection.
('33', 159, 3, 14, 373366) It should trace the history of cow protection in India and methods adopted to achieve it from time to time.
('33', 159, 3, 15, 373474) It should contain statistics giving the number of cattle in India and examine the question of pasture land and the effect of the Government policy about pasture land in India and suggest remedy to be adopted for securing cow protection.
('33', 159, 3, 16, 373711) I am inviting Acharya Anandshanker Dhruva and Sjt.
('33', 159, 3, 17, 373762) C. V. Vaidya to allow themselves to be appointed judges of the essays to be received.
('33', 159, 3, 18, 373848) The terms of competition are subject to change within a fortnight from the date of publication so as to allow me to receive the opinions of friends interested in cow protection from the standpoint of the All India Cow Protection Association.
('33', 159, 3, 19, 374090) And if no change is announced within that fortnight, the foregoing terms may be regarded as final.

('33', 160, 4, 15, 376539) SPURIOUS KHADI
('33', 160, 5, 16, 376554) A friend sends me a pictorial card taken from spurious khadi woven in some of the Indian mills.
('33', 160, 5, 17, 376650) It has printed upon it a charkha with a basket full of slivers and a few bobbins with yarn wound upon them lying in front.
('33', 160, 5, 18, 376773) My correspondent tells me that such imitation khaddar is manufactured in almost all the Indian mills and such stuff is sent here by Japan also.
('33', 160, 5, 19, 376917) He adds that poor people, who know that they should wear khaddar when they see a charkha stamp upon it and
('33', 161, 0, 1, 377024) 162 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 161, 1, 2, 377066) upon applying at the shops have stuff looking like khaddar given to them, unquestioningly buy it and flatter themselves with the belief that they have done something towards the alleviation of the economic distress of India.
('33', 161, 1, 3, 377291) It is a thousand pities that mill owners should lack all patriotic fervour and, in order to swell dividends, or, maybe, now, to be able to keep the mills going, pay no regard to the national will.
('33', 161, 1, 4, 377488) And yet people are not wanting who expect with the assistance of Indian mills to achieve the boycott of foreign cloth.
('33', 161, 1, 5, 377607) The tremendous mistake underlying such belief consists in supposing that the mill industry can ever be utilized for the national purpose before khaddar has attained a proper commercial footing.
('33', 161, 1, 6, 377801) I doubt not that one day all the mills will fall in line with the great national purpose; but that time will not come before khaddar can hold its own against the whole world, in other words, before the national taste has undergone such a revolution that the general body of people would refuse to wear anything but khaddar and they will have been so far educated as to be able without difficulty to distinguish between real khaddar and the base imitation.

('33', 161, 4, 9, 378456) Young India, 29 10 1925
('33', 161, 5, 10, 378480) 95. INTERROGATORIES
('33', 161, 6, 11, 378500) Whilst I was at Lucknow the sub editor of the Indian Daily Telegraph handed me some interrogatories for my answer.
('33', 161, 6, 12, 378615) They are rather interesting.
('33', 161, 6, 13, 378644) I therefore reproduce the most important of them with my answers.
('33', 161, 7, 14, 378710) 1. Do you propose to launch mass civil disobedience within one year, or within any specified time?
('33', 161, 7, 15, 378809) I entertain no present hope of being able to launch mass civil disobedience within any measurable distance of time.
('33', 161, 8, 16, 378925) 2. Do you believe in the dictum ‘the end justifies the means’?
('33', 161, 8, 17, 378988) I have never believed in the dictum.
('33', 161, 9, 18, 379025) 3. A year ago it was reported that you intended to launch civil disobedience, and once launched you would go on with it, even if sporadic violence occurred.
('33', 161, 9, 19, 379182) Absolute non violence being impossible on the part of the
('33', 162, 0, 1, 379240) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 163
('33', 162, 1, 2, 379291) masses, will you now take the risk of a modicum of violence (minimum, so far as it lies in your power) and launch civil disobedience?
('33', 162, 1, 3, 379425) What I said a year ago and what I wish to repeat now is that whatever step I may take now will be, I hope, not conditional, but absolute and irrevocable.
('33', 162, 1, 4, 379579) Whenever I have suspended civil dis obedience I have done so not by reason of any outbreak of violence, but upon the discovery of such violence as had been initiated or encouraged by Congressmen who should have known better.
('33', 162, 1, 5, 379804) Any outbreak of violence would not have brought about suspension, as, for instance, the Moplah outbreak.
('33', 162, 1, 6, 379909) But Chauri Chaura did for the simple reason that persons connected with the Congress were involved in it.
('33', 162, 2, 7, 380015) 4. In the Calcutta riot case, you laid the blame at the door of the Hindus.
('33', 162, 2, 8, 380091) The Marwari Association or some Hindu organization challenged your verdict and produced evidence to prove the guilt of the Muslims in giving sufficient cause for provocation to the Hindus.
('33', 162, 2, 9, 380280) You promised to publicly modify your verdict if you found your previous opinion mistaken.
('33', 162, 2, 10, 380370) Will you now publicly modify your previous verdict?
('33', 162, 2, 11, 380422) I have seen nothing to modify my previous verdict.
('33', 162, 3, 12, 380473) 5. You have consented to accept address from the Municipal Board (which is now in the hands of the Swarajist Party), but you have avoided address from the Hindu Sabha.
('33', 162, 3, 13, 380641) Why do you make this invidious distinction against a body which represents the Hindu community, to which you belong?
('33', 162, 3, 14, 380758) I have never avoided address from the Lucknow Hindu Sabha.
('33', 162, 3, 15, 380817) On the contrary, I told them that I would gladly accept their address when I paid a visit to Lucknow.
('33', 162, 3, 16, 380919) The Swarajist Municipality approa ched me later and pressed me to accept its address even whilst I was passing through Lucknow.
('33', 162, 3, 17, 381047) The Hindu Sabha might have done likewise.
('33', 162, 3, 18, 381089) There was no question of avoidance.
('33', 162, 3, 19, 381125) I simply thought that the Sabha would not want to present me with an address whilst I was merely passing through Lucknow specially as the Sabha had desired to discuss with me the Hindu Muslim tension in Lucknow.
('33', 162, 3, 20, 381337) It will be remembered that I gladly accepted the Hindu Sabha address in Sitapur.
('33', 162, 3, 21, 381418) 6. The Aminabad Park arati namaz question is hanging fire for more
('33', 162, 4, 22, 381485) than a year.
('33', 162, 4, 23, 381498) Will you kindly give your decision, if both parties promise to abide by it?
('33', 162, 4, 24, 381574) I have dealt with this matter in my U.P. Notes.
('33', 162, 5, 25, 381622) 7. As a Hindu what is your candid opinion about the question?
('33', 162, 5, 26, 381684) I have no opinion, as I do not know the facts.
('33', 162, 5, 27, 381731) If I had made up
('33', 163, 0, 1, 381748) 164 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 163, 1, 2, 381790) my mind beforehand, I could not consent to arbitrate even if both the parties were willing to abide by my award.
('33', 163, 2, 3, 381903) 8. Hindus never object to Muslim music during Moharrum, or at any
('33', 163, 3, 4, 381969) Why should Muslims object to Hindu music?
('33', 163, 3, 5, 382011) Are the Hindus not entitled
('33', 163, 4, 6, 382039) to safeguard their religious rights by every means?
('33', 163, 4, 7, 382091) This question deals with two questions of fact about which I know nothing.
('33', 163, 4, 8, 382166) As to the third part of the question, Hindus are entitled to defend their religious rights not by every means but by every truthful and, in my opinion, non violent means.
('33', 163, 5, 9, 382337) 9. At Patna two kidnapped Hindu girls were produced before you.
('33', 163, 6, 10, 382401) Hindu, what steps do you advise the Hindus to take against the growing evil of
('33', 163, 7, 11, 382480) kidnapping throughout India?
('33', 163, 7, 12, 382509) I dealt with this delicate question last week.
('33', 163, 8, 13, 382556) 10. Are not the Hindus justified in organizing themselves, not for any
('33', 163, 9, 14, 382627) aggressive action against Muslims or others, but for safeguarding their re 
('33', 163, 10, 15, 382703) ligious rights and stamping out such evils as kidnapping, etc., as also for the
('33', 163, 11, 16, 382783) physical, social, moral and material advancement of the Hindu community?
('33', 163, 11, 17, 382856) I do not suppose anybody can possibly object to the organization such as the question mentions.
('33', 163, 11, 18, 382952) I certainly do not object.
('33', 163, 12, 19, 382979) 11. Maulana Shaukat Ali sent a message through you to the Bihar Khilafat Conference.
('33', 163, 12, 20, 383064) If Lala Lajpat Rai or Pandit Malaviya send a message through you to a Hindu Conference, will you have any objection to it?
('33', 163, 12, 21, 383187) Maulana Shaukat Ali never sent through me any message to the Bihar Khilafat Conference; but if he had, I would certainly have carried any message from him, provided it was unobjectionable.
('33', 163, 12, 22, 383376) And I should certainly carry out a similar commission entrusted to me by Pandit Malaviyaji or Lala Lajpat Rai.

('33', 163, 14, 24, 383511) 96. U.P. NOTES
('33', 163, 15, 25, 383526) A RICKETY PLATFORM
('33', 163, 16, 26, 383545) At Hajipur my Bihar tour ended.
('33', 163, 16, 27, 383577) It was all orderliness and noiselessness at Hajipur.
('33', 163, 16, 28, 383630) Though I was lodged in the national school huts in front of which the huge public meeting took place, the
('33', 163, 17, 29, 383736) 1Vide”That Eternal Question”, 22 10 1925.
('33', 164, 0, 1, 383778) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 165
('33', 164, 1, 2, 383829) volunteers were disciplined and the crowds were previously informed through notice and otherwise that I was ill able to bear the strain of noise, rush and the touching of feet.
('33', 164, 1, 3, 384006) In spite, therefore, of there being hundreds of men crowding round the school premises, I had perfect quiet.
('33', 164, 1, 4, 384115) Of all the national schools in Bihar, this is perhaps the best managed and the best manned, Janakdhari Babu, a non co operating vakil with a character of great beauty, being the principal.
('33', 164, 1, 5, 384304) There was a purse, too, of nearly Rs. 5,000 at Hajipur.
('33', 164, 1, 6, 384360) With this pleasant ending and the ceremony at Sonepur of opening a Sevashram, chiefly for the purpose of attending to the comfort and requirements of thousands of visitors who annually flock to Sonepur in connection with a unique fair that takes place there every full moon day of the first month of the Hindu year and which draws the finest horses, elephants and cattle to the Sonepur fair, the Bihar tour ended and I entered U.P., Ballia being the first place.
('33', 164, 1, 7, 384823) The travel to Ballia, although requiring only four hours, was most trying .
('33', 164, 1, 8, 384899) The meeting there was a terrible ordeal and a contrast to all I had seen and experienced in Bihar.
('33', 164, 1, 9, 384998) It was a slow train that carried me to Ballia from Chhapra.
('33', 164, 1, 10, 385058) There were stations every few minutes.
('33', 164, 1, 11, 385097) Vast crowds gathered at every station and made a most noisy demonstration which the volunteers were unable to control.
('33', 164, 1, 12, 385216) I know that it was all blind and excessive affection.
('33', 164, 1, 13, 385270) I was to have gone to Ballia in 1921. I was unable to do so then.
('33', 164, 1, 14, 385336) The people, therefore, were almost incredulous, but when I actually did go there, they became delirious with joy.
('33', 164, 1, 15, 385450) The volunteers could keep no control.
('33', 164, 1, 16, 385488) As soon, however, as I could get them to listen to me, and understand my appeal for the Deshbandhu Memorial Fund, they paid freely.
('33', 164, 1, 17, 385620) At Ballia itself, the crowd at the station was most unmanageable.
('33', 164, 1, 18, 385686) Mr. Perill of the American Mission had kindly brought his car to the platform which I could reach with the greatest difficulty but which alone made it possible to pass unhurt through the pressing crowd.
('33', 164, 1, 19, 385889) From the station, we went directly to the public meeting.
('33', 164, 1, 20, 385947) There was a huge and lofty platform which, I saw at a glance, had been erected by an amateur and was wholly unsafe for the number of persons which the floor space could accommodate and for which it was intended.
('33', 164, 1, 21, 386159) There were nearly seven addresses.
('33', 164, 1, 22, 386194) All the members connected with these should naturally have been on the platform.
('33', 164, 1, 23, 386275) The stairs leading to the platform were shaky, slippery and unsafe.
('33', 164, 1, 24, 386343) The platform swung to and fro when anybody walked on it.
('33', 164, 1, 25, 386400) It could hardly bear the weight of ten people and it was dangerous even for one person at a time to walk on
('33', 165, 0, 1, 386508) 166 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 165, 1, 2, 386550) some parts of it.
('33', 165, 1, 3, 386568) The chairman at once recognized that, if a tragedy was to be avoided, all but myself should remove themselves from the platform.
('33', 165, 1, 4, 386697) So they gently hurried down, leaving Rajendra Babu in charge of me.
('33', 165, 1, 5, 386765) Those who were to read the addresses came one at a time and in spite of these precautions, it was not at all certain that the whole structure might not come down at any moment.
('33', 165, 1, 6, 386942) This was by no means my first experience of a dangerously weak platform.
('33', 165, 1, 7, 387015) I recall at least two accidents.
('33', 165, 1, 8, 387048) This was the weakest I had seen.
('33', 165, 1, 9, 387081) The very appearance was enough for an ordinary, trained eye to detect the weakness, but those in charge had no experience and evidently the man who was entrusted with the erection had none.
('33', 165, 1, 10, 387271) Let this Ballia instance be a warning to Congress workers all over that they should not attempt ambitious platforms or, when they do, they should leave the erection to trained men who know what they are doing.
('33', 165, 1, 11, 387481) The meeting too was almost uncontrollable by the volunteers.
('33', 165, 1, 12, 387542) The noise continued whilst the addresses were being read, but, in spite of it all, they observed perfect silence when I appealed to them to give me a hearing.
('33', 165, 1, 13, 387701) I deduced from this fact the conclusion that a little previous preparation as in Bihar would have produced the same results and I would have done much more substantial work at Ballia than I was able to do.
('33', 165, 1, 14, 387907) What is wanted is quiet and sustained work.
('33', 165, 1, 15, 387951) Ballia possesses some very good workers, and it is possible to make it a greater centre of activity.
('33', 165, 1, 16, 388052) I know that the people of Ballia are patient and long suffering.
('33', 165, 1, 17, 388117) Theirs was no mean sacrifice in 1921 22.
('33', 165, 2, 18, 388158) KASHI VIDYAPITH
('33', 165, 3, 19, 388174) From Ballia we went to Banaras where we had to change for Lucknow on our way to Sitapur.
('33', 165, 3, 20, 388263) There was a halt of five hours in Banaras.
('33', 165, 3, 21, 388306) Babu Bhagwan Das took the opportunity of arranging a meeting of students of the Kashi Vidyapith.
('33', 165, 3, 22, 388403) He took me also to see the good work in spinning and weaving done by the middle schools conducted by the Municipality.
('33', 165, 3, 23, 388522) Their work, it will be remembered, was started by Prof.
('33', 165, 3, 24, 388578) Ramdas Gour, and it has been since continued.
('33', 165, 3, 25, 388624) Both takli and the spinning wheel are at work in the school.
('33', 165, 3, 26, 388685) The experiment may fairly be claimed to be a success.
('33', 165, 3, 27, 388739) At the Vidyapith I was shown the workshop.
('33', 165, 3, 28, 388782) Its growing feature is its carpentry department.
('33', 165, 3, 29, 388831) The spinning wheel cannot be claimed to have prospered in the Vidyapith.
('33', 165, 3, 30, 388904) I had occasion in my speech 1 to say to the students
('33', 165, 4, 31, 388957) 1Vide”Speech at Kashi Vidyapith, Banaras”, 17 10 1925.
('33', 166, 0, 1, 389012) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 167
('33', 166, 1, 2, 389063) and the professors that, if they had no faith in the spinning wheel, they should remove it from their curriculum entirely.
('33', 166, 1, 3, 389186) It was no use giving it a place because it was the fashion to consider it part of national activity.
('33', 166, 1, 4, 389287) Time had arrived when every national institution worth the name had to evolve its educational policy and to prosecute it even in spite of opposition and indifference.
('33', 166, 2, 5, 389454) AT LUCKNOW
('33', 166, 3, 6, 389465) From Banaras we went to Lucknow, where there was a halt of over there hours.
('33', 166, 3, 7, 389542) There the Lucknow Municipality did me the honour of presenting me with an address which was written in choice high flown Urdu.
('33', 166, 3, 8, 389669) Special care was taken to make the language as difficult as possible for a simple man like me, not belonging to U.P., to understand.
('33', 166, 3, 9, 389802) Most difficult Persian and Arabic words were used and it seemed as if every word of Sanskrit origin or word spoken by the crowd was deliberately excluded.
('33', 166, 3, 10, 389957) Naturally, therefore, I was supplied with an English translation.
('33', 166, 3, 11, 390023) I, therefore, told the Municipality that it was not possible for me to congratulate it on its high flown Urdu.
('33', 166, 3, 12, 390134) I believe in a national language for interprovincial commerce but that language could neither be Lucknavi Urdu nor Sanskritized Hindi.
('33', 166, 3, 13, 390269) It must be Hindustani, a combination of words generally spoken by the Urdu knowing and the Hindi knowing public, a language easily understood by Hindus and Mussalmans alike.
('33', 166, 3, 14, 390443) The Municipality of Lucknow is essentially a Swarajist municipality.
('33', 166, 3, 15, 390512) It has a record of work in no way inferior to that of its predecessors.
('33', 166, 3, 16, 390584) But I told my audience that it would be improper to be satisfied with merely coming to the standard of its predecessors.
('33', 166, 3, 17, 390705) Congressmen wherever they capture an institution should be able to show a better record, and it was therefore a matter for thought that the Lucknow roads were so bad as they were.
('33', 166, 3, 18, 390885) If want of funds was the cause, the excuse was inadmissible as Congressmen were expected to take up the spade and the shovel and repair the roads by their voluntary labour.
('33', 166, 3, 19, 391058) I congratulated the Municipality on its experiments in dairying, but I warned them against being satisfied until they could supply cheap and pure milk to the population within their jurisdiction.
('33', 166, 3, 20, 391254) The address of the Municipality was discreetly silent about the Hindu Muslim question.
('33', 166, 3, 21, 391341) Speaking, however, amongst friends (most of the councillors, whether Hindus or Mussalmans, were friends whom I knew) I could not ignore the question and therefore spoke upon the growing tension between the two parties.
('33', 166, 3, 22, 391560) I suggested that whatever
('33', 167, 0, 1, 391586) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 167, 1, 2, 391628) happened in other parts of India, Lucknow at least should be able to compose the differences and to achieve a unity unbreakable under any strain and irrespective of what happened in other parts of India.
('33', 167, 1, 3, 391832) I had time, too, to pay a flying visit to its Women’s College.
('33', 167, 1, 4, 391895) This is a college conducted by the American Mission, said to be the oldest institution of its kind in all Asia.
('33', 167, 1, 5, 392007) I saw there girls drawn from almost every part of India.
('33', 167, 1, 6, 392064) They flocked round me to get my autograph in their autograph books.
('33', 167, 1, 7, 392132) I have scared away many autograph mongers by mentioning the condition under which I generally give my autograph, and that is that the applicants should promise to wear khaddar and spin regularly.
('33', 167, 1, 8, 392328) I mentioned the conditions to the girls.
('33', 167, 1, 9, 392369) Nothing daunted, they readily made the promise which the lady superintendent has assured me she would see was religiously kept.
('33', 167, 2, 10, 392497) IN SITAPUR
('33', 167, 3, 11, 392508) From Lucknow we motored to Sitapur, reaching there about 10 p.m.
('33', 167, 3, 12, 392573) Before reaching my quarters I had to attend a meeting of the Hindu Sabha to receive its address.
('33', 167, 3, 13, 392670) In reply to the address, I said that I hardly deserved it because I had done nothing for the Sabha as such; on the contrary, I had even criticized, though in a perfectly friendly spirit, some of its activities; but I accepted the address as I yielded to no one in my devotion to Hinduism.
('33', 167, 3, 14, 392959) I said further that all religious activity was of true service only in so far as it adhered to truth and non violence in their fulness.
('33', 167, 3, 15, 393095) From the Hindu Sabha meeting, I was taken to a public meeting where there was to be an address of the Municipality.
('33', 167, 3, 16, 393211) The next day I visited, in company with the Ali Brothers the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan Conference.
('33', 167, 3, 17, 393307) The Presidential address, admirable in many respects, had scrupulously avoided the use of words of Persian or Arabic origin.
('33', 167, 3, 18, 393432) In my speech, therefore, I was obliged to reiterate the views I expressed in the reply to the Lucknow Municipality address.
('33', 167, 3, 19, 393556) Highly artifcial and Sanskritized Hindi is as avoidable as highly Persianized Urdu.
('33', 167, 3, 20, 393640) Both the speeches are unintelligible to the masses.
('33', 167, 3, 21, 393692) I have accepted Hindustani as a common medium because it is understood by over 20 crores of the people of Inida.
('33', 167, 3, 22, 393805) This is not the artificial Lucknavi Urdu or the Sammelani Hindi.
('33', 167, 3, 23, 393870) And one would expect at least a Sammelan address to be such as would be understood by both Hindus and Mussalmans of the common type.
('33', 167, 3, 24, 394003) The animal who, if he pronounces the name Ishwar dreads to pronounce the name Khuda, or the one who would prnounce the name Khuda at every turn, but would regard it as sinful to utter the name Ishwar, is not an attractive being.
('33', 167, 3, 25, 394232) I reminded the audience, too, that Hindi propaganda in U.P. could only consist in
('33', 168, 0, 1, 394314) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 169
('33', 168, 1, 2, 394365) improving the literature and creating an atmosphere for the advent of a Hindi Rabindranath and that the Sammelan should devote its attention outside U.P. to popularizing Hindustani speech and by publishing standard works of other languages in Devnagari character.
('33', 168, 1, 3, 394629) Maulana Mahomed Ali emphasized my first point by remarking that if Hindustani speech required an artificial stimulus in the home of its birth the atempt to make it the common medium had better be given up.
('33', 168, 1, 4, 394835) In the afternoon, there was the conference presided over by Maulana Shaukat Ali.
('33', 168, 1, 5, 394916) His address, which was a thesis on Hindu Muslim unity, wound up with an exhortation on charkha and khaddar.
('33', 168, 1, 6, 395024) I was called upon to follow him and, therefore, took up the theme the Maulana had just introduced.
('33', 168, 1, 7, 395123) I showed the necessity of the charkha and khaddar and ended with my reasons for helping the Patna decision which, I contended, was not a forced growth, but an exact indication of Congress public opinion.
('33', 168, 1, 8, 395327) Pandit Motilalji, who followed me, took up the Patna resolution and explained it in detail and, whilst reiterating his own belief in the charkha and khaddar, said that the Congress could not be thoroughly representative of the people unless it became predominantly political.
('33', 168, 1, 9, 395603) After passing Panditiji’s resolution confirming the Patna decision and approving the formation of the Spinners’ Association, the delegates went to the Gujarati pandal to partake of light refreshments that were provided by the Gujarati merchants who were domiciled in Sitapur.
('33', 168, 1, 10, 395879) My tour in U.P., if it may be so called, was wound up with a long and hearty discussion with a Hindu Sabha deputation that had come from Lucknow specially to confer with me on the Hindu Muslim tension in Lucknow.
('33', 168, 1, 11, 396092) I told them that I had not gone back on my undertaking to arbitrate upon their disputes.
('33', 168, 1, 12, 396181) I told them that I had offered to hear the evidence last year in Delhi, but I told them that now under the changed conditions, neither party might care to submit the matters in dispute to me.
('33', 168, 1, 13, 396373) But that, if they did, I would gladly make time even to go to Lucknow and arbitrate.
('33', 168, 1, 14, 396458) On the deputation telling me that the Hindus would like me to arbitrate, I advised them to approach the Mussalmans and let me know if the responsible men of both the parties were prepared to abide by my award.
('33', 168, 1, 15, 396668) Thus ended my tour in Bihar and U.P. At the time of writing these notes I find myself in Cutch where I have Mahadev Desai with me to take up the burden of writing down the notes of the interesting experiences of this weird, secluded land.

('33', 169, 1, 2, 396973) 97. MUNICIPAL LIFE
('33', 169, 2, 3, 396992) The fashion, that seems now to have become permanent, of presenting prominent Congressmen with addresses by municipalities and local boards has resulted in my coming in touch with the working of municipalites almost all over India.
('33', 169, 2, 4, 397224) I have come to the conclusion from my observation of so many municipalities that the greatest problem they have to tackle is sanitation.
('33', 169, 2, 5, 397361) I am aware that it is a stupendous problem.
('33', 169, 2, 6, 397405) Some of the national habits are bad beyond description, and yet so ingrained as to defy all human effort.
('33', 169, 2, 7, 397511) Wherever I go this insanitation obtrudes itself upon my gaze in some shape or another.
('33', 169, 2, 8, 397598) In the Punjab and Sind, in total disregard of the elementary laws of health we dirty our terraces and roofs breeding billions of disease producing microbes and founding colonies of flies.
('33', 169, 2, 9, 397786) Down south, we do not hesitate to dirty our streets, and early in the morning, it is impossible for anyone in whom the sense of decency is developed to walk through the streets which are lined with peopleperforming functions of nature which are meant to be performed in seclusion and in spots which human beings need not ordinarily tread.
('33', 169, 2, 10, 398125) In Bengal, the same tale in a varying form has to be told; the same pool in which people have washed their dirt, their pots, and in which cattle have drunk, supplies drinking water.
('33', 169, 2, 11, 398307) And here in Cutch men and women think nothing of repeating the performance I have seen in Madras.
('33', 169, 2, 12, 398405) These are not ignorant people; they are not illiterate; many have travelled even beyond the borders of India.
('33', 169, 2, 13, 398515) They ought to know better; but they do not.
('33', 169, 2, 14, 398559) And nobody worries about giving them an education in the elements of sanitation.
('33', 169, 2, 15, 398640) It is, or should be, one of the privileges of municipalities and local boards to make it their chief concern to eradicate insanitation within their limits.
('33', 169, 2, 16, 398796) If we are to live in cities, if we are to live an organized life, if we are to grow in health and wisdom—we shall have to get rid of insanitation some day or other.
('33', 169, 2, 17, 398961) The sooner we do so the better.
('33', 169, 2, 18, 398993) Let us not postpone everything till swaraj is attained.
('33', 169, 2, 19, 399049) Some things no doubt will only be done when that much wished for event has happened.
('33', 169, 2, 20, 399134) But it will never happen if we do not do the many things which can be done today as easily as under swaraj, and which are signs of corporate and civilized national life.
('33', 169, 2, 21, 399304) No institution can handle this problem better and more speedily than our muncipalities.
('33', 169, 2, 22, 399392) They have, so far as I am aware, all the powers they need in this direction and they can get more, if
('33', 170, 0, 1, 399494) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 171
('33', 170, 1, 2, 399545) necessary.
('33', 170, 1, 3, 399556) Only the will is often wanting.
('33', 170, 1, 4, 399588) It is not recognized that a municipality does not deserve to exist which does not possess model closets and where streets and lanes are not scrupulously clean all the hours of the day and the night.
('33', 170, 1, 5, 399787) But the reform cannot be brought about without infinite application on the part of members of municipalities and local boards.
('33', 170, 1, 6, 399914) To think of all the municipalities in the aggregate and to wait till everyone has begun the work is indifinitely to postpone the reform.
('33', 170, 1, 7, 400051) Let those who have got the will and the ability commence the reform in right earnest now, and the rest will follow.
('33', 170, 1, 8, 400167) It is with this end in view that I reproduce 1 elsewhere a translation of a humorously written letter by Dr. Hariprasad Desai of Ahmedabad and published recently in Navajivan.
('33', 170, 1, 9, 400343) The Municipality of Ahmedabad had taken up the problem seriously.
('33', 170, 1, 10, 400409) Ahmedabad is an exceptionally difficult town to deal with from the sanitary standpoint.
('33', 170, 1, 11, 400497) It is unclean.
('33', 170, 1, 12, 400512) I have not seen a more unclean city.
('33', 170, 1, 13, 400549) Its pols are seething with stench and dirt.
('33', 170, 1, 14, 400593) The superstitions and prejudices to be overcome are immense.
('33', 170, 1, 15, 400654) Insanitation has acquired an almost religious sanction.
('33', 170, 1, 16, 400710) Even the doctrine of ahimsa is invoked in favour of dirty habits!
('33', 170, 1, 17, 400776) I invite the reader to carefully peruse the translation.
('33', 170, 1, 18, 400833) He will then appreciate the difficulties that face the reformer in Ahmedabad.
('33', 170, 1, 19, 400911) Not many volunteers are to be had for this thankless and difficult work.
('33', 170, 1, 20, 400984) The reader will note too that it is being done by the commissioners who are interested in making Ahmedabad a model city in point of sanitation.
('33', 170, 1, 21, 401128) They are doing their work outside office hours and partly as a labour of love.
('33', 170, 1, 22, 401207) No municipality need expect any brilliant result if it is to be satisfied with mere routine work, issuing instructions to its executive officer.
('33', 170, 1, 23, 401352) Every municipal commissioner will have to become a self constituted scavenger in the city under his care if the cities of India are to become fit to live in for the poorest people in a decent sanitary condition.

('33', 171, 9, 9, 402082) 99. SPEECH AT MANDVI 3
('33', 171, 10, 10, 402105) October 31,1925 Who acts courageously and for what purpose?
('33', 171, 10, 11, 402165) One could be courageous in order to be licentious, one could be courageous for the sake of a woman and, even for the sake of wealth.
('33', 171, 10, 12, 402298) However, all this is like being courageous in order to jump into a well.
('33', 171, 10, 13, 402371) Courage should be shown for the purpose of swimming across to the other shore.
('33', 171, 10, 14, 402450) The supreme effort should be made for the sake of self realization.
('33', 171, 10, 15, 402518) We should take up a profession in which we offend no one and in which not a single pie has to be borrowed from anyone.
('33', 171, 10, 16, 402637) Gentlemen with whom I was very familiar and who were like the multi millionaires with whom I conversed the other day have been reduced to the sort of penury described in the couplet.
('33', 171, 10, 17, 402820) 4“I saw the relations of Shah Alam 5
('33', 171, 11, 18, 402857) begging in the streets.” Hence, why should there be all this rush, pretence and fuss about something that is of a fleeting nature?
('33', 171, 11, 19, 402988) Courage should be shown in having a vision of the glory of God and in singing His praises.
('33', 171, 11, 20, 403079) True courage consists in losing one’s mind in looking around at God’s creations.
('33', 171, 11, 21, 403160) These countless stars which shine in the sky, whose is the lustre they shed?
('33', 171, 11, 22, 403237) One may spend many lives in

('33', 172, 1, 2, 403532) trying to solve this riddle.
('33', 172, 1, 3, 403561) Shrimad Rajchandra 1 lay in insufferable agony before his death; however, he was not aware of it, he only eagerly awaited the vision of God.
('33', 172, 1, 4, 403702) Today, I have to say harsh things gently; hence I feel I am lucky in being able to recall to memory of a man like Shrimad Rajchandra and to praise his non violence.
('33', 172, 1, 5, 403867) Let us today derive from the memory of this man the strength to speak out without fear the plain, milk white truth as seen by the soul.
('33', 172, 1, 6, 404003) Let us stand in awe of the self alone; let us be concerned that the Self, which is ever watchful, does not suffer pain.

('33', 172, 4, 10, 404456) SCHEME FOR COW PROTECTION
('33', 172, 5, 11, 404482) The work of cow protection has been going on at a snail’s pace.
('33', 172, 5, 12, 404546) I can assure the gosevaks 3 that the movement does not come to a standstill even for a single moment.
('33', 172, 5, 13, 404648) I keep all the time thinking of it and also discuss it.
('33', 172, 5, 14, 404704) And, as there are many people in Kutch who wish to serve this cause and also because it does not seem likely that I shall be able to come to Kutch again, I have explained my scheme and collected some funds.

('33', 190, 10, 15, 448535) The thing that taxed me most was the ‘untouchable’ question.
('33', 190, 10, 16, 448596) Curious devices were resorted to by the orthodox to satisfy their consciences, but there is a great awakening among the untouchables themselves.
('33', 190, 10, 17, 448741) They are alive to their rights.
('33', 190, 10, 18, 448773) They understand their responsibilities.
('33', 190, 10, 19, 448813) Many have undertaken to give up carrion and drink.
('33', 190, 10, 20, 448864) The common people have no prejudice against them.
('33', 190, 10, 21, 448914) It is only the so called higher castes, a microscopic minority, who make a parade of their belief in untouchability which, in private, they would confess is unreasonable and contrary to real religion.
('33', 190, 10, 22, 449115) But even amongst them, there are a few noble spirits who, in defiance of the caste tyranny, are

('33', 191, 6, 15, 450845) LEST WE FORGET
('33', 191, 7, 16, 450860) J. M. Sengupta 1 writes to me to say that Bengal has decided to hold on Sunday, the 8th November, an all parties’ all Bengal demonstration against internments and imprisonments without trial, and suggests that such meetings should be held all over India.
('33', 191, 7, 17, 451115) For my part, I heartily endorse the suggestion.
('33', 191, 7, 18, 451163) I have passed it on to Pandit Motilal Nehru and, subject to his consent and approval, notices will have been issued before this is in print.
('33', 191, 7, 19, 451304) I am writing this in Cutch, a part of India which is isolated from all chief centres of activity.
('33', 191, 7, 20, 451402) It is, therefore, difficult for me to follow or overtake events that are
('33', 191, 8, 21, 451475) 1 Leader of the Swaraj Party in the Bengal Legislative Council, Mayor of Calcutta and President of the Bengal Provincial Congress Committee
('33', 192, 0, 1, 451615) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 193
('33', 192, 1, 2, 451666) happening outside from day to day.
('33', 192, 1, 3, 451701) I can, therefore, merely express my opinion on the suggestion.
('33', 192, 1, 4, 451764) It is this.
('33', 192, 1, 5, 451776) We may make no impression upon a Government that is irresponsive to public opinion.
('33', 192, 1, 6, 451860) But a demonstration like the one suggested by Sjt.
('33', 192, 1, 7, 451911) Sengupta will be a reminder to us that there are countrymen whom we believe to be innocent, but who are either interned or imprisoned without any trial whatever.
('33', 192, 1, 8, 452073) Every day that passes without bringing these men to an open trial or, in default, without discharging them, makes heavier the indictment against the Government.
('33', 192, 1, 9, 452234) I hope, therefore, that meetings will be held all over India composed of men belonging to all parties to demonstrate the national feeling in the matter.
('33', 192, 2, 10, 452387) A SCHEME OF COW PROTECTION
('33', 192, 3, 11, 452414) In private talks with friends I have often asked them to interest themselves in and help the movement on its constructive side.
('33', 192, 3, 12, 452542) In response to their desire, I publish the scheme I have discussed with some:
('33', 192, 4, 13, 452620) 1. In order to test the efficacy of tanneries as part of a programme of cow protection, it is necessary to own one and to utilize it not for profit, but purely for cow protection.
('33', 192, 4, 14, 452800) For this purpose a sum of Rs. 1,25,000 is required to be invested in one of the existing tanneries.
('33', 192, 4, 15, 452900) The information in my possession shows that the majority of existing tanneries buy and cure the hide of slaughtered cattle, and that India exports the bulk of the hide of dead cattle.
('33', 192, 4, 16, 453084) These conditions of things can only be remedied by lovers of the cow controlling tanneries and preventing by their philanthropy leather becoming an article of trade competition.
('33', 192, 5, 17, 453262) 2. Preliminary research must be carried out for exploring the possibilities not of remunerative dairy farming, but of conducting dairies on a vast scale, if without profit, also without loss in the long run.
('33', 192, 5, 18, 453470) For this preliminary work, a sum of ten thousand rupees at least must be spent inside of twelve months in engaging services of dairy experts and finding out suitable places for accommodating tens of thousands of cattle.
('33', 192, 5, 19, 453690) Without acquiring such control the terrible toll we pay in the slaughter of cattle which are simply through ill use or ignorance rendered profitless and, therefore, sold for slaughter by the goalas in the several cities of India must continue.
('33', 192, 5, 20, 453934) Nothing can save
('33', 193, 0, 1, 453951) 194 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 193, 1, 2, 453993) the cattle from the butcher’s knife if they become uneconomic.
('33', 193, 2, 3, 454056) 3. Scholarships must be found for preparing students for tan nery and dairy work.
('33', 193, 2, 4, 454138) For this a sum of Rs. 5,000 for one year is necessary.
('33', 193, 3, 5, 454193) 4. A sum of Rs. 3,000 is required for books on cattle breeding, dairy farming, tannery, etc.
('33', 193, 4, 6, 454286) Thus, a sum of Rs. 1,28,000 is required for capital expenditure and Rs. 15,000 for research, exploration and preparation.
('33', 193, 4, 7, 454408) I omit the current expenditure, which must be found from the normal income from membership of the All India Cow Protection Association.
('33', 193, 4, 8, 454544) It must be dissolved if it cannot pay its way.
('33', 193, 4, 9, 454591) In terms of the authority given to me, I have already engaged the services of a paid secretary.
('33', 193, 4, 10, 454687) V. G. Desai has been selected for the work to be done.
('33', 193, 4, 11, 454742) Among those whose names were before me, he appeared to me to be the fittest.
('33', 193, 4, 12, 454819) He is an English and Sanskrit scholar.
('33', 193, 4, 13, 454858) He is a lover of animals and has been always a believer in cow protection.
('33', 193, 4, 14, 454933) He had choice of work before him and had made cow protection, I hope, his final and life long choice.
('33', 193, 4, 15, 455035) I have known him intimately ever since my return to India in 1915. He is to receive a salary of Rs. 200 per month.
('33', 193, 4, 16, 455150) At the present moment, he is lodged at the Satyagraha Ashram without having to pay any rent.
('33', 193, 4, 17, 455243) But it may become necessary to pay twenty five rupees in addition, in lieu of rent.
('33', 193, 4, 18, 455327) If donations in respect of the scheme are received, it will be necessary to increase the paid staff.
('33', 193, 4, 19, 455428) At the present moment not even an office boy has been engaged.
('33', 193, 4, 20, 455491) Expansion of the work depends upon public response.
('33', 193, 4, 21, 455543) During the Cutch tour, I have been expounding the scheme to the Cutch friends and they have given me already over Rs. 3,000, which includes the sum of Rs. 500 from a Khoja friend.
('33', 193, 4, 22, 455723) There must be, however, a better response both in donations and membership.

('33', 195, 3, 12, 459016) 109. THE POET AND THE CHARKHA
('33', 195, 4, 13, 459046) When Sir Rabindranath’s criticism of charkha was published some time ago, 1 several friends asked me to reply to it.
('33', 195, 4, 14, 459163) Being heavily engaged, I was unable then to study it in full.
('33', 195, 4, 15, 459225) But I had read enough of it to know its trend.
('33', 195, 4, 16, 459272) I was in no hurry to reply.
('33', 195, 4, 17, 459300) Those who had read it were too much agitated or influenced to be able to appreciate what I might have then written even if I had the time.
('33', 195, 4, 18, 459439) Now, therefore, is really the time for me to write on it and to ensure a dispassionate view being taken of the Poet’s criticism or my reply, if such it may be called.
('33', 195, 4, 19, 459606) The criticism is a sharp rebuke to Acharya Ray 2 for his impatience of the Poet’s and Acharya Seal’s position regarding the charkha, and gentle rebuke to me for my exclusive and excessive love of it.
('33', 195, 4, 20, 459806) Let the public understand that the Poet does not deny its great economic value.
('33', 195, 4, 21, 459886) Let them know that he signed the appeal for the All India Deshbandhu Memorial after he had written his criticism.
('33', 195, 4, 22, 460000) He signed the appeal after studying its contents carefully and, even as he signed it, he sent me the message that he had written something on the charkha which might not quite please me.
('33', 195, 4, 23, 460187) I knew, therefore, what was coming.
('33', 195, 4, 24, 460223) But it has not displeased me.
('33', 195, 4, 25, 460253) Why should mere disagreement with my views displease?
('33', 195, 4, 26, 460307) If every disagreement were to displease, since no two men agree exactly on all points, life would be a bundle of

('33', 196, 2, 26, 462225) I can merely show the hidden possibilities of old and even worn out things.
('33', 196, 2, 27, 462301) The world easily finds an honourable place for the magician who produces new and dazzling things.

('33', 196, 2, 29, 462471) Thus there is no competition between us.

('33', 196, 3, 31, 462584) The fact is that the Poet’s criticism is a poetic licence and he who takes it literally is in danger of finding himself in an awkward corner.
('33', 196, 3, 32, 462726) An ancient poet has said that Solomon arrayed in all his glory was not like one of the lilies of the field.
('33', 196, 3, 33, 462834) He clearly referred to the natural beauty and innocence of the lily contrasted with the artificia lity of Solomon’s glory and his sinfulness in spite of his many good deeds.
('33', 196, 3, 34, 463008) Or take the poetical licence in: ‘It is easier for a camel to pass through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the Kingdom of Heaven.’ We know that no camel has ever passed through the eye
('33', 197, 0, 1, 463210) 198 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 197, 1, 2, 463252) of a needle and we know too that rich men like Janaka have entered the Kingdom of Heaven.
('33', 197, 1, 3, 463342) Or take the beautiful simile of human teeth being likened to the pomegranate seed.
('33', 197, 1, 4, 463425) Foolish women who have taken the poetical exaggeration literally have been found to disfigure, and even harm, their teeth.
('33', 197, 1, 5, 463548) Painters and poets are obliged to exaggerate the proportions of their figures in order to give a true perspective.
('33', 197, 1, 6, 463663) Those therefore who take the Poet’s denunciation of the charkha literally will be doing an injustice to the Poet and an injury to themselves.
('33', 197, 1, 7, 463805) The Poet does not, he is not expected, he has no need, to read Young India.
('33', 197, 1, 8, 463881) All he knows about the movement is what he has picked up from table talk.
('33', 197, 1, 9, 463955) He has, therefore, denounced what he has imagined to be the excesses of the charkha cult.
('33', 197, 2, 10, 464045) He thinks, for instance, that I want everybody to spin the whole of his or her time to the exclusion of all other activity, that is to say, that I want the poet to forsake his muse, the farmer his plough, the lawyer his brief and the doctor his lancet.
('33', 197, 2, 11, 464298) So far is this from truth that I have asked no one to abandon his calling but, on the contrary, to adorn it by giving every day only thirty minutes to spinning as sacrifice for the whole nation.
('33', 197, 2, 12, 464493) I have, indeed, asked the famishing man or woman who is idle for want of any work whatsoever to spin for a living and the half starved farmer to spin during his leisure hours to supplement his slender resources.
('33', 197, 2, 13, 464705) If the Poet span half an hour daily his poetry would gain in richness.
('33', 197, 2, 14, 464776) For it would then represent the poor man’s wants and woes in a more forcible manner than now.
('33', 197, 3, 15, 464870) The Poet thinks that the charkha is calculated to bring about a death like sameness in the nation and, thus imagining, he would shun it if he could.
('33', 197, 3, 16, 465019) The truth is that the charkha is intended to realize the essential and living oneness of interest among India’s myriads.
('33', 197, 3, 17, 465140) Behind the magnificent and kaleidoscopic variety, one discovers in nature a unity of purpose, design and form which is equally unmistakable.
('33', 197, 3, 18, 465281) No two men are absolutely alike, not even twins, and yet there is much that is indispensably common to all mankind.
('33', 197, 3, 19, 465397) And behind the commonness of form there is the same life pervading all.
('33', 197, 3, 20, 465469) The idea of sameness or oneness was carried by Shankara to its utmost logical and natural limit and he exclaimed that there was only one truth, one God—Brahman—and all form, nam, rupa was illusion or illusory, evanescent.
('33', 197, 3, 21, 465691) We need not debate whether what we see is
('33', 198, 0, 1, 465733) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 199
('33', 198, 1, 2, 465784) unreal; and whether the real behind the unreality is what we do not see.
('33', 198, 1, 3, 465857) Let both be equally real, if you will.
('33', 198, 1, 4, 465896) All I say is that there is a sameness, identity or oneness behind the multiplicity and variety.
('33', 198, 1, 5, 465992) And so do I hold that behind a variety of occupations there is an indispensable sameness also of occupation.
('33', 198, 1, 6, 466101) Is not agriculture common to the vast majority of mankind?
('33', 198, 1, 7, 466160) Even so, was spinning common not long ago to a vast majority of mankind?
('33', 198, 1, 8, 466233) Just as both prince and peasant must eat and clothe themselves so must both labour for supplying their primary wants.
('33', 198, 1, 9, 466351) The prince may do so if only by way of symbol and sacrifice, but that much is indispensable for him if he will be true to himself and his people.
('33', 198, 1, 10, 466497) Europe may not realize this vital necessity at the present moment, because it has made of exploitation of non European races a religion.
('33', 198, 1, 11, 466634) But it is a false religion bound to perish in the near future.

('33', 201, 1, 2, 472447) 111. A HOTCH POT OF QUESTIONS
('33', 201, 2, 3, 472477) I have got some taxing readers of Young India who often ask inconvenient questions.
('33', 201, 2, 4, 472561) But, as they please them, I must suffer the inconvenience and answer their questions, however vexing they may be.
('33', 201, 2, 5, 472675) This is how a correspondent fires the first shot:
('33', 201, 3, 6, 472725) Who is responsible for the word ‘Mahatma’ before your name in the list of Executive Councillors, A.I S.A, as given in Young India of 1st October?
('33', 201, 4, 7, 472871) The correspondent may depend upon it that the editor is not responsible for the appearance of the word ‘Mahatma’ in the list of members of the Council of A.I.S.A. Those who passed the consti tution are certainly responsible for it.
('33', 201, 4, 8, 473103) Had I offered satyagraha against it, the word might not have appeared.
('33', 201, 4, 9, 473174) But I did not consider the offence to be serious enough to call for the use of that terrible weapon.
('33', 201, 4, 10, 473275) Unless some catastrophe takes place the offensive word will always be associated with my name, and the patient critics must tolerate it even as I do.
('33', 201, 5, 11, 473425) You say you live, in common with other fellow workers, on the charity of friends who defray the expenses of Sabarmati Satyagraha Ashram.
('33', 201, 5, 12, 473562) Do you think it proper for an institution of able bodied men to live on the charity of friends?
('33', 201, 6, 13, 473658) The correspondent has taken the word ‘charity’ too literally.
('33', 201, 6, 14, 473720) Let him understand that every member of the institution gives both his or her body and mind to its work.
('33', 201, 6, 15, 473825) But the institution can still be said to live on the charity of friends, because the latter get no return for their donations.
('33', 201, 6, 16, 473952) The fruits of the labour of the inmates go to the nation.
('33', 201, 7, 17, 474010) What is your view on what Tolstoy calls ‘bread labour’?
('33', 201, 7, 18, 474066) Do you really earn your living by your bodily labour?
('33', 201, 8, 19, 474120) Strictly speaking, bread labour is not a word of Tolstoy’s coining.
('33', 201, 8, 20, 474188) He took it from another Russian writer Bondarif, and it means that everyone is expected to perform sufficient body labour in order to entitle him to it.
('33', 201, 8, 21, 474341) It is not, therefore, necessary to earn one’s living by bread labour, taking the word living in its broader sense.
('33', 201, 8, 22, 474456) But everyone must perform some useful body labour.
('33', 201, 8, 23, 474507) For me, at the present moment, spinning is the only body labour I give.
('33', 201, 8, 24, 474579) It is a mere symbol.
('33', 201, 8, 25, 474600) I do not give enough body labour.

('33', 202, 1, 2, 474709) reasons why I consider myself as living upon charity.

('33', 204, 1, 4, 480304) My repugnance to war was as strong then as it is today; and I could not then have and would not have shouldered a rifle.

('33', 205, 1, 2, 482483) 112. THE CANKER OF SUPERIORITY
('33', 205, 2, 3, 482514) The following remarkable paper handed to me at Mymensing by the District Vaisya Sabha Association cannot fail to be of general interest.
('33', 205, 3, 4, 482651) It is likely that there is some exaggeration in the foregoing statement.
('33', 205, 3, 5, 482724) But the reason why I have reproduced the paper is to show how deep the canker of superiority has eaten into the very vitals of Hinduism.
('33', 205, 3, 6, 482861) The writers, themselves a despised group in the estimation of their so called superiors, have not hesitated to claim for themselves a status superior to and distinct from those more despised.
('33', 205, 3, 7, 483053) The same notion of superiority and inferiority runs through the despised untouchables.
('33', 205, 3, 8, 483140) I notice throughout my tour in Cutch that, as in other parts of India, the untouchables have among themselves also superior and inferior castes, and the higher caste Antyajas will not touch the lower caste, will positively refuse to send their children to schools belonging to the lower caste.
('33', 205, 3, 9, 483434) Inter marriage and inter dining between them is unthinkable.
('33', 205, 3, 10, 483495) This is caste reduced to the grossest absurdity.
('33', 205, 3, 11, 483544) And it is by way of protest against this arrogation of superiority by one class over another that I delight in calling myself a Bhangi, that is, a sweeper, beyond which so far as I am aware inferiority does not travel.
('33', 205, 3, 12, 483763) He is the social leper shunned by all and yet he belongs to the one group more indispensable than any other for the sanitary well being of society, and, therefore, its very physical existence.
('33', 205, 3, 13, 483956) My sympathies are all with gentlemen on whose behalf the foregoing statement was given to me.
('33', 205, 3, 14, 484050) But I warn them against claiming superiority over men more unfortunately placed than themselves.
('33', 205, 3, 15, 484147) Let it be their privilege to take even these with them and refuse to take privileges which may be denied to others.
('33', 205, 3, 16, 484263) It is necessary, if we will rid Hinduism of the curse of unnatural inequalities, for some of us to rise with our whole soul in revolt against it.
('33', 205, 3, 17, 484409) In my opinion, he who claims superiority by the very nature of the claim forfeits it.
('33', 205, 3, 18, 484495) Real, natural superiority comes without the claiming.
('33', 205, 3, 19, 484549) It is recognized ungrudgingly, and ever refused, not pompously, not out of a false sense of modesty, but because the superiority is not even felt, and because the superior man knows that there is no distinction whatso ever between the soul within himself and the soul within one who regards himself as his inferior.
('33', 205, 3, 20, 484865) Recognition of the essential identity and oneness of all that lives excludes the very idea of superiority and

('33', 209, 3, 7, 490769) 118. OUR IMPOTENCE
('33', 209, 4, 8, 490788) The following letter has been addressed to me by Hakimsaheb Ajmal Khan and Dr. Ansari who have just returned from a prolonged tour on the continent including Syria:
('33', 209, 5, 9, 490953) Recent events in Southern Syria, the country where the Druses live, and where an armed resistance is being carried on by these oppressed people against the French, the Mandatory Power, have brought to light the fringhtfulness of the French authorities there.
('33', 209, 5, 10, 491212) A cable, received two days back from Palestine sent by Syed Jamaluddin al Husaini, Secretary of Lajnatut Tanfiziyah, the most popular and influential organization of the people of Palestine, says that the town of Damascus has terribly suffered from the French bombardment and the death roll has been tremendous.
('33', 209, 5, 11, 491524) Although from the various accounts published in the British Press one could gather that things were bad in Syria, yet this telegram from Palestine and Reuter’s cable from Cairo, received subsequently, show the utter barbarity and inhumanity which is being practised by the French of the pupulation in the Druse country and Damascus.
('33', 209, 6, 12, 491857) Apart from the recent instances of frightfulness, our tour in Syria brought under our observation many facts which proved the callousness of the French and their utter disregard for the elementary rights of the people of the mandated territory in Syria.
('33', 209, 7, 13, 492111) We have already published our experiences in the Indian Press, but in order to save you the trouble of reading the Urdu reports, published in the Hamdard, we would briefly give you some of the most salient facts regarding the situation in Syria.
('33', 209, 8, 14, 492357) When the League of Nations gave the mandate of Syria to France, the French Government and the High Commissioner made a public declaration to the people of Syria of granting them complete autonomy regarding their internal affairs, Syria was to be divided in several autonomous provinces each with a governor, elected by the people and an advisory council representing the people and elected by them.
('33', 209, 8, 15, 492756) Whilst this promise was partially and outwardly carried out in the provinces of Lebanon and Damascus, the province of Hauran, the country of the Druses, was neither given auto nomy nor a council for a president elected by them, but a French officer Captain Carbiollet, was forced on the Druses against their wish and when they made demons trations and representations against this, their deputation was
('33', 210, 0, 1, 493159) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 211
('33', 210, 1, 2, 493210) insulted, their nota bles were publicly thrashed and imprisoned, and their womenfolk were maltreated.
('33', 210, 2, 3, 493312) Captain Carbiollet, who had come from French Congo, practised all the atrocities to which the poor inhabitants of the French Congo had been subjected by the French, but the Druses being an ancient, proud, warlike race resisted these methods and were forced to take up arms.
('33', 210, 2, 4, 493586) They inflicted considerable losses on the French forces and have so far resisted the French invasion of their country success fully, but the methods practised by the French in the adjoining parts of Syria, viz.
('33', 210, 2, 5, 493797) Damascus and Alleppo, are causing the spread of revolt to these parts.
('33', 210, 2, 6, 493868) The telegrams quoted above refer to the most recent atrocities committed on the people of Damascus.
('33', 210, 3, 7, 493968) The French Government are also practising unfair and dishonest methods and are depleting the country of its wealth by removing all the gold in the country and replacing it by paper money.
('33', 210, 3, 8, 494156) They are gradually undermining all the economic resources of the country which is resulting in destitution and poverty.
('33', 210, 3, 9, 494276) To add to this depletion, they have also been collecting gold from the people of town and villages in the shape of fines and punishments.
('33', 210, 4, 10, 494414) We are writing this to you in order to elicit your sympathy for these Asiatic brethren, and to request you, as the President of the Congress, to send a cable to the League of Nations which has granted this mandate to France, and to instruct other Congress organizations to do the same.
('33', 210, 4, 11, 494700) We are conscious that the present situation in India is not very favourable to such an action, but it is our considered opinion as Indians, as Muslims, and as Asiatics that we should sympathize with all the oppressed Asiatic people and cultivate friendly relations with them which would be beneficial to us and to them.
('33', 210, 4, 12, 495020) I could not see my way to accept their advice to send a cable to the League of Nations in the name of the Congress, and therefore sent the following answer: 1
('33', 210, 5, 13, 495179) But the next best thing I could do was to publish the valuable letter and my reply.
('33', 210, 5, 14, 495263) I do not believe in making appeals when there is no force behind them whether moral or material.
('33', 210, 5, 15, 495360) Moral force comes from the determination of the appellants to do something, to sacrifice something for the sake of making their appeal effective.
('33', 210, 5, 16, 495506) Even children instinctively know this elementary principle.
('33', 210, 5, 17, 495566) They starve, they cry, or, if they are naughty, they do not hesitate to strike their mothers who will not grant their peremptory demands.
('33', 210, 5, 18, 495704) Unless we recognize and are prepared to reduce to practice this principle we can but expose the Congress and ourselves to ridicule, if not worse.
('33', 210, 5, 19, 495850) We cannot be naughty even if we will.
('33', 210, 5, 20, 495888) We can suffer if only we
('33', 210, 6, 21, 495913) 1Vide” Letter to Dr. M.A. Ansari”, 7 11 1925.
('33', 211, 0, 1, 495959) 212 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 211, 1, 2, 496001) I want us as Indians, Hindus or Mussalmans, Christians or Parsis, or Asiatics to realize our impotence in the face of this humiliation, babarity, Dyerism, or call it what you will, inflicted on Syria.
('33', 211, 1, 3, 496202) A definite realization of our impotence might teach us to imitate if it is only the animals who in the presence of stormy weather come close together and seek warmth and courage from one another.
('33', 211, 1, 4, 496398) They do not make a vain appeal to the god of the weather to moderate his wrath.
('33', 211, 1, 5, 496478) They simply provide against it.
('33', 211, 1, 6, 496510) And we?
('33', 211, 1, 7, 496518) Hindus and Mussalmans fight against one another and the gulf seems to be daily widening.
('33', 211, 1, 8, 496607) We have not yet understood the meaning of the charkha.
('33', 211, 1, 9, 496662) Those that have find all kinds of pretexts not to wear khaddar and not to spin.
('33', 211, 1, 10, 496742) The storm is raging round us.
('33', 211, 1, 11, 496772) And instead of seeking warmth one from the other, we prefer to shiver or petition the god of storms to stay his hand.
('33', 211, 1, 12, 496890) If I cannot bring about Hindu Muslim union or persuade the people to take up the wheel, I have the wisdom at least not to sign any petition for mercy.
('33', 211, 1, 13, 497041) And what is the League of Nations?
('33', 211, 1, 14, 497076) Is it not in reality merely England and France?
('33', 211, 1, 15, 497124) Do the other powers count?
('33', 211, 1, 16, 497151) Is it any use appealing to France which is denying her motto of Fraternity, Equality and Justice?
('33', 211, 1, 17, 497249) She has denied justice to Germany, there is little fraternity between her and the Riffs, and the doctrine of equality she is trampling underfoot in Syria.
('33', 211, 1, 18, 497404) If we would appeal to England, we need not go to the League of Nations.
('33', 211, 1, 19, 497476) She is much nearer home.
('33', 211, 1, 20, 497501) She is perched on the heights of Simla except when she descends to Delhi for a brief period.
('33', 211, 1, 21, 497594) But to appeal to her is to appeal to Caesar against Augustus.
('33', 211, 1, 22, 497656) Let us then perceive the truth in its nakedness and learn to appeal to the nation to do her duty.
('33', 211, 1, 23, 497754) Relief of Syria lies through India.
('33', 211, 1, 24, 497790) And if we cannot appreciate our greatness, let us confess our littleness and say nothing.
('33', 211, 1, 25, 497880) But we need not be little.
('33', 211, 1, 26, 497907) Let us do at least one thing thoroughly—either fight to the bitter end, even as our brothers the four footed animals often do, or, as men, let us learn and teach through co operation on the largest scale known to the world the uselessness, nay, the sinfulness of exploitation of those weaker than ourselves.
('33', 211, 1, 27, 498215) That co operation among millions is possible only through the spinning wheel.

('33', 212, 1, 2, 498368) 119. NOTES
('33', 212, 2, 3, 498379) MESSENGER OF PEACE
('33', 212, 3, 4, 498398) Mr. C. F. Andrews’s self chosen function is to do the service he can and think no more about it.
('33', 212, 3, 5, 498495) His service takes the form of bringing about peace.
('33', 212, 3, 6, 498547) He had hardly finished his work in Orissa among the men or cattle in distress or among the mill hands of Bombay, when he felt the call to go to South Africa and help the Indian settlers who are in distress.
('33', 212, 3, 7, 498754) But he will be helping not only the Indians there but also the Europeans.
('33', 212, 3, 8, 498828) He has no malice or anger in him.
('33', 212, 3, 9, 498862) He wants no favours for the Indians.
('33', 212, 3, 10, 498899) He wants bare justice.
('33', 212, 3, 11, 498922) Mr. Andrews is no stranger to South Africa 1. South African statesmen know and admit that he is as much Europeans’ friend as Indians.
('33', 212, 3, 12, 499056) The Indian question has reached a most critical stage.
('33', 212, 3, 13, 499111) For the Indians resident in South Africa it is a matter practically of life and death.
('33', 212, 3, 14, 499198) Mr.Andrews’s presence in their midst at this juncture must bring the greatest comfort to them.
('33', 212, 3, 15, 499293) May this good friend’s labours bear ample fruit as they have done before now.
('33', 212, 3, 16, 499371) Let the settlers, however, not be lulled into a sense of false security by Mr. Andrews’s presence which by itself can bring them little relief.
('33', 212, 3, 17, 499515) He can but guide, advise and negotiate.
('33', 212, 3, 18, 499555) But all the guidance, advice and negotiation will come to nothing if there is no cohesion or courage among the settlers themselves.
('33', 212, 4, 19, 499687) AN OPIUM REPORT
('33', 212, 5, 20, 499703) The Congress Opium Enquiry Report for Assam has been just published and can be had at the Congress Office, Jorhat, Assam, or of Mr. C F. Andrews, Santiniketan, for Rs. 1/8 or two shillings.
('33', 212, 5, 21, 499893) It is well printed and covers 166 pages including a map, appendices, a glossary of unusual terms and a subject index.
('33', 212, 5, 22, 500011) The report itself covers 44 pages.
('33', 212, 5, 23, 500046) It has nine chapters.
('33', 212, 5, 24, 500068) There is, too, an introduction by Mr. C. F. Andrews who was a co opted member and who is mainly responsible for the creation of the Committee and the conduct of the Enquiry.
('33', 212, 5, 25, 500242) Kuladhar Chatia was the chairman of the Committee.
('33', 212, 5, 26, 500293) This is the tribute Mr. Andrews pays to the workers:
('33', 212, 6, 27, 500346) I wish to express my sincere admiration for the devoted courage and perseverance of the workers on the present committee who have sacrificed time and
('33', 212, 7, 28, 500496) 1 Andrews had visited the country in 1914, when Gandhiji was still there.
('33', 213, 0, 1, 500570) 214 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 213, 1, 2, 500612) ease and leisure and business occupations in order to do this service to their country.
('33', 213, 1, 3, 500700) This enquiry is one among a series.
('33', 213, 1, 4, 500736) Assam was the first province chosen because it has the blackest record for opium in all India.
('33', 213, 1, 5, 500831) Whereas the standard medical requirement of opium , according to the League of Nations, is 6 seers per each 10,000, the lowest figure for Assam is over 45 seers and the highest over 237 seers!
('33', 213, 1, 6, 501024) The report shows that, during the Non co operation period, the figures for opium dropped from 1,614 maunds to 884. This was due to picketing which was rendered illegal.
('33', 213, 1, 7, 501193) 1,100 workers were imprisoned including lawyers, graduates, college students , etc.
('33', 213, 1, 8, 501277) But I must not anticipate the pleasure that a patriot or a reformer would gain by reading the whole of the instructive report.
('33', 213, 1, 9, 501404) I must, therefore, close this review of the report by copying the recommendations.
('33', 213, 2, 10, 501487) (1) The sale of opium and its derivations should be ultimately limited to the medical and scientific needs of Assam.
('33', 213, 3, 11, 501604) (2) Provision should be made for confirmed addicts above the age of forty, enabling them to procure a rationed amount of opium, their names being registered for that purpose.
('33', 213, 4, 12, 501779) (3) All opium addicts, who are under forty years of age, should be dealt with as medical patients.
('33', 213, 4, 13, 501878) Wherever opium is needed by them, it should be given only under the order of a fully qualified doctor, the medical permission to obtain it being subject to quarterly renewal.
('33', 213, 5, 14, 502053) (4) These changes would be carried out within the next five years.
('33', 213, 5, 15, 502120) At the end of five years, opium should be placed on the list of poisons under a Dangerous Drugs Act, and treated as such for all inhabitants of Assam.
('33', 213, 6, 16, 502271) While much depends of the Government action, we feel that no progress can be made without the education of public opinion.
('33', 213, 6, 17, 502394) The Non co operation movement showed what a great advance could be made in opium restriction by voluntary effort and public propaganda.
('33', 213, 6, 18, 502530) The decrease in consumption in a single year is a proof of what can be done by these methods.
('33', 213, 6, 19, 502624) This work needs to be still further promoted and sustained.
('33', 213, 7, 20, 502684) We, therefore, appeal to all those who desire the welfare or Assam to organize themselves into anti opium societies and to advocate opium prohibition amongst the people in general.
('33', 213, 7, 21, 502865) This will lead to the education of public opinion against the opium evil and create a moral atmosphere, without which no great success can be achieved.
('33', 213, 7, 22, 503017) Every avenue of approaching the illiterate masses, who are the greatest consumers, should be employed.
('33', 213, 7, 23, 503120) Especially necessary is the careful training of the young children in all the elementary schools of the Assam valley and among the hill tribes.
('33', 213, 7, 24, 503264) We would invite the co operation of all sections of the community in this educational

('33', 214, 1, 3, 503563) Finally, we would venture to ask Mahatma Gandhi once more to come to Assam and put himself at the head of a great anti opium campaign to be carried on by entirely peaceful means.

('33', 214, 2, 17, 504639) COW PROTECTION ESSAY
('33', 214, 3, 18, 504660) The readers will be glad to learn that Acharya Dhruva and Sjt.
('33', 214, 3, 19, 504723) C. V. Vaidya have both kindly consented to be judges of the competition essays.
('33', 214, 3, 20, 504803) I only hope that the essays will be worthy of the great scholars who have consented to judge them and the subject chosen.
('33', 214, 3, 21, 504925) Acharya Dhruva suggests that I should make it clear that the scholars should examine the Shastras not from the dry and profitless dialectic standpoint but from the broad historical standpoint.
('33', 214, 3, 22, 505118) So also does he hope the essayists will deal with the question of tanneries and dairies.
('33', 214, 3, 23, 505207) They will, therefore, historically trace the growth of cow protection and examine all possible ways of protecting and preserving the cow and hence cattle life, not inconsistent with the sanctions of religion.
('33', 214, 3, 24, 505416) A correspondent inquires what length the essay should be.
('33', 214, 3, 25, 505474) No limit has been considered necessary because it depends upon the manner of treatment.
('33', 214, 3, 26, 505562) But I would say generally that the shorter the essay the better it would be.
('33', 214, 3, 27, 505639) I know the judges well enough to be able say for them that they will not in any way be influenced by the length of the essays.
('33', 214, 3, 28, 505766) Each competitor will therefore use his own discretion.

('33', 216, 2, 7, 508805) A KHADI CATALOGUE
('33', 216, 3, 8, 508823) The manager of the Khadi Bhandar, Princess Street, run in Bombay by the All India Khadi Board (now All India Spinners’ Association) has sent me a copy of his neatly printed price list, It shows the progress made by khaddar.
('33', 216, 3, 9, 509047) The total sales during the four years of its existence amount to Rs, 8,30, 329. The highest sales were in 1922 23 , viz , Rs. 2,45,515, the lowest during the current year, viz., Rs. 1,68,280. It has been suggested that the sales went up in 1922 23 because I was in jail.
('33', 216, 3, 10, 509318) People thought and rightly that the more khaddar they used, the nearer was swaraj.
('33', 216, 3, 11, 509401) And swaraj meant my discharge.
('33', 216, 3, 12, 509432) The flaw, however, consisted in the reasoning that khaddar was only a temporary necessity.
('33', 216, 3, 13, 509523) Whereas the fact is that it is as necessary for all times as native food and native air are.
('33', 216, 3, 14, 509616) The lower sales therefore are better in a way if they represent permanent custom.
('33', 216, 3, 15, 509698) The existence of this and other khaddar stores shows that they supply a felt want, The political effect of khaddar however can be obtained only when the sales are not a little over one hundred thousand rupees per year but they amount to several crores, strictly speaking, sixty crores.
('33', 216, 3, 16, 509984) Bombay, therefore, should support not one or two such stores but several hundred, even as it today supports several hundred foreign cloth stores.
('33', 216, 3, 17, 510130) There is now no excuse for the public not to support this and such other stores.
('33', 216, 3, 18, 510211) For they satisfy all reasonable tastes.
('33', 216, 3, 19, 510251) I observe in the catalogue, shirtings, muslin khadi, saris, handkerchiefs, towels, dhotis, ready made shirts, vests, caps, bags, bedsheets, shawls, curtains, counterpanes, tablecloths, pillow slips, blouses, drawers for babies and adults, etc.” But,” says the critic,” compare the prices.” I compare them and satisfy myself that, where the price is apparently higher, it is in reality cheaper, for in addition to getting khaddar for your money, you contribute towards the attainment of swaraj.
('33', 216, 3, 20, 510745) If you do not believe in the capacity of khaddar to secure swaraj, then know that by buying khaddar you are at least partly supporting some starving man or woman.

('33', 217, 4, 6, 511256) SABARMATI, November 13, 1925
('33', 217, 5, 7, 511285) DEAR FRIEND, I have your very kind letter.
('33', 217, 5, 8, 511328) 1 Miss Slade quickly followed it.
('33', 217, 5, 9, 511362) What a treasure you have sent me!
('33', 217, 5, 10, 511396) I shall try to be worthy of the great trust.
