('33', 218, 4, 9, 513138) “Juna Jogi” 1 writes as follows: 2
('33', 218, 5, 10, 513173) This letter has been lying with me for two months.
('33', 218, 5, 11, 513224) I had hoped, when I had leisure, to place it before the readers of Navajivan.
('33', 218, 5, 12, 513302) I have found that leisure today or, rather, I have contrived to find it.
('33', 218, 5, 13, 513375) The writer has advised me not to go fault finding.
('33', 218, 5, 14, 513426) And let it not be said that I am finding fault with his letter if I happen to criticize it, for the motive behind my criticism is somehow to fit it into these pages so as to expound the glory of God.
('33', 218, 5, 15, 513626) Let the writer and others know that I am adopting whatever in it is worth adopting.
('33', 218, 5, 16, 513710) I feel I have nothing new to learn about the glory of Ramanama as I have realized it through experience.
('33', 218, 5, 17, 513815) And I hold that it cannot be propagated in the same manner as khadi or swaraj.
('33', 218, 5, 18, 513894) In these very difficult times, even the utterance of the Name is done in a wrong way.
('33', 218, 5, 19, 513980) In other words, I have heard it repeated often for mere show, sometimes for selfish ends and sometimes even in order to feed licentious conduct.
('33', 218, 5, 20, 514125) There would be nothing to object to if one uttered Mara reversing the order of syllables, while chanting the Name.
('33', 218, 5, 21, 514240) We read of the pure in heart having attained mukti even by chanting it in an erroneous manner and we can believe this too to be true.
('33', 218, 5, 22, 514374) However, what are we to say of sinners who, although their pronunciation is perfect, chant the mantra of Ramanama in order to nourish their sins?
('33', 218, 5, 23, 514520) That is why I am afraid of any propaganda for Ramanama.
('33', 218, 5, 24, 514576) Those persons who believe that by sitting together in company and loudly repeating the Name they

('33', 219, 1, 6, 515272) How can a servant of Rama put it down in writing saying hat no one in this world has been able to convert learned men?
('33', 219, 1, 7, 515391) 1 It does not seem to me that I am under any delusion.

('33', 219, 1, 9, 515555) The truth of the matter is that no one but a devotee can convert learned persons.
('33', 219, 1, 10, 515637) And I, who hope to become a devotee, am ever trying to make these persons understand.
('33', 219, 1, 11, 515723) And as I have no delusion, I am not angry with those who do not understand but rather with myself because my devotion is imperfect.
('33', 219, 1, 12, 515855) Hence in order that Rama may for ever dwell in my heart I welcome the advice that I should further purify my heart, and I constantly give myself such advice.

('33', 220, 1, 18, 519514) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 15 11 1925
('33', 220, 2, 19, 519552) 123. MY NOTES
('33', 220, 3, 20, 519566) RAILWAY TRAVEL There was a time when I actually experienced the discomforts of a railway journey and then I also felt strongly about them; those days are over for me.
('33', 220, 3, 21, 519733) I now get little first hand experience of them, as I no longer travel third class.
('33', 220, 3, 22, 519816) One does not take notice of what one does not constantly experience.
('33', 220, 3, 23, 519885) Moreover, other matters, which appear to be more important to my mind, occupy all my time; hence it rarely occurs to me to write on the hardships of passengers or to investigate
('33', 221, 0, 1, 520063) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 221, 1, 2, 520105) this matter.
('33', 221, 1, 3, 520118) During my tour of Kutch, however, Shri Jivraj Nensey reminded me that a day had been set apart every year for recalling passengers’ grievances and he then asked me to write something on this subject.
('33', 221, 1, 4, 520318) A day should thus be set apart and passengers should recall their grievances on that day.
('33', 221, 1, 5, 520408) Ways should be found to remedy these, and new measures should be devised only after those taken during the previous year have been reviewed.
('33', 221, 1, 6, 520549) Here, however, as on every question there are two aspects.
('33', 221, 1, 7, 520608) It is not only the authorities who are to blame for the hardships that the passengers have to undergo.
('33', 221, 1, 8, 520711) It has been my experience that much of the blame has to be shared by the latter also.
('33', 221, 1, 9, 520797) What could the railway authorities do if the passengers make no complaints or do not know they have any rights?
('33', 221, 1, 10, 520909) Or, how can we blame the railway authorities when the passengers themselves are responsible for committing offences?
('33', 221, 1, 11, 521026) Hence, I expect some self examination to take place when such gatherings are held.
('33', 221, 1, 12, 521109) It is all very well to find fault with others.
('33', 221, 1, 13, 521156) but along with that one should also look at one’s own faults.
('33', 221, 1, 14, 521218) If we do not get rid of some of our bad habits, many of the hardships suffered by passengers will continue, however good the railway regulations and however honest the authorities may be.
('33', 221, 1, 15, 521406) Moreover, some grievances have their origin in the entire system of Government being evil; these cannot be done away with so long as the system is not changed.
('33', 221, 1, 16, 521566) For instance, the basic objective of the railways is not to serve passengers but to drain the wealth of India and also to suppress any revolt that we may raise.
('33', 221, 1, 17, 521727) In other words, the railway is meant for the military authorities.
('33', 221, 1, 18, 521794) The hardships result from this which is the very root of the problem.
('33', 221, 1, 19, 521864) Swaraj is the only remedy for it; and swaraj should be a government based on morality.
('33', 221, 1, 20, 521951) In this manner, in calling to memory the hardships of passengers, we find that there are three aspects of the question which should be considered and I hope the organizers will consider them all.

('33', 222, 4, 22, 524356) INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA

('33', 224, 7, 17, 526938) THE NAKED TRUTH
('33', 224, 8, 18, 526954) We did not conquer India for the benefit of the Indians.
('33', 224, 8, 19, 527011) I know it is said at missionary meetings that we conquered India to raise the level of the Indians.
('33', 224, 8, 20, 527111) That is cant.
('33', 224, 8, 21, 527125) We conquered India as the outlet for the goods of Great Britain.
('33', 224, 8, 22, 527190) We conquered India by the sword and by the sword we should hold it.
('33', 224, 8, 23, 527258) (“Shame!”) Call shame if you like.
('33', 224, 8, 24, 527293) I am stating facts.
('33', 224, 8, 25, 527313) I am interested in missionary work in India and have done much work of that kind, but I am not such a hypocrite as to say we hold India for the Indians.
('33', 224, 8, 26, 527466) We hold it as the finest outlet for British goods in general, and for Lancashire cotton goods in particular.
('33', 224, 9, 27, 527575) This is reported to have been said by Sir William Johnson Hicks.
('33', 224, 9, 28, 527640) But he is not the first minister to have reminded us of our serfdom.
('33', 224, 9, 29, 527709) Why should truth be at all unpalatable?
('33', 224, 9, 30, 527749) It must do us good to know ourselves as we are—destined to be hewers of wood and drawers of water for the benefit of whosoever will claim us by the prowess of his sword.
('33', 224, 9, 31, 527919) It is good, too, that due emphasis is laid on Lancashire goods.
('33', 224, 9, 32, 527983) The sword will be sheathed as soon as Manchester calico ceases to be saleable in India.
('33', 224, 9, 33, 528071) It is much more economical expeditious and possible to give up the use of Manchester and, therefore, foreign calico than to blunt the edge of Sir William’s

('33', 225, 2, 6, 528709) GOVERNMENT SERVANTS AND A.I.S.A.

('33', 225, 4, 16, 529955) PASSENGERS’ DAY
('33', 225, 5, 17, 529971) It is a good idea to observe a Passengers’ Day and review the progress of improvement in the condition of millions of passengers who use either the railways or the waterways connecting one part of India with another.
('33', 225, 5, 18, 530188) In my palmy days when I enjoyed the privilege of travelling 3rd class I used to have much to say about the condition of 3rd class passengers whether by rail or water.
('33', 225, 5, 19, 530355) 1 But, on the principle of ‘out of sight out of mind’, not experiencing in my own person the
('33', 225, 6, 20, 530448) 1Vide” Railway Passengers”, before 26 7 1916,” Letter to the Press on Third Class Travelling on Indian Railways”, 25 9 1917;” Letter to Commerce and Industries Secretary”, 31 10 1917.
('33', 226, 0, 1, 530632) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 227
('33', 226, 1, 2, 530683) difficulties of 3rd class railway travelling, I have ceased to write upon it.
('33', 226, 1, 3, 530761) But the forthcoming Passengers’ Day reminds one ofone’s duty towards the dumb millions who are packed like sardines in ill constructed, dirty compartments and whose wants nobody ever cares to look after.
('33', 226, 1, 4, 530965) The difficulites due to the indifference of railway authorities are however one part of the distress.
('33', 226, 1, 5, 531067) It would be well to lay stress upon that part; but the indifference and ignorance of the passengers themselves are almost equally responsible for their difficulties.
('33', 226, 1, 6, 531233) The speakers, therefore, at the meetings that would be held in different parts of the country would do well to emphasize the duty of passengers towards themselves.
('33', 226, 1, 7, 531397) Our insanitary habits, want of consideration for our neighbours, insistence upon getting into overcrowded compartments and a host of other bad habits must be removed before 3rd class railway travelling can be made bearable.
('33', 226, 1, 8, 531621) It requires great vigilance and there is risk of an association that deals with the internal aspect of the question even courting unpopularity in the initial stages.
('33', 226, 1, 9, 531787) I wish every success to the effort of Mr. Jivraj Nensey and his fellow organizers.

('33', 228, 2, 17, 537691) TREE PROTECTION
('33', 228, 3, 18, 537707) All religion is presumably in response to the human aspiration or need.

('33', 232, 2, 7, 544203) 127. OUR INSANITATION
('33', 232, 3, 8, 544225) During my wanderings nothing has been so painful to me as to observe our insanitation throughout the length and breadth of the land.
('33', 232, 3, 9, 544358) I do not believe in the use of force for carrying out reforms, but when I think of the time that must elapse before the ingrained habits of millions of people can be changed, I almost reconcile myself to compulsion in this the most important matter of insanitation.
('33', 232, 3, 10, 544624) Several diseases can be directly traced to insanitation.
('33', 232, 3, 11, 544681) Hookworm, for instance, is such a direct result.
('33', 232, 3, 12, 544730) Not a single human being who observes the elementary principles of sanitation need suffer from hookworm.
('33', 232, 3, 13, 544835) The disease is not even due to poverty.
('33', 232, 3, 14, 544875) The only reason is gross ignorance of the first principles of sanitation.
('33', 232, 3, 15, 544949) These reflections arise from the abominations I saw in Mandvi.
('33', 232, 3, 16, 545012) The people of Mandvi are not poor.
('33', 232, 3, 17, 545047) They cannot be classed as ignorant.
('33', 232, 3, 18, 545083) And yet their habits are dirty beyond description.
('33', 232, 3, 19, 545134) Men and women dirty the streets that they walk on with bare feet.
('33', 232, 3, 20, 545200) They do this every morning.
('33', 232, 3, 21, 545228) There is practically no such thing as a closet in that port.
('33', 232, 3, 22, 545289) It was with the greatest difficulty that I was able to pass through these streets.
('33', 232, 3, 23, 545372) Let me not be hard on the poor inhabitants of Mandvi.
('33', 232, 3, 24, 545426) I know that I saw nothing better in many streets of Madras.
('33', 232, 3, 25, 545486) The sight of grown up people lining the river banks and, after the performance, proceeding with criminal thoughtlessness to the river and cleaning themselves in it and injecting into its sacred water typhoid, cholera and dysentery germs has not yet faded from memory.

('33', 246, 1, 2, 575839) 138. A SILENCE DAY NOTE
('33', 246, 2, 3, 575863) [On or before November 24, 1925] 1
('33', 246, 3, 4, 575898) It is not usual for me to allow such things to appear in the pages of Young India.
('33', 246, 3, 5, 575981) Though much as I value the opinion of so great and so good a writer as Romain Rolland, I cannot afford to print his certificates.
('33', 246, 3, 6, 576111) But an accident is responsible for the publication of the foregoing as also premature introduction to the reader of Mirabai as we in the Ashram call Miss Madeleine Slade, more for the sake of the convenience of children and those many who do not know English than for anything else.
('33', 246, 3, 7, 576394) As an Indian name had to be chosen the one that best describes Miss Slade’s aspirations was chosen.
('33', 246, 3, 8, 576494) The accident happened this way.
('33', 246, 3, 9, 576526) As Mirabai was sitting by my bedside spinning her takli which she learnt the moment she took it in her hand, she pleadingly asked,” Can I not render some service to you during your fast?”” Oh yes, you can edit Young India for me this week,” I replied smilingly.
('33', 246, 3, 10, 576788) She said,” If you mean seriously I take up the challenge.” And an old man of India was beaten by a mere English girl.
('33', 246, 3, 11, 576906) She had to share the responsibility with Mahadev Desai for editing the current issue.
('33', 246, 3, 12, 576992) Hence the foregoing advertisement.
('33', 246, 3, 13, 577027) I had not the heart to reject it.
('33', 246, 3, 14, 577061) Let the reader know that I had not the strength to give anything original in its place.
('33', 246, 3, 15, 577149) I was loath to replace it with an admirable extract from Mr. Page’s pamphlet 2, which has been crowded out this week.
('33', 246, 4, 16, 577267) From the original: C.W. 5445. Courtesy: Mirabehn.
('33', 246, 4, 17, 577317) Also G.N. 9147

('33', 247, 3, 4, 577644) Don’t You Be Alarmed Irregularities on the part of many boys have necessitated my undertaking the lightest fast I can, that is, seven days.
('33', 247, 3, 5, 577784) If I could be sure of [your] not knowing about it at all till it was finished, I would certainly have kept the news from you till it was finished, but as so many people know locally that it is almost impossible to keep it from you.
('33', 247, 3, 6, 578016) I do not want you to run up to Sabarmati either.
('33', 247, 3, 7, 578065) But you must go straightaway to Kutch and restore yourself completely.
('33', 247, 3, 8, 578136) You may depend upon it that I have not taken this fast without much thought.
('33', 247, 3, 9, 578213) I have given two nights to it.
('33', 247, 3, 10, 578244) The first symptoms came upon me on Sunday 3 night.
('33', 247, 3, 11, 578295) I made the final decision this morning at the school prayer meeting.
('33', 247, 3, 12, 578364) I have become so much used to fasting that seven days is merely nothing, and I do not know that I shall not feel even physically the better for it in the end, as I certainly did after 21 days, fast 4. This letter is not only for you sisters but it is also for Mithubehn and Jaibehn.
('33', 247, 3, 13, 578647) I am not going to write to them separately, and I appoint you as my general agent to console all those who may out of false compassion unnecessarily disturb themselves.

('33', 251, 1, 2, 585091) 144. NOTES
('33', 251, 2, 3, 585102) A SILENT WORKER
('33', 251, 3, 4, 585118) No country possesses a record of the names of its noblest sons.
('33', 251, 3, 5, 585182) They are known only by their works like the authors of the most valuable ancient books.
('33', 251, 3, 6, 585270) There are many young men who die in the service of their country and yet remain unknown to fame.
('33', 251, 3, 7, 585367) I have received the news of the death of such a silent worker in the cause of khadi in Arambagh, Hooghly.
('33', 251, 3, 8, 585473) He and his friends went to one of the most malarial districts of Bengal first to tend and nurse the sick when an epidemic broke out in that district.
('33', 251, 3, 9, 585623) They remained there to develop khadi among and through its needy people.
('33', 251, 3, 10, 585696) This is what his friend and fellow worker writes about him: 1
('33', 251, 4, 11, 585758) It is with deep sorrow that I send you the news of the death of my .
('33', 251, 4, 12, 585827) friend .
('33', 251, 4, 13, 585836) Hazra .
('33', 251, 4, 14, 585844) the best worker of the centre.
('33', 251, 4, 15, 585875) He was the” nurse” of the centre....
('33', 251, 4, 16, 585912) He could spin well and was a weaver withal.
('33', 251, 4, 17, 585956) Now God takes him away for the higher grade service, and as you so beautifully wrote to me, for service to be rendered under” better auspices”.
('33', 251, 4, 18, 586100) He leaves behind him his parents and two younger brothers.
('33', 251, 5, 19, 586159) May this noble soul have peace and may his parents and brothers preserve the memory of the deceased by continuing the work left by him.
('33', 251, 5, 20, 586295) For Hazra I do believe that he has left the corruptible body having outgrown its use and has gone to a better state.
('33', 251, 6, 21, 586412) JUVENILE BRANCH
('33', 251, 7, 22, 586428) Little children have been writing to ask why they cannot become members even though they may be confirmed khadi weavers and be spinning most regularly.
('33', 251, 7, 23, 586580) Among these is a girl nine years old.
('33', 251, 7, 24, 586618) The proposition is being seriously considered to form a juvenile branch.
('33', 251, 7, 25, 586691) I am now engaged in wooing a little girl to take the lead and trying to secure her parents’ permission to form such a branch.
('33', 251, 7, 26, 586817) It would be useless to form it, if only a few boys and girls come forward.
('33', 251, 7, 27, 586892) It would be worth while only if many parents co operate to make it a success.
('33', 251, 7, 28, 586970) Every school, government or national, can help the movement which has been made purposely non political.
('33', 251, 7, 29, 587075) No one need fight shy of itwho does not dread the political consequence of khadi, viz., the
('33', 251, 8, 30, 587167) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('33', 252, 0, 1, 587204) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 253
('33', 252, 1, 2, 587255) displacing through it of foreign cloth.
('33', 252, 1, 3, 587295) The juvenile branch, if it comes into being, will be a true league of mercy to bind little children to an act of sacrifice for the sake of the famishing millions.
('33', 252, 2, 4, 587458) THE WHY OF IT
('33', 252, 3, 5, 587472) An American friend sent me sometime ago a pamphlet written by Mr. Page with an introduction by Mr. Harry Emerson Fosdick.
('33', 252, 3, 6, 587594) It is an illuminating essay on the causes of the late world War.
('33', 252, 3, 7, 587659) An examination of the causes of that great upheaval will never be considered stale and as these have been compressed in a closely reasoned pamphlet of 89 pages octavo, I make no apology for reproducing some of the most telling extracts from it.
('33', 252, 3, 8, 587904) The author who appears to be an earnest Christian seeker divides the causes under five heads—economic imperialism, militarism, alliances secret diplomacies, fear.
('33', 252, 3, 9, 588067) Under the first head he remarks: 1
('33', 252, 4, 10, 588102) The extracts 2 regarding the other four causes will be reproduced later as space permits.
('33', 252, 4, 11, 588192) The following is the second instalment of the causes of the Great War from Mr. Page’s pamphlet.
('33', 252, 4, 12, 588288) I had not the heart to remove anything save the footnotes.
('33', 252, 5, 13, 588347) I give below the next instalment from Mr. Page’s illuminating pamphlet without removing a single word except the footnotes.
('33', 252, 6, 14, 588471) Mr. Page thus concludes his chapter on the losses of the war.
('33', 252, 7, 15, 588533) In the concluding chapter of his pamphlet Mr. Page discusses the methods of preventing war.
('33', 252, 7, 16, 588625) The reader will find the writer weak in his statement of remedies, not because he is weak in his belief, but because it is new ground for everybody.
('33', 252, 7, 17, 588774) Nobody wants war.
('33', 252, 7, 18, 588792) But how can an age long institution be easily destroyed?
('33', 252, 7, 19, 588849) Is it at all possible to do away with it?
('33', 252, 7, 20, 588891) Let us listen to what the author has to say.
('33', 252, 7, 21, 588936) He suggests five measures.
('33', 252, 7, 22, 588963) I present to the reader the first of them in this issue of Young India 6.

('33', 252, 8, 24, 589288) For dates of the instalments, vide Appendix” Swaraj or Death”, 27 8 1925.

('33', 253, 0, 1, 589503) 254 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 253, 1, 2, 589545) His last chapter is called by Mr. Page” What Shall the Churches Do about War?” I have given it a name more suited to thereaders of Young India.
('33', 253, 1, 3, 589689) 1 They will note that much of Mr. Page’s argument applies to all religions.
('33', 253, 1, 4, 589765) In the sections into which Chapter IV is divided Mr. Page has examined in his own able manner the different reasons summarized by him, the first being” War is inherently and essentially a supreme violation of Jesus’ way of life”.
('33', 253, 1, 5, 589995) Though for the orthodox Christian there is much in the section that is worth reading, the average reader will not understand the reference summarized by the writer.
('33', 253, 1, 6, 590160) But the writer shows that modern war is a calamity which no man with any moral sense can contemplate with equanimity and quotes the following from Winston S. Churchill’s writings:
('33', 253, 2, 7, 590340) It differed from all ancient wars in the immense power of the
('33', 253, 3, 8, 590402) combatants and their fearful agencies of destruction.
('33', 253, 3, 9, 590456) Torture and
('33', 253, 4, 10, 590468) cannibalism were the only two expedients that the civilized, scientific,
('33', 253, 5, 11, 590541) Christian States had been able to deny themselves.
('33', 253, 5, 12, 590592) The second reason why men of religion should oppose war is that it is” ineffective as a means of furthering Christ’s Kingdom and is self defeating in its very nature” and he proceeds.
('33', 253, 6, 13, 590776) We are now nearing the end of Mr. Page’s valuable pamphlet.
('33', 253, 6, 14, 590836) I omit the last three sections as not being sufficiently interesting for the readers of Young India.
('33', 253, 6, 15, 590937) The third section of the last chapter is an attempt to show that” the absolute repudiation of war by individuals, groups and corporate bodies is the most effective way of compelling Governments to abandon the war system and to discover more ade quate means of securing safety and justice”.
('33', 253, 6, 16, 591227) The following paragraphs are useful for all religiously minded men and for all reform.
('33', 253, 7, 17, 591314) Young India, 26 11 1925

('33', 254, 0, 1, 591464) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 255
('33', 254, 1, 2, 591515) 145. INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA
('33', 254, 2, 3, 591544) The departure of C. F. Andrews for South Africa, the impending departure of the Government of India deputation and the impending arrival of a deputation to India headed by Dr. Abdur Rahman make the South African question the question of the hour.
('33', 254, 2, 4, 591791) For the Indian settlers it is a question of life and death.
('33', 254, 2, 5, 591851) The Union Government seem to be determined to put an end to Indian existence in South Africa not by straightforward means offorcible expulsion but by the dishonest process of squeezing.
('33', 254, 2, 6, 592037) The proposed legislation practically deprives them of all the honourable avenues of earning and by so doing it seeks to deprive them of every shred of self respect.
('33', 254, 2, 7, 592202) The Union Government will cease to be troubled about the Indian question when they have ceased to be troubled by the presence in their midst of self respecting and independent Indians and have to deal only with labourers, waiters, cooks and the like.
('33', 254, 2, 8, 592453) They want a few servants, they do not want equals, fellow farmers or fellow traders.
('33', 254, 2, 9, 592538) The answer therefore returned by the Union Government to the Indian deputation that waited on them is not surprising.
('33', 254, 2, 10, 592656) They have avowed their determination to proceed with the proposed legislation.
('33', 254, 2, 11, 592735) They will only consider” constructive suggestions” in details.
('33', 254, 2, 12, 592798) They have not made up their minds about a round table conference.
('33', 254, 2, 13, 592864) I expect a great deal from Mr. Andrews’ presence in South Africa if the settlers show firmness and cohesion among themselves.
('33', 254, 2, 14, 592990) The Government of India deputation can do much if they have instructions not to yield on fundamentals.
('33', 254, 2, 15, 593093) No repatriation and no curtailment, at the very least, of rights existing at the time of the Settlement of 1914. The proposed legislation is a deprivation of these rights.
('33', 254, 2, 16, 593265) Anyone who knows anything of the condition of South Africa knows that there is no real active opposition on the part of the mass of the European population to the presence of the Indian settlers.
('33', 254, 2, 17, 593461) If there was, the overwhelmingly large European population would without legislative aid make it impossible for the Indian settler to remain in South Africa.
('33', 254, 2, 18, 593619) Nor is the original population of South Africa hostile to the settlers.
('33', 254, 2, 19, 593691) It is because the general European and Native population is not only not ill disposed towards the Indian settler but willingly and
('33', 255, 0, 1, 593822) 256 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 255, 1, 2, 593864) freely deals with him that he can at all live there.
('33', 255, 1, 3, 593917) The proposed legislation is an attempt to interfere with the free mercantile intercourse between Europeans and Natives on the one hand and Indians on the other.
('33', 255, 1, 4, 594078) If therefore the Government of India take up a firm attitude the Union Government’s case must fall to pieces.
('33', 255, 1, 5, 594188) The legitimate fear of being swamped by India’s millions having been removed in 1914 the Union Government were in honour bound to grant and guarantee to the resident Indian population full rights of inter migration, trade and ownership of land.

('33', 258, 1, 2, 600160) 149. ‘0UR TIME A TRUST!’ 1
('33', 258, 2, 3, 600187) Often in these columns have I reported Gandhiji having said to various audiences on various occasions that our time is a trust.
('33', 258, 2, 4, 600315) But the lesson was burnt deep into me the other day only when I myself happened to be the offender.
('33', 258, 2, 5, 600415) I have often laughed at these people’s expense.
('33', 258, 2, 6, 600463) Let them laugh today at mine.
('33', 258, 2, 7, 600493) Outwardly it is a story of how I began and ended the study of French....
('33', 258, 2, 8, 600566) I asked my teacher [Miss Madeleine Slade] whether Gandhiji knew that I had begun French.
('33', 258, 2, 9, 600655) She said, he did and that” he was amused and surprised.”” Surprised” gave me a sort of alarm and I began to imagine in my mind what was coming.
('33', 258, 2, 10, 600799) And scarcely had I finished the second lesson when the message came that I was wanted by Gandhiji.
('33', 258, 2, 11, 600898) I went, of course, in fear and trembling, though hardly prepared for all that followed.
('33', 258, 2, 12, 600986) There was some casual inquiry and I thought only my consciencehad made a coward of me.
('33', 258, 2, 13, 601073) But no.
('33', 258, 2, 14, 601081) The storm came almost as soon as I had begun to re assure myself.” So you have begun French?”, he asked, smiling, disguising all his indignation.
('33', 258, 2, 15, 601227) I smiled an affirmative answer.
('33', 258, 2, 16, 601259) I thought, when she was making the appointment with you yesterday, that you were going to her to give her a lesson in Hindi.
('33', 258, 2, 17, 601384) But she told me this morning, as I asked her how she had spent her time, that she gave you a French lesson for an hour.
('33', 258, 2, 18, 601504) Do you know what I told her?
('33', 258, 3, 19, 601533) “Yes,” I said,” she told me you were amused and surprised.”
('33', 258, 4, 20, 601593) Well then, I tell you what I said.
('33', 258, 4, 21, 601628) I said Caesar aimed at the crown and failed!
('33', 258, 5, 22, 601673) And then began a volley of questions.
('33', 258, 6, 23, 601711) What have you begun learning French for?
('33', 258, 6, 24, 601752) Because Miss Slade, a French scholar, is here?
('33', 258, 6, 25, 601799) Or you want to read Romain Rolland in French?
('33', 258, 6, 26, 601845) Or to read our French correspondence?
('33', 258, 7, 27, 601883) No, I have been long wanting to learn French.
('33', 258, 7, 28, 601929) French knowing friends told me that it was easy to learn the language, and useful too.
('33', 258, 7, 29, 602016) Well, do you know that not all Englishmen know French, and the best of them are content to read the French authors in translations?
('33', 258, 7, 30, 602148) And much of the best French literature is turned into English as soon as it is published.
('33', 258, 8, 31, 602238) There was a pause for a minute or two.

('33', 260, 4, 17, 604890) 150. SLAUGHTER AND SHOES
('33', 260, 5, 18, 604915) We present to the reader below some illuminating extracts 1 from the Minutes of Evidence recorded by the Indian Industrial Commission in Bengal and the Central Provinces which throw a flood of light upon the subject and serve to establish beyond the shadow of a doubt that the quality shoes which we wear as well as the pretty attache cases we proudly carry in our hands and the ponderous suit cases in which we pack our precious clothing, be it khadi, mill made or foreign, are tarnished with the blood of innocent cattle, although we will be so blind as not to see it; and if there is any such thing as a moral government of the universe, we must answer for it some day.
('33', 260, 5, 19, 605588) The foregoing extracts have been culled and copied verbatim by Sri.
('33', 260, 5, 20, 605656) [V. G.] Desai from the voluminous evidence recorded by the Industrial Commission.
('33', 260, 5, 21, 605738) If they move the reader he must become a member of the All India Cow Protection Association (Sabarmati), or if he can afford to pay more, he should send a donation so as to enable it to carry out the scheme adumbrated in these pages regarding tanneries where the hides of dead cattle only shall be manufactured into leather.

('33', 261, 8, 9, 606349) DEAR DR.

('33', 261, 8, 11, 606386) Do you not see any difference between a cable to the President of the League of Nations and Council work?
('33', 261, 8, 12, 606492) Personally I am as much opposed to Council entry as I ever was.
('33', 261, 8, 13, 606556) You may depend upon it that my part in the Patna Resolution was a matter of necessity and not of choice.
('33', 261, 8, 14, 606661) Necessity in the sense that I recognize the democratic character of the Congress.
('33', 261, 8, 15, 606743) And knowing that I could not convince the Swarajists of the error of Council entry and knowing also that my best friends and co workers had become Swarajists, I took it that I could not do less than throw my weight with them as against other political parties.
('33', 261, 8, 16, 607004) Thus though I would personally dislike my appeal to the League of Nations while we were impotent, if there were two parties one wanting to approve of the French atrocity and another wanting to help the sufferers, I would throw in my weight with the latter.
('33', 261, 8, 17, 607261) You do not know how much people have strayed away from the true path.
('33', 261, 8, 18, 607331) What is the use of making myself ludicrous when I know that I would get no more than Rs. 100/ in answer to my appeal.
('33', 261, 8, 19, 607449) I am sick unto death over the unreality and untruth that surrounds us at the present moment.
('33', 261, 8, 20, 607542) Please therefore forget me for any other work than the humble work of khadi and untouchability and the unpopular method of protecting the cow.
('33', 261, 8, 21, 607685) I confess my utter inability to tackle successfully any other problem.

('33', 262, 3, 4, 607921) November 26, 1925
('33', 262, 4, 5, 607939) DEAR FRIEND, I have your printed letter.
('33', 262, 4, 6, 607980) My own conviction is that the prisoners will lose nothing by giving the undertaking asked for.
('33', 262, 4, 7, 608075) In my opinion, the Gurdwara Act is a tremendous step in advance and it is gained by the determined resistance of the Sikhs, and when the central point is gained, the undertaking, which I believe is in itself harmless, is a matter of little concern.
('33', 262, 4, 8, 608324) But if the prisoners remain adamant and refuse to give any undertaking whatsoever, they have a perfect right to do so.
('33', 262, 4, 9, 608443) But then, we must not grumble for the sufferings that they might have to undergo.
('33', 262, 4, 10, 608525) It is also my opinion that if they endure persecution long enough in refusing compliance with the Government conditions, the prisoners would be released.
('33', 262, 4, 11, 608679) But what I will not do myself, I must not commend to the public.
('33', 262, 4, 12, 608744) If I write anything publicly, I should write advising waiving of the conditions.
('33', 262, 4, 13, 608825) But if the prisoners decline to give the undertaking, they will have my passive praise for their sufferings.

('33', 262, 7, 16, 609062) 154. LETTER TO RASIK
('33', 262, 8, 17, 609083) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, Thursday, Ma[gsar] Sud 11 [November 26, 1925] 1
('33', 262, 9, 18, 609161) BHAISHRI RASIK, Herewith answers to your questions: 1. There is nothing wrong in the shraddha ceremony performed after death, and it may be regarded as essential for thosewho believe in it.
('33', 262, 9, 19, 609351) It is quite proper that you will not give a community feast.
('33', 262, 9, 20, 609412) I regard
('33', 262, 10, 21, 609421) 1 The source has the entry,” 4 2 1925”, but the day and the date do not tally.
('33', 263, 0, 1, 609500) 264 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 263, 1, 2, 609542) it as neither necessary nor proper.
('33', 263, 1, 3, 609578) Unlike the shraddha ceremony it is devoid of any religious sentiment.
('33', 263, 1, 4, 609648) If your mother asks you to feast the community after her death, you should humbly suggest to her not to bind you with such a wish.
('33', 263, 1, 5, 609779) If she still insists on it, you should feed some invalids with the amount which might have been thus spent or hand over the sum to the community for utilizing it as a scholarship for some needy student.
('33', 263, 1, 6, 609982) 2. If you really do not want to get married and if your mother importunes you, you should humbly resist the pressure.
('33', 263, 1, 7, 610100) I think parents have no right to marry their children against the latter’s wishes.
('33', 263, 1, 8, 610183) 3. And the simple diet you take will help you in your practice of brahmacharya.
('33', 263, 1, 9, 610263) But for checking impure thoughts you should make ceaseless efforts with absolute devotion to God, in the form of recitation of Ramanama and should harness your mental as well as physical energies to some benevolent activity or to some honest profession.
('33', 263, 1, 10, 610517) 4. You simply cannot serve in a place where you are required to utter falsehood or practise deceit, even if this means starvation or ruin of your family.
('33', 263, 1, 11, 610671) It is on this account that I have often maintained that a person desirous of staying free should teach himself some independent craft as weaving and the like and subsist on that.
('33', 263, 1, 12, 610850) In my opinion it is absolutely not binding to support an able bodied member of the family.
('33', 263, 1, 13, 610941) 5. To a certain extent physical strength and spiritual strength are necessarily related.
('33', 263, 1, 14, 611030) We do come across some instances where an extremely dynamic soul dwells in an extremely feeble body.
('33', 263, 1, 15, 611131) But if the body is worn out with disease the soul too usually loses its vigour.
('33', 263, 1, 16, 611211) 6. There is no harm in taking milk and ghee to acquire a reasonable amount of physical strength.
('33', 263, 2, 17, 611308) Vandemataram from
('33', 263, 3, 18, 611326) MOHANDAS KARAMCHAND GANDHI

('33', 265, 6, 8, 613012) 158. THE VINAY MANDIR AT ODE
('33', 265, 7, 9, 613041) Is there anyone who is not pained by reading this note?
('33', 265, 7, 10, 613097) 3 I at any rate am very much pained, as I have very pleasant memories of ode.
('33', 265, 7, 11, 613175) I cannot forget the enthusiasm displayed by its residents.
('33', 265, 7, 12, 613234) What a contrast between that ode and the one described by Mahadev Desai.
('33', 265, 7, 13, 613307) Its Vinay Mandir counts among the better national schools.
('33', 265, 7, 14, 613366) It has many pupils and able teachers.
('33', 265, 7, 15, 613404) The people of Ode have money; how sad that, despite all this, even the funds already collected for the school are not being used and those who established it, no longer wish to see it continue its existence!
('33', 265, 7, 16, 613612) But, then, can anyone win over people whose only concern is self interest?

('33', 265, 7, 18, 613780) Whatever the standard of a national school, where else will the pupils get the education for freedom which it provides?
('33', 265, 7, 19, 613900) Will the leaders of Ode wake up even now and save a school which can still be rescued without much effort?

('33', 266, 1, 2, 614272) 159. INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA
('33', 266, 2, 3, 614301) The problem of Indians in South Africa is attracting increasing public attention, for, while Mr. Andrews will be soon leaving for South Africa, the emissaries of the Government would have been able to leave for that country before this appears in print and, from the other side, the representatives of the Indians there will shortly be here.
('33', 266, 2, 4, 614643) Public attention, therefore, is bound to be drawn to this problem.
('33', 266, 3, 5, 614710) A sword is hanging over the heads of the Indian settlers in South Africa.
('33', 266, 3, 6, 614784) The Government there does not have the courage to forcibly expel the Indians in a direct and straightforward manner, but is planning indirectly to make them leave South Africa by harassing them.
('33', 266, 3, 7, 614979) If any of the Indians remain behind, there would be a handful employed in various capacities, whose presence the whites desire, such as, for instance, the farm labourers, cooks and bearers.
('33', 266, 3, 8, 615169) The rest, independent Indians, businessmen and others, who have a sense of self respect and cherish it, would not continue to live there even for an hour under the conditions which Government wishes to create, for under the new Bill it seeks to deprive these Indians of all their present rights in regard to ownership of land, trade and interprovincial movement.
('33', 266, 3, 9, 615532) Indians would have nothing to fear if a judicial settlement of the problem were sought.
('33', 266, 3, 10, 615620) There will be no need, then, for any emissary from here to proceed to South Africa or any representative from there to come here.
('33', 266, 3, 11, 615750) Any unbiased judge would rule in favour of the Indians, with costs.
('33', 266, 4, 12, 615818) However, they wish to follow the law of the sword, of brute force.
('33', 266, 4, 13, 615885) They do not wish to respect the principle of equal rights for all, their principle is that might is right.
('33', 266, 4, 14, 615992) The British Government will tolerate even injustice perpetrated by the Government of South Africa; at the most it will plead with the Union Government for a little mitigation of it, and, if the request is not heeded, it will remain quiet.
('33', 266, 4, 15, 616231) If South Africa is in the British Empire, it is through the grace of the whites.
('33', 266, 4, 16, 616312) While in the case of India even experienced Englishmen believe that she is held in the Empire by the sword of the latter, and that is on the whole true.
('33', 266, 4, 17, 616465) If the whites of South Africa chose they could leave the British Empire right now.
('33', 266, 4, 18, 616548) The slaves in India, however much they might like to, cannot leave the Empire without the consent of the British Government.
('33', 266, 4, 19, 616673) This being the trueposition, the Indians,in
('33', 267, 0, 1, 616717) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 267, 1, 2, 616759) South Africa, too, can remain there only through the goodwill of the government there.
('33', 267, 1, 3, 616846) India, who is herself a prisoner, can give only as much help to the Indian prisoners in South Africa as one prisoner can give to another.
('33', 267, 1, 4, 616984) Under such unhappy conditions, every Indian must depend on his own determined effort to win his own freedom.
('33', 267, 1, 5, 617093) Only if the Indians in South Africa can put forward such an effort, can act, though slaves, as if they were free, can they hope to be delivered.
('33', 267, 1, 6, 617238) How long can one live on the goodwill of others?
('33', 267, 1, 7, 617287) Goodwill cannot be assured through documents.
('33', 267, 1, 8, 617333) Once it vanishes, even documents which may have been signed are trampled under foot.
('33', 267, 1, 9, 617418) Nevertheless, India must do all she can.
('33', 267, 1, 10, 617459) It is our duty to welcome the representatives from South Africa who are due to arrive here and help them to the best of our ability.
('33', 267, 1, 11, 617592) To discharge this duty is the least we can do.
('33', 267, 2, 12, 617639) The guests who will be arriving include Dr. Abdur Rahman, who is a
('33', 267, 3, 13, 617706) well known Malay doctor from Cape Town.
('33', 267, 3, 14, 617746) He has Indian blood too.
('33', 267, 3, 15, 617771) The second
('33', 267, 4, 16, 617782) member is James Godfrey, a barrister and son of an Indian Christian school teacher.
('33', 267, 5, 17, 617866) The third member is Sorabji, the brave son of the late Parsi Rustomji.
('33', 267, 5, 18, 617937) He is a tried soldier and has been to prison.
('33', 267, 5, 19, 617983) Those who have read the History of Satyagraha in
('33', 267, 6, 20, 618032) South Africa will be familiar with his name.
('33', 267, 6, 21, 618077) I pray that their visit and their efforts may meet with success.
('33', 267, 7, 22, 618142) [From Gujarati].
('33', 267, 8, 23, 618159) Navajivan, 29 11 1925
('33', 267, 9, 24, 618181) 160. THE LATEST FAST
('33', 267, 10, 25, 618202) November 30, 1925 This the latest (seven days) fast of mine which is closing tomorrow morning could not be kept from the public in spite of my attempt to the contrary.
('33', 267, 10, 26, 618370) It has brought many inquiries and some angry protests.
('33', 267, 10, 27, 618425) The public may rest perfectly at ease about my health.
('33', 267, 10, 28, 618480) It is something for me to be able to write this myself on the seventh day of my fast.
('33', 267, 10, 29, 618566) But by the time this is in the hands of the reader, I hope to be almost up and doing.
('33', 267, 10, 30, 618652) The alarm was felt on the fourth day when I was much exhausted with work.
('33', 267, 10, 31, 618726) In my vanity I had thought that during the comparatively brief fast, I would be able to work all the fullseven days.
('33', 267, 10, 32, 618843) In fairness to myself I must say that much of the work I did
('33', 268, 0, 1, 618904) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 269
('33', 268, 1, 2, 618955) during the three and a half days was inevitable as it was connected with the object of the fast.
('33', 268, 1, 3, 619052) But as soon as I realized that I had overworked myself, I stopped all work, and on the last day I am stronger than on the fourth.
('33', 268, 2, 4, 619182) But the public will have to neglect my fasts and cease to worry about them.
('33', 268, 2, 5, 619258) They are a part of my being.
('33', 268, 2, 6, 619287) I can as well do without my eyes, for instance, as I can without fasts.
('33', 268, 2, 7, 619359) What the eyes are for the outer world, fasts are for the inner.
('33', 268, 2, 8, 619423) And much as I should like the latest fast to be the very last in my life, something within me tells me that I might have to go through many such ordeals and, who knows, much more trying.
('33', 268, 2, 9, 619610) I may be wholly wrong.
('33', 268, 2, 10, 619633) Then the world will be able to write an epitaph over my ashes: ‘Well deserved thou fool.’ But for the time being my error, if it be one, must sustain me.
('33', 268, 2, 11, 619787) Is it not better that I satisfy my conscience though misguided, because not perfectly pure, than that I should listen to every voice, be it ever so friendly but by no means infallible?
('33', 268, 2, 12, 619972) If I had a guru,—and I am looking for one,—I should surrender myself body and soul to him.
('33', 268, 2, 13, 620063) But in this age of unbelief a true guru is hard to find.
('33', 268, 2, 14, 620120) A substitute will be worse than useless, often positively harmful.
('33', 268, 2, 15, 620187) I must therefore warn all against accepting imperfect ones as gurus.
('33', 268, 2, 16, 620256) It is better to grope in the dark and wade through a million errors to Truth than to entrust oneself to one who” knows not that he knows not”.
('33', 268, 2, 17, 620399) Has a man ever learnt swimming by tying a stone to his neck?
('33', 268, 2, 18, 620460) And who shall lose by erroneous fasting?
('33', 268, 2, 19, 620501) of course only myself.
('33', 268, 2, 20, 620524) But I am public property, it is said.
('33', 268, 2, 21, 620562) So be it.
('33', 268, 2, 22, 620572) But I must be taken with all my faults.
('33', 268, 2, 23, 620612) I am a searcher after truth.
('33', 268, 2, 24, 620641) My experiments I hold to be infinitely more important than the best equipped Himalayan expeditions.
('33', 268, 2, 25, 620741) And the results?
('33', 268, 2, 26, 620758) If the search is scientific, surely there is no comparison between the two.
('33', 268, 2, 27, 620834) Let me therefore go my way.
('33', 268, 2, 28, 620862) I shall lose my usefulness the moment I stifle the still small voice within.
('33', 268, 3, 29, 620939) Well, this fast has nothing to do with the public.
('33', 268, 3, 30, 620990) I am conducting a big institution called the Satyagraha Ashram.
('33', 268, 3, 31, 621054) Trusting friends have given me already over two lacs of rupees for land and buildings alone.
('33', 268, 3, 32, 621147) They are paying for its annual upkeep not less than eighteen thousand rupees per year.
('33', 268, 3, 33, 621234) They do so in the hope that I am building up character.
('33', 268, 3, 34, 621290) There are grown up men and women in the Ashram.
('33', 268, 3, 35, 621338) There are boys and girls.
('33', 268, 3, 36, 621364) The latter are trained to remain unmarried as long as possible.
('33', 268, 3, 37, 621428) At no place within my knowledge do women andgirls enjoy so much freedom as at the Ashram.
('33', 268, 3, 38, 621518) It is my best and only
('33', 269, 0, 1, 621541) 270 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 269, 1, 2, 621583) creation.
('33', 269, 1, 3, 621593) The world will judge me by its results.
('33', 269, 1, 4, 621633) No man or woman, no boy or girl can live there, if I do not want them.
('33', 269, 1, 5, 621704) I believe that it contains some of the purest characters we have in India.
('33', 269, 1, 6, 621779) If I am to deserve the implicit trust of friends who support it, I must be doubly vigilant, since they will neither examine the accounts, nor the activity of the Ashram.
('33', 269, 1, 7, 621949) I discovered errors among the boys and somewhat among the girls.
('33', 269, 1, 8, 622014) I know that hardly a school or any other institution is free from the errors I am referring to.
('33', 269, 1, 9, 622110) I am anxious to see the Ashram free from errors which are sapping the manhood of the nation and undermining the character of the youth.
('33', 269, 1, 10, 622246) It was not permissible to punish the boys.
('33', 269, 1, 11, 622289) Experience gained in two schools under my control.
('33', 269, 1, 12, 622340) has taught me that punishment does not purify, if anything it hardens children.
('33', 269, 1, 13, 622420) In such cases in South Africa I have resorted to fasts with, in my opinion, the best of results.
('33', 269, 1, 14, 622517) I have resorted to the same process here and let me say of a milder type.
('33', 269, 1, 15, 622591) The basis of the action is mutual love.
('33', 269, 1, 16, 622631) I know that I possess the love of the boys and the girls.
('33', 269, 1, 17, 622689) I know too that if the giving up of my life can make them spotless, it would be my supreme joy to give it.
('33', 269, 1, 18, 622796) Therefore I could do no less to bring the youngsters to a sense of their error.
('33', 269, 1, 19, 622876) So far the results seem to be promising.
('33', 269, 1, 20, 622917) What however if I cannot perceive the fruit?
('33', 269, 1, 21, 622962) I can but do the will of God as I feel it The result is in His disposing.
('33', 269, 1, 22, 623036) This suffering for things great and small is the keynote of satyagraha.
('33', 269, 1, 23, 623108) But why should not the teachers perform the penance?
('33', 269, 1, 24, 623161) They cannot, so long as I remain the chief.
('33', 269, 1, 25, 623205) If they had fasted with me all work would have come to a standstill.
('33', 269, 1, 26, 623274) As with big institutions so with small ones.
('33', 269, 1, 27, 623319) As the king must share the sins of his subjects even as he arrogates to himself all their virtues so must I, a tiny chosen king in the little Ashram, atone for the sins of the least among the children of the Ashram, if I may proudly claim the presence in it of many noble characters.
('33', 269, 1, 28, 623603) If I am to identify myself with the grief of the least in India, aye, if I have the power, the least in the world, let me identify myself with the sins of the little ones who are under my care.
('33', 269, 1, 29, 623797) And so doing in all humility I hope some day to see God—Truth—face to face.
('33', 269, 2, 30, 623873) Young India, 3 12 1925
('33', 270, 0, 1, 623896) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 271
('33', 270, 1, 2, 623947) 161. THE CURSE OF UNTOUCHABILITY
('33', 270, 2, 3, 623980) Mahatma Gandhi writes to The survey (America) of December 1, 1925:
('33', 270, 3, 4, 624047) The movement for the removal of untouchability in India is one of purification of Hinduism—a religion that is professed by nearly two hundred and forty million human beings.
('33', 270, 3, 5, 624221) It is estimated that over forty million human beings are regarded as untouchables.
('33', 270, 3, 6, 624304) This untouchability takes in the Southern parts of India the extreme form even of unapproachability and invisibility.
('33', 270, 3, 7, 624422) Untouchability is refraining on the part of the so called higher classes from touching those who are branded with the stigma of untouchability.
('33', 270, 3, 8, 624566) Unapproa chable are those whose approach within a stipulated distance pollutes the higher classes.
('33', 270, 3, 9, 624665) The invisibles are those whose very sight defiles.
('33', 270, 3, 10, 624716) These outcastes of Hindu society are confined to what may be fitly described as ghettos.
('33', 270, 3, 11, 624805) They are denied the usual services that in a well ordered society are regarded as the right of every human being, such for instance as medical aid, the offices of barbers, washermen, etc.
('33', 270, 3, 12, 624993) This suppression of a large number of human beings has left an indelible mark on the suppressors themselves and the canker of untouchability, is eating into the vitals of Hinduism, so much so that it has degraded what was at one time a noble institution.
('33', 270, 3, 13, 625248) I mean varnashrama, falsely or perhaps loosely rendered as caste.
('33', 270, 3, 14, 625314) What was meant to be a scientific division of labour and occupation has become an elaborate system regulating inter dining and intermarriage.
('33', 270, 3, 15, 625456) one of the noblest religions on earth has been reduced to a farcical code of dining and marriage rules.
('33', 270, 3, 16, 625560) Why then do I cling to a religion which tolerates such a curse?.
('33', 270, 3, 17, 625625) For the simple reason that I do not regard it as an integral part of Hinduism which is described as the religion par excellence of truth and non violence or love.
('33', 270, 3, 18, 625788) I have tried to understand the Hindu scriptures, some in the originals, the rest through translations.
('33', 270, 3, 19, 625891) I have tried in my humble way to live up to the teachings of that religion.
('33', 270, 3, 20, 625967) After having studied Christianity, Islam and other great faiths of the world, I have found in Hinduism my highest comfort.
('33', 270, 3, 21, 626090) I have not found any to be perfect.
('33', 270, 3, 22, 626126) I have discovered superstition and error in the practice of all these faiths.
('33', 270, 3, 23, 626204) It is enough therefore for me that I do not believe in untouchability.
('33', 270, 3, 24, 626275) I can certainly find no warrant in theHindu scriptures for the belief that a simple person becomes
('33', 271, 0, 1, 626374) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 271, 1, 2, 626416) untouchable by reason of his birth in a particular family or clan.
('33', 271, 1, 3, 626483) But if I must call myself a Hindu, as I do, I owe it to my faith as I owe it to my country to fight the evil of untouchability with my whole soul, counting no cost too much for achieving the reform.
('33', 271, 1, 4, 626682) Let not the reader imagine that I am the only reformer.
('33', 271, 1, 5, 626738) There are hundreds of educated Indians, who take pride in calling themselves Hindus, fighting the evil with all their might.
('33', 271, 1, 6, 626863) It is the accepted creed of the enlightened Hindus that swaraj is unattainable without the removal of the curse.
('33', 271, 1, 7, 626976) The way we are combating the sin is to demonstrate to the so called higher classes the enormity of the wrong, and passing resolutions at mass meetings condemning the practice.
('33', 271, 1, 8, 627152) The Congress has made the reform an integral part of its programme.
('33', 271, 1, 9, 627220) The reformers seek also to improve the condition of the suppressed classes by opening schools for their children, digging wells for them, pointing out to them the bad habits they have contracted through the criminal neglect of the higher classes, and so forth.
('33', 271, 1, 10, 627481) Whenever it is found necessary as at Vaikam (Vykom) even the direct method of satyagraha is being adopted.
('33', 271, 1, 11, 627588) In no case is violence offered to blind orthodoxy but an attempt is being made to win them over by patient argument and loving service.
('33', 271, 1, 12, 627724) The reformers suffer for their cause without imposing suffering on their opponents.
('33', 271, 1, 13, 627808) My conviction is that the effort is bearing fruit and that before long Hinduism will have purified itself of the sin of untouchability.
('33', 271, 2, 14, 627944) The Hindu, 19 1 1926
('33', 271, 3, 15, 627965) 162. SPEECH TO STUDENTS
('33', 271, 4, 16, 627989) December 1, 1925
('33', 271, 5, 17, 628006) Before breaking his fast on the morning of the 1st December, he gathered the boys to his bed side and delivered the following message in slow, moving accents:
('33', 271, 6, 18, 628165) Think of last Tuesday, when I began my fast.
('33', 271, 6, 19, 628210) Why did I take that step?
('33', 271, 6, 20, 628236) There were three ways open to me: 1. PUNISHMENT: I could have followed the easy road of corporal punishment.
('33', 271, 6, 21, 628345) Usually a teacher on detecting errors on the part of pupils would flatter himself with having done a good thing if he punished them.
('33', 271, 6, 22, 628478) I have been a teacher myself, thoughmy
('33', 272, 0, 1, 628517) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 273
('33', 272, 1, 2, 628568) preoccupations prevent me from teaching you during these days.
('33', 272, 1, 3, 628631) As a teacher I had no option but to reject this accepted method for I know by experience it is futile and even harmful.
('33', 272, 1, 4, 628751) 2. INDIFFERENCE: I could have left you to your fate.
('33', 272, 1, 5, 628804) Not unoften does a teacher do so.
('33', 272, 1, 6, 628838) ‘It is enough’, he argues, ‘that the boys do their lessons tolerably well and reproduce what they are taught.
('33', 272, 1, 7, 628948) Surely I am not concerned with their private behaviour.
('33', 272, 1, 8, 629004) And even if I was, how am I to keep watch over them?’ This indifference could not appeal to me.
('33', 272, 1, 9, 629100) 3. The third was the method of Love.
('33', 272, 1, 10, 629137) Your character is to me a sacred trust.
('33', 272, 1, 11, 629177) I must therefore try to enter into your lives, your innermost thoughts, your desires and your impulses, and help you to detect and eradicate impurities, if any.
('33', 272, 1, 12, 629338) For inward cleanliness is the first thing that should be taught, other things must follow after the first and most important lesson has gone home.
('33', 272, 1, 13, 629485) I discovered irregularities amongst you.
('33', 272, 1, 14, 629526) What was I to do?
('33', 272, 1, 15, 629544) Punishing you was out of the question.
('33', 272, 1, 16, 629583) Being the chief among the teachers, I had to take the punishment on myself in the form of the fast which breaks today.
('33', 272, 1, 17, 629702) I have learnt a lot during these days of quiet thinking.
('33', 272, 1, 18, 629759) What have you?
('33', 272, 1, 19, 629774) Could you assure me that you will never repeat your mistake?
('33', 272, 1, 20, 629835) You may err again but this fast will be lost on you if you do not realize the way out if it.
('33', 272, 1, 21, 629928) Truthfulness is the master key.
('33', 272, 1, 22, 629960) Do not lie under any circumstances whatsoever.
('33', 272, 1, 23, 630007) Keep nothing secret, take your teachers and your elders into your confidence and make a clean breast of everything to them.
('33', 272, 1, 24, 630131) Bear ill will to none, do not say an evil thing of anyone behind his back, above all” to thine own self be true”, so that you are false to no one else.
('33', 272, 1, 25, 630283) Truthful dealing even in the least little things of life is the only secret of a pure life.
('33', 272, 1, 26, 630375) You must have noticed that I receive my inspiration on such occasions from the hymn, Vaishnava Jana to tene kahiye (He is the true Vaishnava, etc.).
('33', 272, 1, 27, 630524) That hymn is enough to sustain me, even if I were to forget the Bhagavad Gita.
('33', 272, 1, 28, 630603) To tell you the truth, however, there is one thing which is even simpler, but which may possibly be difficult for you to understand.
('33', 272, 1, 29, 630736) But that has been my pole star all along during life’s journey—the conviction that Truth is God and untruth a denial of Him.
('33', 272, 2, 30, 630861) Young India, 10 12 1925

('33', 273, 1, 2, 630927) 163. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('33', 273, 2, 3, 630955) December 1, 1925
('33', 273, 3, 4, 630972) Mahatmaji, though weak, gave the following statement regarding the reasons for the fast: I have dealt with it fully in the pages of Young India.
('33', 273, 3, 5, 631117) 1I do not, therefore, propose to anticipate them, save to say that they were purely private and personal and for Ashram purification.
('33', 273, 3, 6, 631251) I have kept perfectly healthy and reasonably strong throughout the week.
('33', 273, 3, 7, 631324) There never was the slightest cause for any anxiety.
('33', 273, 3, 8, 631377) After the breaking of the fast I am feeling perfectly well There is no reaction yet noticeable that generally follows breaking of fast.
('33', 273, 3, 9, 631513) I hope soon to regain the lost weight and vitality.
('33', 273, 3, 10, 631565) I hope also, if friends will be indulgent and not over tax me, to go through the programme I had mapped out before this fast.
('33', 273, 3, 11, 631691) Easy journey and mild conversation will not, I think, tax me out.
('33', 273, 3, 12, 631757) Friends need have no anxiety about my health.
('33', 273, 3, 13, 631803) I am sorry to have caused grief during the fast.
('33', 273, 3, 14, 631852) Such is my life.
('33', 273, 3, 15, 631869) If I could have saved them grief, I certainly would have done so; but I saw no way out.
('33', 273, 4, 16, 631957) After the statement was made, Mahatmaji was asked whether he would go to Dholka, as decided.
('33', 273, 4, 17, 632050) He replied: Certainly so.
('33', 273, 4, 18, 632076) I cannot defer that.
('33', 273, 5, 19, 632097) The Hindu, 1 12 1925

('33', 275, 5, 10, 633696) 168. NOTES
('33', 275, 6, 11, 633707) SPINNERS’ DIFFICULTIES
('33', 275, 7, 12, 633730) A spinner asks,” What is a member of A.I.S.A. 1 expected to do under the rules?” His duty shall be to carry on propaganda for hand spinning and khadi.
('33', 275, 7, 13, 633881) A greedy president like me would expect a member to go out among the people and invite them to wear khadi, spin regularly and become members of the A.I.S.A. He would also ask him to hawk khadi among them and to teach them spinning and to collect donations among friends.
('33', 275, 7, 14, 634152) But to expect is one thing, to have one’s expectation fulfilled is another.
('33', 275, 7, 15, 634228) Therefore when one becomes a member and scrupulously and diligently spins and never uses anything but khadi, wherever cloth is required, he has done the minimum required of him.
('33', 275, 7, 16, 634406) The majority would no doubt fluctuate between the two extremes.
('33', 275, 8, 17, 634470) Another asks,” Though khadi is habitual with me, I do wear foreign cloth on twenty five occasions out of a hundred.
('33', 275, 8, 18, 634586) I spin regularly.
('33', 275, 8, 19, 634604) Can I become a member of the A.I.S.A.?” I fear that such men cannot become members of the A.I.S.A. Habitual wear of khadi excludes the use of other cloth save for extraordinary and unavoidable causes.
('33', 275, 8, 20, 634805) Though on the part of the founders the desire to swell the list of members was no doubt strong, the desire to get ‘whole hoggers’ was stronger still.
('33', 275, 8, 21, 634955) For the Association to be useful must have as its members workers who are uncompromising believers in khadi.
('33', 275, 8, 22, 635064) We have to convert millions.
('33', 275, 8, 23, 635093) We cannot succeed if we begin with half heartedness.
('33', 275, 8, 24, 635146) Those who cannot wear khadihabitually may send yarn self spun or money or cotton and help
('33', 275, 9, 25, 635236) 1 All India Spinners’ Association
('33', 276, 0, 1, 635270) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 277
('33', 276, 1, 2, 635321) the movement in a variety of other ways.
('33', 276, 2, 3, 635362) SPURIOUS KHADI
('33', 276, 3, 4, 635377) A correspondent sends me from Nagpur a pictorial label taken from cloth which is palmed off as genuine khadi on gullible people and he tells me that people buy it largely in the belief that it is good khadi.
('33', 276, 3, 5, 635585) The belief is strengthened by their seeing the label which contains a hideous caricature of my likeness and a spinning wheel.
('33', 276, 3, 6, 635711) This kind of practice can hardly be called patriotic or pure and it gives rise to a feeling against mills which one would fain avoid.
('33', 276, 3, 7, 635845) Cannot the Mill owners’ Association deal with such questionable practices of which I have been obliged to take notice from time to time?
('33', 276, 4, 8, 635982) Young India, 3 12 1925
('33', 276, 5, 9, 636005) 169. COW PROTECTION ESSAY
('33', 276, 6, 10, 636031) Several competition essays have already been received.
('33', 276, 6, 11, 636086) Most of them are indifferently written.
('33', 276, 6, 12, 636126) Some are written on both sides of the paper.
('33', 276, 6, 13, 636171) Some are illegible.
('33', 276, 6, 14, 636191) The future competitors are requested to write their essays 1. on one side of the paper only; 2. in legible, clear, bold hand in ink; 3. on stout paper well bound, giving full name and address of the competitor.
('33', 276, 6, 15, 636402) The competitors are also warned that rejected essays will not be returned.
('33', 276, 6, 16, 636477) Those therefore who desire copies should make and keep them before sending.

('33', 278, 1, 2, 637824) 173. LETTER TO G. D. BIRLA
('33', 278, 2, 3, 637851) Friday [December 4, 1925] 1
('33', 278, 3, 4, 637879) BHAISHRI GHANSHYAMDASJI,
('33', 278, 4, 5, 637904) I had sent a reply to your letter through Jamnalalji; I hope you had it.
('33', 278, 4, 6, 637977) When I got your lengthy letter, I sent a detailed reply under a registered cover to your Solan address.
('33', 278, 4, 7, 638081) I fail to understand why it has not reached you.
('33', 278, 4, 8, 638130) Let me repeat what I wrote in it.
('33', 278, 4, 9, 638164) I had appreciated your action in contributing Rs. l,00,000/ to the All India Deshbandhu Memorial Fund, and had made a request for early payment of the sum.
('33', 278, 4, 10, 638320) I had also given my reasons for not being able to co operate with Pujya 2 Malaviyaji and Pujya Lalaji but had affirmed a deep sense of respect for both.
('33', 278, 4, 11, 638473) I help Pandit Motilalji and the Swarajya Party because after all their ideals are somewhat close to mine.
('33', 278, 4, 12, 638579) There is no question of my helping individuals.
('33', 278, 4, 13, 638627) I wrote many other things in that letter; but now I cannot recall all of them.
('33', 278, 4, 14, 638706) I hope both of you are in good health.
('33', 278, 4, 15, 638745) You must have heard of my fast.
('33', 278, 4, 16, 638777) That I am gaining strength will be evident from the fact that I am writing this to you.
('33', 278, 4, 17, 638865) I hope to undertake a little physical work in a few days.
('33', 278, 4, 18, 638923) I shall reach Wardha on the 10th and stay there for some ten days.
('33', 278, 6, 19, 638990) MOHANDAS GANDHI

('33', 279, 1, 2, 639151) 174. SPEECH AT GUJARAT VIDYAPITH CONVOCATION AHMEDABAD 1
('33', 279, 2, 3, 639208) December 5, 1925
('33', 279, 3, 4, 639225) I congratulate the students who have taken their degrees and won their prizes today.
('33', 279, 3, 5, 639310) I wish them long life, and may their degrees and their knowledge do credit to them and their country.
('33', 279, 3, 6, 639412) Let us not lose our way in the surrounding darkness of despair.
('33', 279, 3, 7, 639476) We shall have to look for rays of hope not in the outward firmament, but in the inward firmament of our hearts.
('33', 279, 3, 8, 639588) The student who has faith, who has cast off all fear, who is absorbed in his work, who finds his rights in the performance of his duties, will not cower before the surrounding gloom.
('33', 279, 3, 9, 639771) He will know that the gloom is transitory and that the light is near.
('33', 279, 3, 10, 639841) Non co operation has not failed.
('33', 279, 3, 11, 639874) Co operation and non co ope ration have been there from the beginning of time.
('33', 279, 3, 12, 639953) Truth and falsehood, peace and strife, life and death and all the dual throng is bound to be there.
('33', 279, 3, 13, 640053) But if we have to co operate with truth, we have to non co operate with falsehood; if loyalty to the motherland is laudable, disloyalty is despicable; if we have to co operate with liberty we have to non co operate with slavery.
('33', 279, 3, 14, 640282) Whether, therefore, there be one national school or many, whether there be one student there or many, the future historian will have to give the national school a prominent place among the means for the attainment of freedom.
('33', 279, 3, 15, 640508) Ours are new fangled enterprises.
('33', 279, 3, 16, 640542) The critic will find therein much to cavil at.
('33', 279, 3, 17, 640589) Some drawbacks we can see ourselves.
('33', 279, 3, 18, 640626) We shall have to go on with our endeavours to remedythem.
('33', 279, 3, 19, 640684) I know that our administration leaves much to be desired, that our organizers and professors are imperfect.
('33', 279, 3, 20, 640792) We are quite watchful about these things and shall leave no stone unturned to remove the shortcomings.
('33', 279, 3, 21, 640895) Students, have patience.
('33', 279, 3, 22, 640920) Believe that you are soldiers in the army of swaraj.
('33', 279, 3, 23, 640973) Do nothing, speak nothing, think nothing unbecoming of such a soldier.
('33', 279, 3, 24, 641044) May God bless you.
('33', 279, 4, 25, 641063) Young India, 10 12 1925
('33', 279, 5, 26, 641087) 1 From a report by Mahadev Desai; the speech was read out by the Registrar; Gandhiji, the Chancellor, was present at the function.

('33', 280, 1, 2, 641269) 175. SPEECH TO VIDYALAYA SOCIAL, AHMEDABAD 1
('33', 280, 2, 3, 641314) December 5, 1925
('33', 280, 3, 4, 641331) Social gatherings are part of student life.
('33', 280, 3, 5, 641375) There are many benefits to be gained from such gatherings.
('33', 280, 3, 6, 641434) I have also known their disadvantages.
('33', 280, 3, 7, 641473) I would like to suggest one benefit.
('33', 280, 3, 8, 641510) It is as much necessary to develop sympathy for the poor of India as it is desirable for the students to cultivate fellow feeling among themselves.
('33', 280, 3, 9, 641658) How can I bring home to the students that yarn is the bond of such sympathy?
('33', 280, 3, 10, 641735) There must be some divine power in the yarn and that must be why God has been given the name of Sutradhar 2. How nice it would be if we become little sutradhars in the army of that great Sutradhar?

('33', 281, 6, 13, 642796) 177. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, DHOLKA 2
('33', 281, 7, 14, 642836) December 6, 1925 I am thankful that in spite of my physical inability, God has enabled me to keep my promise to pay you a visit.
('33', 281, 7, 15, 642965) I hear that there are many talukdars here.
('33', 281, 7, 16, 643008) I hope they will cultivate and maintain sweet relations with their tenants.
('33', 281, 7, 17, 643084) I am told there is no Hindu Muslim tension here.
('33', 281, 7, 18, 643133) Let the relations be more friendly than they are.
('33', 281, 7, 19, 643183) How am I to convince you that spinning and exclusive use of khaddar is the swiftest way to swaraj?
('33', 281, 7, 20, 643282) A yard of khaddar used by you means four or five annas in the pockets of your poor countrymen.
('33', 281, 7, 21, 643377) I wish I could also carry home to you my conviction that to regard any human being as ‘untouchable’ is to insult oneself and one’s religion.
('33', 281, 7, 22, 643518) It is the evil passions in us that are untouchables; let us be rid of them.
('33', 281, 7, 23, 643594) Purify yourselves and spin half an hour daily as a sacrifice, if.
('33', 281, 7, 24, 643660) you think spinning need not add to your income.
('33', 281, 7, 25, 643708) Spin in the name of God and spin for the poor of your land.
('33', 281, 7, 26, 643768) I have given my message.
('33', 281, 7, 27, 643793) You cannot have a new or fresh message from me.
('33', 281, 7, 28, 643841) Carry out that message and let me know the results.
('33', 281, 8, 29, 643893) Young India, 17 12 1925
('33', 281, 9, 30, 643917) 1 Gandhiji was in Dholka on this date.

('33', 283, 8, 13, 645887) December 8, 1925
('33', 283, 9, 14, 645904) I thank God for giving me the strength to attend this function.
('33', 283, 9, 15, 645968) This is one of the few surviving national schools and I congratulate its teachers on their selfless dedication to the work.
('33', 283, 9, 16, 646092) Just now I have learnt that the teachers have voluntarily reduced their salaries by fifteen per cent.
('33', 283, 9, 17, 646194) It is also extremely gratifying that the principal works entirely gratis.
('33', 283, 9, 18, 646268) I hope that the public will appreciate and encourage this school.
('33', 283, 9, 19, 646334) Children, you should realize that you came to this school to learn national service.
('33', 283, 9, 20, 646419) Most of what you study here should therefore be dedicated to the country.
('33', 283, 9, 21, 646493) This is the significance of the charkha.
('33', 283, 9, 22, 646534) Those of you who spin, do so for the country and its poor.
