('33', 285, 1, 2, 648655) 182. THE SOUTH AFRICAN DEPUTATION
('33', 285, 2, 3, 648689) Here is the full list of the deputation that is coming from South Africa and is due to reach here on the 12th instant.
('33', 285, 2, 4, 648808) 1. Dr. Abdur Rahman 2. Mr. Sorabji Rustomji 3. Sjt.
('33', 285, 2, 5, 648860) B. S. Pather 4. Seth G. Mirza 5. Seth Amod Bhayat 6. Mr. James Godfrey 7. Seth Haji Esmail 8. Sjt.
('33', 285, 2, 6, 648959) Bhawani Dayal
('33', 285, 3, 7, 648973) This is a representative deputation of persons well known in South Africa.
('33', 285, 3, 8, 649048) They can speak for the different groups and interests among our countrymen in South Africa.
('33', 285, 3, 9, 649140) Dr. Abdur Rahman, the headof the deputation, is South African born, as for that matter are some others.
('33', 285, 3, 10, 649244) The worthy doctor is popularly known as a Malay doctor.
('33', 285, 3, 11, 649300) But he has Indian blood in him.
('33', 285, 3, 12, 649332) The Malays are an integral part of the South African community.
('33', 285, 3, 13, 649396) They are without exception Mussalmans.
('33', 285, 3, 14, 649435) Malay women freely marry Indian Mussalmans; The unions are happy and the children born of such mixtures are some of them highly educated.
('33', 285, 3, 15, 649573) Dr. Abdur Rahman belongs to that distinguished category.
('33', 285, 3, 16, 649630) He received his medical training in Scotland and is a successful practitioner in Cape Town.
('33', 285, 3, 17, 649722) He was a member of the old Cape Legislative Council and also a prominent Corporator.
('33', 285, 3, 18, 649807) But even he has not been unexposed to the colour prejudice.
('33', 285, 3, 19, 649867) The deputation is assured of a warm welcome and a patient hearing.
('33', 285, 3, 20, 649934) The question of Indians overseas is happily not a party question.
('33', 285, 3, 21, 650000) It is a question on which Anglo Indian opinion too has ranged itself on the side of Indians.
('33', 285, 3, 22, 650093) The cause itself is supremely just.
('33', 285, 3, 23, 650129) The question is, therefore, merely of India’s ability to vindicate justice.
('33', 285, 3, 24, 650205) If the Government of India remains firm and is backed by the Imperial Government, the Union Government cannot but yield to the decisive pressure from the Centre.
('33', 285, 3, 25, 650367) But there is the fear of South Africa ‘cutting the painter’.
('33', 285, 3, 26, 650428) Imperialists alone know the value of keeping unwilling partners tied up in a knot which may snap under the slightest strain.
('33', 285, 3, 27, 650553) This excessive anxiety to hold together forces that are
('33', 286, 0, 1, 650609) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 287
('33', 286, 1, 2, 650660) mutually disruptive has degraded imperial politics to the formula of exploitation of African and Asiatic races, to the exclusion, if possible, of other European powers from the spoils of exploitation.
('33', 286, 1, 3, 650861) Great Britain’s policy in the matter of the treatment of Indian settlers in the Dominions is an acid test of her intentions.
('33', 286, 1, 4, 650986) Will she dare to do the right in spite of the pressure from the Union Government?
('33', 286, 1, 5, 651068) The South African deputation is coming for an answer to that question.
('33', 286, 2, 6, 651139) Young India, 10 12 1925
('33', 286, 3, 7, 651163) 183. NATIONAL EDUCATION
('33', 286, 4, 8, 651187) The Gujarat Vidyapith had its annual convocation 1 for the granting of degrees and prizes.
('33', 286, 4, 9, 651278) There was the annual stock taking; an unvarnished truthful tale of diminution in the number of boys and girls studying in the various institutions managed under it or affiliated to it.
('33', 286, 4, 10, 651463) Gujarat has perhaps the best financed national institutions if not also the best managed.
('33', 286, 4, 11, 651553) Of these institutions, at least, it can be said that it is not due to want of funds that they appear to be dwindling.
('33', 286, 4, 12, 651671) There can be no doubt that national institutions are just now not popular.
('33', 286, 4, 13, 651746) They cannot boast handsome and expensive buildings or furniture.
('33', 286, 4, 14, 651811) They cannot boast highly paid teachers and professors.
('33', 286, 4, 15, 651866) Nor can they claim continuity of tradition or method.
('33', 286, 4, 16, 651920) Nor can they promise alluring careers.
('33', 286, 4, 17, 651959) What they claim offers no temptation to many.
('33', 286, 4, 18, 652005) They claim many selfless, patriotic teachers who are living in penury and want, so that the youth of the country may benefit by their tuition.
('33', 286, 4, 19, 652148) These institutions teach hand spinning and all it means.
('33', 286, 4, 20, 652205) They teach the art of service.
('33', 286, 4, 21, 652236) They try to impart instruction through the medium of the vernaculars.
('33', 286, 4, 22, 652306) They endeavour to revive national games and teach national music.
('33', 286, 4, 23, 652372) They strive to prepare the boys for service in the villages and to that end cultivate in them fellow feeling with the poor of India.
('33', 286, 4, 24, 652505) But this is not sufficiently attractive.
('33', 286, 4, 25, 652546) Hence the falling off in numbers.
('33', 286, 4, 26, 652580) The so called unattractiveness is, however, not the sole reason for the unpopularity of these institutions.
('33', 286, 4, 27, 652688) Many things were done in 1921—that year of excitement, intoxication and hope.
('33', 286, 4, 28, 652766) The intoxication having subsided, depression has followed as a matter of course.
('33', 286, 4, 29, 652847) The boys have gone in for calculation and not knowing that patriotism is not a matter of mathematical calculation have arrived at
('33', 286, 5, 30, 652977) 1 For Gandhiji’s speech, vide”Speech at Gujarat Vidyapith Convocation, Ahmedabad”, 5 12 1925.
('33', 287, 0, 1, 653071) 288 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 287, 1, 2, 653113) wrong conclusions and given preference to the Government schools and colleges.
('33', 287, 1, 3, 653192) No fault of theirs.
('33', 287, 1, 4, 653212) Everything around us has been reduced to terms of commerce and bargain.
('33', 287, 1, 5, 653284) It is too much to expect boys and girls to rise above the surrounding atmosphere.
('33', 287, 1, 6, 653366) Nor is this all.
('33', 287, 1, 7, 653383) National teachers are not perfect.
('33', 287, 1, 8, 653418) They are not all selfless.
('33', 287, 1, 9, 653445) They are not all above petty intrigues.
('33', 287, 1, 10, 653485) They are not all patriotic.
('33', 287, 1, 11, 653513) Again, no fault of theirs.
('33', 287, 1, 12, 653540) We are all creatures of circumstances.
('33', 287, 1, 13, 653579) Brought up only to work as servants under constant constraint and with all initiative killed in us, we cannot respond to the call for self sacrifice, for love of the country above love of self or family, for service without distinction.
('33', 287, 1, 14, 653816) It is, therefore, perfectly possible to account for the present deprssion.
('33', 287, 1, 15, 653891) But my faith in national schools as in every other item of our original programme is undying.
('33', 287, 1, 16, 653985) I recognize the depression in the national barometer and therefore even promote Congress resolutions recognizing the situation.
('33', 287, 1, 17, 654113) But I remain unaffected by it and invite others to do likewise.
('33', 287, 1, 18, 654177) These national institutions in spite of their falls are to me so many oases in the desert of our hopes and aspirations.
('33', 287, 1, 19, 654297) From them must rise the nation of the future, as they even today supply to us the largest number of unpaid or poorly paid silent workers.
('33', 287, 1, 20, 654435) Go wherever you will, you cannot but find non co operating young men and even young girls, who are devoting all their powers to the service of the motherland without the slightest expectation of reward.
('33', 287, 1, 21, 654638) I must, therefore, refuse to listen to the advice of a critic who writes to me to say that the Gujarat Mahavidyalaya should be closed because of the diminishing numbers.
('33', 287, 1, 22, 654808) If the people support it or if the teachers have the stamina whether the people support it or not, the Mahavidyalaya must continue so long as there is one true boy or girl who will finish his or her training in that institution with all its ideals.
('33', 287, 1, 23, 655057) Fair weather was no condition of the continuance of that institution.
('33', 287, 1, 24, 655127) As with national servants so with national institutions.
('33', 287, 1, 25, 655184) They must go through their programme through fair weather or foul.

('33', 288, 1, 2, 655326) 184. NOTES
('33', 288, 2, 3, 655337) THE BREAKING OF THE FAST
('33', 288, 3, 4, 655362) Friends who are interested in my health will be glad to learn that if I lost nine pounds during the seven days’ fast, I have regained upto the seventh day after the breaking of the fast over six pounds in weight.
('33', 288, 3, 5, 655575) I am even able to take moderate exercise and go through a fair amount of work every day.
('33', 288, 3, 6, 655664) By the time this is out, I shall find myself in Wardha where I propose to take as much rest as possible up to the time of the meeting of the Congress.
('33', 288, 3, 7, 655815) May I therefore ask C. P. and other friends not to regard me as being in Wardha on business?
('33', 288, 3, 8, 655908) It will tax all my energy to attend to my weekly editing and daily correspondence.
('33', 288, 3, 9, 655991) I hope to regain much of the lost strength by the time I reach Cawnpore.
('33', 288, 4, 10, 656064) TO CORRESPONDENTS
('33', 288, 5, 11, 656082) I regret to inform my correspondents that owing to the fast I am considerably in arrears regarding my correspondence.
('33', 288, 5, 12, 656200) Whilst my assistants have dealt with the bulk of it, I see before me quite a pile awaiting my attention.
('33', 288, 5, 13, 656305) The correspondents will forgive me for the delay.
('33', 288, 5, 14, 656355) I hope to overtake the correspondence as early as possible.
('33', 288, 6, 15, 656415) THE HIDE TRADE
('33', 288, 7, 16, 656430) The hide industry of India ranks fifth in value of the products of India.
('33', 288, 7, 17, 656504) The normal value of the annual export of hides is about Rs. 1,170 lacs.
('33', 288, 7, 18, 656576) Of these over Rs. 844 lacs are exported from Calcutta.
('33', 288, 7, 19, 656631) The bulk of this trade was before the War and is now in German hands.
('33', 288, 7, 20, 656701) Nationalization of tanneries means therefore not only the saving of thousands of cattle that are slaughtered for hides but the retention of hides in India means utilization of skilled labour in the country itself and additional wealth.
('33', 288, 8, 21, 656937) ALL INDIA DESHBANDHU MEMORIAL

('33', 288, 10, 23, 657000) The progress though slow is steady.
('33', 288, 10, 24, 657036) The list shows too that the habit of paying only to influence rather than the cause still persists[sic].
('33', 288, 10, 25, 657141) I would urge the would be subscribers not to reverse the process.

('33', 289, 2, 6, 657430) Motilal Roy the chief of the Sangh changed his depot there into a pure khadi depot.

('33', 289, 3, 8, 657529) We have transferred our ‘Mrinalini Bastralaya Kanyalay’ at
('33', 289, 4, 9, 657588) Chandernagore and the ‘Pravartak Emporium’ in Calcutta into pure khadi
('33', 289, 5, 10, 657659) centres from 20th October last, and informed you on the very day of the great
('33', 289, 6, 11, 657737) change.
('33', 289, 6, 12, 657745) The whole organization now stands for pure khadi but you are surely
('33', 289, 7, 13, 657813) aware what considerable risks we have taken on our shoulders for such a
('33', 289, 8, 14, 657885) venture.
('33', 289, 9, 15, 657894) I am sorry I never saw the intimation of the change referred to by him.
('33', 289, 9, 16, 657966) I tender my congratulations to Moti Babu on the change and hope that the change to pure khadi will persist in spite of initial difficulties which every khadi organization has to face.

('33', 290, 1, 2, 658395) 186. LETTER TO V. L. PHADKE
('33', 290, 2, 3, 658423) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, WARDHA, [December 10, 1925] 1
('33', 290, 3, 4, 658472) BHAI MAMA, I could read your letter only today after reaching Wardha.
('33', 290, 3, 5, 658542) At the Ashram whatever energy I had I spent for Ashram work and for Young India and Navajivan.
('33', 290, 3, 6, 658637) I came here today and devoted my time entirely to correspondence.
('33', 290, 3, 7, 658703) I am quite well.
('33', 290, 3, 8, 658720) I am here till the 21st.
('33', 290, 3, 9, 658745) On the 22nd morning I leave for Kanpur reaching there on the 23rd.
('33', 290, 3, 10, 658812) What you say about living in the Ashram is true.
('33', 290, 3, 11, 658861) At Kanpur I shall make a final decision regarding this.
('33', 290, 3, 12, 658917) I am also inclined to stay at the Ashram.
('33', 290, 3, 13, 658959) But”with a frail thread has Hari tied me and I turn the way He pulls me.” 2 This is my position and it will always be so.
('33', 290, 3, 14, 659081) We shall talk about Godhra when I come to the Ashram.
('33', 290, 3, 15, 659135) When you ask for Antyaja children I presume you are offering them freeships.
('33', 290, 3, 16, 659212) Are we to bear all the expenditure?
('33', 290, 3, 17, 659248) Lakshmi’s is a difficult case.
('33', 290, 3, 18, 659279) Can you take up the challenge of looking after her?
('33', 290, 3, 19, 659331) Are you ready to give me an Anyaja boy?
('33', 290, 3, 20, 659371) You did not say how many students you have at present.
('33', 290, 3, 21, 659426) I am certainly serving as your canvasser.
('33', 290, 3, 22, 659468) Never again think of exhibiting the children; that will surely ruin the Ashram.
('33', 290, 3, 23, 659548) It is not proper to lure children into the Ashram and neglect their development.
('33', 290, 3, 24, 659629) It cannot be your business to hunt for children.
('33', 290, 3, 25, 659678) Your task is to educate a lone boy if he is the only inmate.
('33', 290, 3, 26, 659739) It is another matter that you maintain contacts with the local Antyajas and serve them as far as you can.
('33', 290, 3, 27, 659845) But this too you must not do at the cost of education.
('33', 290, 3, 28, 659900) Nor should you be tempted to impart muchlearning.
('33', 290, 3, 29, 659950) Improve the quality; the pattern will take care of itself.
('33', 290, 3, 30, 660009) But if you concentrate on the pattern, nothing will be accomplished; the quality too will suffer.

('33', 296, 14, 20, 667095) 197. THE PHYSICAL EFFECTS OF FASTING
('33', 296, 15, 21, 667132) [December 13, 1925] 1
('33', 296, 16, 22, 667154) A medical friend who believes in fasting cure under certain circumstances invites me to reduce to writing the physical effects of fasting as I might have observed them.
('33', 296, 16, 23, 667323) As they are not inconsiderable and as I know many cases in which people who fasted have done themselves harm, I gladly comply with the medical friend’s request.
('33', 296, 16, 24, 667484) Though almost all my fasts have been undertaken for a moral purpose, being an inveterate diet reformer and a believer in fasting as a cure for many obstinate diseases, I have not failed to note their physical effects.
('33', 296, 16, 25, 667702) I must, however, confess that I have not made any
('33', 296, 17, 26, 667752) 1 Written on the twelfth day after breaking the fast
('33', 297, 0, 1, 667805) 298 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 297, 1, 2, 667847) accurate observations for the simple reason that it was not possible for me to combine the two.
('33', 297, 1, 3, 667943) I was much too preoccupied with the moral values to note or mind the physical.
('33', 297, 1, 4, 668022) I can therefore only give the general impressions.
('33', 297, 1, 5, 668073) For accurate observations I can only refer the reader to Drs.
('33', 297, 1, 6, 668135) Ansari and Abdur Rahman who were my medical guides throughout the long fast of last year.
('33', 297, 1, 7, 668225) They were most painstaking.
('33', 297, 1, 8, 668253) They were constantly by my bed side and had thrown themselves heart and soul into the work of looking after me.
('33', 297, 1, 9, 668365) Let me at the outset note a disaster that befell me after the second long fast, that is, of fourteen days, in South Africa in 1914. Almost on the second day of the breaking of the fast I began strenuous walking, feeling that I should come to no harm.
('33', 297, 1, 10, 668616) I walked nearly three miles, the second or the third day, and suffered excruciating pains in the muscleless calves.
('33', 297, 1, 11, 668732) Not knowing the cause I persisted in walking as soon as the pain subsided.
('33', 297, 1, 12, 668807) It was in this condition that I left South Africa for England and came under the observation of Dr. Jivraj Mehta, who warned me that if I persisted I might be a cripple for life and that I must lie in bed for at least a fortnight.
('33', 297, 1, 13, 669038) But the warning was too late to keep my general health, which used to be excellent such that I was capable of taking a forty mile march without being over fatigued.
('33', 297, 1, 14, 669203) Twenty miles in a day was nothing for me in those days.
('33', 297, 1, 15, 669259) It was as a result of the strain I ignorantly put upon my body that I had to suffer from a violent attack of pluerisy which permanently injured a constitution that was fairly sound.
('33', 297, 1, 16, 669441) It was the first serious attack of any disease in my life.
('33', 297, 1, 17, 669500) From this very costly experiment I learned that perfect physical rest during fast and for a time proportionate to the length of the fast, after the breaking of it, is a necessity, and if this simple rule can be observed no evil effect of fasting need be feared.
('33', 297, 1, 18, 669762) Indeed, it is my conviction that the body gains by a well regulated fast.
('33', 297, 1, 19, 669836) For during fasting the body gets rid of many of its impurities.
('33', 297, 1, 20, 669900) During the last year’s fast, as during this year, but unlike the previous fast, I took water with salt and bicarbonate of soda added to it.
('33', 297, 1, 21, 670040) Somehow or other I develop during fasts a distaste for water.
('33', 297, 1, 22, 670102) With the addition of salt and soda it becomes somewhat bearable.
('33', 297, 1, 23, 670167) I found that drinking copious draughts of water kept the system clean and the mouth moist.
('33', 297, 1, 24, 670258) To every six to eight ounces of water five grains of salt and an equal quantity of soda were added, and I drank during the day from forty to forty eight ounces of water, in six to eight doses.
('33', 297, 1, 25, 670451) I took also regularly every day an enema containing nearly three quarters of a pint of water
('33', 298, 0, 1, 670544) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 299
('33', 298, 1, 2, 670595) with nearly forty grains of salt and nearly an equal quantity of soda dissolved in it.
('33', 298, 1, 3, 670682) The water was always warm.
('33', 298, 1, 4, 670709) I had also a sponge bath every day given to me in bed.
('33', 298, 1, 5, 670764) I had both during last year’s and this year’s fast refreshing sleep at night and at least an hour during the day time.
('33', 298, 1, 6, 670883) For three days and a half during the last fast, I worked practically from 4 o’clock in the morning till 8 o’clock in the evening, holding discussions on the question that had entailed the fast, and attending to my correspon dence and editing.
('33', 298, 1, 7, 671126) On the fourth day I developed a violent headache and the strain was proving unbearable.
('33', 298, 1, 8, 671214) In the afternoon of the fourth day I stopped all work.
('33', 298, 1, 9, 671269) The following day I felt recuperated, the feeling of exhaustion was gone, headache had almost subsided.
('33', 298, 1, 10, 671373) On the sixth day I felt fresher still and on the seventh day which was also my silent day I felt so fresh and strong that I was able to write with a steady hand my article 1 on the fast.
('33', 298, 1, 11, 671560) I am not aware during the whole of the fast of having suffered any pangs of hunger.
('33', 298, 1, 12, 671644) Indeed on the day of breaking the fast I was in no hurry, I broke it half an hour later than I need have.
('33', 298, 1, 13, 671750) There was no difficulty during the fast about spinning.
('33', 298, 1, 14, 671806) I was able to sit up every day for over half an hour, with a pillow to support the back, and spin almost with my usual speed.
('33', 298, 1, 15, 671932) Nor did I have to miss any of the three daily prayer meetings.
('33', 298, 1, 16, 671995) During the last four days I had to be carried on a cot to these meetings.
('33', 298, 1, 17, 672069) With an effort I could even have sat up at the meetings, but I thought it better to conserve my energy.
('33', 298, 1, 18, 672173) I am not conscious of having suffered much physical pain.
('33', 298, 1, 19, 672231) The only pain which the memory has stored is a feeling of nausea, creeping over me now and then, which was as a rule overcome by sipping water.
('33', 298, 1, 20, 672375) I broke the fast on orange juice and grape juice, about six ounces altogether, and I sucked the pulp of an orange.
('33', 298, 1, 21, 672490) I repeated the performance two hours after, adding ten grapes, which too were slowly sucked, leaving out all the skin.
('33', 298, 1, 22, 672609) Later in the day and after the enema, I had six ounces of goat’s milk with two ounces of water, followed by an orange and ten grapes.
('33', 298, 1, 23, 672743) The next day the quantity of milk was raised to eighteen ounces, water always added, and thus I continued to increase the quantity of milk by six ounces every day, till I reached forty eight ounces.
('33', 298, 1, 24, 672942) Milk is still diluted with water, though now one ounce of water is added to each portion.
('33', 298, 1, 25, 673032) For one day and a half I tried undiluted milk, but I noticed a certain heaviness, which I attribute to undiluted milk and have therefore gone back to diluting it.
('33', 298, 2, 26, 673195) 1Vide”The Latest Fast”, 30 11 1925.
('33', 299, 0, 1, 673231) 300 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 299, 1, 2, 673273) At the time of writing these notes it is the twelfth day after the breaking of the fast.
('33', 299, 1, 3, 673362) 1 I have not yet taken any solid food.
('33', 299, 1, 4, 673401) Part of the fruit is still turned into juice and during the past three days I have added to grapes and oranges either papaw or pomegranate and chiku.
('33', 299, 1, 5, 673551) The largest quantity of milk I have taken is sixty four ounces.
('33', 299, 1, 6, 673615) The average is forty eight.
('33', 299, 1, 7, 673643) I add at times baker’s bread or home made light chapati.
('33', 299, 1, 8, 673700) But for months together I have been living simply on milk and fruit and keeping myself in a fit condition.
('33', 299, 1, 9, 673807) My highest weight since my discharge from prison has been 112 lbs.
('33', 299, 1, 10, 673874) The weight lost during the seven days of fast was 9 Ibs.
('33', 299, 1, 11, 673931) I have now regained the whole of that weight and am now weighing a little over 103 lbs.
('33', 299, 1, 12, 674019) For the last three days, I have taken regular exercise, both in the morning and evening, without the slightest fatigue.
('33', 299, 1, 13, 674139) There is no difficulty in walking on level ground.
('33', 299, 1, 14, 674190) There is still some strain felt in ascending or descending steps.
('33', 299, 1, 15, 674256) The bowels move fairly regularly, and I sleep almost to order.
('33', 299, 1, 16, 674319) My own opinion is that I have lost physically nothing as a result either of the twenty one days’ fast or this the latest seven days’ fast.
('33', 299, 1, 17, 674458) The loss of weight during the seven days was no doubt somewhat alarming, but it was clearly due to the severe strain that was put upon the constitution during the first three and a half days.
('33', 299, 1, 18, 674650) A little more rest, and I should regain my original vitality with which I started the fast and probably regain without difficulty the weight and strength lost in Cutch.
('33', 299, 1, 19, 674819) From a layman’s and from a purely physical standpoint I should lay down the following rules for all those who may wish to fast on any account whatsoever: 1. Conserve your energy both physical and mental from the very beginning.
('33', 299, 1, 20, 675047) 2. You must cease to think of food whilst you are fasting.
('33', 299, 1, 21, 675106) 3. Drink as much cold water as you can, with or without soda and salt, but in small quantities at a time (water should be boiled, strained and cooled).
('33', 299, 1, 22, 675258) Do not be afraid of salt and soda, because most waters contain both these salts in a free state.
('33', 299, 1, 23, 675355) 4. Have a warm sponge daily.
('33', 299, 1, 24, 675384) 5. Take an enema regularly during fast.
('33', 299, 1, 25, 675424) You will be surprised at the impurities you will expel daily.
('33', 299, 1, 26, 675486) 6. Sleep as much as possible in the open air.
('33', 299, 2, 27, 675532) 1 Gandhiji broke his fast on December 1.
('33', 300, 0, 1, 675573) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 301
('33', 300, 1, 2, 675624) 7. Bathe in the morning sun.
('33', 300, 1, 3, 675653) A sun and air bath is at least as great a purifier as a water bath.
('33', 300, 1, 4, 675721) 8. Think of anything else but the fast.
('33', 300, 1, 5, 675761) 9. No matter from what motive you are fasting, during this precious time, think of your Maker, and of your relation to Him and His other creation, and you will make discoveries you may not have even dreamed of.
('33', 300, 1, 6, 675972) With apologies to medical friends, but out of the fulness of my own experience and that of fellow cranks I say without hesitation, fast (l) if you are constipated, (2) if you are anaemic, (3) if you are feverish, (4) if you have indigestion, (5) if you have a headache, (6) if you are rheumatic, (7) if you are gouty, (8) if you are fretting and fuming, (9) if you are depressed, (10) if you are overjoyed; and you will avoid medical prescriptions and patent medicines.
('33', 300, 1, 7, 676442) Eat only when you are hungry and when you have laboured for your food.
('33', 300, 2, 8, 676513) Young India, 17 12 1925
('33', 300, 3, 9, 676537) 198. MY NOTES
('33', 300, 4, 10, 676551) GUJARATI NATLONAL SCHOOL IN BOMBAY
('33', 300, 5, 11, 676586) Among the national schools which continue to run despite the sword that is hanging over their heads, the Gujarati School in Bombay is one.
('33', 300, 5, 12, 676725) It could be said of it that it owes its survival to this day solely to the efforts of the teachers.
('33', 300, 5, 13, 676825) I hope that the Bombay Provincial [Congress] Committee will maintain this school or make a substantial contribution towards its maintenance.
('33', 300, 5, 14, 676966) The annual function of this school was celebrated on the 8th of this month.
('33', 300, 5, 15, 677042) On that occasion the students enacted some dramatic pieces, revealed their musical talent and rendered set dialogues in Hindi, Sanskrit, English and Gujarati.
('33', 300, 5, 16, 677201) Some of the students acquitted themselves very well.
('33', 300, 5, 17, 677254) The music, too, was of a higher standard than what I had heard on a previous occasion.
('33', 300, 5, 18, 677341) The enunciation of Sanskrit was clear.
('33', 300, 5, 19, 677380) On the whole, the students made a good impression on me, at any rate, with their artistic talents.
('33', 300, 5, 20, 677479) We see from the report of this school that all the subjects are taught in it through the mother tongue.
('33', 300, 5, 21, 677583) The teachers claim to teach history and geography according to new methods.
('33', 300, 5, 22, 677659) It is no small
('33', 301, 0, 1, 677674) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 301, 1, 2, 677716) advantage to the pupils to be taught subjects like geometry through Gujarati.
('33', 301, 1, 3, 677794) Stress is laid on Sanskrit and Hindi too.
('33', 301, 1, 4, 677836) Accountancy finds a place in the curriculum.
('33', 301, 1, 5, 677881) The handicrafts taught of course include spinning on the takli and the spinning wheel, but in addition to this pottery, carpentry, painting and such other crafts are also being taught.
('33', 301, 2, 6, 678066) The teachers are inspired by a spirit of self sacrifice.
('33', 301, 2, 7, 678123) They have voluntarily agreed to a cut of fifteen per cent in their salaries.
('33', 301, 2, 8, 678200) The head master himself serves in an honorary capacity There is an Educational Association too, with Shri Revashankar Jagjivan Jhaveri as its President.
('33', 301, 2, 9, 678353) The accounts of the Association seem to be well maintained.
('33', 301, 2, 10, 678413) It is but proper that people should help a school such as this—in which the education is liberal, the teachers are patriotic and the accounts in proper order—by giving it financial assistance and by enrolling pupils in it.
('33', 301, 3, 11, 678636) There is only one point which calls for criticism.
('33', 301, 3, 12, 678687) In the dramatic performances the costumes used were made of foreign cloth, and this was out of keeping with the national character of the school and therefore painful.
('33', 301, 3, 13, 678855) Was it quite necessary to use such costumes?
('33', 301, 3, 14, 678900) The people did not go there to see a play acted, they went there to see the attainments of the pupils.
('33', 301, 3, 15, 679003) It is usual in plays to use rich, gorgeous clothes which, in spite of their dazzle, are not pleasing to a fastidious eye.
('33', 301, 3, 16, 679125) This practice should certainly not be followed in an educational institution which aspires to cultivate idealism in the pupils.
('33', 301, 3, 17, 679253) We should place before the boys nothing less than the highest ideal.
('33', 301, 3, 18, 679322) There should be no need to dress Hamlet in foreign clothes.
('33', 301, 3, 19, 679382) We may dress him in the costume of his time, or in one imagined by us as proper to him.
('33', 301, 3, 20, 679470) We can dress him according to our Indian image of him, since what he thinks and feels is a universal experience.
('33', 301, 3, 21, 679583) The costume of characters belonging to Moghul times can be in the genuine Moghul style or in some other style imagined by us.
('33', 301, 3, 22, 679709) We are lovers of khadi and, therefore, should use khadi in all such performances.
('33', 301, 3, 23, 679791) I did not like even the curtains which were procured from a theatre.
('33', 301, 3, 24, 679860) If I could have my way, I would not use such curtains but would design, instead, some artistic arrangement with khadi.
('33', 301, 3, 25, 679979) This, however, will be done only if the workers have great love for khadi and give careful thought to such matters.
('33', 301, 3, 26, 680095) Where else shall we look for either if not in those who run a national school?
('33', 301, 3, 27, 680174) Let us pray that the national schools should demonstrate in their practice the ideals of future
('33', 302, 0, 1, 680270) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 303
('33', 302, 1, 2, 680321) India, that they should be the sources, as holy as Gangotri and Jamnotri, from which will flow noble thoughts and noble ideals of conduct.
('33', 302, 2, 3, 680460) SPINNING WHEEL FOR FAMINE RELIEF

('33', 302, 3, 5, 680600) Atrai and some other parts of Bengal were the first to do this.
('33', 302, 3, 6, 680664) In Orissa a successful experiment is being carried on to introduce spinning in areas which have suffered heavy losses through floods, though the work being done there can be on a larger scale still.

('33', 303, 7, 13, 682151) 201. LETTER TO PUNJABHAI
('33', 303, 8, 14, 682176) Magsar Vad 13 [December 13, 1925] 2
('33', 303, 9, 15, 682212) BHAI PUNJABHAI, I regularly get your nice letters.
('33', 303, 9, 16, 682263) I hope you had the letter 3 I wrote after reaching here.
('33', 303, 9, 17, 682320) With persistent efforts you will be able to clear your eye [of evil].
('33', 303, 9, 18, 682390) Always be on the alert.
('33', 303, 9, 19, 682414) The way to escape violence in speech is to talk as little as possible and not to speak at all without weighing your words.
('33', 303, 9, 20, 682537) Blessings from BAPU BHAI PUNJABHAI (NANA) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM SABARMATI

('33', 310, 6, 9, 691203) 213. A STUDENT’S QUESTIONS
('33', 310, 7, 10, 691230) A student who is carrying on post graduate studies in America writes:
('33', 310, 8, 11, 691300) I am one of those who are extremely interested in the utilization of Indian resources as one of the means for remedying the poverty of India.
('33', 310, 8, 12, 691442) This is my sixth year in this country My special field is wood chemistry.
('33', 310, 8, 13, 691516) I would have entered executive services or taken up medical studies if I were not so profoundly convinced of the importance of the industrial development of India.
('33', 310, 8, 14, 691680) Would you approve of my going into industrial enterprise, say pulp and paper manufacture?
('33', 310, 8, 15, 691770) What is your attitude in general on the question of adopting a sane, humanitarian industrial policy for India?
('33', 310, 8, 16, 691881) Do you stand for the progress of science?
('33', 310, 8, 17, 691923) I mean such progress which brings blessings to mankind, e.g., the work of Pasteur of France and that of Dr. Benting of Toronto.
('33', 310, 8, 18, 692051) I answer this question publicly as so many inquiries are received by me from students all over, and as so much misconception exists regarding my views on science.
('33', 310, 8, 19, 692214) I should have no objection whatsoever to industrial enterprise such as the student has in view.
('33', 310, 8, 20, 692310) Only I would not call it necessarily humanitarian.
('33', 310, 8, 21, 692361) A humanitarian industrial policy for India means to me a glorified revival of hand spinning, for through it alone can pauperism, which is blighting the lives of millions of human beings in their own cottages in this land, be immediately
('33', 310, 9, 22, 692598) 1 The letter evidently was written after Gandhiji had visited the Utkal tannery at Cuttack on August 19, 1925. In 1925 Paush Sud I corresponded to the 16th of December when Gandhiji was at Wardha.
('33', 310, 9, 23, 692795) 2 Vinoba Bhave
('33', 311, 0, 1, 692810) 312 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 311, 1, 2, 692852) removed.
('33', 311, 1, 3, 692861) Everything else may thereafter be added, so as to increase the productive capacity of this country.
('33', 311, 1, 4, 692961) I would therefore have all young men with a scientific training to utilize their skill in making the spinning wheel, if it is possible, a more efficient instrument of produc tion in India’s cottages.
('33', 311, 1, 5, 693161) I am not opposed to the progress of science as such.
('33', 311, 1, 6, 693214) On the contrary the scientific spirit of the West commands my admiration and if that admiration is qualified, it is because the scientist of the West takes no note of God’s lower creation.
('33', 311, 1, 7, 693403) I abhor vivisection with my whole soul.
('33', 311, 1, 8, 693443) I detest the unpardonable slaughter of innocent life in the name of science and humanity so called, and all the scientist discoveries stained with innocent blood I count as of no consequence.
('33', 311, 1, 9, 693635) If the circulation of blood theory could not have been discovered with out vivisection the human kind could well have done without it.
('33', 311, 1, 10, 693770) And I see the day clearly dawning when the honest scientist of the West will put limitations upon the present methods of pursuing knowledge.
('33', 311, 1, 11, 693911) Future measurements will take note not only of the human family but of all that lives and even as we are slowly but surely discovering that it is an error to suppose that Hindus can thrive upon the degradation of a fifth of themselves or that peoples of the West can rise or live upon the exploitation and degradation of the Eastern and African nations, so shall we realize in the fulness of time, that our dominion over the lower order of creation is not for their slaughter, but for their benefit equally with ours.
('33', 311, 1, 12, 694429) For I am as certain that they are endowed with a soul as that I am.
('33', 311, 2, 13, 694497) The same student asks:
('33', 311, 3, 14, 694520) I would like to know your very frank evaluation of the work of Christian missionaries in India.
('33', 311, 3, 15, 694616) Do you believe that Christianity has some contribution to make to the life of our country?
('33', 311, 3, 16, 694707) Can we do without Christianity?
('33', 311, 3, 17, 694739) In my opinion Christian missionaries have done good to us indirectly.
('33', 311, 3, 18, 694809) Their direct contribution is probably more harmful than otherwise.
('33', 311, 3, 19, 694876) I am against the modern method of proselytizing.
('33', 311, 3, 20, 694925) Years’ experience of proselytizing both in South Africa and India has convinced me that it has not raised the general moral tone of the converts who have imbibed the superficialities of European civilization, and have missed the teaching of Jesus.
('33', 311, 3, 21, 695173) I must be understood to refer to the general tendency and not to brilliant exceptions.
('33', 311, 3, 22, 695260) The indirect contribution, on the other hand, of Christian missionary effort is great.
('33', 311, 3, 23, 695347) It has stimulated Hindu and Mussalman
('33', 312, 0, 1, 695385) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 313
('33', 312, 1, 2, 695436) religious research.
('33', 312, 1, 3, 695456) It has forced us to put our own houses in order.
('33', 312, 1, 4, 695505) The great educational and curative institutions of Christian missions I also count, amongst indirect results, because they have been established, not for their own sakes, but as an aid to proselytizing.
('33', 312, 1, 5, 695708) The world, and therefore we, can no more do without the teaching of Jesus than we can without that of Mahomed or the Unpanishads.
('33', 312, 1, 6, 695838) I hold all these to be complementary to one another, in no case exclusive.
('33', 312, 1, 7, 695913) Their true.
('33', 312, 1, 8, 695925) meaning, their interdependence and interrelation, have still to be revealed to us.
('33', 312, 1, 9, 696008) We are but indifferent representatives of our respective faiths which we believe more often than not.
('33', 312, 1, 10, 696110) The third question put by the student is as follows: In our united staies of India, are we going to leave the present native States intact, or have a democracy there?
('33', 312, 1, 11, 696277) In order to have political unity, what should be our common language?
('33', 312, 1, 12, 696347) Why can’t we make it English?
('33', 312, 1, 13, 696377) The Indian States are even now changing their character, be it ever so imperceptibly.
('33', 312, 1, 14, 696463) They cannot he autocratic when the bulk of India becomes democratic.
('33', 312, 1, 15, 696532) What, however, Indian democracy will be no one can tell.
('33', 312, 1, 16, 696589) It is easy enough to foresee the future, if English were our common language.
('33', 312, 1, 17, 696667) For it would be then the democracy of a mere handful But if we desire to realize, as we must, the political unity of the vast mass of Indian humanity, he must be a prophet who would foretell the future.
('33', 312, 1, 18, 696870) And the common language of the vast mass can never be English.
('33', 312, 1, 19, 696933) It is as a matter of course a resultant of Hindi and Urdu or Hindustani as I would call it.
('33', 312, 1, 20, 697025) Our English speech has isolated us from the millions of our countrymen.
('33', 312, 1, 21, 697097) We have become foreigners in our own land.
('33', 312, 1, 22, 697140) The manner in which English speech has permeated the political minded men of India constitutes in my humble opinion a crime against the country, indeed humanity; because we are a stumbling block in the progress of our own country, and the progress of what is after all a continent must mean the progress of humanity and vice versa.
('33', 312, 1, 23, 697472) Every English educated Indian who has penetrated the villages has realized this burning truth, even as I have.
('33', 312, 1, 24, 697583) I have profound admiration for the English language and many noble qualities of the English people, but I have no manner of doubt in my mind that the English language and the English people occupy a place in our life which retards our progress and theirs as well.
('33', 312, 2, 25, 697847) Young India, 17 12 1925
('33', 313, 0, 1, 697871) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 313, 1, 2, 697913) 214. LAST YEAR’S KHADI WORK
('33', 313, 2, 3, 697941) The report of the All India Khadi Board, now converted into the All India Spinners’ Association, on khadi work done by the late Board during the last year is an instructive document which I commend to the attention not merely of every lover of khadi but also of every critic and sceptic.
('33', 313, 2, 4, 698229) The report can be had from the Secretaries, All India Spinners’ Association, Sabarmati.
('33', 313, 2, 5, 698317) It omits mention of no weak point, it sufficiently deals with the delays and the neglect of provincial bodies, it takes note of the tremendous difficulties in the progress of the spinning wheel.
('33', 313, 2, 6, 698512) But when all is said and done, what remains of substantial work shows the headway khadi has made, not yet enough to be striking, not yet enough to affect the villagers’ life, nor yet enough to bring about the coveted boycott of foreign cloth, but by itself the record is striking.
('33', 313, 2, 7, 698793) Superficial observers tell me that khadi is on the wane, because in big cities they see fewer white caps than before.
('33', 313, 2, 8, 698911) I call them ‘white’ because all white caps are not khadi caps.
('33', 313, 2, 9, 698974) Experience has taught me that these caps were a gross deception.
('33', 313, 2, 10, 699039) Many of these wearers were no more khadi lovers than the honest man who because he does not otherwise discard foreign cloth refuses to wear the khadi cap for a mere show or worse.
('33', 313, 2, 11, 699219) The figures tell a different tale altogether.
('33', 313, 2, 12, 699265) More khadi is being manufactured today than in 1921, more charkhas are plying than before, their output is larger, and the quality of khadi manufacture is far superior to what it was four years ago.
('33', 313, 2, 13, 699464) The work has become more systematized and better organized for more rapid progress.
('33', 313, 2, 14, 699548) There are more spinners spinning for hire.
('33', 313, 2, 15, 699591) The number of steady voluntary spinners is also growing though slowly.
('33', 313, 2, 16, 699662) More young men and women are earning their livelihood as khadi organizers than in any other national department.
('33', 313, 2, 17, 699775) Khadi service is an ever growing service.
('33', 313, 2, 18, 699817) Its capacity for paying a decent salary to honest, intelligent, and indus trious workers is almost limitless.
('33', 313, 2, 19, 699927) Khadi claims also the largest number of unpaid national workers.
('33', 313, 2, 20, 699992) Above all it has now become an established fact that khadi work cannot be done without an efficient organization exclusively devoted to it and commanding the services paid and unpaid, of an army of able workers.
('33', 313, 2, 21, 700204) Its technical department is responsible for several important inventions, as for instance, an improved yarn press for pressing and baling small quantities of yarn.
('33', 313, 2, 22, 700368) It examines samples of khadi, samples of yarn and detects spurious
('33', 314, 0, 1, 700435) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 315
('33', 314, 1, 2, 700486) It trains also students as organized or workers in their own homes.
('33', 314, 1, 3, 700554) It has been carrying on experiments in dyeing and introducing waterproof khadi.
('33', 314, 1, 4, 700634) And both of these experiments have met with considerable success.
('33', 314, 1, 5, 700700) Let the sceptic verify the facts for himself by securing a copy of the report, and if he is satisfied, let him join the Association, or if he cannot yet fulfil the conditions, help it with such work as he can do, or with such funds as he can spare.

('33', 314, 3, 7, 700973) 215. NOTES
('33', 314, 4, 8, 700984) COUNCILS ENTRY
('33', 314, 5, 9, 700999) An American publicist writes:
('33', 314, 6, 10, 701029) I am sorry to see you support, in any way, going into the Councils.
('33', 314, 6, 11, 701097) If you were right before you came to this position, you are wrong now, I have always likened Councils to a tin plate given to a baby with the statement:”This is the moon; play, dear, with it, all you wish.” The writer reading scrappy bits from my writing, has evidently misunderstood my position.
('33', 314, 6, 12, 701394) I hold to the same position that I occupied in 1920 21 regarding Councils entry.
('33', 314, 6, 13, 701475) I do not support going into the Councils.
('33', 314, 6, 14, 701517) But I claim to be a practical man.
('33', 314, 6, 15, 701552) I do not blind my eyes and refuse to see facts that stare me in the face.
('33', 314, 6, 16, 701626) I recognize that some of my best friends and coworkers who sailed in the same vessel with me in 1920 21 have gone off the vessel and altered their course.
('33', 314, 6, 17, 701781) They are as much representatives of the nation as I claim to be.
('33', 314, 6, 18, 701846) I have therefore to determine the extent to which I can accommodate my course to theirs, and Councils entry being a fact which I cannot alter, I have had no hesitation in tendering to my colleagues, the Swarajists, such help as it is possible for me to give, just as, though pacifist myself, I cannot help sympathizing with the brave Riffs as against the European usurpers.
('33', 314, 7, 19, 702220) MALAVIYAJI AND LALAJI
('33', 314, 8, 20, 702242) An active member of the Hindu Mahasabha has sent me fifteen questions to answer in the pages of Young India and Navajivan.
('33', 314, 8, 21, 702365) Another has discussed several matters after the style of these questions.
('33', 314, 8, 22, 702439) I do not propose to answer all of them.
('33', 314, 8, 23, 702479) But some of them I dare not avoid.
('33', 314, 8, 24, 702514) They draw my attention to the attacks being made in the Press on Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviyaji and Lalaji.
('33', 315, 0, 1, 702621) 316 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 315, 1, 2, 702663) questions put to me are:
('33', 315, 2, 3, 702688) Do you question their good faith?
('33', 315, 2, 4, 702722) Do you regard them as being opposed to Hindu Muslim unity either directly or indirectly?
('33', 315, 2, 5, 702811) Do you consider them to be capable wilfully of doing harm to the country?
('33', 315, 2, 6, 702885) I do occasionally see the attacks made against these patriots.
('33', 315, 2, 7, 702948) I know also that many of my Mussalman friends thoroughly distrust both these distinguished public men.
('33', 315, 2, 8, 703051) But however much I may differ from them in many respects, I have never been able to distrust either of them.
('33', 315, 2, 9, 703160) Indeed I have noticed among Hindu circles similar attacks on several prominent Mussalman workers as I have in Mussalman circles against Malaviyaji and Lalaji.
('33', 315, 2, 10, 703319) I have not been able to believe either the one or the other charge.
('33', 315, 2, 11, 703387) But I have not been able to carry home my belief to either party.
('33', 315, 2, 12, 703453) Malaviyaji and Lalaji are both tried servants of the country, both have to their credit a long, unbroken and distinguished record of service.
('33', 315, 2, 13, 703595) I have had the privilege of enjoying confidential relations with them, and I cannot recall a single occasion when I have found them to be anti Muslim.
('33', 315, 2, 14, 703746) Not that therefore they have not distrusted Mussalman leaders, or that their views and mine about the solution of the very difficult and delicate question have been identical.
('33', 315, 2, 15, 703922) They have never questioned the necessity of unity, and they have ever, according to their own lights, striven for it.
('33', 315, 2, 16, 704040) In my opinion to question the good faith of these leaders is to doubt the possibility of unity.
('33', 315, 2, 17, 704136) The voices will count as effectively in Hindu society when.
('33', 315, 2, 18, 704196) we come to terms—as some day we must as say, precisely, the voices of Hakim Saheb and Maulana Abul Kalam Azad will count in Muslim circles.
('33', 315, 2, 19, 704336) Indeed my prescription to every public worker is to take every worker at his own word till there is positive proof to the contrary.
('33', 315, 2, 20, 704468) A believer loses nothing even where he has been misled and cheated.
('33', 315, 2, 21, 704536) Public life in the midst of suspicion and distrust becomes intolerable when it does not become impossible.

('33', 316, 2, 3, 705300) POTENCY OF CHARKHA
('33', 316, 3, 4, 705319) Acharya Rama Deva of Kangri Gurukul who has just returned from his East African tour says among other things:
('33', 316, 4, 5, 705429) I am convinced more than ever that British domination will not cease, so long as its motive lasts, and the motive is economic exploitation.
('33', 316, 4, 6, 705569) The only effective means of rendering economic exploitation an impossibility and of shutting out the drain upon our resources is khaddar.
('33', 316, 4, 7, 705707) In the Gurukul all the boys of the Secondary Department and many boys m the colleges know spinning and most of the former and a sufficiently large number of the latter spin regularly.
('33', 316, 4, 8, 705891) The principal of our Veda Mahavidyalaya, Pandit Deva Sharma Vidyalankar, is a regular spinner who spins religiously every day.
('33', 316, 4, 9, 706018) Two or three of our professors are trying to follow in his footsteps.
('33', 316, 4, 10, 706088) I am not sure that, when we meet next time, you will not find me a spinner.
('33', 316, 4, 11, 706164) Principal Vidyawati is anxious to improve the teaching of spinning and to introduce weaving in the Kanya Gurukul at Delhi.
('33', 316, 4, 12, 706287) I hope that Acharya Rama Deva will prove as good as his word, and that when I meet him I shall find him as accomplished a spinner as he is a scholar.
('33', 316, 4, 13, 706437) I tender my congratulations to the boys and to the professors who are spinning regularly by way of sacrifice.
('33', 316, 5, 14, 706547) KENYA INDIANS, BEWARE
('33', 316, 6, 15, 706569) Acharya Rama Deva was in East Africa for close on six months.
('33', 316, 6, 16, 706631) He gives me a gloomy picture of Indian life there.
('33', 316, 6, 17, 706682) He tells me that many Hindus and Mussalmans have taken to drink, they do not mind the use of videshi things even when they are avoidable.
('33', 316, 6, 18, 706820) He considers the local Congress finances to be in a bad way, and he ends by saying that the leaders are not leading.
('33', 316, 6, 19, 706937) He makes several other allegations and even authorizes me to publish them but I refrain for the moment.
('33', 316, 6, 20, 707041) I wish I could act in accordance with his suggestion that I should depute someone to East Africa and inquire into the allegations he makes.
('33', 316, 6, 21, 707181) I am sorry, however, that it is not possible for me to do so, at any rate for the time being.
('33', 316, 6, 22, 707275) But I do appeal to the Kenya Indians to go through the process of introspection, filling the blank spaces left in this note and get their own house in order.
('33', 316, 6, 23, 707433) Those who are given to drink must get rid of the drink habit, and those who are not, should help their less fortunate co settlers to avoid the curse.

('33', 320, 10, 19, 713017) 223. MY DHARMA
('33', 320, 11, 20, 713032) There are many friends who point out”my dharma” to me, and I am happy that they do it.
('33', 320, 11, 21, 713119) The fact that they write to me freely is evidence of their love for me and their confidence that what they say will not hurt me.

('33', 320, 11, 25, 713466) I, therefore, give it here with a few omissions: 2
('33', 320, 12, 26, 713517) 1 From the postmark,”Sabarmati, December 21, 1925”; the source, however, has”Posh Vad 3” which corresponds to January 13, 1925.
('33', 320, 13, 27, 713645) 2 The letter is not translated here.

('33', 321, 0, 1, 713801) 322 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 321, 1, 2, 713843) Though the letter has been written with a good motive and seems at first to be well reasoned, I am unable to follow the advice of these friends.
('33', 321, 2, 3, 713988) Our holy books tell us in the plainest words that one’s own dharma is to be preferred even though it may require no great virtue to follow it.
('33', 321, 2, 4, 714131) Another’s dharma may seem to have superior virtue in it but it is better even to lose one’s life in following one’s modest dharma.
('33', 321, 2, 5, 714262) It is dangerous to follow another’s dharma.
('33', 321, 2, 6, 714306) Can I leave the field merely because today people do not accept my views?
('33', 321, 2, 7, 714380) The idea of non co operation was conceived first by me.
('33', 321, 2, 8, 714436) I did not know then how it would be received.
('33', 321, 2, 9, 714482) I put into practice what I believed to be dharma and invited others to follow me.
('33', 321, 2, 10, 714564) A good many were attracted by the idea.
('33', 321, 2, 11, 714604) What difference does it make to me if it has now lost attraction for them?
('33', 321, 2, 12, 714679) Should I give up my dharma because of that?
('33', 321, 2, 13, 714723) If It do so, I would dishonour my ideal of service.
('33', 321, 2, 14, 714775) My faith in the efficacy of non co operation remains what it was at the time of its inception.
('33', 321, 3, 15, 714870) The alternation of flood and ebb is a law of nature.
('33', 321, 3, 16, 714923) Why should we be elated with pride at flood tide and be filled with despair at ebb tide?
('33', 321, 3, 17, 715012) one who has no control over the helm may lose direction.
('33', 321, 3, 18, 715069) My hands are.
('33', 321, 3, 19, 715083) firm on the helm and, therefore,.
('33', 321, 3, 20, 715117) I have no such fear.
('33', 321, 3, 21, 715138) People’s love of khadi has increased rather than diminished.
('33', 321, 3, 22, 715199) Blind worship has changed into intelligent love.
('33', 321, 3, 23, 715248) On the whole, the quality of khadi being produced is.
('33', 321, 3, 24, 715302) daily improving and the demand for it is increasing.
('33', 321, 3, 25, 715355) Among public activities which are going on independently of the Government, I think there is none which is as much alive as the Khadi Movement.
('33', 321, 3, 26, 715499) This statement can be proved with the help of figures.
('33', 321, 3, 27, 715554) It is a fact that spinning and carding have stopped in a few places; nevertheless, they are better organized today than they were at any time during the past four years.
('33', 321, 3, 28, 715724) The Hindu Muslim problem is, today, like the lump of clay on the potter’s wheel.
('33', 321, 3, 29, 715805) The Almighty alone knows what kind of pot will emerge.
('33', 321, 3, 30, 715860) However, having regard to the unparalleled popular awakening, the present developments, though painful, should surprise no one.
('33', 321, 3, 31, 715988) All the dirt has come up to the surface and, therefore, it is all that we see.

('33', 321, 3, 33, 716204) They have no choice but to become united, and so I am not worried on that score.
('33', 321, 3, 34, 716285) If Fate has decreed that we should fight
('33', 322, 0, 1, 716326) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 323
('33', 322, 1, 2, 716377) a few battles among ourselves, let us.
('33', 322, 1, 3, 716416) This will not be the first instance of such fighting in the annals of the world.
('33', 322, 1, 4, 716497) Brothers sometimes fight with one another, but unite again.
('33', 322, 1, 5, 716557) When the era of peace dawns upon us, wars will seem barbaric.
('33', 322, 1, 6, 716619) Today, however, fighting is looked upon as civilized.
('33', 322, 1, 7, 716673) Untouchability is on its last legs.
('33', 322, 1, 8, 716709) Its soul is dead, what we see is only its skeleton.
('33', 322, 1, 9, 716761) We need not be filled with despair because our struggle for swaraj has resulted in creating disunity among us.
('33', 322, 1, 10, 716872) Such things have taken place among all nations which have become free.
('33', 322, 1, 11, 716943) Our duty is only to take note of them and seek remedies for them; to lose heart in the face of them would be evidence of our cowardice.
('33', 322, 1, 12, 717079) A person who has accepted defeat in India, what can he give to America or bring thence for our country?
('33', 322, 1, 13, 717183) People’s admiration for me in America or Europe cannot blind me.
('33', 322, 1, 14, 717248) We shall profit nothing by begging for help from the West.
('33', 322, 1, 15, 717307) My returning with a certificate from the West would be a matter of shame for the country and me.
('33', 322, 1, 16, 717404) I see no good reason at present which could induce me to go to Europe or America.
('33', 322, 1, 17, 717486) Let no one believe that the leaders of those continents are simply pining to meet me or hear me.

('33', 322, 1, 19, 717712) They, too, like me, seem to have nothing else to do and so build castles in the air and formulate plans for the betterment of the world.

('33', 322, 1, 22, 718026) Whatever strength I have can best be demonstrated in our country.
('33', 322, 1, 23, 718092) Hills seem beautiful from a distance.
('33', 322, 1, 24, 718130) Immediately I leave India, I shall have stepped out of my true sphere, and such persons have no place anywhere in the world.
('33', 322, 1, 25, 718255) Even in Africa, I can do nothing now.

('33', 322, 1, 27, 718445) My Krishna would not be there by my side now.
('33', 322, 1, 28, 718491) A soldier distinguishes himself in a fight which comes to him unsought.

('33', 325, 6, 26, 724021) 227. SPEECH AT WARDHA 2
('33', 325, 7, 27, 724045) December 21, 1925
('33', 325, 8, 28, 724063) Ten years have passed since I left South Africa.
('33', 325, 8, 29, 724112) I have received hundreds of letters, and have replied to them.
('33', 325, 8, 30, 724175) I have explained this matter a hundred times over in Young India and in Navajivan, and yet, when I come to the Wardha Ashram I am being asked the very same questions.
('33', 325, 8, 31, 724342) This has revived old memories for me and distressed me very much.
('33', 325, 8, 32, 724408) I do not say that such questions should not occur to anyone, but, if they do, people may approach Vinoba and have their doubts answered.
('33', 325, 8, 33, 724545) However, the reason for my being distressed was that it has become a widespread disease to ask such questions.
('33', 325, 8, 34, 724656) We should
('33', 325, 9, 35, 724666) 1Vide the following item.
('33', 325, 10, 36, 724692) 2 At the morning prayer in the Ashram
('33', 326, 0, 1, 724730) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 327
('33', 326, 1, 2, 724781) resist the temptation to ask them.
('33', 326, 1, 3, 724816) Please understand my words properly.
('33', 326, 1, 4, 724853) What I wish to say is that such questions may certainly occur to us, but, they should be kept back in one’s mind.
('33', 326, 1, 5, 724967) When, thousands of yearsago, the battle of Kurukshetra was fought, the doubts which occurred to Arjuna were answered by Shri Krishna in the Gita; but that battle of Kurukshetra is going on, will go on, for ever within us, the Prince of Yogis, Lord Krishna, the universal atman dwelling in the hearts of us all, will always be there to guide Arjuna, the human soul, and our Godward impulses represented by the Pandavas will always triumph over the demoniac impulses represented by the Kauravas.
('33', 326, 1, 6, 725461) Till, however,.
('33', 326, 1, 7, 725477) that victory is won, we should have faith and let the battle go on, and be patient meanwhile.
('33', 326, 1, 8, 725571) This does not mean that we should suppress our inner urge for fear of anyone; it means that if such an urge takes the form of the question”Who created God?”, we should curb it, tell ourselves that it is impious to ask such a question and have faith that the question will answer itself by and by.
('33', 326, 1, 9, 725868) This physical frame which God has given us is a prison, but it is also the door leading to deliverance and, if we wish that it should serve only that purpose, we should understand its limitations.
('33', 326, 1, 10, 726065) We may well desire to clutch the stars in the heavens, but we should note that it is beyond our power to do so; for our soul is imprisoned in a cage, its wings, therefore, have been clipped and it cannot fly as high as it would.
('33', 326, 1, 11, 726294) It can secure a great many occult powers, but it will fail in its aim of winning deliverance if it goes after such powers.
('33', 326, 1, 12, 726417) Hence, the kind of abstract questions which were put to me the other day should be avoided —in the conviction that in the course of time the soul will become strong enough and know the answers to them.
('33', 326, 1, 13, 726619) Instead of discussing such abstract questions, we should follow the advice of the poet:”Let us spend today to some purpose, for who knows what tomorrow will bring?” This line may seem to come from the pen of Charvak, who also says:”Live in ease while you live, drink ghee even if you have to borrow money for it, for the body will never return to life after it is cremated.” But the line is not by Charvak.
('33', 326, 1, 14, 727026) Its author was a devotee and, when he advised us to spend today profitably, he meant that we should discharge the duty which lies before us today.
('33', 326, 1, 15, 727173) We do not know if we shall be alive tomorrow, though a little later he says that we shall be born again.
('33', 326, 1, 16, 727278) This duty is what was explained by Vinoba the other day,”ending the misery of all creatures that suffer”, destroying the chain of ever recurring birth and death.
('33', 326, 1, 17, 727440) The only
('33', 327, 0, 1, 727449) 328 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 327, 1, 2, 727491) means for this is bhakti 1. An Englishman named Newman, a grate devotee, wrote in a poem of his”One step enough for me.” This half line is the quintessence of all philosophy.
('33', 327, 1, 3, 727666) That one step means patient, unswerving bhakti.
('33', 327, 1, 4, 727714) If a sick person gets up and tries to walk down a staircase, he would feel giddy and fall.
('33', 327, 1, 5, 727805) If we do not understand our limitations and try to get knowledge which is beyond us, we would not only not be able to digest it but would be sick with surfeit.
('33', 327, 1, 6, 727965) We should, therefore, cure ourselves of the disease of asking abstract questions, should attend to the immediate duty before us today and leave these questions for some other day.
('33', 327, 1, 7, 728145) The couplet from a bhajan which was sung here today teaches us the very same thing, that instead of talking about mukti 2 all the time we should spend our time in bhakti.
('33', 327, 1, 8, 728316) Without bhakti there can be no deliverance.
('33', 327, 1, 9, 728360) Only he, therefore, wins deliverance who is devoted to duty and fills his heart with love of God—he alone wins deliverance who never thinks about it.
('33', 327, 2, 10, 728510) Bhakti, moreover, does not imply ineptitude in practical affairs.
('33', 327, 2, 11, 728576) That which produces such ineptitude cannot be called bhakti.
('33', 327, 2, 12, 728637) It may, of course, be that, looking at the way we conduct our affairs, people will think of us as simpletons.
('33', 327, 2, 13, 728747) A true devotee, though fully attentive to practical affairs, brings the spirit of bhakti into them.
('33', 327, 2, 14, 728847) His conduct will always be in harmony with dharma.
('33', 327, 2, 15, 728898) It is because Krishna acted in this manner that he is looked upon as the Purnavatara 3. A devotee finds no difficulty in attending to the practical affairs of life.
('33', 327, 2, 16, 729063) Ashrams like this one are established so that such a way of life in complete harmony with dharma may prevail everywhere.
('33', 327, 2, 17, 729184) I have, therefore, always cherished the hope that these Ashrams will serve as instruments for raising the country and teaching and spreading true dharma.
('33', 327, 2, 18, 729338) I do not worry whether that hope will be fulfilled in the present or after many generations—it is sufficient for us that we go on doing our duty along the path we have chalked out for ourselves.
('33', 327, 2, 19, 729533) For this, we should strive to cultivate the qualities of both a Brahmin— truth and faith—and a Kshatriya and non violence.
('33', 327, 2, 20, 729656) It is my faith that this Ashram will help its inmates to cultivate both these types of qualities.
('33', 327, 2, 21, 729754) I do not suggest, of course, that other Ashrams cannot do that.
('33', 327, 2, 22, 729818) I believe that this Ashram, at any rate, will do some good.
('33', 327, 2, 23, 729878) If we realize that truth and non violence have a particular value for us and
('33', 327, 3, 24, 729955) 1 Loving devotion to God 2 Deliverance 3 Prefect avatar
('33', 328, 0, 1, 730011) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 329
('33', 328, 1, 2, 730062) practise them in our lives, if we have the faith that there is no principle in this world which admits of an exception, we shall in the course of time understand the meaning of perfect truth and perfect non violence.
('33', 328, 1, 3, 730279) The peace which I have enjoyed here during the past ten days on observing that the inmates of the Ashram perform their duty in the spirit I have explained, I have enjoyed nowhere else, and you can very well imagine what my feelings must be now that I shall have to leave this peaceful atmosphere and go back to a world full of turmoil.
('33', 328, 1, 4, 730615) But, as I told a friend, our study of the Gita would have been to no purpose if we get frightened of the turmoil in the world; we should get our peace not from the external environment; but from within us, and so I do not worry.

('33', 332, 1, 2, 737699) 232. NOTES
('33', 332, 2, 3, 737710) TOTAL PROHIBITION
('33', 332, 3, 4, 737728) C. Rajagopalachari has issued a very brief but telling manifesto recommending total prohibition as a constructive single item in the Congress as it will be constituted, when and if it endorses the Patna Resolution.
('33', 332, 3, 5, 737943) In a private letter he says that total prohibition can be, should be and is”the only unifying political force”.
('33', 332, 3, 6, 738055) It can bring together Brahmins and non Brahmins.
('33', 332, 3, 7, 738104) It can weld all political parties and it can also appeal to the masses who are directly concerned in and are to be affected by total prohibition.
('33', 332, 3, 8, 738250) There is not a shadow of a doubt that total prohibition is a crying need and that without it the ruin that the drink curse has brought to thousands of happy homes must continue its deadly course at an ever increasing pace.
('33', 332, 3, 9, 738473) It is therefore to be hoped that the suggestion made in the manifesto will be taken up by all concerned.
('33', 332, 4, 10, 738578) AMERICAN SATISFACTION Whilst several Indian friends have of late been rebuking me for not having accepted the invitation to visit America, an esteemed American friend who knows India fairly well says: May I express my gratification at your answer to the request of some American friends to visit this country?
('33', 332, 4, 11, 738888) I hope you will maintain this attitude because you can do us very much more good from India.
('33', 332, 4, 12, 738981) There is an element of curiosity hunting in even the best of our people to which I should exceedingly dislike to see you subjected.
('33', 332, 4, 13, 739113) I may assure the writer that there is no fear of my visiting America to satisfy idle curiosity.
('33', 332, 4, 14, 739209) I am quite clear in my mind that whether for better or for worse, not till I have made good my position in India can a visit to America or Europe by me be of any service either to the West or to the East.
('33', 332, 5, 15, 739414) TO WHAT STATE FALLEN

('33', 332, 6, 18, 739681) Presently we shall perform an operation in amputation so that we have nothing but the useless trunk left!

('33', 334, 5, 14, 743503) 233. THE SOUTH AFRICAN PUZZLE
('33', 334, 6, 15, 743533) The more one reads the papers brought with them by the Indian deputation from South Africa, the more insoluble the puzzle appears to be.
('33', 334, 6, 16, 743670) Dr. Malan thinks that his proposed Bill 1 does not constitute any violation of the Smuts Gandhi Agreement of 1914. Mr. James Godfrey who led the deputation that waited on him, and who is now in India as one of the members of the deputation successfully combated the view.
('33', 334, 6, 17, 743942) Now that Agreement finally closed all the questions that were the subject matter of satyagraha or passive resistance as it was known at the time.
('33', 334, 6, 18, 744088) That struggle was intended to close once for all the door against legislation based upon racial or colour distinctions.
('33', 334, 7, 19, 744208) 1 Areas Reservation and Immigration and Registration (Further Provison) Bill
('33', 335, 0, 1, 744285) 336 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 335, 1, 2, 744327) central fact was brought out not once but again and again during the six years that the struggle lasted.
('33', 335, 1, 3, 744432) A time was reached when both the late General Botha and General Smuts were ready to concede almost every material point, provided what they called the sentimental objec tion against race distinction was waived by the Indian community.
('33', 335, 1, 4, 744667) From that time, i.e., from 1908 the struggle chiefly centred round that one”sentimental” objection and General Botha had declared that on that point no South African Government could yield an inch; and he said that in further prosecuting the struggle the Indian community would be”kicking against pricks”.
('33', 335, 1, 5, 744973) Surely then it was the essence of the Agreement that no race distinction should be made in any legislation affecting the Indian community.
('33', 335, 1, 6, 745112) Dr. Malan’s Billon the other hand breathes through every line of it the racial spirit.
('33', 335, 2, 7, 745199) In my humble opinion, therefore, the Bill is a clear breach of that Agreement in this respect.
('33', 335, 2, 8, 745294) Moreover, the struggle was one against the imposition of further disabilities upon Indians.
('33', 335, 2, 9, 745386) The Settlement was to be an augury of a better future for the Indian community.
('33', 335, 2, 10, 745466) It is so stated in the correspondence.
('33', 335, 2, 11, 745505) What could be the meaning of the Settlement?
('33', 335, 2, 12, 745550) Where was any security for the Indian residents against further encroachments upon their status, if new restrictions could be imposed at the sweet will of the Government of the day?
('33', 335, 2, 13, 745732) Let there be no mistake that the Settlement was wrung from an unwilling Government after eight years’ hard and prolonged struggle involving sufferings of thousands of Indians and death of a good few.
('33', 335, 2, 14, 745932) What could be the value of a settlement which closes matters in dispute only to re open them the very next day?
('33', 335, 2, 15, 746044) Were the existing laws to be administered with punctilious regard for existing rights, only to attack the latter with new laws?
('33', 335, 2, 16, 746172) Yet such is the meaning of Dr. Malan’s contention and interpretation of the Agreement.
('33', 335, 2, 17, 746259) There is, however, some consolation even in the Minister’s tragic contention in that he does not repudiate the Settlement, but says that his Bill is not in breach of it.
('33', 335, 2, 18, 746429) One would therefore suppose that if it could be proved that the Bill was in breach of the Agreement it would have to go.
('33', 335, 3, 19, 746550) What then is to be done when parties to an agreement differ as to its interpretation?
('33', 335, 3, 20, 746636) Everybody knows the usual remedy, but let me quote two South African precedents.
('33', 335, 3, 21, 746717) There were about the year of
('33', 336, 0, 1, 746746) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 337
('33', 336, 1, 2, 746797) 1893 certain matters in dispute between the Government of the South African (Transvaal) Republic and the British Government regarding the status of British Indian settlers in the Transvaal.
('33', 336, 1, 3, 746987) Among these was the question of interpretation of Law 3 of 1885. All these matters were referred to arbitration by mutual consent, and Chief Justice Melins de Villiers of the then Orange Free State was appointed sole arbitrator.
('33', 336, 1, 4, 747216) The second precedent is a question of interpretation of the Treaty of Vereeniging between the Transvaal Government represented by General Botha and the British Government.
('33', 336, 1, 5, 747388) I think it was the late Sir Henry Campbell Bannerman who laid down that the interpretation that the weaker party, i.e., the Transvaal Government, put upon the Treaty should be accepted, and without arbitration and without further ado General Botha’s interpretation was accepted as against Lord Kitchener’s by the British Government.
('33', 336, 1, 6, 747721) Will Dr. Malan follow either precedent, or will he say after the style of the giant in the story of the giant and the dwarf that his contention must be always right?
('33', 336, 1, 7, 747887) Anyway the Indian deputation has a strong case for arbitration, seeing that Dr. Malan accepts the Settlement of 1914.
('33', 336, 2, 8, 748005) In their able statements for the Viceroy they have made out an overwhelming case.
('33', 336, 2, 9, 748087) Perhaps naturally they have not discussed the disabilities enumerated there in terms of the Settlement of 1914, having been summarily told by Dr. Malan that his proposed legislation is not in breach of the Agreement.
('33', 336, 2, 10, 748304) But it is a case not to be easily abandoned.
('33', 336, 2, 11, 748349) Theirs is undoubtedly a difficult task.
('33', 336, 2, 12, 748389) Here is a stubborn Government determined upon going on with its highly racial legislation.
('33', 336, 2, 13, 748480) All European parties seem to be in agreement on this one question.
('33', 336, 2, 14, 748547) General Smuts, Mr. Andrews tells us, has thrown his weight on the Government side.
('33', 336, 2, 15, 748630) It does not surprise me because he has always chosen to sail with the wind.
('33', 336, 2, 16, 748706) No statesman has perhaps shown so much contempt for past promises and declarations as General Smuts,—a trait in him which has earned for him the title of”Slim Janny”.
('33', 336, 2, 17, 748873) But right is clearly on the Indian side and if they have also a fixed determination not to yield an inch of ground on matters of principle, they must win.
('33', 336, 3, 18, 749028) Dr. Malan wanted James Godfrey to accept the principle of the measure, and to discuss matters of detail, to make, what he was pleased
('33', 337, 0, 1, 749162) 338 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 337, 1, 2, 749204) to call, constructive proposals.
('33', 337, 1, 3, 749237) I am glad to note that he resolutely declined to fall into the trap.
('33', 337, 1, 4, 749306) The Deputation will have all the aid that India, weak as she is, can give them.
('33', 337, 1, 5, 749386) They will have the support of all the parties.
('33', 337, 1, 6, 749433) Let them take heart and fight on.

('33', 338, 7, 25, 752960) In twenty years the population has gone up from 294 millions to 318; the area under cultivation of food grains from 177 to 204 millions.
('33', 338, 7, 26, 753097) Therefore the food grain area per head has apparently gone up from .60 to .64, but the increase is deceptive.

('33', 339, 0, 1, 753222) 340 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 339, 1, 2, 753264) underfed in 1901. It was still more underfed in 1921, for food grain area has to show a much larger increase than the increase in population, if the standard of nutriment is to keep pace with the increasing population.
('33', 339, 1, 3, 753483) The foregoing figures were prepared for me to show the comparative rise in cotton area.
('33', 339, 1, 4, 753571) From 9.6 to 15 million acres is a phenomenal rise.
('33', 339, 1, 5, 753622) No doubt it has brought more money to cultivators but it has also increased the price of food grains, thus adding to the starvation of the people making it more and more difficult for the lowest strata of society to buy enough grain.
('33', 339, 1, 6, 753856) Becauseit must be remembered that whilst those who grow cotton increase the price of food grains the balance of the population representing a vast majority not growing cotton havenot been able to increase their capacity for buying.
('33', 339, 1, 7, 754088) If these figures were further explored it would be found that the increase in cultivation area means so much displacement of grazing area with the result that either our cattle become co sharers with us in our food or are like ourselves becoming increasingly underfed and therefore giving us less milk, which is what has happened as a matter of fact.
('33', 339, 1, 8, 754439) And thus it is that those who have studied the cattle question tell us that our cattle have become a burden on the land.
('33', 339, 1, 9, 754560) This does not mean that they should necessarily become a burden.
('33', 339, 1, 10, 754625) The figures present a case for overhauling the land revenue system.
('33', 339, 1, 11, 754693) They demand a scientific study of the relative value of cotton growing and the growing of grains, and the scientific method of breeding, rearing and feeding cattle.
('33', 339, 1, 12, 754858) The figures also demonstrate the absolute necessity of cottage industry auxiliary to cultivation.
('33', 339, 1, 13, 754956) No agricultural country in the world can possibly support a population on less than one acre per head, if the population is to subsist merely or principally on agriculture.
