('33', 344, 5, 13, 765134) 241. SPEECH ON RESOLUTION ON SOUTH AFRICAN INDIANS, SUBJECTS COMMITTEE MEETING
('33', 344, 6, 14, 765213) December 25, 1925
('33', 344, 7, 15, 765231) Mr. Gandhi moved:
('33', 344, 8, 16, 765249) The Congress extends its cordial welcome to the South African Indian
('33', 344, 9, 17, 765318) Congress deputation and assures the Indian settlers of South Africa of its full
('33', 344, 10, 18, 765398) support in their struggle against the consolidated forces which threaten their
('33', 344, 11, 19, 765477) very existence in that sub continent.
('33', 344, 12, 20, 765515) This Congress is emphatically of opinion that the proposed
('33', 344, 13, 21, 765574) legislation known as the Areas Reservation and Immigration Registration
('33', 344, 14, 22, 765646) (Further Provision) Bill is a breach of the Smuts Gandhi Agreement of 1914 in
('33', 344, 15, 23, 765724) that it is racial in character and is calculated not only to make the position of
('33', 344, 16, 24, 765806) settlers much worse than it was in 1914, but is designed to make the residence
('33', 344, 17, 25, 765885) in that country of any self respecting Indian impossible.
('33', 344, 17, 26, 765943) In the opinion of the
('33', 344, 18, 27, 765965) Congress, if the interpretation of the said Agreement, as put upon it on behalf
('33', 344, 19, 28, 766045) of the settlers, is not accepted by the Union Government, it should be decided
('33', 344, 20, 29, 766124) by reference to arbitration as was done in 1893 in connection with matters
('33', 344, 21, 30, 766199) affecting the Indian settlers of the Transvaal and in matters arising from the
('33', 344, 22, 31, 766278) administration of Law 3 of 1885.
('33', 344, 23, 32, 766311) The Congress heartily endorses the suggestion that a round table
('33', 344, 24, 33, 766376) 1 The postmark bears the date”December 28, 1925.” The Friday prior to this date was December 25.
('33', 345, 0, 1, 766473) 346 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 345, 1, 2, 766515) conference containing among others proper Indian representatives should be called to settle the question and trusts that the Dominion Government will accept that reasonable suggestion.
('33', 345, 1, 3, 766700) In the event of the proposal of a round table conference and the proposal regarding arbitration failing, the Congress is of opinion that the Imperial Government should withhold Royal assent to the Bill, should it pass through the Union Parliament.
('33', 345, 2, 4, 766948) Pandit Benarsidas Chaturvedi held that culpable negligence was shown by the Congress regarding the plight of Indians overseas.
('33', 345, 2, 5, 767075) He wanted the various leaders to organize a big agitation for support and help, otherwise the promise of”full support” made in the resolution was meaningless.
('33', 345, 2, 6, 767234) He also deplored the mentality created among the masses that the cause of Indians abroad could not be helped till they got swaraj.
('33', 345, 3, 7, 767365) Mr. Gandhi, replying, acknowledged that Pandit Benarsidas was one of the few workers in the cause of Indians overseas, but he had been led away by overzeal.
('33', 345, 3, 8, 767522) The Congress had done all it possibly could in the past.
('33', 345, 3, 9, 767579) They were not capable of doing much.

('33', 345, 3, 13, 767886) He himself had supplied funds to Pandit Benarsidas.
('33', 345, 3, 14, 767938) As regards the objection taken by another speaker who had urged the deletion of the sentence asking the British Government to withhold assent, Mr. Gandhi asked, if they deleted it, what consolation would it be to South African Indians?
('33', 345, 3, 15, 768174) Then, again, had they not gone to work the Councils?
('33', 345, 3, 16, 768227) He wished, he could do without it, but they could not.

('33', 347, 4, 20, 771614) 245. SPEECH ON RESOLUTION ON SOUTH AFRICAN INDIANS, KANPUR CONGRESS December 26, 1925
('33', 347, 5, 21, 771700) In his Hindi speech on the Congress resolution about the situation in South Africa, Mr. Gandhi said that the Class Areas Bill if passed into law would compel every Indian with any sense of self respect to leave South Africa.
('33', 347, 5, 22, 771925) It was worse than repatriation inasmuch as it was legalized expulsion without any compensation to be given to those expelled.
('33', 347, 5, 23, 772051) It symbolized the determination of the white race to root out the Asiatics from South Africa.
('33', 347, 5, 24, 772145) Not even the tallest amongst the Indians—doctors, barristers like Mr. James Godfrey, one of the members of the deputation who was born and bred up there and who is visiting India for the first time—were to be suffered to stay there.
('33', 347, 5, 25, 772378) The resolution suggested three solutions of the question—arbitration, round table conference and, failing both, the Govern ment of India asking the Imperial Government to exercise the right of veto.
('33', 347, 5, 26, 772577) It asked Indians to stand by their countrymen in the hour of their trial, and to render them full help.
('33', 347, 5, 27, 772681) If they decided on satyagraha, the Indians should render them all material help in their power.
('33', 347, 6, 28, 772777) 1 As in the source
('33', 348, 0, 1, 772796) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 349
('33', 348, 1, 2, 772847) would he start a satyagraha campaign in India on this tremendous issue, but the atmosphere was against him.
('33', 348, 1, 3, 772955) If the Hindu and Mussal mans could convince him that they were united for a peaceful campaign of satyagraha, if they could convince him that they had forgotten their differences in the dark hour of the Hindus and Mussalmans in South Africa, He would readily gird up his loins and get ready for the fight.
('33', 348, 1, 4, 773260) Until then, the fight had to be carried on by the Indians over there, and India had to rest content with rendering them all help in her power.
('33', 348, 1, 5, 773403) In order that Dr. Rahman may understand his feelings in the matter, and in order also that his word of warning may reach the ears of the South African statesmen, Mr. Gandhi expressed himself at length in English thus:
('33', 348, 2, 6, 773621) SHRIMATI SAROJINI DEVI AND FRIENDS,
('33', 348, 3, 7, 773657) I do not know if you have, received copies of the resolution that is in my hand; in that case, I want to spare you the trouble of listening to the resolution and save some portion of the nation’s time.
('33', 348, 3, 8, 773859) This is how the resolution reads: 1
('33', 348, 4, 9, 773895) This is the resolution which I have not only the greatest pleasure in submitting to you for approval but I consider it a rareprivilege that I am authorized by Sarojini Devi to place it before you.
('33', 348, 4, 10, 774092) She has introduced me to you as a South African.
('33', 348, 4, 11, 774141) She might have added, ‘by adoption’.
('33', 348, 4, 12, 774178) Though born in India, I was adopted by South Africa, and you will discover that when Dr. Rahman, the leader of the deputation to which you will extend your cordial welcome—comes on this platform, he will tell you that Indians of South Africa claim that they have given me to you.
('33', 348, 4, 13, 774458) I accept that claim.
('33', 348, 4, 14, 774479) It is perfectly true that whatever service I have been able to render—it may be disservice—to India, comes from South Africa.
('33', 348, 4, 15, 774605) If it is disservice it is not their fault, it is through my limitations.
('33', 348, 4, 16, 774678) I propose to place before you facts in support of the statement made here that the Bill, which is hanging like the sword of Damocles over the heads of our countrymen in South Africa, is designed not merely to heap greater wrongs upon their heads, but virtually to expel them from South Africa.
('33', 348, 5, 17, 774972) LORD READING’S REPLY
('33', 348, 6, 18, 774993) Such is admittedly the meaning of the Bill.
('33', 348, 6, 19, 775037) It is admitted by the Europeans of South Africa and it is not denied by the Union
('33', 348, 7, 20, 775119) 1 This paragraph beginning with the salutation has been taken from The Report of the Indian National Congress, Fortieth Session, Cawnpore, 1925. For the text of the resolution, vide”Speech on Resolution on South African Indians, Subjects Committee Meeting”, 25 12 1925.
('33', 349, 0, 1, 775389) 350 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 349, 1, 2, 775431) Government itself.
('33', 349, 1, 3, 775450) If such is the result, you can imagine how keenly the Indians in South Africa must feel.
('33', 349, 1, 4, 775539) Imagine for one moment that an Expulsion Bill is to be passed in the next session of the Assembly, expelling one hundred thousand Indians from India.
('33', 349, 1, 5, 775689) What should we do or how should we behave under such a crisis?
('33', 349, 1, 6, 775752) It is under such circumstances that you have the deputation in your midst.
('33', 349, 1, 7, 775827) It comes here for support from the people of India, from the Congress, from the Viceroy, the Government of India and through it the Imperial Government itself.
('33', 349, 1, 8, 775987) Lord Reading has given them a long reply, and I wish I could have said also a satisfactory reply.
('33', 349, 1, 9, 776085) The reply His Excellency has given is as unsatisfactory as it is long.
('33', 349, 1, 10, 776156) and if that was all the comfort that Lord Reading proposed to give to the members of the deputation he could have said that in a few words and spared them, and spared this land, the humiliating spectacle of a great Government confessing its inability to render proper redress to those, who for no fault of their own and who, as many South African Europeans would admit, for their very virtues, are now in danger of being expelled from South Africa.
('33', 349, 1, 11, 776605) To some of them South Africa is a land of their birth.
('33', 349, 1, 12, 776660) It was no comfort to those friends of ours, it is no comfort to us, to be told that the Indian Government has always reserved to itself the right of making representations to the South African Government—the right of petitioning.
('33', 349, 1, 13, 776890) That is to say, a mighty Government, a Government which is supposed to hold the destinyof 300 millions of people in the hollow of its hand that Government confesses its powerlessness !
('33', 349, 1, 14, 777075) And why?
('33', 349, 1, 15, 777084) Because South Africa enjoys Dominion Status, because South Africa threatens to ‘‘cut the painter” if the Indian and the Imperial Governments intervene in any of the steps that the Government of South Africa may take.
('33', 349, 2, 16, 777301) “DOMESTIC POLICY”
('33', 349, 3, 17, 777319) Lord Reading has told the deputation that the Indian Government or Imperial Government may not interfere with the domestic policy of a colony enjoying Dominion Status.
('33', 349, 3, 18, 777487) What is the meaning of”domestic policy” when that policy is calculated to bring ruin upon the homes of thousands of Indian settlers domiciled there, and whom they deny the common rights of humanity?
('33', 349, 3, 19, 777686) Is that domestic policy?
('33', 349, 3, 20, 777711) Well, what would be the case if instead of Indians they happened to be Europeans or Englishmen?
('33', 349, 3, 21, 777807) Let me quote a precedent.
('33', 349, 3, 22, 777833) Do you know why the great Boer War
('33', 350, 0, 1, 777868) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 351
('33', 350, 1, 2, 777919) took place?
('33', 350, 1, 3, 777931) It took place in order to protect the Europeans of South Africa who were domiciled there,”Uitlanders” as they were described by the Transvaal Republican Government.
('33', 350, 1, 4, 778096) The late Mr. Joseph Chamberlain claimed for the British Government that even though the Transvaal was an independent Government he declined to admit that this was purely a domestic question.
('33', 350, 1, 5, 778287) He claimed to protect the rights of the”Uitlanders” of the Transvaal, and that was why the great Boer War took place.
('33', 350, 2, 6, 778405) CONFLICT OF CIVILIZATIONS
('33', 350, 3, 7, 778431) Lord Lansdowne, in justification of the war, said that it made his blood boil when he thought of the disabilities of Indians in the Transvaal.
('33', 350, 3, 8, 778574) He held that one of the potent causes of the Boer War was the disabilities of Indians in South Africa, or more accurately Indians of the Transvaal.
('33', 350, 3, 9, 778722) Where are those declarations today?
('33', 350, 3, 10, 778758) Why does not the British Government go to war against the Union Government when the life, honour and livelihood of one hundred and fifty thousand Indians are at stake?
('33', 350, 3, 11, 778926) Nobody questions the description I have given to you of the effects of this legislation.
('33', 350, 3, 12, 779015) Nobody questions the ever growing grievances of the British Indians in South Africa.
('33', 350, 3, 13, 779100) If you have seen a beautiful little pamphlet published by Bishop Fisher who went only a few mouths ago to South Africa, you will find that there he gives a summary of the wrongs that are being heaped upon the South African Indians.
('33', 350, 3, 14, 779332) The Bishop has come to the impartial conclusion that for these wrongs the Indians are not to blame.
('33', 350, 3, 15, 779432) It is the jealousy and theinsolence of the European trader that is responsible for these wrongs.
('33', 350, 3, 16, 779529) He gives his testimony that Indians have deserved better at the hands of Europeans of South Africa.
('33', 350, 3, 17, 779629) If justice counts, if Right rules this world, it should be impossible to bring this Bill and unnecessary for me to waste your precious time and for the deputation to waste their money.
('33', 350, 3, 18, 779814) But evidently Right does not count.
('33', 350, 3, 19, 779850) Might is Right.

('33', 359, 5, 12, 798256) 252. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA, KANPUR
('33', 359, 6, 13, 798308) December 29, 1925
('33', 359, 7, 14, 798326) Interviewed by the Associated Press representative regarding his attitude towards Pandit Motilal’s resolution which was passed last evening in the Congress.
('33', 359, 7, 15, 798483) Gandhiji said:
('33', 359, 8, 16, 798498) I did not attend yesterday’s Congress because it was my silence day and I avoid, as far as possible, going out of my place during my time of silence.
('33', 359, 8, 17, 798648) So far as the resolution itself is concerned, my position is this.
('33', 359, 8, 18, 798715) At Patna I personally surrendered all control to the Swaraj Party and I promised to give them all such support as an anti Council man could give.
('33', 359, 8, 19, 798861) I still remain opposed to Council entry on principle, but I had to make my choice either to abandon my old colleagues entirely or to render them such support as I could give.
('33', 359, 8, 20, 799036) I had no difficulty about making my choice.
('33', 359, 8, 21, 799080) If I could not help them actively I felt that I should at least refrain from instructing them in any shape or form.
('33', 359, 8, 22, 799196) I, therefore, felt that I should advise the No changers, like myself, to abstain from striving for controlling the Congress but to surrender it voluntarily to the Swarajists which I am glad to say they have done.
('33', 359, 9, 23, 799409) Q. Will you tell me if you are satisfied with the resolution passed by the
('33', 359, 10, 24, 799484) Congress?
('33', 359, 11, 25, 799494) A: As a matter of fact Pandit Motilal showed the resolution to
('33', 360, 0, 1, 799557) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 361
('33', 360, 1, 2, 799608) me and when he showed it to me I told him that it was for him and the Swarajists to decide what the text should be and as he showed the resolution to me I endeavoured to suggest some alterations.
('33', 360, 1, 3, 799804) He accepted what he thought he could conscientiously do but there were certain suggestions which he could not accept but it was not for me to press for their acceptance.
('33', 360, 1, 4, 799974) I had to deliver the goods and I could only deliver the goods if I accepted what resolution commended itself to a majority of Swarajist representatives.
('33', 360, 2, 5, 800127) Asked what his future programme would be as the result of the Congress decision, Gandhiji replied: My position is to remain passive and do the constructive work of which I am capable and to leave the rest, that is, the working out of the resolution of the Congress entirely into the hands of the Swarajists unhampered by me and even aided by me wherever it is possible.
('33', 360, 3, 6, 800497) The Hindustan Times, 31 12 1925

('33', 364, 3, 11, 806357) January 1, 1926
('33', 364, 4, 12, 806373) DEAR SATIS BABU, It is now morning of New Year’s day.
('33', 364, 4, 13, 806427) I reached here yesterday noon.
('33', 364, 4, 14, 806458) Bharucha told me that you were sad and moody.
('33', 364, 4, 15, 806504) [He] could not make out the reason nor could I. I asked Jamnalalji.

('33', 364, 4, 17, 806691) Whatever the cause, you dare not be moody or morose.
('33', 364, 4, 18, 806744) You must learn to rough it and get on under all circumstances.
('33', 364, 4, 19, 806807) You and I and several others have embarked upon a work of service the equal of which I do not know in the whole world.
('33', 364, 4, 20, 806926) The greater the service the greater the restraint, the greater the toleration the greater the suffering required.
('33', 364, 4, 21, 807040) Nothing therefore can be allowed to ruffle our spirits.
('33', 364, 4, 22, 807096) We must be able to get on with all temperaments: Please then let me have a line that you are yourself again.

('33', 368, 5, 16, 813424) 266. THE CONGRESS
('33', 368, 6, 17, 813442) The prophets of doom had been active about the Kanpur Congress.
('33', 368, 6, 18, 813506) If Sarojini Devi became the President, they prophesied, she would have a tough time with the audience; there would be hardly any visitors at this session; few delegates would attend, etc., etc.
('33', 368, 6, 19, 813700) But as things turned out, it cannot be said that the last Congress session was inferior to any.
('33', 368, 6, 20, 813796) In some respects, it was even better than usual.
('33', 368, 6, 21, 813845) The general arrangements were better.
('33', 368, 6, 22, 813883) Usually the delegates’ chief complaint is about food.
('33', 368, 6, 23, 813937) I heard, however, nothing but praise in this regard.
('33', 368, 6, 24, 813990) Seldom in the past was the food better than it was this time.
('33', 368, 6, 25, 814052) The delegates got as much milk, curds, papad 1, vegetables, and so on and as often as they wanted.
('33', 368, 6, 26, 814151) The provisions, too, were of the best quality and service was very prompt.
('33', 368, 6, 27, 814226) In fact, there were so many volunteers that no one had to ask for a helping.
('33', 368, 6, 28, 814303) The cleanliness left nothing to be desired.
('33', 368, 6, 29, 814347) I inspected the arrangements myself and found no ground for complaint.
('33', 368, 6, 30, 814418) The credit for these excellent arrangements goes to Lala Fulchand.
('33', 368, 6, 31, 814485) The lodging arrangements were as good as the boarding.
('33', 368, 6, 32, 814540) All the people were put up in tents.
('33', 368, 6, 33, 814577) There was little danger of anyone catching cold.
('33', 368, 6, 34, 814626) The sanitary arrangements were also excellent.
('33', 368, 6, 35, 814673) Neat trenches had been dug and every seat curtained off.
('33', 368, 6, 36, 814730) Volunteers always stood ready to spread earth after a latrine had been used.
('33', 368, 6, 37, 814807) Bhangis had been engaged, but the volunteers did not feel the slightest aversion to

('33', 376, 1, 2, 826002) Ashram, certainly not out of Ahmedabad, except for imperative reasons of health or some unforeseen event.
('33', 376, 1, 3, 826108) This decision has been arrived at after consultation at Cawnpore with the principal co workers who were there during the Congress Week.
('33', 376, 1, 4, 826244) The reasons for the decision are chiefly three: 1. To give my tired limbs as much rest as is possible to give them.
('33', 376, 1, 5, 826360) Dr. Ansari has sent me elaborate instructions forbidding even all avoidable mental toil.
('33', 376, 1, 6, 826449) 2. To enable me to give personal attention to the Ashram.
('33', 376, 1, 7, 826507) I was expected to do this when it was opened, but I have not been able to do so except for the first year of its existence.
('33', 376, 1, 8, 826631) 3. To enable me to put the affairs of the A.I.S.A., satisfactory as they are, on a sound businesslike basis.
('33', 376, 1, 9, 826740) This requires constant supervision and attention to details.
('33', 376, 1, 10, 826801) This is possible only if I am available at all times to the organizing secretary.
('33', 376, 1, 11, 826883) Any one of these reasons is by itself sufficient to warrant the step I have taken.
('33', 376, 1, 12, 826966) But the three combined make an overwhelming case for tying me down to the Ashram.

('33', 377, 6, 23, 830566) Only those who are devoid of all imagination could after witnessing the demonstration at Cawnpore during the Congress Week
('33', 377, 7, 24, 830689) 1 From November 22, 1925; vide”The Latest Fast”, 30 11 1925.
('33', 378, 0, 1, 830750) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 379
('33', 378, 1, 2, 830801) say that the influence of the Congress was on the wane.
('33', 378, 1, 3, 830857) The belittling process commenced with its birth.
('33', 378, 1, 4, 830906) It has however survived forty summers and promises to survive many more.
('33', 378, 2, 5, 830979) The demonstration began with the dazzling splendour that greeted the President on her arrival at Cawnpore.
('33', 378, 2, 6, 831086) The feeble voice of protest was hushed in the midst of the grateful shouts of thousands who had gathered to do honour to the first Indian woman who was to preside over the deliberations of the great national assembly.
('33', 378, 2, 7, 831304) The roads were one vast mass of beaming human faces.
('33', 378, 2, 8, 831357) Every balcony was occupied by the women of Cawnpore who were eager to see the face of Shrimati Sarojini Devi.
('33', 378, 2, 9, 831467) The merchants vied with one another in making the decorations effective and striking.
('33', 378, 2, 10, 831553) The Congress ground was packed to overflowing.
('33', 378, 2, 11, 831600) The pandal was filled on the opening day.
('33', 378, 2, 12, 831642) No session had so many European visitors as this.
('33', 378, 2, 13, 831692) The delegates were attentive and yielded implicit obedience to the chair.
('33', 378, 2, 14, 831766) The President by her tact, perseverance, punctuality and sweetness combined with firmness came up to all the expectations that were raised of her by friends and severely disappointed her critics who had prophesied a complete failure.
('33', 378, 2, 15, 832000) Her address—the shortest yet written by any President of the Congress—was a prose poem.
('33', 378, 2, 16, 832088) In the brief space of twelve octavo pages she had summarized the struggles and the aspirations of the people in whose name she spoke.
('33', 378, 2, 17, 832222) True, there was nothing new in the address.

('33', 388, 1, 2, 851119) know the truth about these matters.
('33', 388, 1, 3, 851155) The correspondent has described some incidents of harassment to him and members of his family, but I do not think it necessary to reproduce them.
('33', 388, 1, 4, 851301) I cannot say whether ghosts and spirits exist or do not exist.
('33', 388, 1, 5, 851364) I can only say that I have been living for many years as if they did not exist.
('33', 388, 1, 6, 851444) I do not know of any instance in which persons who did not believe in their existence came to harm in any way.
('33', 388, 1, 7, 851555) I have also observed that those who believe in their existence are sometimes harassed.
('33', 388, 1, 8, 851642) It is best, therefore, to go by the saying,”One’s own wish the ghost and one’s own fear the witch.” Let us, however, assume for a moment that ghosts and spirits exist.
('33', 388, 1, 9, 851810) Even then, they are a part of God’s creation.
('33', 388, 1, 10, 851856) The God who rules over us has also created these ghosts and spirits, and anyone who believes in God alone will worship no one else.
('33', 388, 1, 11, 851988) He who serves God will serve no one else.
('33', 388, 1, 12, 852030) For a believer in God, therefore, Rama is the only effective shield against ghosts and spirits, as He is his only sovereign support when he suffers at the hands of other human beings.
('33', 388, 1, 13, 852214) The correspondent and members of his family should keep repeating Ramanama with full faith, and that will drive away all ghosts and spirits.
('33', 388, 1, 14, 852355) Millions in this world do not believe in the existence of any such creatures and the latter seem powerless to harm them in any way.
('33', 388, 1, 15, 852487) The correspondent actually writes that these spirits harass his father, but do not harass himself when he is away from the father.
('33', 388, 1, 16, 852618) This fact itself suggests the remedy.
('33', 388, 1, 17, 852656) The father seems to be afraid of ghosts and spirits and is, therefore, harassed by them much in the same we that a king can punish only those who fear the punishment.
('33', 388, 1, 18, 852823) How can a king’s power of punishing avail against one who is not deterred by it?
('33', 388, 1, 19, 852904) Likewise, how can a ghost harass one who fears no ghost?
('33', 388, 2, 20, 852961) [From Gujarati]
('33', 388, 3, 21, 852977) Navajivan, 10 1 1926

('33', 389, 2, 4, 853095) Rajaji 1 has shown that there can be.

('33', 393, 7, 20, 860542) DEAR SIR, I have preserved your letter all these long days so as to enable me to reply when I get a little leisure.

('33', 393, 7, 22, 860741) As you have put the ideas, they have considerable
('33', 393, 8, 23, 860791) 1 Hakim Ajmal Khan
('33', 394, 0, 1, 860810) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 395
('33', 394, 1, 2, 860861) I would now put them in my own way.
('33', 394, 1, 3, 860897) 1. Art including music has its proper place in the spiritual evolution of man but there comes a time when he supersedes art that depends for its appreciation on sense perception.
('33', 394, 1, 4, 861076) Thus art as I understand it to mean can never be an end in itself.
('33', 394, 1, 5, 861143) 2. Just as one who perceives the endless beauty of the sky would need no canvas for his enjoyment, so one who can read the beauty of the sky within would want little need from the sky overhead.
('33', 394, 1, 6, 861337) As a matter of fact, the three processes go on to gather.
('33', 394, 1, 7, 861395) Truest inward joy is possible for one who is physically blind and deaf and dumb.
('33', 394, 1, 8, 861476) 3. I do believe that complete annihilation of one’s self—individ uality, sensuality, personality—whatever you call it, is an absolute con dition of perfect joy and peace.
('33', 394, 1, 9, 861647) But here again what is individuality, personality, etc.?
('33', 394, 1, 10, 861704) I draw no distinction between Buddhistic nirvana and Brahma nirvana of Shankara.

('33', 394, 1, 12, 861860) Buddhistic nirvana as a mere emptiness.
('33', 394, 1, 13, 861900) It is therefore highly likely that your definition of individuality is totally different from mine.
('33', 394, 1, 14, 862000) Has an ocean drop an individuality of its own as apart from the ocean?
('33', 394, 1, 15, 862071) Then a liberated soul has an individualityof its own.
('33', 394, 1, 16, 862125) Consciousness of disease.
('33', 394, 1, 17, 862151) But I must not go into deeper waters.
('33', 394, 1, 18, 862189) 4. I do not present the charkha to all for their spiritual emancipation.
('33', 394, 1, 19, 862262) But for me it is that, for the association I have built up round it, even as Ramanama which may mean nothing to a European was heavenly music for Tulsidas and his like.
('33', 394, 1, 20, 862431) I know how imperfect my answers are to your very sincere questions.

('33', 397, 5, 17, 867185) 303. THE CRIME OF CASTE
('33', 397, 6, 18, 867209) In South Africa it is the crime of colour and race for which we are being punished.
('33', 397, 6, 19, 867293) In India we Hindus punish our co religionists for the crime of caste.
('33', 397, 6, 20, 867363) The fifth caste man the Panchama—is the greatest offender deserving the punishment of untouchability, unapproa chability, invisibility and what not.
('33', 397, 6, 21, 867512) An extraordinary case that was tried in a Madras Presidency court brings vividly to light the sad plight of our suppressed countrymen.
('33', 397, 6, 22, 867647) A simple cleanly dressed Panchama entered a temple in a perfectly devotional spirit without the slightest intention of hurting anybody’s feeling or insulting any religion.
('33', 397, 6, 23, 867819) He had been in the habit of paying his respects at this temple every year though he did not enter it.
('33', 397, 6, 24, 867921) But last year in his ecstatic mood he forgot himself and entered the temple.
('33', 397, 6, 25, 867998) The priest in charge could not distinguish him from the others and therefore accepted his offering.
('33', 397, 6, 26, 868098) But when he regained self possession he was terrified to find himself in a prohibited place and ran away from the temple.

('33', 399, 4, 12, 871910) A WRONG REDRESSED
('33', 399, 5, 13, 871928) The Government of Bombay, and I suppose also the Government of India, may congratulate themselves on having though reluctantly redressed a grievous wrong done to a brave Englishman and to India.
('33', 399, 5, 14, 872123) For they have summoned up sufficient courage not to prohibit Mr. Horniman’s entry into India—the land of his love and labours.
('33', 399, 5, 15, 872250) No one knows the real reason for Mr. Horniman’s sudden and secret deportation.

('33', 399, 5, 17, 872445) Such high handed and arbitrary deportations bring vividly before the public eye the real nature of the despotic powers possessed and wielded by the Government of India.
('33', 399, 5, 18, 872614) No one more eloquently pleaded for the abrogation of such powers as Mr. Horniman till he himself became a victim of such powers.

('33', 400, 2, 5, 873448) It is from that Government that Mr. Andrews expects pressure enough to bring about at least a long enough postponement of the consideration of the anti Asiatic measure so that there may be time for passions to cool and reason to have play.

('33', 400, 2, 9, 874147) But the way things are being managed in South Africa, it is debatable whether the Union Government will show even the courteous consideration that one Government may expect from another.

('33', 401, 5, 16, 876756) VAIKAM SATYAGRAHA
('33', 401, 6, 17, 876774) Hindu reformers who are intent on removal of untouchability should understand the implications of Vaikam Satyagraha and its results.
('33', 401, 6, 18, 876907) The immediate goal of the satyagrahis was the opening of the roads surrounding the temple, not their entry into the latter.
('33', 401, 6, 19, 877031) Their contention was that the roads should be opened to the so called untouchables as they were to all other Hindus and even non Hindus.
('33', 401, 6, 20, 877168) That point has been completely gained.
('33', 401, 6, 21, 877207) But whilst satyagraha was directed to the opening of roads, the ultimate aim of reformers is undoubtedly removal of every disability that ‘the untouchables’ are labouring under and which the other Hindus are not.
('33', 401, 6, 22, 877420) It therefore includes access to temples, wells, schools, etc., to which other non Brahmins are freely admitted.
('33', 401, 6, 23, 877532) But for achieving these reforms much remains to be done before the method of direct action can be adopted.
('33', 401, 6, 24, 877639) Satyagraha is never adopted abruptly and never till all other and milder methods have been tried.
('33', 401, 6, 25, 877737) The reformers of the South have to cultivate public opinion in the matter of temple entry, etc.
('33', 401, 6, 26, 877833) This is moreover a disability not peculiar to the South but unfortunately and, to our shame it must be admitted, common, to more or less extent, to
('33', 402, 0, 1, 877981) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 403
('33', 402, 1, 2, 878032) Hinduism throughout India.
('33', 402, 1, 3, 878059) I therefore welcome the decision of Sjt.
('33', 402, 1, 4, 878100) Kellappen Nayar who was in charge of the camp at Vaikam to concentrate his effort on working among the unhappiest and the most suppressed among ‘the untouchables’, i.e., Puliyas whose very shadow defiles.
('33', 402, 1, 5, 878305) It is a golden rule to follow out every direct action with constructive work, i.e., work of conservation.
('33', 402, 1, 6, 878411) Reform has to be undertaken at both ends to make savarnas do their duty by the untouchables whom they have so cruelly suppressed and to help the latter to become more presentable and to shed habits for which they can in no way be held accountable but which nevertheless have to be given up if they are to occupy their proper place in the social scale.

('33', 403, 1, 2, 879991) 305.”DASTURI” AND BOMBAY SWEEPERS
('33', 403, 2, 3, 880025) Papers have been sent to me in which I am reported to have said in 1918 among other things that ‘the evidence and statements made (as to bribery euphemistically known as dasturi said to have been paid by the sweepers in the employ of the Municipal Corporation, Bombay) were such that no impartial person could accept them.’ The papers also show that the present Municipal Commissioner has quoted the above statement in support of his judgment that no such dasturi is being paid by the employees.
('33', 403, 2, 4, 880521) I have no recollection of what I said in 1918, but in my opinion it is hardly relevant or fair to quote testimony given seven years ago to refute fresh allegations of a similar nature.
('33', 403, 2, 5, 880706) Assuming the accuracy of the report of my conversation with the Health Officer in 1918, it does not follow because a few witnesses whom I examined then were found to be unreliable that there was no bribery and corruption at the time or that the witnesses who may have recently tendered evidence are equally unreliable.
('33', 403, 2, 6, 881025) I do know, moreover, that Mr. Thakkar whose ability for impartial judgment has been questioned and who has been accused of bias against public officers is utterly unworthy of such charges.
('33', 403, 2, 7, 881214) We have few public workers of Mr. Thakkar’s honesty or impartiality.
('33', 403, 2, 8, 881283) He would not wilfully misjudge any person.
('33', 403, 2, 9, 881326) For one thing he has no axe to grind, no wrong to conceal.
('33', 403, 2, 10, 881385) So far as the charge of bribery is concerned I wish to place on record my opinion arrived at after seven years’ observation that bribery is rampant in the Municipal Corporation as elsewhere.
('33', 403, 2, 11, 881576) I am free also to confess that it is a most difficult charge to prove especially regarding the helpless ‘untouchables’.
('33', 403, 2, 12, 881696) If the Municipal Commissioner wishes to find out the truth let him do what Vikramaditya did, go in disguise and see whether he does not succeed in extracting ten rupee notes from these poor people for the favour of getting employment or an increase in pay.
('33', 403, 2, 13, 881953) That the Commissioner will have to learn the language of the people and dress like his underlings is surely a matter of detail when he is bent upon pursuit of truth in the cause of humanity said to be oppressed under his regime.

('33', 408, 4, 13, 889600) We are born with some of the traits of our parents.

('33', 413, 1, 2, 899838) 317. SPEECH AT MARRIAGE CEREMONY 1
('33', 413, 2, 3, 899873) January 18, 1926 We do two things on the occasion of a marriage here.
('33', 413, 2, 4, 899943) We bless the couple on behalf of the Ashram and ponder over the propriety of participating in a function apparently opposed to the ideals of the Ashram.
('33', 413, 2, 5, 900096) In non violence there is no room for force and so there should be, and there can be, no compulsion in the observance of vows.
('33', 413, 2, 6, 900222) Myself and my companions have seen that it is easy to practise brahmacharya, once it is understood; but the understanding has to issue from the heart, not from the head.
('33', 413, 2, 7, 900392) One cannot master it solely with the intellect.
('33', 413, 2, 8, 900440) And so do the Shastras emphasize that only a rare individual can practise it in thought, word and deed.
('33', 413, 2, 9, 900544) Its practice becomes difficult for yet another reason.
('33', 413, 2, 10, 900599) Our experiments here are opposed to the normal ways of the world.
('33', 413, 2, 11, 900665) To keep the appearance of worldliness and yet to practise brahmacharya, this makes it all the more difficult.
('33', 413, 2, 12, 900775) The Shastras do not seem to have laid much stress on restraining the palate; but if this can be achieved, brahmachary is much more easy.
('33', 413, 2, 13, 900912) Restraining the palate is more difficult than practising brahmacharya.
('33', 413, 2, 14, 900983) I have tried many devices and resigned myself to the conclusion.
('33', 413, 2, 15, 901048) A man may restrict himself just to four items or to milk alone but all these restrictions are of no avail.
('33', 413, 2, 16, 901155) Thereby he controls the senses but does not conquer them.
('33', 413, 2, 17, 901213) He may smack his lips over a single item of food.
('33', 413, 2, 18, 901263) I have known it myself.
('33', 413, 2, 19, 901287) A single item can give all the tickle to the palate, the mouth waters all through the day, and we are aware of it.
('33', 413, 2, 20, 901402) If one eats for the sake of nutrition only without delighting in its savour and without being a slave of the palate, that is the correct attitude.
('33', 413, 2, 21, 901549) Very few people can achieve this state.
('33', 413, 2, 22, 901589) It is difficult to say how many of us practise this restraint and to what extent.
('33', 413, 2, 23, 901671) We do claim, however, that we practise brahmacharya.
('33', 413, 2, 24, 901724) How strange, then, that we celebrate a function opposed to it!
('33', 413, 2, 25, 901787) We do not know whether it is dharma or adharma.
('33', 413, 2, 26, 901835) I would translate”What to do and what not to do” of the Gita as”What is dharma and what is adharma” .
('33', 413, 3, 27, 901937) 1 Of Najuklal Choksi and Moti, daughter of Lakshmidas Assar, at Satyagraha Ashram, Sabarmati
('33', 414, 0, 1, 902030) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 415
('33', 414, 1, 2, 902081) In my view, marriage is dharma.
('33', 414, 1, 3, 902113) All worldly activities are intended for learning self restraint.
('33', 414, 1, 4, 902178) Our sense gratification should therefore be restricted to the indispensable.
('33', 414, 1, 5, 902255) Where other people find pleasure, my inner self finds none.
('33', 414, 1, 6, 902315) On such occasions I pray to God for deliverance.
('33', 414, 1, 7, 902364) Even while eating, I remember defecation.
('33', 414, 1, 8, 902406) The occasion of marriage should remind us of self restraint.
('33', 414, 1, 9, 902467) If desires cannot be conquered, they should be harnessed, that is, they should be directed to one object.
('33', 414, 1, 10, 902573) Such restriction is better than promiscuity.
('33', 414, 1, 11, 902618) The marriage vow repeatedly enjoins on the bridegroom not to go astray, leaving his wife.
('33', 414, 1, 12, 902708) Moreover, this marriage ceremony has been performed with bare religious rites.
('33', 414, 1, 13, 902787) There were no inducements, no dowry, no ornaments, nor any discord between the marriage parties.
('33', 414, 1, 14, 902884) All this again teaches restraint.
('33', 414, 1, 15, 902918) In these matters also we should seek and practise restraint.
('33', 414, 1, 16, 902979) That is why all and sundry have not been invited to this function.
('33', 414, 1, 17, 903046) It is the good fortune of the Ashram that it has had an opportunity to solemnize the marriage of persons who understand what restraint means and are resolved to practise it.
('33', 414, 1, 18, 903220) All others who wish to marry should frankly say so and put all inmates of the Ashram at ease.
('33', 414, 1, 19, 903314) Let them not feel that the Ashram would come in their way.

('33', 415, 5, 8, 904429) 319. INTERVIEW TO LANGELOTH AND KELLY
('33', 415, 6, 9, 904467) [Before 21 January 21, 1926] 2
('33', 415, 7, 10, 904498) Mrs. Langeloth and Mrs. Kelly, delegated personally to present to Gandhiji the resolution of invitation to visit America on behalf of the Fellowship of Faiths, League of Neighbours, and Union of East and West, visited him last week.
('33', 415, 7, 11, 904731) They were evidently prepared for the reply, but the resolution had to be presented.
('33', 415, 7, 12, 904815) Not without considerable hesitation said Mrs. Kelly:”Would you not visit America, Mr. Gandhi?
('33', 415, 7, 13, 904909) We would very much like to hear from you your message.
('33', 415, 7, 14, 904964) Money, I know, is no consideration to you, but I may say that your visit can help us to render you pecuniary assistance in your work here.
('33', 415, 7, 15, 905103) There are private homes there ready to receive you and to look after you whilst you are there.” [GANDHIJI:] I know, I would be overwhelmed with affection if ever I went to America.
('33', 415, 7, 16, 905284) But as I have already explained to other friends I cannot as yet think of going there, without having finished my work here.
('33', 415, 7, 17, 905409) I must work away amongst my own people, and not swerve from my path.
('33', 415, 7, 18, 905478) Dr. Ward writing to me the other day said he was entirely at one with me in thinking that my visit would not be of much use in the present circumstances.
('33', 415, 7, 19, 905632) And don’t you think he is right?
('33', 415, 7, 20, 905665) I know crowds would gather around me to hear me, I would get receptions everywhere but beyond that my visit would have no other result.

('33', 417, 10, 26, 910345) 320. IN DEFENCE OF UNAPPROACHABILITY
('33', 417, 11, 27, 910382) A Travancore correspondent writes:
('33', 417, 12, 28, 910417) There seems to be a misunderstanding about the Brahmins and their customs or acharas.
('33', 417, 12, 29, 910503) You praise ahimsa, but we the Brahmins are the only
('33', 417, 13, 30, 910555) community that observe it as a religious function.
('33', 417, 13, 31, 910606) Anyone who violates it is regarded as an outcaste by us.
('33', 417, 13, 32, 910663) ‘The very association with those who kill or eat flesh is considered by us as sinful.
('33', 417, 13, 33, 910749) At the approach of the slaughterer, fisherman and toddy extractor, as well as at the touch of the flesh eater, wine drinker, and the irreligious, our moral as well as the physical atmosphere becomes poisoned, tapas or religious merit diminishes, and pure magnetism
('33', 417, 14, 34, 911014) becomes lost.
('33', 417, 15, 35, 911028) This, we consider as pollution, and we have to bathe forthwith.
('33', 417, 15, 36, 911092) It is by keeping up such rules that the Brahmins have been able to preserve their
('33', 418, 0, 1, 911174) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 419
('33', 418, 1, 2, 911225) hereditary virtues so long even though time and fortune have undergone many changes.
('33', 418, 1, 3, 911310) If free communication with others be allowed without these restrictions, the Brahmin will gradually degrade himself to the lowest of the outcastes, indulge in the vices in private, and pretend to be pure trying at the same time to do away with the barriers of restrictions which give him much trouble in keeping his sins secret.
('33', 418, 1, 4, 911639) We know that many of the nominal Brahmins of today are of this sort, and that they are moving heaven and earth to drag others to their degraded level.
('33', 418, 2, 5, 911790) In a place where people are grouped together into different communities according to their habits and notions of right and wrong (not as per colour, wealth or power as is wrongly followed in the West) and located in different centres, according to their professional, social and domestic conveniences, with perceptible demarcation lines as in our motherland, it is not possible for anyone to remain unobserved for long, if he changes his habits.
('33', 418, 2, 6, 912236) If on the contrary one is put up in the midst of slaughterers, meateaters and drunkards, it is impossible for him to maintain himself there, preserving his foreign virtues.
('33', 418, 2, 7, 912409) Naturally, we seek such surroundings as suit our tastes.
('33', 418, 2, 8, 912466) Therefore it is that the surroundings of a Brahmin’s abode have also to be preserved physically, morally and religiously pure, free from the encroachment of the slaughterers, fishermen, toddy extractors.
('33', 418, 2, 9, 912670) In India profession and the caste system have been inseparably linked together, and it is therefore natural to believe a man belonging to a caste, to be invariably following that profession.
('33', 418, 2, 10, 912861) These are the grounds on which unapproachability and untouchability have been enjoined on us.
('33', 418, 2, 11, 912955) These, as mentioned above, not only protect the purity of our line but also act as a direct social or religious punishment of excommunication on the wrongdoers, and indirectly induce them to give up their bad habits if they want free communication with us.
('33', 418, 2, 12, 913212) You may therefore publicly ask them to renounce their sins and to take to weaving and spinning along with the necessary religious observances of bathing regularly, fasting, prayer, etc., if they want to destroy their unapproachability in the course of a few years.
('33', 418, 2, 13, 913477) They should not also associate with those who have not mended their old ways of living.
('33', 418, 2, 14, 913565) This is the way sanctioned by the Shastras.
('33', 418, 2, 15, 913609) Since there is no way of verifying the private sins or virtues of a man, it is useless to talk of the mental purities of one or the mental impurities of another.
('33', 418, 2, 16, 913771) It is from public habits that we should judge a man’s private nature.
('33', 418, 2, 17, 913841) Therefore, anyone, who cannot publicly embrace your or our Mother’s ahimsa dharma, or at least to the extent of slaughtering, fish or flesh eating, cannot be considered fit to transcend their hereditary unapproachability.
('33', 418, 2, 18, 914063) In fact this unapproachability and untouchability are
('33', 419, 0, 1, 914117) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 419, 1, 2, 914159) nothing but a practical means of preserving and spreading our ahimsa dharma.
('33', 419, 1, 3, 914236) Though the question raised by the correspondent has been often dealt with in these columns, it is perhaps necessary to re expose the fallacy underlying the correspondent’s argument.
('33', 419, 1, 4, 914418) In the first place the claim advanced on behalf of the Brahmins as to vegetarianism is not wholly true.
('33', 419, 1, 5, 914522) It is true only regarding the Brahminsof the South.
('33', 419, 1, 6, 914574) But elsewhere they freely eat fish and in Bengal, Kashmir, etc., even meat.
('33', 419, 1, 7, 914650) Moreover, in the South all meat eaters and fish eaters are not unapproachables.
('33', 419, 1, 8, 914730) And even an ‘unapproachable’ who is severely pure is an outcaste, because he is born in a family unlawfully regarded as ‘untouchable’ or ‘unapproachable’.
('33', 419, 1, 9, 914885) Do not Brahmins brush sho ulders with meat eating non Brahmins if they happen to be persons in authority?
('33', 419, 1, 10, 914991) Do they not pay respect to the meat eating Hindu royalty?
('33', 419, 2, 11, 915049) It is surprising and painful to find cultured men like the correspondent in their blind zeal defend an indefensible and tottering system, forgetting the obvious implications of their own argument.
('33', 419, 2, 12, 915246) The correspondent strains at the himsaic”gnat” of meateating and swallows the trebly himsaic camel of deliberate suppression of millions of fellow beings in order to preserve an imaginary purity.
('33', 419, 2, 13, 915442) I suggest to the correspondent that a vegetarianism that demands for its protection a degrading excommunication of others is not worth preserving.
('33', 419, 2, 14, 915589) Thus preserved it becomes a hothouse growth doomed to perish under the first blast of cold air.
('33', 419, 2, 15, 915685) I treasure vegetarianism.
('33', 419, 2, 16, 915711) I am convinced the Brahmins have gained spiritual advancement through their vegetarianism and other self imposed disciplinary restraints.
('33', 419, 2, 17, 915849) But when they were at their height, they did not need protection for their purity from without.
('33', 419, 2, 18, 915945) Every virtue loses its vitality when it becomes incapable of withstanding outside influences.
('33', 419, 3, 19, 916039) Moreover, it is too late in the day for Brahmins to claim protection of the type mentioned by the correspondent.
('33', 419, 3, 20, 916152) Happily the number of Brahmins who not only disdain such protection but who are leading the reform movement at the peril of being persecuted is daily on the increase.
('33', 419, 3, 21, 916319) And in that lies the best hope of the reform making rapid progress.

('33', 420, 4, 5, 916969) BORODADA GONE
('33', 420, 5, 6, 916983) It is difficult to believe that Dwijendranath Tagore is no more.
('33', 420, 5, 7, 917048) A wire from Shantiniketan gives me the sad news that Borodada known as Dwijendranath Tagore has found his rest.
('33', 420, 5, 8, 917160) He was nearing ninety and yet he was so bright, so cheerful that one could never feel whilst in his presence that his days of earthly existence were numbered.
('33', 420, 5, 9, 917319) Borodada was a distinguished member in that family of geniuses.
('33', 420, 5, 10, 917383) Besides being a great scholar— as familiar with Sanskrit as he was with English—Barodada was a deeply religious man of broad sympathies.
('33', 420, 5, 11, 917520) Whilst he held tenaciously to the teachings of the Upanishads, he was open to receive light from all the other scriptures of the world.
('33', 420, 5, 12, 917656) He loved his country with the passion of a most devoted patriot.
('33', 420, 5, 13, 917721) Yet his patriotism was not exclusive.
('33', 420, 5, 14, 917759) He understood the spiritual beauty of non violent non co operation, though he never failed to appreciate its political significance.
('33', 420, 5, 15, 917892) He believed in the spinning wheel with a full heart and had adopted khaddar even at his ripe age.
('33', 420, 5, 16, 917990) He kept himself in closest touch with the current events with the ardour of a youth.
('33', 420, 5, 17, 918075) Borodada’s death means the withdrawal of a great sage, philosopher and patriot from our midst.
('33', 420, 5, 18, 918170) I tender my condolences to the Poet and the members of the Ashram at Shantiniketan.

('33', 426, 13, 22, 929299) 329. SPINNING WHEEL v.
('33', 426, 14, 23, 929322) A Hindi professor has written a long letter which, being of interest for Gujarati readers too, I summarize below: Do you intend to continue the spinning wheel movement even after we have swaraj?
('33', 426, 14, 24, 929517) Will not the number of Indian mills go up automatically then and, their products being cheap, will not the cause of the spinning wheel suffer?
('33', 426, 15, 25, 929660) 1 From the postmark 2 Gujarati translation of Pilgrim’s Progress
('33', 427, 0, 1, 929725) 428 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 427, 1, 2, 929767) And finally, since these mills themselves will have accomplished the boycott of foreign cloth, will not your idea of ending hunger in the villages through the spinning wheel remain a mere fancy?
('33', 427, 1, 3, 929962) Or may it not happen that under swaraj we shall discover some other remedy for poverty?
('33', 427, 1, 4, 930050) If so, why should you not devote your strenuous efforts to multiplying the number of mills in order to ensure the success of the boycott movement instead of to the spinning wheel?
('33', 427, 1, 5, 930230) If you agree that after we have swaraj the spinning wheel movement is bound to stop, but think that it must continue meanwhile for ten or fifteen years, could you not have new mills set up during that period and ensure immediate boycott [of foreign cloth]?
('33', 427, 2, 6, 930487) The arguments advanced here have been answered some time or other in Navajivan.
('33', 427, 2, 7, 930567) If, nevertheless, even a learned gentleman like this correspondent, a regular reader too of Young India and Navajivan, has still doubts in the matter, it may be worthwhile to try to answer his questions.
('33', 427, 3, 8, 930771) I am convinced that the spinning wheel will stay even after we have won swaraj.
('33', 427, 3, 9, 930851) The movement has its origin in the condition of villages.
('33', 427, 3, 10, 930909) Even after swaraj, cultivators will need a subsidiary occupation and, in our country, spinning is the only possible occupation of the sort.
('33', 427, 3, 11, 931049) It is not as if the moment we get swaraj new mills will spring up overnight like mushrooms after the rains.
('33', 427, 3, 12, 931157) Setting up a mill requires capital, and those who put it up expect interest.
('33', 427, 3, 13, 931234) For a mill we must have land, facilities of water, etc., and workers and machinery.
('33', 427, 3, 14, 931318) These resources cannot be created as easily as spinning wheels.
('33', 427, 3, 15, 931382) If a sufficiently large number of people decide, they can produce one crore spinning wheels in the country in one day; on the contrary, even if thirty crores wish it, they cannot set up a mill with thirty crore spindles in one day.
('33', 427, 3, 16, 931614) Experience has proved positively that a spinning wheel can produce nearly thesame amount of yarn in eight hours which one spindle produces in a mill.
('33', 427, 3, 17, 931764) If, therefore, the Indian people choose, they can, in a few months, produce enough cloth for themselves with the help of spinning wheels and handlooms.
('33', 427, 3, 18, 931916) Given a little will and corresponding action, it is possible to bring about immediate boycott [of foreign cloth] with the help of the spinning wheel, whereas it is not possible to do so with the help of mills, however much we may wish or try.
('33', 427, 3, 19, 932159) Moreover, if we seek to effect the
('33', 428, 0, 1, 932194) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 429
('33', 428, 1, 2, 932245) boycott with the help of mills, we shall have for a long time to depend on foreign countries for two things for years to come we shall have to get the machinery and engineers from outside.
('33', 428, 2, 3, 932434) Again, the multiplication of mills can never end the hunger of the poor.
('33', 428, 2, 4, 932507) If we cannot find today some other means of ending their poverty, we have no reason to believe that we shall discover it after we win swaraj.
('33', 428, 2, 5, 932649) No one, so far, has even tried and demonstrated how to employ the other means which have been suggested in place of the spinning wheel for ending mass hunger.
('33', 428, 3, 6, 932808) I am, therefore, of the view that nothing besides the spinning wheel can satisfy the hunger of the crores in the country.
('33', 428, 4, 7, 932930) This being my unalterable view, there can be no question, as far as I am concerned, whether the spinning wheel movement will succeed or fail.
('33', 428, 4, 8, 933072) I have even stated my view that without boycott of foreign cloth there can be no swaraj for the millions.
('33', 428, 4, 9, 933178) I am firm in this view of mine too.
('33', 428, 4, 10, 933214) Hence, whether it takes one year or a hundred years for the spinning wheel to become universal, it is the sovereign means of winning swaraj.
('33', 428, 4, 11, 933355) I am, moreover, serving the untouchable communities through it.
('33', 428, 4, 12, 933419) I am also making a great contribution towards Hindu Muslim unity, since I appeal to Muslims, too, that they should take up ginning, carding, spinning and weaving.
('33', 428, 4, 13, 933582) Setting up more mills will produce none of these benefits.
('33', 428, 4, 14, 933641) The effort will have been worth while only if it succeeds.
('33', 428, 4, 15, 933700) It can yield no great benefit.
('33', 428, 4, 16, 933731) In my view, boycott brought about by any sort of means can do no good.
('33', 428, 4, 17, 933802) Only the boycott which has been brought about by the concerted efforts of millions and which has, in the process, satisfied their hunger, can be of immense benefit.
('33', 428, 4, 18, 933967) Moreover, whether the spinning wheel movement succeeds or not, it is without any flaw and that is why it can never fail.
('33', 428, 5, 19, 934088) [From Gujarati]
('33', 428, 6, 20, 934104) Navajivan, 24 1 1926
('33', 429, 0, 1, 934125) 430 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 429, 1, 2, 934167) 330. LETTER TO KALYANJI DESAI
('33', 429, 2, 3, 934197) ASHRAM, January 24, 192[6] 1
('33', 429, 3, 4, 934226) BHAI KALYANJI, I wanted to write to you as soon as I had the news, but I just could not do it.
('33', 429, 3, 5, 934321) And then I fell ill.
('33', 429, 3, 6, 934342) All that is born is only destined to decay and die.
('33', 429, 3, 7, 934394) Why then should we lament over it?
('33', 429, 3, 8, 934429) It is natural that you should grieve for the death of a grownup daughter.
('33', 429, 3, 9, 934503) But if we look deep into our grief we shall find there nothing but our selfishness and fear.
('33', 429, 3, 10, 934596) There is selfishness in regarding her as belonging to us and since we ourselves do not want to die we are also frightened by other people’s death.
('33', 429, 3, 11, 934743) It is in the nature of the soul to be untouched by both [selfishness and fear].
('33', 429, 3, 12, 934823) But we mistake the body for the soul and therefore lament over one another’s sorrows and go on feeding our fears.
('33', 429, 3, 13, 934937) May God grant you peace.

('33', 431, 0, 1, 937720) 432 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 431, 1, 2, 937762) 332. SOUTH AFRICAN QUESTION
('33', 431, 2, 3, 937790) I am sorry to say that Lord Reading’s pronouncement on the acute position that has arisen in South Africa does not inspire me with hope.
('33', 431, 2, 4, 937927) He may by some diplomatic stroke secure postponement of consideration of the Bill during the present session of the Union Parliament.
('33', 431, 2, 5, 938061) But the grim fact that stares us in the face is that, as the recent cablegram shows, action is being taken already in South Africa as if the Bill had become the law of the land, and renewals of licenses are being refused.
('33', 431, 2, 6, 938283) The principle of the measure is itself wrong.
('33', 431, 2, 7, 938329) What appears to me Lord Reading is after is that he will secure some trifling alteration in the details but nothing in the substance of the Bill, the substance being the curtailment of the rights of the resident Indian population as they existed at the Settlement of 1914. The fulcrum of that Settlement of that long struggle was no more disabilities, but the steady improvement in the position of the resident population, after the fear of unrestricted immigration of Indians had been removed for all time.
('33', 431, 2, 8, 938837) That fear was removed, not merely in 1914 but when Natal passed its Immigration Law and the Cape followed suit.
('33', 431, 2, 9, 938949) There never was a large Indian population in the Transvaal.
('33', 431, 2, 10, 939009) The Indian population in the Orange Free State was never anything to speak of.
('33', 431, 2, 11, 939088) But under a popular government once you excite feelings you are bound to satisfy them in some shape or other.
('33', 431, 2, 12, 939198) All the South African statesmen had excited the feelings of the people, which to be accurate they themselves shared without having studied the question.
('33', 431, 2, 13, 939351) The Government having however allayed the fear by passing a very strict immigration restriction measure, the resident Indian population had every right to hope that their position would steadily improve in process of time.
('33', 431, 2, 14, 939574) But evidently such was not to be the case and the history since 1914 is a history of a series of attacks upon the Indian position.
('33', 431, 2, 15, 939705) If Lord Reading means to do his duty he has not merely to secure a postponement of the consideration of the measure but to insist upon at least a reversion to the position of 1914, bad as even that position would be.
('33', 431, 2, 16, 939922) Let it not be said when the result of his negotiations is known that Lord Reading had secured nothing which might be considered substantial relief from the point of view of the settlers themselves.
('33', 431, 3, 17, 940120) Young India, 28 1 1926
('33', 432, 0, 1, 940143) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 433
('33', 432, 1, 2, 940194) 333. KHADDAR PROPAGANDA
('33', 432, 2, 3, 940218) It is a sign of the times that some of the most cultured people are at the present moment engaged in khadi work, with a selflessness reminding one of the old traditions of this land when national or religious religious was rendered for the love of it.
('33', 432, 2, 4, 940470) I am reminded of this fact by a letter from Satis Babu of Khadi Pratishthan.
('33', 432, 2, 5, 940547) He tells me that Dr. Prafulla Ghosh is tirelessly going about Bengal, popularizing khadi by lectures arranged for him by Congress organizations, and by hawking khaddar, Bharucha like, carrying pieces on his own devoted shoulders.
('33', 432, 2, 6, 940777) Dr. Ghosh was one of the favourite pupils of Dr. Roy, held an appointment carrying Rs. 500 in the Mint.
('33', 432, 2, 7, 940881) He is now taking no more than Rs. 30 and I have seen personally how he is living at the present moment.
('33', 432, 2, 8, 940985) Nor is he the only person in Bengal, or for that matter in India, who is living like a beggar and serving the cause of the poor through the spinning wheel There are many youths of great ability and education in several organizations in Bengal and outside Bengal, who have made khadi their principal, if not sole occupation, and who are doing it for a mere pittance.
('33', 432, 2, 9, 941351) But since khadi means the service of millions of India’s paupers it naturally demands the devotion of not several hundreds but tens of thousands of young men and women.
('33', 432, 3, 10, 941520) Young India, 28 1 1926
('33', 433, 0, 1, 941543) 434 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('33', 436, 1, 2, 945294) 338. ASHRAM TRUST DEED 1
('33', 436, 2, 3, 945319) February 2, 1926
('33', 436, 3, 4, 945336) Declaration of Trust, Rs. 2,75,000. We, Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi and Maganlal Khushal chand Gandhi, both Vanias by caste, aged about 55 and 43 years respectively, by profession weavers and cultivators, both residing in Satyagraha Ashram, Vadaj, Taluk North Daskroi, District Ahmedabad, hereby declare as follows: After our return to India from South Africa in 1915, we and our co workers established on 25 5 1915 an institution named Satyagraha Ashram with the aim of carrying on activities of public service.
('33', 436, 3, 5, 945848) The land and buildings shown in the accompanying schedule, of the value of about Rs. 2,75,000 (rupees two lac and seventy five thousand only), which are the property of that institution, were purchased on its behalf in our names and they have been and are being used and managed under the direction of the heads of the institution in accordance with its aims and objects.
('33', 436, 3, 6, 946220) We hereby declare these aims and also declare that the said properties are held in our names in our capacities as trustees of the institution and that we and our heirs and successors did not and do not have any personal right or share in them.
('33', 436, 3, 7, 946464) The aims for which the property of the”Satyagraha Ashram”, mentioned in the schedule to this document, is being used are as under: 1. Antyaja uplift; 2. cultivation of cotton and development of the crafts connected with it, hand ginning, carding, spinning and weaving; 3. to train workers for activities necessary for the moral, economic and political uplift of India; 4. to establish and run schools to impart education in letters and other training; and 5. to undertake other activities for public welfare such as cow protection, improvement in the breed of cows, etc.
('33', 436, 4, 8, 947035) 1 Presented for registration by Gandhiji at the office of the Sub Registrar, Ahmedabad, on February 12, 1926, between 11 a.m.
('33', 436, 4, 9, 947161) and 12 noon, and registered under serial No.

('33', 436, 4, 11, 947223) 1. G. V. Mavalankar and Vinoba Bhave signed as witnesses.

Shri Chhaganlal Khushalchand Gandhi We declare that the said trustees have the following rights and powers in respect of the afore mentioned property: 1. To do anything or take any steps which may appear necessary from time to time in furtherance of the objects and aims of the Trust and to manage and use the property which is the subject of the Trust in any manner they may deem fit; 2. to sell or mortgage the property which is the subject of the Trust for furthering its aims; 3. to appoint, by a majority vote, new trustees to fill up vacancies among themselves; 4. to act with the concurrence of not less than three from among themselves; 5. to raise, by a majorit vote, the number of trustees by two if it appears necessary for them to do so.
