('33', 438, 7, 17, 949796) 340. TOTAL PROHIBITION
('33', 438, 8, 18, 949819) The Swaraj Party in Madras deserves the congratulations of all friends of the poor for having included total prohibition in their programme.
('33', 438, 8, 19, 949960) Were it not for the very potential force of inertia we would long since have done away with this evil.
('33', 438, 8, 20, 950063) It is sapping the vitality of the labouring classes, who need to be helped against themselves.
('33', 438, 8, 21, 950158) There is no country in the world which is so well fitted for immediate prohibition as India.
('33', 438, 8, 22, 950251) Public opinion has always been on the right path.
('33', 438, 8, 23, 950301) No referendum is necessary as it would be in European countries for the simple reason that in India the intellectual classes do not drink as in European countries.
('33', 438, 8, 24, 950465) The Rev.
('33', 438, 8, 25, 950474) W. L. Ferguson of Madras has brought out a pamphlet clearly showing the need for prohibition.
('33', 438, 8, 26, 950568) Of the financial burden the reverend gentleman says: 1
('33', 438, 9, 27, 950623) No country, however rich and prosperous, can really afford to drink, for drink brings nations to the verge of ruin and sometimes topples them over the brink.
('33', 438, 9, 28, 950781) India is a poor country as yet.
('33', 438, 9, 29, 950813) She is poor in her capital wealth; she is poor in education; she is poor in sanitation and public health; she is poor in housing, she is poor in agriculture and manufacturing, she is poor in means of communication in rural
('33', 438, 10, 30, 951036) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('33', 439, 0, 1, 951073) 440 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 439, 1, 2, 951115) areas....
('33', 439, 1, 3, 951125) India cannot afford the use of intoxicants.
('33', 439, 1, 4, 951169) Financially the drain is too heavy.
('33', 439, 1, 5, 951205) Just what the cost is in rupees we are unable to say; but some idea of it can be obtained from the revenues derived by the Government in the Excise Department I do not believe that we shall err very far if we .
('33', 439, 1, 6, 951416) place the amount at Rs. 80,00,00,000. Now of this vast sum the greater part comes from the earnings of the labouring classes— the very people who need it most for promoting the welfare of themselves, their families and their communities.
('33', 439, 1, 7, 951654) If we assume that three fourths of the drink and drug bill of India is paid by the poor and the labouring classes, some Rs. 60,00,00,000 is the burden they are bearing.
('33', 439, 1, 8, 951823) And what could be done towards putting India’s poor on their feet, if this vast revenue annually were saved from intoxicants and used for home building and nation building enterprises !
('33', 439, 2, 9, 952009) The moral loss is even greater than the financial.
('33', 439, 2, 10, 952060) Drinks and drugs degrade those who are addicted to them and those who traffic in them.
('33', 439, 2, 11, 952147) The drunkard forgets the distinction between wife, mother and sister and indulges in crimes of which in his sober moments he will be ashamed.
('33', 439, 2, 12, 952289) Anyone who has anything to do with labour knows to what create the labourers are reduced when they are under the satanic influence of drink.
('33', 439, 2, 13, 952430) Nor are the other classes better off.
('33', 439, 2, 14, 952468) I have known the captain of a ship forgetting himself in his drunken state.
('33', 439, 2, 15, 952544) The ship had to be entrusted to the care of the chief officer.
('33', 439, 2, 16, 952607) Barristers having drunk have been known to be rolling in gutters.
('33', 439, 2, 17, 952673) Only, these better placed men are protected by the police all over the world whereas the poor drunkard is punished for his poverty.
('33', 439, 3, 18, 952805) If drink in spite of its harmfulness was not a fashionable vice among Englishmen, we would not find it in the organized state we do in this pauper country.
('33', 439, 3, 19, 952961) If we were not hypnotized we refuse to educate our children out of the proceeds of vice which the drink and the drug revenue undoubtedly H.
('33', 439, 4, 20, 953101) Mr. Ferguson suggests fresh taxation to replace this vice begotten revenue.
('33', 439, 4, 21, 953177) In my opinion no taxation is necessary, if only Government will reduce the frightful military expenditure not required for defence against aggression but minifestly imposed to suppress internal commotion.
('33', 439, 4, 22, 953382) The demand therefore for prohibition must go hand in hand with the demand for a corresponding reduction in military expenditure.
('33', 439, 4, 23, 953511) The missionary bodies if they will range themselves alongside of public opinion and will insist on prohibition, study the question of military expenditure, and if with are satisfied that much of the expenditure is a false fear of internal trouble, must demand reduction in military expenditure at least to the extent of the
('33', 440, 0, 1, 953835) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 441
('33', 440, 1, 2, 953886) drink and drug revenue.
('33', 440, 1, 3, 953910) The duty before the Swaraj and other political parties is quite clear.
('33', 440, 1, 4, 953981) They owe it to the country to demand total and immediate prohibition with one voice.
('33', 440, 1, 5, 954066) If the demand is not granted, the Swaraj Part has an additional count in the indictment against the Government.
('33', 440, 1, 6, 954178) Prohibition, as Mr. C. Rajagopalachari has so aptly shown, is an item of first class political education of the masses.
('33', 440, 1, 7, 954298) And it is one item on which all parties, all races and all denominations can be easily united.
('33', 440, 1, 8, 954393) Since writing the foregoing, I have seen the report of the proceedings of the prohibition Convention held at Delhi under the chairmanship of Dewan Bahadur M. Ramchandra Rao.
('33', 440, 1, 9, 954567) The Convention has passed what I would call a third resolution.
('33', 440, 1, 10, 954631) After avowing the imperative need for total prohibition it”urges upon the Government of India and the Local Governments to accept total prohibition of alcoholic liquor as the goal of their excise policy”.
('33', 440, 1, 11, 954836) This I suppose neither the Government of India nor the Local Governments would have any difficulty in accepting.
('33', 440, 1, 12, 954949) Swaraj is the accepted goal of all parties including the Government of India, but it is the immediate thing for the Congress to attain, a distant goal for the Government to cherish, though unattainable.
('33', 440, 1, 13, 955152) So will total prohibition be an unattainable goal with the Government.
('33', 440, 1, 14, 955223) Quite in keeping with this resolution is the advice of the Convention to the Government to”afford adequate facilities for ascertaining the will of the people with regard to this question, the introduction of the local option laws being in the opinion of the Convention the best means of ascertaining thewishes of the people in this matter”.
('33', 440, 1, 15, 955564) As I have already stated, there is no question of ascertaining the wishes of the people, for they are already known.
('33', 440, 1, 16, 955681) The question is one of the Government foregoing the drink and drug revenue.
('33', 440, 1, 17, 955757) I wish the Convention had taken up a stronger, more enlightened and more consistent line of action.
('33', 440, 1, 18, 955857) The Convention has now become a national prohibition party called the Prohibition League of India.
('33', 440, 1, 19, 955956) Let me hope that this League will adopt a more forward policy and not treat total prohibition as a goal to be realized in the dim and distant future, but a national policy to be immediately adopted and enforced without the cumbersome process of taking a referendum.
('33', 440, 2, 20, 956222) Young India, 4 2 1926
('33', 441, 0, 1, 956244) 442 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 441, 1, 2, 956286) 341. NOTES
('33', 441, 2, 3, 956297) INDEFATIGABLE MR. ANDREWS
('33', 441, 3, 4, 956323) Whatever the fate of the anti Indian measure of the Union Government, there is no doubt that Mr. Andrews’ contribution to the solution of the problem will rank as the highest.
('33', 441, 3, 5, 956499) His tireless energy, ceaseless watchfulness and gentle persuasive powers have brought us within hope of success.
('33', 441, 3, 6, 956612) He himself though despondent in the beginning stages now holds out hope that the Bill is likely to be shelved at least for this session.
('33', 441, 3, 7, 956749) He has been quietly interviewing editors and public men.
('33', 441, 3, 8, 956806) He has been enlisting the sympathy of the clergy and drawing from them emphatic pronouncement against the measure.
('33', 441, 3, 9, 956921) Thus he has shaken even South African European opinion that had ranged itself in favour of the measure.
('33', 441, 3, 10, 957025) His deep study of the question has enabled him to show to the satisfaction of several leaders of public opinion in South Africa that the measure is a manifest breach of the Smuts—Gandhi Agreement.
('33', 441, 3, 11, 957222) He has also brought together scattered Indian forces to focus themselves upon attacking the Bill.
('33', 441, 3, 12, 957320) Mr. Andrews has thus made a very substantial addition to his many services to—India and humanity.
('33', 441, 3, 13, 957418) No single living Englishman has done so much as Mr. Andrews to sweeten the relations between Englishmen and Indians.
('33', 441, 3, 14, 957535) His one hope is to establish an indissoluble bond between the two peoples, a bond based upon mutual respect and absolute equality.
('33', 441, 3, 15, 957666) May his dream be realized.
('33', 441, 4, 16, 957693) MIXED KHADI IS NO KHADI
('33', 441, 5, 17, 957717) A correspondent writes:
('33', 441, 6, 18, 957741) In Palnad in Guntur District is being prepared a variety of so called khadi with special designs in the border, called ‘Kuppadam’ border.
('33', 441, 7, 19, 957879) The yarn used in the border is admittedly foreign.
('33', 441, 7, 20, 957930) This is used as pure khadi and is being approved even by Mahatma Gandhi.
('33', 441, 7, 21, 958003) Is this right?
('33', 441, 7, 22, 958018) This is certainly not right.
('33', 441, 7, 23, 958047) I have never approved of any such thing.
('33', 441, 7, 24, 958088) I consider it a fraud to describe such dhotis as pure khadi.
('33', 441, 7, 25, 958149) The question was brought up even as early as l919 when mill made dhotis with borders of foreign yarn were used and I know several friends were obliged to reject their dhotis because their borders were discovered to be made of foreign yarn.
('33', 441, 7, 26, 958389) Such things appear small on the surface but they constitute a silent encroachment upon the reality.
('33', 442, 0, 1, 958489) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 443
('33', 442, 1, 2, 958540) One cannot therefore be too correct about such matters.
('33', 442, 1, 3, 958596) The only thing I have countenanced is the activities of the ladies in Bombay, who do embroidery work upon whole pieces of khadi.
('33', 442, 1, 4, 958725) For this embroidery.
('33', 442, 1, 5, 958746) they are obliged to use foreign silk.
('33', 442, 1, 6, 958784) But then, they do not cheat anybody.
('33', 442, 1, 7, 958821) They want to avoid this foreign silken thread if they can get hand spun.
('33', 442, 1, 8, 958894) But so long as they cannot, in order to sell their khadi amongst fashionable people, they are obliged to give them some embroidery, and they tell people plainly who use their saris, to what extent the embroidery contains foreign yarn.
('33', 442, 1, 9, 959129) But from embroidery on pure khadi to the use of foreign yarn in the preparation of khadi itself and calling the latter khadi, is a long and dangerous jump, which cannot be tolerated.
('33', 442, 2, 10, 959312) THE SPINNING WHEEL IN MYSORE
('33', 442, 3, 11, 959341) The Hindu publishes a long report of what it calls”a grand charkha demonstration and spinning competition” held recently at Bangalore under the auspices of its Spinners’ Association.
('33', 442, 3, 12, 959524) The chief event of this interesting and instructive function was the address delivered by the Chairman, Mr. Z. Mecci, the Director of Industries and Commerce, Mysore.
('33', 442, 3, 13, 959691) Mr. Mecci gave an exhaustive, and, in my opinion, a convincing reply to the critics of the spinning wheel.
('33', 442, 3, 14, 959798) He insisted that the wheel was to be considered from the point of view ‘of poverty and unemployment’.
('33', 442, 3, 15, 959900) He said:
('33', 442, 4, 16, 959909) It was well known that more than 50 per cent of the population was engaged in agriculture and for about half the year they all remained idle.
('33', 442, 4, 17, 960051) Not only this but the rainfall was so fitful and uncertain that famine conditions seemed to be a recurring factor every time.
('33', 442, 4, 18, 960177) And he showed that for this population the spinning wheel was the only industry during its leisure hours.
('33', 442, 4, 19, 960283) He added that but for the distortion and degeneration of the national taste, khaddar would make much greater headway than it had.
('33', 442, 4, 20, 960413) Of the earning capacity of the wheel, Mr. Mecci said:
('33', 442, 5, 21, 960467) It has been ascertained by careful calculation that a person by devoting 2_ hours a day to spinning could easily earn Rs. 2 8 a month, and taking the total number of persons on an average in a family to be 5, and 2 of these to take to spinning 2_ hours a day, the total extra income to the ‘have nots’ in the State would amount to more than 50 lakhs of rupees a month, or 6 crores of rupees per year.
('33', 442, 5, 22, 960868) Did their critics seriously ask them to throw away this sum by
('33', 443, 0, 1, 960931) 444 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 443, 1, 2, 960973) abstaining from spinning?
('33', 443, 1, 3, 960999) There was no doubt that the spinning industry had a great future before it and was sure to gain a great stimulus, if the educated, cultured and the wealthy classes were favourably disposed towards the use of khaddar.
('33', 443, 2, 4, 961216) Young India, 4 2 1926

('33', 445, 5, 9, 963404) 345. HINDUISM OF TODAY 1
('33', 445, 6, 10, 963429) A correspondent styling himself ‘Sanatani Hindu’ writes: 2
('33', 445, 7, 11, 963488) Hinduism of today presents many a curious anomaly.
('33', 445, 7, 12, 963539) No one cares to
('33', 445, 8, 13, 963555) study it, excepting perhaps some European missionaries .
('33', 445, 9, 14, 963612) There is no definite body of doctrines of practices which may be called sanatana and should be respected.
('33', 445, 10, 15, 963718) A Sudra’s status in a province where the Brahmins eat meat or fish is different from that in any province where the Brahmins and Vaishnavas alike
('33', 445, 11, 16, 963864) refrain from meat or fish.
('33', 445, 11, 17, 963891) You have somewhere said:”If you have no objection
('33', 445, 12, 18, 963941) to drinking clean water given by a Sudra, you should have none to drink it at
('33', 445, 13, 19, 964019) the hands of an untouchable.
('33', 445, 13, 20, 964048) some Hindus have religious scruples against
('33', 445, 14, 21, 964092) having water at the hands of meat eaters, some against doing so at the hands
('33', 445, 15, 22, 964169) of beef eaters.” .
('33', 445, 15, 23, 964188) I wish you could call a meeting of the untouchables of the
('33', 445, 16, 24, 964247) whole province and take promises from them to abstain from beef or carrion as
('33', 445, 17, 25, 964325) a preliminary to their being taken into the Hindu fold.
('33', 445, 17, 26, 964381) The letter presents only one side of the case.
('33', 445, 17, 27, 964428) There is reason for the correspondent’s complaint.
('33', 445, 17, 28, 964479) But Hinduism is a living organism liable to growth and decay, and subject to the laws of Nature.
('33', 445, 17, 29, 964576) One and indivisible at the root, it has grown into a vast tree with innumerable branches.
('33', 445, 17, 30, 964666) The changes in the seasons affect it.
('33', 445, 17, 31, 964704) It has its autumn and summer, its winter and spring.
('33', 445, 17, 32, 964757) The rains nourish and fructify it too.
('33', 445, 17, 33, 964796) It is and is not based on scriptures.
('33', 445, 17, 34, 964834) It does not derive its authority from one book.

('33', 457, 6, 10, 981168) I have been receiving the oranges sent by you.

('33', 459, 2, 3, 983184) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, February 10, 1926

('33', 459, 6, 12, 983727) 361. LETTER TO ESTHER MENON
('33', 459, 7, 13, 983755) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, February 10, 1926
('33', 459, 8, 14, 983792) MY DEAR CHILD, I have your letter and I have the parcel too from Menon.
('33', 459, 8, 15, 983864) There are no directions in the parcel beyond saying that there is a powder as an opening medicine and the contents of the bottle are for malaria.
('33', 459, 8, 16, 984010) So far as I am myself concerned at the present moment, I am free.
('33', 459, 8, 17, 984076) If I get a renewal of the attack I do not know that I can take the medicine, for as you are aware, I can take only five ingredients during any 24 hours whether for food or for medicine, Most of these Ayurvedic medicines contain dozens of ingredients.
('33', 459, 8, 18, 984327) Therefore, however useful they may be in themselves, for me they are perfectly useless.
('33', 459, 8, 19, 984415) But so many people get malaria here and I would gladly try Menon’s remedy if I get the directions.
('33', 459, 8, 20, 984514) Please, therefore, ask him to send them to me and if he knows the ingredients, lie may give me an idea of them.
('33', 459, 8, 21, 984626) Now about Friendship.
('33', 459, 8, 22, 984648) You have used the word ‘friend’ in three
('33', 460, 0, 1, 984689) VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926 461
('33', 460, 1, 2, 984740) different senses.
('33', 460, 1, 3, 984758) If we have the capacity, we can all become friends as Jesus was.
('33', 460, 1, 4, 984823) There, the word ‘friend’ means a kind helper.
('33', 460, 1, 5, 984869) The friendship between ourselves and those who are superior to us is also a one sided thing.
('33', 460, 1, 6, 984962) A father is and should be his children’s friend.
('33', 460, 1, 7, 985011) There it becomes companionship with the good, satsanga as it is called in Sanskrit.
('33', 460, 1, 8, 985095) What I hare written about is intimacy between two or more persons, where there is no secret and where mutual help is the consequence of, not a motive for, friendship.
('33', 460, 1, 9, 985262) The motive is some indefinable attraction.
('33', 460, 1, 10, 985305) It is this exclusive relationship which I have considered to be undesirable and antagonistic to communion with God.
('33', 460, 1, 11, 985421) Such was the friendship between the person I have described in the Autobiography 1 and myself.
('33', 460, 1, 12, 985516) Does not spinning naturally interest you?
('33', 460, 1, 13, 985558) I should expect you, if you spin at all, to spin because you are interested in it.
('33', 460, 1, 14, 985641) And if you are interested, you should master the mechanism and keep your instrument in perfect order as you will keep your stove in order if you are interested in cooking.
('33', 460, 1, 15, 985813) Spinning for me is an emblem of fellowship with the poorest of the land and its daily practice is a renewal of the bond between them and ourselves.
('33', 460, 1, 16, 985961) Thus considered, it is for me a thing of beauty and joy for ever.
('33', 460, 1, 17, 986027) I would rather to go without a meal.
('33', 460, 1, 18, 986064) than without the wheel and I would like you to understand this great implication of the wheel.
('33', 460, 1, 19, 986159) If you are to spin at all, I do not expect you to take up the wheel simply because I commend or the Congress recommends or because it is likely to be of economic value.
('33', 460, 1, 20, 986328) I am daily picking up strength little by little.
('33', 460, 1, 21, 986377) With love to you all,
('33', 460, 3, 22, 986399) BAPU MRS.
('33', 460, 3, 23, 986409) ESTHER MENON PORTO NOVO (S.I.R.)
('33', 460, 4, 24, 986442) From a photostat.

('33', 461, 0, 1, 986573) 462 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 461, 1, 2, 986615) APPENDICES
('33', 461, 2, 3, 986626) APPENDIX I
('33', 461, 3, 4, 986637) A. I. C. C. RESOLUTIONS
('33', 461, 4, 5, 986661) THE FRANCHISE
('33', 461, 5, 6, 986675) A. In view of the fact that there is a demand from a considerable section in the Congress for a revision of the franchise and there is a general consensus of opinion that having regard to the present situation the franchise should be extended, the All India Congress Committee resolves that Article VII of the Congress Constitution be repealed and replaced by the following:
('33', 461, 6, 7, 987050) Article VII.
('33', 461, 6, 8, 987063) (i) Every person not disqualified under Article IV and paying a subscription of 4 annas per year in advance, or 2,000 yards of evenly spun yarn of his or her own spinning, shall be entitled to become a member of any primary organi zation controlled by a Provincial Congress Committee, provided that no person shall be a member of two parallel Congress organizations at one and the same time.
('33', 461, 7, 9, 987455) (ii) The yarn subscription mentioned in sub section (i) shall be sent direct by the spinner to the Secretary, All India Spinners’ Association, or to any person nominated by the Secretary in this behalf, and a certificate from the Secretary, All India Spinners’ Association, to the effect that he has received 2,000 yards of evenly spun yarn of the holders’ own spinning as his or her yearly subscription, shall entitle the holder to the membership mentioned in sub section (i) hereof, provided that for the purpose of checking the accuracy of the returns made by the All India Spinners’ Association, the A. I. C. C., or any P. C. C., or any Sub Committee thereunder shall have the right to inspect the accounts, the stock and the vouchers of the All India Spinners’ Association or any subordinate organization thereunder and provided further that in the event of any inaccuracy or error discovered by the inspecting body in the accounts, stock or vouchers examined, the certificates issued by the All India Spinners’ Association in respect of persons with reference to whose membership the accounts have been examined, shall be declared cancelled; provided that the All India Spinners’ Association or the person disqualified shall have the right of appeal to the Working Committee.
('33', 461, 7, 10, 988737) Any person wishing to spin for the membership of the Congress may, if he or she desires, be supplied, upon due security, with cotton for spinning.
('33', 461, 8, 11, 988884) (iii) The yarn of the membership shall be reckoned from the 1st January to 31st December and there shall be no reduction in the subscription to be paid by members joining in the middle of the year.
('33', 461, 9, 12, 989082) (iv) No person shall be entitled to vote at the election of representatives or delegates of any Committee or sub Committee or any Congress organization
('33', 462, 0, 1, 989234) 463 VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926
('33', 462, 1, 2, 989285) whatsoever or to be elected as such, or to take part in any meeting of the Congress or any Congress organization, or any Committee or Sub Committee thereof, if he has not complied with sub section (i) hereof or does not wear hand spun and hand woven khaddar at political and Congress functions or while engaged in Congress business; the Congress expects Congressmen to wear khaddar also on all other occasions and in no case shall they wear or use foreign cloth.
('33', 462, 2, 3, 989748) (v) All the existing members at the end of the year shall be entitled to remain such up to the 31st January following although they may not have paid their subscription for the new year.
('33', 462, 3, 4, 989935) Saving Clause: sub section (i) shall not affect the rights of those who have been already registered as members under the Article repealed provided their membership is otherwise in order, and provided further that those who shall have paid yarn subscription, whether of self spun or hand spun yarn up to September 1925, shall remain members for the current year though they may not pay any further yarn.
('33', 462, 3, 5, 990339) B. Whereas the Congress in its 39th Session held at Belgaum endorsed an agreement entered into between Mahatma Gandhi on the one hand and Deshbandhu C. R. Das and Pandit Motilal Nehru acting on behalf of the Swaraj Party on the other, whereby the Congress activity was restricted to the constructive programme mentioned therein and it was provided that “the work in connection with the Central and Provincial Legislatures should be carried on by the Swaraj Party on behalf of the Congress and as an integral part of the Congress organization and that for such work the Swaraj Party should make its own rules and administer its own funds” and;
('33', 462, 4, 6, 990982) Whereas subsequent events have shown that this restriction should not continue under the altered circumstances that face the country and that the Congress should henceforth be a predominantly political body; It is resolved that the Congress do now take up and carry on all such political work as may be necessary in the interest of the country and for this purpose do employ the whole of the machinery and funds of Congress, save and except such funds and assets as are specially earmarked and such funds and assets as belong to the All India Khaddar Board and Provincial Khaddar Boards, which shall be handed over with all existing financial obligations to the All India Spinners’ Association to be started by Mahatma Gandhi as an integral part of the Congress organization, but with independent existence and full powers to administer these other funds for the fulfilment of its object; Provided that the work in the Indian and Provincial Legislatures shall be carried on in accordance with the policy and programme laid down by the Swaraj Party under the constitution framed by the Party and the rules made thereunder subject to such modifications made by the Congress as may be found necessary from time to time for the purpose of carrying out the said policy.
('33', 462, 4, 7, 992247) Young India, 1 10 1925
('33', 463, 0, 1, 992270) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 463, 1, 2, 992312) APPENDIX II
('33', 463, 2, 3, 992324) FROM EUROPE
('33', 463, 3, 4, 992336) Not only India but also the rest of the earth has heard your message of satyagraha and swadeshi, A great number of young people in Europe believe in your creed.
('33', 463, 3, 5, 992497) They see in it a new attitude to political things put into action, of which till now they had only dreamed.
('33', 463, 4, 6, 992605) But also among the young people who are convinced of the truth of your message are many who dissent from some details of your demands on men which seem wrong to them.
('33', 463, 4, 7, 992772) In their name is this letter written.
('33', 463, 5, 8, 992810) In answer to a question you declared on the 21st of March, 1921 that satyagraha demands absolute non violence and that even a woman who is in danger of being violated must not defend herself with violence.
('33', 463, 5, 9, 993016) On the other hand, it is known that you recommended the punishment of General Dyer by the English Government, which shows that you see the necessity for law guaranteed through violence.
('33', 463, 5, 10, 993202) From this I can but conclude that you do not object to capital punishment and so do not condemn killing in general.
('33', 463, 5, 11, 993318) You value life so low that you allow thousands of Indians to lose theirs for satyagraha and doubtless you know that the least interference with the life of men, imprisonment, is mainly based on the same principle as the strongest, killing, for in each case men are caused by an outside force to diverge from their dharma.
('33', 463, 5, 12, 993640) A man who thinks logically knows that it is the same principle that causes his imprisonment for a few days or his execution and that the difference is only in the size not in the kind of interference.
('33', 463, 5, 13, 993841) He knows, too, that a man who stands for punishment in general must not shrink from killing.
('33', 463, 6, 14, 993934) You see in non co operation not an ideal only but also a safe and quick way to freedom for India, a way possible only there where a whole population has to revolt against a government that has the force of arms.
('33', 463, 6, 15, 994146) But when a whole State wants to get its rights from another State, then the principle of non co operation is powerless, for this other one may get a number of other States to form an alliance with it even when some of the other States remain neutral.
('33', 463, 6, 16, 994397) Not until a real League of Nations exists, to which every State belongs, can non co operation become a real power, since no State can afford to be islolated from all the others.
('33', 463, 6, 17, 994575) That is why we fight for the League of Nations, but that is also the reason why we try to retain a strong police force, lest internal revolts and disorder should make all foreign policy impossible.
('33', 463, 6, 18, 994773) That is why we understand that other governments are doing what they forbade us to do: arming themselves in case of an attack by their enemies.
('33', 463, 6, 19, 994917) They are, for the time being, obliged to do so, and we really ought to do the same if we don’t want to be continually violated.
('33', 463, 6, 20, 995045) We hope that you will see our point.
('33', 463, 6, 21, 995082) If you do, we should be very much obliged to you if you would say so in answer to this letter, for it is necessary that the
('33', 464, 0, 1, 995206) 465 VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926
('33', 464, 1, 2, 995257) youth of Europe learns your true attitude to these questions.
('33', 464, 1, 3, 995319) But please do not think that we want you to forswear something that is one of the main points of your creed, satyagraha.
('33', 464, 2, 4, 995440) But we see satyagraha not in an absolute non violence which never, nowhere, has been really carried out, even by you, or even by Christ himself who drove the usurers out of the temple.
('33', 464, 2, 5, 995625) With us, satyagraha is the unreserved disposition to brotherhood and sacrifice which you are showing us so splendidly with the Indian people and we hope to be growing into the same state of mind, since it has been understood that a system may be wicked but never a whole class or a whole people (you wrote about this on the 13th of July 1921) and that one ought to feel pity but not hatred for the blind defenders of wickedness.
('33', 464, 2, 6, 996054) Men who come to understand this are taking their first steps on the new way to brotherhood between all men and this way will lead to the goal, to the victory of truth, to satyagraha.We ask you, in your answer not only to advise us to fight for our country in the way we think right, but we would very much like to know, what you think to be right, especially how you justify an entire non violence which we see as a resignation to all real fighting against wickedness and for this reason wicked in itself,—as we would call a policeman wicked who let a criminal escape unpunished.
('33', 464, 3, 7, 996634) Our conviction is that we ought to follow our own dharma first and before all that we ought to live the life designed for us by God, but that the right and the duty is given to us to interfere with the life of our fellow men when they ask us to do so or when we see in such interference a way to fight a threatening evil for all the world.
('33', 464, 3, 8, 996974) We believe that otherwise one is not right in interfering, for only God can see through the soul of men and judge what is the right way for men and we believe that there is no greater sacrilege to be found than to assume the place of God— which sacrilege we believe the English people to be guilty of, as they think to have the mission to interfere with people all over the world.
('33', 464, 4, 9, 997355) For this reason we don’t understand how you can recommend to married people to deny themselves to each other without mutual agreement, for such an interference with the rights given by marriage can drive a man to crimes.
('33', 464, 4, 10, 997576) You ought to advise divorce in those cases.
('33', 464, 5, 11, 997620) Please answer these our questions.
('33', 464, 5, 12, 997655) We are so glad to have the model given by you that we want very much to be quite clear about the right way to live up to your standards.
('33', 464, 5, 13, 997792) Young India, 8 10 1925
('33', 465, 0, 1, 997815) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 465, 1, 2, 997857) APPENDIX III
('33', 465, 2, 3, 997870) EUROPEAN CIVILIZATION
('33', 465, 3, 4, 997892) Europe boasts of her civilization, her Christian civilization.
('33', 465, 3, 5, 997955) The triumphant career of the white race throughout the earth is the watchword of the time .
('33', 465, 3, 6, 998047) A triumphant career of the race—that is true.
('33', 465, 3, 7, 998093) But of civilization, humanity, Christianity?
('33', 465, 3, 8, 998138) Justice turns her face away and weeps.
('33', 465, 3, 9, 998177) Will you find a hell of racial hatred and inhumanity?
('33', 465, 3, 10, 998231) Then go to Europe.
('33', 465, 3, 11, 998250) Look at the collective policy of the Christian Powers in China.
('33', 465, 3, 12, 998314) First act: shameless extortion, exercised for ages by European profiteers.
('33', 465, 3, 13, 998389) Second act: the enraged natives react by killing a German ambassador.
('33', 465, 3, 14, 998459) Third act: Europe undertakes her “Hunnish crusade” under German lead and in the spirit of that watchword, which was ironically pronounced by the satirical paper Simplicissimus in an imagined
('33', 465, 4, 15, 998650) speech of a German officer : ‘Now I propose a toast to a vigorous propagation of the Gospel and a victorious walk over the Chinese swine dogs (schweinehunde)!’
('33', 465, 5, 16, 998810) Too justly the Chinese have called us ‘the red haired barbarians’ or ‘red haired devils’.
('33', 465, 5, 17, 998900) Let us now look at some species of the European Homo sapiens.
('33', 465, 5, 18, 998962) The Italians may deserve honourable mention, because Christianity caused them to give up their bestial baitings of wild beasts about 400 A.D. How unwillingly the ancient Romans gave up their circenses appears from a curious
('33', 465, 6, 19, 999186) anecdote.
('33', 465, 6, 20, 999196) A clergyman found it difficult to keep the converted away from the circus.
('33', 465, 6, 21, 999271) Then he said; ‘Dear Christians!
('33', 465, 6, 22, 999303) You must avoid these bloody heathen plays.
('33', 465, 7, 23, 999346) in reward, you may hope that in heaven there may be a peep hole through which you may regard the condemned sinners in the eternal fire of hell!’ Indeed, a fine and noble ‘Christian’ idea!
('33', 465, 7, 24, 999534) To characterize the standard of the ‘most Christian’ nation of Spaniards, it is sufficient to mention the fact that the favourite play of the nation is till this day the bullfight.
('33', 465, 7, 25, 999715) The national hero is the grand toreador—a cruel tormentor of animals.
('33', 465, 7, 26, 999785) France has created the hunting parforce.
('33', 465, 8, 27, 999826) England adheres to the same noble sport.
('33', 465, 8, 28, 999867) Look at the illustrated papers published in honour of the Christmas, the Christian feast of peace and charity!
('33', 465, 8, 29, 999978) During a dinner in Denmark, a Danish gentlemen by the way told an English lady that he had shot a fox.
('33', 465, 8, 30, 1000081) ‘Good gracious!
('33', 465, 8, 31, 1000097) You don’t say so!
('33', 465, 8, 32, 1000115) Shot a fox?’ cried she immediately, seizing him by his arm.
('33', 465, 8, 33, 1000175) Then she turned him her back with contempt—for it was unworthy of a gentleman not to torment the poor animal to
('33', 465, 9, 34, 1000287) A Danish clergyman sailing on the Red Sea once witnessed the natives diving from the steamer for coins.
('33', 465, 9, 35, 1000391) But the English ladies were not content to see
('33', 466, 0, 1, 1000438) 467 VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926
('33', 466, 1, 2, 1000489) them jump out from the deck; they ordered them to jump out from the tops of the masts, to make it more exciting!
('33', 466, 1, 3, 1000602) The opium war and the treatment of Ireland in past centuries are other proofs of English morals.
('33', 466, 1, 4, 1000699) Owing to the resistance of the English nation to conscription, England fortunately has avoided the use of forced cannon food.
('33', 466, 1, 5, 1000825) But what was the munificently promised reward of the Indian volunteers in the Great War?
('33', 466, 1, 6, 1000914) It is sufficient to name Amritsar.
('33', 466, 1, 7, 1000949) Germany has created the most brutal ‘moral of masters’ before the Bolshevism and the most systematic oppression of the nations ‘of minor value’ (minderwertig).
('33', 466, 1, 8, 1001109) The Pan German programme of 1895 privileges the ‘full Germans’
('33', 466, 2, 9, 1001172) to vote, to be elected for parliaments and offices, and to buy ground property.
('33', 466, 2, 10, 1001252) ‘They willingly tolerate the foreigners in the country as exercisers of the inferior bodily labour.’ A Danish surgeon as visitor in a German hospital once witnessed
('33', 466, 3, 11, 1001417) the transfer of living tissue from one body into another.
('33', 466, 3, 12, 1001475) As he wondered how it would be possible to obtain sufficient mass of tissue, the German professor answered : “Wir haben ja Polen genug (we have enough of Poles).” The Delbruck
('33', 466, 4, 13, 1001651) Law of 1912 enabled German emigrants to remain secretly citizens of the German Empire after they had officially obtained the citizenship of the unsuspecting foreign states—fine and noble means of creating thousands of underground agents of Pan Germanism.
('33', 466, 4, 14, 1001906) Conscription procured the Germans millions of sons of the minderwertig nations to serve as cannon food in their wars, while the relations of
('33', 466, 5, 15, 1002047) the victims were oppressed at home in the most brutal manner.
('33', 466, 5, 16, 1002109) 6,000 Danes from North Schlesvig were thus slaughtered in the Great War for a foreign and hated cause.
('33', 466, 5, 17, 1002212) Through the ‘civil conscription’, the Germans carried away thousands of Belgians into slavery; sometimes, these wretches were even forced to work within the line of fire.
('33', 466, 5, 18, 1002383) Bolshevism is indebted to the great German Staff for the fortunate foundation of its rule.
('33', 466, 5, 19, 1002474) Pan German methods of brutality and lie are unfortunately practised and even surpassed.
('33', 466, 5, 20, 1002562) We observe an element of Jewish fanaticism, which results in mere madness.
('33', 466, 5, 21, 1002637) We may here refer to the contents of a Bolshevist poem from the collection Tsheks ulibajet, published in 1922 by A. Saprudni: “You prefer
('33', 466, 6, 22, 1002775) to sing of love.
('33', 466, 6, 23, 1002792) I will teach you other songs, of blood, execution, and death.
('33', 466, 6, 24, 1002854) Enough of the gentle fragrance of lilacs!
('33', 466, 6, 25, 1002896) I prefer the flowers of murder.
('33', 466, 6, 26, 1002928) It is the highest delight to crucify the man who loves his neighbour.
('33', 466, 6, 27, 1002998) What a fun to cut a man to pieces.
('33', 466, 6, 28, 1003033) Look, how he quivers for fear, look at his convulsions while he is slowly strangled by the hangman.
('33', 466, 6, 29, 1003133) What a pleasure to inflict wounds.
('33', 466, 6, 30, 1003168) Listen to our sentence of death: a rope, a shot!
('33', 466, 6, 31, 1003217) A wall!
('33', 466, 6, 32, 1003225) Give fire!—And the grave is your fate.” Three points of European morals are emphasized, viz, the moral of masters, the policy of lie, and the policy of murder.
('33', 466, 6, 33, 1003385) In order to illustrate the European standard, I quote an address delivered by Professor Theol.

('33', 470, 1, 2, 1010828) APPENDIX V THE CANKER OF SUPERIORITY
('33', 470, 2, 3, 1010865) 1. Our Samiti aims at unity and regeneration of our community.
('33', 470, 2, 4, 1010928) 2. Your mission as we understand is threefold: (a) Introduction and spread of khaddar and charkha.
('33', 470, 2, 5, 1011027) (b) Hindu Muslim unity.
('33', 470, 2, 6, 1011051) (c) Removal of untouchability.
('33', 470, 2, 7, 1011082) The first two are common to all.
('33', 470, 2, 8, 1011115) We have come to you mainly in connection with the third item and beg leave to give you an idea as to how untouchability stands in the way of unification of the Hindus in Bengal.
('33', 470, 2, 9, 1011293) 3. In Bengal, Hindu Society may be principally grouped into two classes.
('33', 470, 2, 10, 1011366) (i) Jal acharaniya (ii) Anacharaniya.
('33', 470, 3, 11, 1011404) Group (i) consists of: Brahmins Baidyas Kayasthas Navashakas (meaning 9 or 10 castes)
('33', 470, 4, 12, 1011490) Group ( ii) : Baishyashahas Subarnabanikas (Goldsmiths) Sutradharas (Carpenters) Jogis (Weavers) Sundis (Wine sellers)
('33', 470, 5, 13, 1011609) Fishermen Bhui Malis (Sweepers) Dhopas (Washermen) Muchis or Reshees (Cobblers and Drummers) Kapaliks Namsudras, and others.
('33', 470, 6, 14, 1011734) Some of these are classified as depressed classes by the Census authorities.
('33', 470, 7, 15, 1011811) Of the first group the first three classes claim to dominate the rest of the Hindu Society and not only do they despise them (particularly those belonging to group (ii) at heart, but oppress them in various ways, e.g., (i) Freedom of worship in our access to public temples not allowed (ii) mess and hostel difficulties of the students of the 2nd group; (iii) entrance into hotels and sweetmeat shops resented.
('33', 470, 7, 16, 1012222) In Bengal, those who are taking lead in the movement for removal of untouchability are not, in our opinion, adopting the right method and have not made any appreciable progress in this direction.
('33', 470, 7, 17, 1012418) According to the census of 1921, of the total Hindu population of Bengal

('33', 471, 2, 3, 1012681) only 28,09,000 1 or thereabouts.

('33', 472, 2, 6, 1015808) APPENDIX VI
('33', 472, 3, 7, 1015820) SPINNING IN AMERICA
('33', 472, 4, 8, 1015840) The Revolution was a war of independence by independents; for aside from their pioneer daring and courage, faith, endurance and marksmanship, their main strength of preparedness lay in the fact that every home made its own food, drink, medicine, fuel, lighting, clothing and shelter.
('33', 472, 4, 9, 1016124) It was more effective than gun powder.
('33', 472, 4, 10, 1016163) In this winter climate without the handlooms and spinning wheels, and the flax and sheep fold of every home, the American soldier would have died of exposure to the winter cold.
('33', 472, 4, 11, 1016341) The wool and flax were raised and spun at home into thread and yarn, and knit into stockings, mittens, caps and blankets, or woven into clothing.
('33', 472, 4, 12, 1016487) After the hard work of clearing trees and pulling stumps, as well as removing large stones, the flax and hemp patch was planted.
('33', 472, 4, 13, 1016616) This operation alone took all the energy that is consumed in several football games, with fewer fatalities.
('33', 472, 4, 14, 1016724) Even the children were given a share in the work, as they had to weed the patch.
('33', 472, 4, 15, 1016805) The stalks were very tender when they first came up, and the children had to work bare footed and step facing the wind, so if any plants were trodden down the wind would blow the fallen plant back into place.
('33', 472, 4, 16, 1017014) * * * Daughters’ feet in those days were used to work the treadle, and often to rock a heavy wooden cradle, while mother churned the butter, and she was cheered with the thought that at night, she could put on a clean kerchief and adjust her curls, and go on spinning, but she would have help for the sweetheart would come after sunset when he had finished swingling the flax.
('33', 472, 4, 17, 1017391) She would spin until the clock reel ticked at rare and propitious moments, when it had counted the exact number of strands in a knot—usually forty.
('33', 472, 4, 18, 1017539) Then the spinner would stop and tie the knot while her companion would do what he could in those rare moments toward trying
('33', 473, 0, 1, 1017663) 474 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 473, 1, 2, 1017705) another kind of knot, for according to a quaint old ballad, “He kissed Mistress Polly when the clock reel ticked”.
('33', 473, 1, 3, 1017820) When the early American woman wished to spend the day in cheerful companionship, she would rise with the sun, do her household chores, then jump on horseback and with her flax wheel tied behind, and the baby under one arm, ride to her neighbour's home, sometimes at quite a distance from her home.
('33', 473, 2, 4, 1018118) SPINNING TOURNAMENTS
('33', 473, 3, 5, 1018139) In 1754, spinning exhibitions were held and on such occasions, ministers preached to the spinsters as they gathered with their wheels.
('33', 473, 3, 6, 1018274) One of these is described by an old antiquarian in a quaint way: “A number of respectable ladies of the town, met at sunrise with their wheels, to spend the day at the house of the Rev.
('33', 473, 3, 7, 1018460) Jedidiah Jewell, in the laudable design of a spinning match.
('33', 473, 4, 8, 1018521) “At an hour before sunset, the ladies there appearing neatly dressed, principally in homespun, a polite and generous repast of American production was set for their entertainment.
('33', 473, 4, 9, 1018701) After which many being present of both sexes, Mr. Jewell delivered a profitable discourse from Romans xii, 2: ‘Not slothful in business, fervent in spirit, serving the Lord’.”
('33', 473, 5, 10, 1018877) Matters of church and patriotism were never far apart in New England, so when spinners gathered at New London, Newbury, Ipswich or Beverly, they always had a sermon, with an appropriate text.
('33', 473, 5, 11, 1019069) One favourite text was: “And all the women that were wise hearted did spin with their hands.” Exodus xxxv, 25.
('33', 473, 6, 12, 1019180) “Truly it was a pleasing sight; some spinning, some reeling, some carding cotton, some combing flax, as they were preached to,” said a contemporary writer.
('33', 473, 6, 13, 1019336) * * * In 1640 the courts of Massachusetts and Connecticut passed two orders directing the growth of flax, ascertaining what colonists were skilful in breaking, spinning, weaving, ordering that boys and girls be taught to spin, and offering a bounty for linen, grown, spun and woven in the colony.
('33', 473, 6, 14, 1019633) Every family was ordered to spin so many pounds of flax a year, or to pay a fine.
('33', 473, 6, 15, 1019715) Prizes were offered for quantity and quality and societies were formed for promoting industry, and frugality by the rich and poor.
('33', 473, 6, 16, 1019846) Benjamin Franklin wrote later in Poor Richard’s Almanac: “Many estates are spent in the getting, Since women for tea forsook spinning and knitting.” The ‘all wool and a yard wide’ goods which we purchase so easily today meant the work of many weeks and months to the colonial dame.
('33', 473, 6, 17, 1020128) Wool spinning is one of the most flexible and alert series of movements imaginable and to its varied poises our grandmothers may owe part of the dignity of carriage that was so characteristic of them.
('33', 474, 0, 1, 1020329) 475 VOL. 33 : 25 SEPTEMBER, 1925 10 FEBRUARY, 1926
('33', 474, 1, 2, 1020380) * * * In the summer of 1775, Congress made a demand on the people, for 13,000 warm coats to be ready for the soldiers by cold weather.
('33', 474, 1, 3, 1020515) There were no contractors then to supply cloth and garments, but throughout the country by hundreds of hearthstones, wool wheels and hand looms were started eagerly at work, and the order was filled by the work of patriotic women of America.
('33', 474, 2, 4, 1020757) HEROES IN HOMESPUN
('33', 474, 3, 5, 1020776) Washington’s army was called “the Homespuns” in derision, but there was more in the name than they knew just then.
('33', 474, 3, 6, 1020891) As for women, they grew to love their looms as companions in the conflict, and they wove their prayers and love into the cloth.
('33', 474, 4, 7, 1021019) In 1775, one of these patriotic women of Colchester, Coun, named Abigail Foote, wrote down her daily work in her diary, and here is sample of a day’s work:
('33', 474, 5, 8, 1021175) “Fixed gown for Prude, mended mother’s riding ho, spun short thread, fixed two gowns for Welch’s girls, carded tow, spun linen, worked on cheese basket, hatchel’d flax with Hannah, (we did 51 pounds apiece), spooled a piece, milked the cows, spun the linen, did 50 knots, made a broom of Guinea wheat straw, spun thread to whiten, set a red dye, had two scholars from Mrs. Taylor’s.
('33', 474, 5, 9, 1021558) I carded two pounds of whole wool, spun twine, scoured the pewter,” * * *
('33', 474, 6, 10, 1021632) The sound of the spinning wheel, the song of the spinster, and the snapping of the clock reel, all have ceased.
('33', 474, 6, 11, 1021744) The thwack of the loom is heard only in the factory.
('33', 474, 7, 12, 1021797) The spinning wheel no longer hums in the house of the farmer but it has left a song in our hearts, so that for the sake of beauty alone, it is beginning to hum in the halls of learning.
('33', 474, 7, 13, 1021983) Right here in the old Hampstead house atmosphere, the wheel is beginning to turn in Charter house, and the homelike art of weaving is being revived, and spinning contests take place at commencement, as the Priscillas of today seek their beloved wheels again.
('33', 474, 7, 14, 1022242) Longfellow’s poem “The Courtship of Miles Standish” has given us the words to the song of the spinning wheel, and in this poem Priscilla shows the magic of the wheel in love: “Straight up rose from her wheel the beautiful Puritan maiden.
('33', 474, 7, 15, 1022480) Pleased with the praise of thrift from him whose praise was the sweetest: Drew from the reel on the table, a snowy skein of her spinning, Thus making an answer, meanwhile to the flattering praises of Alden; ‘Come, you must not be idle if I am a pattern for housewives,
('33', 475, 0, 1, 1022749) 476 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('33', 475, 1, 2, 1022791) Show yourself equally worthy of being the model of husbands Hold this skein on your hands, while I wind it, ready for knitting.’ * * * Thus with a jest and a laugh, the skein on his hands she adjusted, He sitting awkwardly there, with his arms extended before him, She standing graceful, erect and winding the thread from his fingers, Sometimes chiding a little his clumsy manner of holding, Sometimes touching his hands, as she disentangled expertly Twist or knot in the yarn, unawares for how could she help it?” If one has any prejudice against Priscilla, let him read this peaceful poem, and catch the spirit of the spinning, and the homely sound of the humming.
